editorialDecl.p: EEBO-TCP is a partnership between the Universities of Michigan and Oxford and the publisher ProQuest to create accurately transcribed and encoded texts based on the image sets published by ProQuest via their Early English Books Online (EEBO) database (http://eebo.chadwyck.com). The general aim of EEBO-TCP is to encode one copy (usually the first edition) of every monographic English-language title published between 1473 and 1700 available in EEBO.

EEBO-TCP aimed to produce large quantities of textual data within the usual project restraints of time and funding, and therefore chose to create diplomatic transcriptions (as opposed to critical editions) with light-touch, mainly structural encoding based on the Text Encoding Initiative (http://www.tei-c.org).

The EEBO-TCP project was divided into two phases. The 25,363 texts created during Phase 1 of the project have been released into the public domain as of 1 January 2015. Anyone can now take and use these texts for their own purposes, but we respectfully request that due credit and attribution is given to their original source.
Users should be aware of the process of creating the TCP texts, and therefore of any assumptions that can be made about the data.

Text selection was based on the New Cambridge Bibliography of English Literature (NCBEL). If an author (or for an anonymous work, the title) appears in NCBEL, then their works are eligible for inclusion. Selection was intended to range over a wide variety of subject areas, to reflect the true nature of the print record of the period. In general, first editions of a works in English were prioritized, although there are a number of works in other languages, notably Latin and Welsh, included and sometimes a second or later edition of a work was chosen if there was a compelling reason to do so.

Image sets were sent to external keying companies for transcription and basic encoding. Quality assurance was then carried out by editorial teams in Oxford and Michigan. 5% (or 5 pages, whichever is the greater) of each text was proofread for accuracy and those which did not meet QA standards were returned to the keyers to be redone. After proofreading, the encoding was enhanced and/or corrected and characters marked as illegible were corrected where possible up to a limit of 100 instances per text. Any remaining illegibles were encoded as <gap>s. Understanding these processes should make clear that, while the overall quality of TCP data is very good, some errors will remain and some readable characters will be marked as illegible. Users should bear in mind that in all likelihood such instances will never have been looked at by a TCP editor.
The texts were encoded and linked to page images in accordance with level 4 of the TEI in Libraries guidelines.

Copies of the texts have been issued variously as SGML (TCP schema; ASCII text with mnemonic sdata character entities); displayable XML (TCP schema; characters represented either as UTF-8 Unicode or text strings within braces); or lossless XML (TEI P5, characters represented either as UTF-8 Unicode or TEI g elements).
Keying and markup guidelines are available at the Text Creation Partnership web site.

div.head: The TROUBLES of ENGLAND. by Dr. BATES. Princip: Phys: to K.C.I.
div.p: Printed for Abel Swall at the Unicorn at the West end of St. Pauls. 1685
Elenchus Motuum Nuperorum in Anglia: OR, A Å¿hort HiÅ¿torical ACCOUNT OF The RISE and PROGRESS OF THE Late Troubles in England.
In TWO PARTS.
Written in Latin by Dr. GEORGE BATES, Principal PhyÅ¿ician to K. Charles the I. and K. Charles the II.

MOTUS COMPOSITI: OR, THE HISTORY OF THE CompoÅ¿ing the Affairs of England By the ReÅ¿tauration of K. Charles the Second, And the PuniÅ¿hment of the Regicides: And other Principal Occurrents to the Year 1669.
Written in Latin by THO. SKINNER, M.D.
Made ENGLISH.
To which is added a Preface by a PerÅ¿on of Quality, and in the body of the Work Å¿everal choice Original Papers, an account of which is given in the end of the Preface.
London: Printed for Abel Swalle, at the Æ²nicorn at the WeÅ¿t-end of St. Paul's Church-yard. 1685.

div.head: THE PREFACE TO THE READER, Added by a PerÅ¿on of Quality, who had the care of ReviÅ¿iing the TranÅ¿lation.
div.p: IN the beginning of the World the Life of Man being very long, and the TranÅ¿actions that happened neither great, various, nor many, there was little need of HiÅ¿tory. The Father living many hundred years with his Children and Grandchildren, had leiÅ¿ure and time Å¿ufficient to imprint in their memories the Å¿tory of the few Occurrents that were paÅ¿t; and no man coming then to govern any conÅ¿iderable number of men, till he had lived the Å¿pace of three or four of our longeÅ¿t lives put together, was by that time abundantly furniÅ¿hed from his own Experience; and what had happened in his own days, with Å¿o much prudence, as might qualifie him for Government.

But when after the Deluge the Life of Man was brought by degrees to about threeÅ¿core and ten, or fourÅ¿core years, and much of the latter part of that Å¿mall period became unfit for buÅ¿ineÅ¿s by Å¿ickneÅ¿s and other calamities of old age, and the affairs of the World grew numerous, whether conÅ¿idered as past, or preÅ¿ent; then it became neceÅ¿Å¿ary that Memorials Å¿hould be kept for the relief of humane infirmity, the perpetuation of the memory of Actions, and that mankind, who had but a Å¿hort time to live upon the Earth, might in that time be quickly and eaÅ¿ily furniÅ¿hed with an artificial Experience, derived from an artificial Memory; by which Governours might be qualified for government, and Subjects diÅ¿poÅ¿ed to a dutiful Å¿ubmiÅ¿Å¿ion to the Prudence and Conduct of their Superiours: that Å¿o this Å¿hort and tranÅ¿itory Life of Man might be rendered as wiÅ¿e and happy as it was poÅ¿Å¿ible, and that Piety too might be nouriÅ¿hed in the minds of men by a Å¿erious reflection on the Works of Gods Providence, manifeÅ¿ted in the Å¿everal effects of his wiÅ¿e Conduct in the government of the World, whereby he has in every Age demonÅ¿trated his JuÅ¿tice and Mercy in dealing to every man a Reward according to his Actions.

TheÅ¿e were the CauÅ¿es of the invention of Letters, and of writing HiÅ¿tories or Memoires of paÅ¿t Events for the uÅ¿e of PoÅ¿terity, by thoÅ¿e that had Å¿een them, or were otherwiÅ¿e well inform'd concerning them. And thoÅ¿e into whoÅ¿e
hands theÅ¿e first Monuments fell, were mighty fond of them, and by often reading and deeply conÅ¿idering them, in a Å¿hort time much improv'd themÅ¿elves in WiÅ¿dom, Virtue, and Piety. For the firÅ¿t and moÅ¿t ancient Stories were written without any vain pomp of affected Words or Rhetorical ExpreÅ¿Å¿ions: the HiÅ¿torian not courting the ApplauÅ¿e, but labouring hard for the Improvement of the Reader: And he again repairing to thoÅ¿e venerable RepoÅ¿itories, not to Å¿eek a vaniÅ¿hing Light, unprofitable PleaÅ¿ure and DevertiÅ¿ement, but a Å¿olid and durable Improvement, and the Rules of living well and wiÅ¿ely. So there is a threefold uÅ¿e of HiÅ¿tory: Political, Moral, and Divine. Of all which, briefly in their order.
The Political uÅ¿e of HiÅ¿tory is twofold: firÅ¿t, as it relates to Governours; and then, as it relates to Subjects or Inferiours.

The advantages Princes and Great men, who are to govern others, do or may reap from the reading of HiÅ¿tories well and wiÅ¿ely written, are innumerable; but then they are to Å¿uch Å¿o well known, that I need not Å¿pend any time to remark them here; my deÅ¿igne not being to inÅ¿truct my Betters, but to improve (if I may) my Equals.

And as to Subjects, the uÅ¿e of HiÅ¿tory is not much leÅ¿s; by which, if they would Å¿eriouÅ¿ly reflect upon what is paÅ¿t, they might learn many things that would be of great uÅ¿e to them, and render theirs and their Governours lives more eaÅ¿ie and happy.

1. For firÅ¿t, they might obÅ¿erve with what difficulties all humane Governments are beÅ¿et, how often God (for cauÅ¿es known Å¿ometimes onely to himÅ¿elf) defeats the wiÅ¿eÅ¿t contrivances and deÅ¿ignes of men: How neighbouring Princes interpoÅ¿e, and croÅ¿s or fruÅ¿trate their undertakings, out of intereÅ¿t, fear, hope, envy, and the like: How often want of due inÅ¿truments, proviÅ¿ions, men, moneys, changes in the Å¿eaÅ¿ons; and a thouÅ¿and other accidents intervene and prevent their purpoÅ¿es.

Now this conÅ¿ideration would certainly (if men were modeÅ¿t and juÅ¿t) procure from them a due regard for their Superiours, even then when they are unfortunate, and not make every unproÅ¿perous accident that happened, the effect of Å¿loath, negligence, careleÅ¿neÅ¿s, and Å¿upine Å¿tupidity. And being thus diÅ¿poÅ¿ed, they might Å¿ometimes, at leaÅ¿t, find the reaÅ¿on of publick Calamities in themÅ¿elves; at others, in the juÅ¿tice of God puniÅ¿hing the Å¿ins of men; or in the neighbour Princes, or any other cauÅ¿e, rather than traduce and defame their Governours, and Å¿uÅ¿pect their fidelity to their own IntereÅ¿ts and Honour, which muÅ¿t be infinitely dear to any man of Å¿ence.

2. HiÅ¿tory will teach men, that Religion and Liberty are very ill Å¿ecured for the moÅ¿t part by Civil War and Rebellion: for as to the firÅ¿t, the right hand of God planted it in the World by Miracles and the effect of a mighty Providence, without Force, Wealth, Eloquence, or Policy, by
the Bloud and Patience, the MeekneÅ¿s and Å¿implicity, the HolineÅ¿s and ReÅ¿ignation of Saints, Martyrs, and Holy men: And as it was planted, Å¿o it muÅ¿t be defended, Å¿o it muÅ¿t be preÅ¿erved.

But then there is nothing in the world more contrary to this method, than for Subjects to raiÅ¿e Tumults, encourage InÅ¿urrections, liÅ¿t Armies, and attempt the ruine and deÅ¿truction of their Princes and fellow-Subjects, to defend this Faith; which was planted by MeekneÅ¿s, and watered with the blouds and tears of the Martyrs: and this, if Religion be never Å¿o apparently perÅ¿ecuted and endeavoured to be deÅ¿troyed. But who can delineate the madneÅ¿s of perpetrating all theÅ¿e horrid Villanies out of meer fear & jealouÅ¿ie Religion Å¿hould be deÅ¿igned upon, before there is one drop of Bloud Å¿pilt, or one man ruined or attempted to be ruined?

And as to Civil Liberty and Property, they were won from kind and good-natured Princes, by the dutiful Carriage and Civility of their Subjects. And therefore there is Å¿carce a footÅ¿tep of them to be found amongst thoÅ¿e Nations that were never Civilized; and many of them have never enjoyed thoÅ¿e rare BleÅ¿Å¿ings, but in a low degree, and Å¿ome Å¿carce at all, as the ancient Egyptians.

Now as there is nothing more ungrateful, than for men to turn the Favours of their Princes, or indeed of any man, into occaÅ¿ions of Quarrels and ReÅ¿iÅ¿tance, even when there is a real cauÅ¿e to be concern'd for the loÅ¿s of theÅ¿e precious
and ineÅ¿timable Jewels; Å¿o is there nothing more fooliÅ¿h, than for men to put theÅ¿e Darlings of theirs to nurÅ¿e in Fields and Camps, reeking with the Bloud of their fellow-Subjects, Å¿urrounded with Fire and Smoak amidÅ¿t the roaring of Cannon, the ratling of Drums, the Å¿hrikes and groans of dying men, and all that is dreadful to fleÅ¿h and bloud; and after all to fall into the hands of an enraged Prince, if he prevails; and into the leÅ¿s-merciful clutches of their own Souldiers, if they happen to overcome their Prince. Certainly there cannot be a more impolitick Errour committed by Subjects, than to reÅ¿iÅ¿t and rebel, when their Priviledges are really invaded: but then to do all this by way of prevention to be wheadled and cajoled into Å¿uch miÅ¿eries as thoÅ¿e with the meer fears and jealouÅ¿ies of contingent and poÅ¿Å¿ible deÅ¿ignes, this is a degree of Rage beyond all other human madneÅ¿Å¿es, and can be inÅ¿pired by nothing but Furies & incroaching Devils, who take poÅ¿Å¿eÅ¿Å¿ion of the very Å¿ouls of Å¿uch men, as they are Å¿aid to have done heretofore of Å¿ome mens bodies. And there is not a more powerful Amulet againÅ¿t theÅ¿e MiÅ¿eries, than a due obÅ¿ervation of the Tragedies theÅ¿e Devils have heretofore raiÅ¿ed in the world. The truth is, almoÅ¿t all the Nation are Å¿atisfied that next the Mercies of God, nothing did more contribute to our late PreÅ¿ervation, than the remembrance of our former MiÅ¿eries: And the HiÅ¿tory of them may have very near the Å¿ame effect upon our PoÅ¿terity.

3. The third and laÅ¿t Political uÅ¿e of HiÅ¿tory, is to acquaint the World with the nature and temper of men. There is Å¿carce any thing more difficult than for a man to know himÅ¿elf well; and if he did not Å¿ometimes Å¿ee himÅ¿elf in others, he would hardly perhaps ever do it: But then who but God can pretend to know all the various, changeable, and inconÅ¿tant humours, deÅ¿ignes, and ends of the MaÅ¿s of Mankind in the Å¿pace of thoÅ¿e few years we are to live? and yet if it were poÅ¿Å¿ible, how infinite is the danger of being miÅ¿taken and purchaÅ¿ing our experience at the price of our ruine?

But HiÅ¿tory, like a kind MiÅ¿triÅ¿s, leads us by the hand into her delightful Gardens, and there reads Lectures upon every Flower, Plant, and Weed, and truly acquaints us how this and the other Å¿ped well or ill; and then aÅ¿Å¿ures us our Fortune will be the Å¿ame, if we be not Å¿o wiÅ¿e as to take her word, but will be trying over again the Å¿ame Experiments upon our Å¿elves or others. But above all, if we take Demagoues, People-drivers, the Flatterers and Adorers of the Many, for good men, or good friends, or in Å¿hort, any man for a good Commonwealths-man or Patriot, who is not a good loyal hearty Subject.

If men would thus a while conÅ¿ult in HiÅ¿tory the honeÅ¿t policy of preÅ¿erving themÅ¿elves and their Countries from Ruine and ConfuÅ¿ion, they could not but obÅ¿erve, that Immorality was in every Age the greateÅ¿t Enemy of Mankind.
That Ambition, Pride, Avarice, Revenge, LuÅ¿t, and Luxury, and the reÅ¿t of thoÅ¿e horrid deformities of Mortality, were the real weights which Å¿et theÅ¿e Machines in motion, which have torn down Empires, and ruined the most flouriÅ¿hing Kingdoms; and particularly have in the memory of man twice, bid fair for the ruine of ours, under two Princes of Å¿o exact a JuÅ¿tice, and Å¿o God-like a Clemency and GoodneÅ¿s, that their Subjects having no real Calamities to complain of (which is a Felicity rarely given by Heaven to the beÅ¿t Ages) our wanton Countrymen, Å¿ick of Peace, Plenty, and ProÅ¿perity, rifled the Cabinet of God Almighty, and the innocent boÅ¿oms of two excellent Princes, and pretended they diÅ¿covered their deÅ¿ignes of introducing Popery and Arbitrary Government. And by theÅ¿e Chimerical fears intoxicated and bewiched the poor Populace, and putting them at last in fearful Commotions, theÅ¿e quick-Å¿ighted Privado's of Heaven, the CenÅ¿ors of Princes, the Darlings of the Rabble, mounted the Saddle, and drove the People as the Devils did the heard of Swine down the Å¿teep Rocks of Rebellion, SchiÅ¿m, and TreaÅ¿on, while they who put them into this miÅ¿erable condition, reaped the Wealth, and divided the Honours and Employments of the Nation amongst them, and under the mask of a pompous Piety, were religiouÅ¿ly proud, covetous, ambitious, revengeful, inÅ¿olent, treacherous, perjurous, and in a word, a parcel of the moÅ¿t Å¿anctified Rogues and Traytors that ever the Sun Å¿hin'd upon.

When God Almighty reduced us out of our Hell of MiÅ¿ery, and Chaos of ConfuÅ¿ion, there was no Apologie more frequent in the mouths of men than this: Who could have thought that men of Å¿uch Å¿eeming Piety, of Å¿o exalted and eminent a zeal for the Glory of God, the ProteÅ¿tant Religion, and the Liberty and Property of the Subject, that Å¿uch men, I Å¿ay, as theÅ¿e Å¿hould hatch in their minds Å¿uch horrid Villanies, TreaÅ¿ons, Rapines, Murders, Perjuries, and ambitious Projects, as we have Å¿ince with aÅ¿toniÅ¿hment Å¿een them practiÅ¿e? Well, if they had wiÅ¿ely conÅ¿idered the HiÅ¿tories of other Countries, or of former Ages, they might eaÅ¿ily have foreÅ¿een and prevented all this MiÅ¿ery: for whenever men are more Å¿ollicitous for the faults of their Superiours, than careful to amend their own; when they Å¿eek to win the entire love and eÅ¿teem of Subjects from their Princes and Governours; let the outÅ¿ide be what it will, there is Pride, Ambition, Avarice, and DiÅ¿content within: and therefore Å¿uch men, of all others, are never to be truÅ¿ted.

This Thought well purÅ¿ued, will lead a man home too, and give him an occaÅ¿ion to Å¿earch his own heart, and try diligently whether he is a good and uÅ¿eful Member of the Civil Society in which he lives: If he is under the dominion of any of theÅ¿e Vices, let him never call himÅ¿elf a loyal Subject, or a good Patriot; for whatever his preÅ¿ent intentions are, he will be neither,
when his IntereÅ¿t Å¿hall lie croÅ¿s to his Duty. And becauÅ¿e it is much harder to believe ill of ones Å¿elf, than of another, let HiÅ¿tory acquaint him how many men have been drawn in by their own Å¿ecret, and in all probability to themÅ¿elves undiÅ¿covered Vices, till beyond their firÅ¿t intentions or thoughts, they have been Å¿wallowed up in an AbyÅ¿s of horrible Crimes and DiÅ¿orders; and what have betided them, may be our lot too, if we do not purge out, or at leaÅ¿t watch the motions of theÅ¿e DiÅ¿turbers of the World in us.

The Doctrines of Morality are Å¿ometimes unpleaÅ¿ant and uneaÅ¿ie to corrupted minds, and do not eaÅ¿ily inÅ¿inuate and obtain admiÅ¿Å¿ion; and when they are received, do often make Å¿uch Å¿light impreÅ¿Å¿ions, that they vaniÅ¿h in oblivion and forgetfulneÅ¿s: but examples convey them to us with pleaÅ¿ure and delight, and the variety and wonderful accidents that are to be met with in all HiÅ¿tories, which are nothing but the imagery and various colours of Virtues and Vices embodied and made viÅ¿ible to us, make vived and laÅ¿ting impreÅ¿Å¿ions on the minds of men, and Å¿tamp and engrave the Ideas of them on the fancy and memory, Å¿o that nothing but death can deÅ¿troy or obliterate thoÅ¿e impreÅ¿Å¿ions. And this was one reaÅ¿on why the Ancients cloathed their moral ObÅ¿ervations in Apologues, Fables, and Parables; but HiÅ¿tory having the reality of perÅ¿ons, names, times, and places, do infinitely exceed theÅ¿e fictitious repreÅ¿entations:
and therefore as HiÅ¿tory grew up in the World, theÅ¿e fictitious Images of it were laid by and antiquated.

Examples fit all Capacities, at leaÅ¿t Å¿ome or others of them, in a vaÅ¿t variety; whereas Precepts can hardly be Å¿o cloathed, but Å¿ome will deÅ¿piÅ¿e the meanneÅ¿s of the language, or others not underÅ¿tand the goodneÅ¿s of it: whereas Examples fit themÅ¿elves to all Capacities, and teach men before they are aware of it, the lovelineÅ¿s of Virtue, the turpitude and baÅ¿eneÅ¿s of Vice, and the different events which for the moÅ¿t part in every Age have attended them.

This brings me to the third particular I propoÅ¿ed, the divine uÅ¿e of HiÅ¿tory. As the World was not the Product of blind Fate or Chance, but the Work of a Great, WiÅ¿e, and Holy God, who raiÅ¿ed and built it out of Nothing by his infinite Power, and by his WiÅ¿dom brought it into this beautiful order in which we behold and admire it: So neither did he deÅ¿ert it when he had form'd and adorn'd it, but has ever Å¿ince govern'd it with one unÅ¿earchable and irreÅ¿iÅ¿tible Providence and WiÅ¿dom. And this not onely the inanimate and irrational part of it, but above all, his eyes are upon the children of men; and in the government, protection, preÅ¿ervation, rewarding and puniÅ¿hing, exalting and abaÅ¿ing them, he exerciÅ¿eth Å¿o Å¿teady, juÅ¿t, and reaÅ¿onable a Providence, but withal, Å¿o abÅ¿truÅ¿e, hidden, and reÅ¿erved, that it exceeds the WiÅ¿dom of the greateÅ¿t
and wiÅ¿eÅ¿t of men to penetrate into the reaÅ¿ons of it, or to foreÅ¿ee the events before they diÅ¿cover themÅ¿elves in time.

Now in the HiÅ¿tory of the Actions and Events of mankind, there is an undeÅ¿igned HiÅ¿tory of this Providence of God, which like Å¿ome Rivers, Å¿ometimes run above ground plain and delightful, or terrible and inÅ¿tructive at the firÅ¿t glance; but at others, buries it Å¿elf under Mountains and Hills: and though in thoÅ¿e Å¿ecret receÅ¿Å¿es it Å¿till (like thoÅ¿e Rivers) maintains an uninterrupted courÅ¿e, yet can no mortal eyes purÅ¿ue its Å¿treams, and obÅ¿erve its windings and turnings, or when and where it will break out and again diÅ¿cover it Å¿elf, till he himÅ¿elf is pleaÅ¿ed to bring it into the light again.

Now HiÅ¿tory has brought down an uninterrupted thread of the methods of Providence from the creation of the World to this day; by which, as in a GlaÅ¿s, we may Å¿ee a repreÅ¿entation of the JuÅ¿tice and Mercy of God in his dealings with the Å¿ons of men, and admire that wonderful WiÅ¿dom and Power, which, without offering violence to the freedom of mens wills, has yet been able to diÅ¿poÅ¿e them to effect his own moÅ¿t holy purpoÅ¿es, when they leaÅ¿t deÅ¿igned it; without any violence has protected Virtue againÅ¿t the utmost rage of Men and Devils, and preÅ¿erved it through all the Ages of an ill World; and puniÅ¿hed Vice by it Å¿elf, in ways Å¿o abÅ¿truÅ¿e and Å¿ecret, that the Workers of Iniquity
have been Å¿tun'd and amazed to Å¿ee not onely their ill deÅ¿ignes over-ruled, but made the InÅ¿truments of their own deÅ¿erved ruine.

There is no one thing that hath in every Age Å¿o much Å¿taggered the belief of a divine Providence governing the World and the Affairs of Mankind, as the proÅ¿perity of wicked and lewd men, and the miÅ¿ery and oppreÅ¿Å¿ion of good and virtuous men. But this MiÅ¿t will vaniÅ¿h like Å¿moak, when men are pleaÅ¿ed to take a view of past Ages, and obÅ¿erve the CataÅ¿trophies of the Å¿everal Periods and Ages: for that which may Å¿eem at one time to be all MyÅ¿tery and Riddle, will by degrees open and unfold it Å¿elf, till at laÅ¿t there will be nothing more apparent, than that God had all this while his eyes upon both the one and the other, and kept the inviÅ¿ible Reins in his own hands, and by ways, unperceived both by the good and bad, at laÅ¿t, tho not Å¿uddenly, brought them to their deÅ¿erved ends, and recompenced both according to their different deÅ¿erts; and this will give us an aÅ¿Å¿urance, that as it has been in paÅ¿t Ages, Å¿o it will be in ours; the Å¿ame God is Å¿till at the Helm, and he will, as heretofore he has, conduct us alÅ¿o to that end we have deÅ¿erved, be it good or bad, without reÅ¿pect of perÅ¿ons, which will preÅ¿erve us in Peace and Virtue, diÅ¿pel all melancholly thoughts, and free us both from Å¿peculative and practical temptations.

It is not hard to apply all I have Å¿aid to the HiÅ¿tory of our Late Revolutions in England;
but as I deÅ¿igne a Preface to a very Å¿hort HiÅ¿tory of them, and Å¿o muÅ¿t not be long: Å¿o the Reader will be much more inÅ¿tructed and better pleaÅ¿ed to reflect upon that HiÅ¿tory, and to compare it with this Preface, and then determine with himÅ¿elf whether theÅ¿e thoughts of mine upon this occaÅ¿ion are pertinent, and whether there be any thing in the following Story that will prove and illuÅ¿trate the truth of what I have here Å¿aid; and therefore to him I Å¿hall leave it.
But becauÅ¿e theÅ¿e Pieces never appeared before in EngliÅ¿h, may I have the Readers leave to give him a Å¿hort account of the deÅ¿ignes of them.

The Author of the firÅ¿t two Parts was Dr. Geo. Bates, a learned and an eminent PhyÅ¿ician of London in the laÅ¿t Age, who was afterwards PhyÅ¿ician to Oliver Cromwel, and Å¿o muÅ¿t of neceÅ¿Å¿ity be intimately acquainted with many things which were not known to others, and had means to look through all the diÅ¿guiÅ¿es of that cunning ImpoÅ¿tor, as his Station and Employment alÅ¿o afforded him an eaÅ¿ie acceÅ¿s to most of the Grandees that had then a large Å¿hare in promoting the MiÅ¿eries of England. The firÅ¿t part was publiÅ¿hed in the time of Oliver Cromwel, and yet is written in an Air and Stile which Å¿hews the Author durst Å¿peak truth, when if diÅ¿covered, his life would have paid the price of his Veracity; and yet that time too may yield us a good aÅ¿Å¿urance he did not venture his life for falÅ¿hoods and Å¿launders; it was not
then a time to bely proÅ¿perous, inÅ¿olent, and inraged Villains.
He gives us this account of the Work himÅ¿elf by an Epilogue added in a latter impreÅ¿Å¿ion, at the end of the FirÅ¿t Part.

WhilÅ¿t the Original of this Å¿mall HiÅ¿tory was in Writing, it was Å¿everal times Å¿een by the Reverend George Lord BiÅ¿hop of WincheÅ¿ter, the Worthy Nicholas Oudart Secretary and CounÅ¿ellour to the Prince of Orange; by Sir John Wederburn Knight; by Dr. Richard Owen ProfeÅ¿Å¿or of Divinity, and Rector of St. Swithins in London; by Dr. George Ent, heretofore PhyÅ¿ician to Charles the FirÅ¿t, and now to the preÅ¿ent King; and alÅ¿o by Fabian Philips an Attorney, who was my AÅ¿Å¿iÅ¿tant in Å¿earching the Rolls, Offices, and Monuments of the Law, (that I may not mention Dugard who printed it) men above all exceptions: although there is an inÅ¿olent Defamer, who pretends I have fathered another mans Work, whoÅ¿e Calumnies I neither value nor fear.

This PaÅ¿Å¿age is inÅ¿erted by him onely to prove he was the Author of it, but is at the Å¿ame time a Å¿trong proof of his integrity: for it is very well known, theÅ¿e PerÅ¿ons were not all of one Å¿ide in our late DiÅ¿tractions.

The firÅ¿t Part of this Piece was firÅ¿t printed about the year 1651, without his name, for the information of Strangers, and therefore he premiÅ¿eth a Å¿hort account of the Prerogatives of the
Crown, and the Priviledges of Parliament, and Liberties of the Subject, here; which had been Å¿o abominably miÅ¿repreÅ¿ented to Forreigners, that they Å¿tood generally in great doubt on which Å¿ide the right lay, and conÅ¿idering the time when it came out firÅ¿t, nothing could be of greater uÅ¿e and benefit to the then-oppreÅ¿Å¿ed intereÅ¿t of our late Soveraign.

Nor was it onely uÅ¿eful abroad, but at home alÅ¿o: for the People of England were then Å¿o diÅ¿tracted by the Contradictions betwixt the Royal and the Rebel Party, that they, at leaÅ¿t many of them, did as little know on which Å¿ide to give their Verdict, as the Neighbour Nations. Hence the Learned and Ingenuous Mr. Henry Foulis, in his Preface to his HiÅ¿tory of the wicked Plots of our pretended Saints, gives us this Account of himÅ¿elf: As for the Author (Å¿aith he) whilÅ¿t a School-boy, he was too much Å¿way'd to Presbytery; and delighting in the Stories of our Times, had none to peruÅ¿e, but May, Vicars, Ricraft, and Å¿uch-like partial Relators: by which means believing, with the ignorant, all things in print to be true, he was perÅ¿waded to encline to the wrong Å¿ide. But a little before his going to the Æ²niverÅ¿ity, lighting by chance upon Dr. Bates's judicious Book Elenchus Motuum, he found the Laws and true Government to be oppoÅ¿ite to his former Readings, and therein the Knavery and Jugling of their OppoÅ¿ers, Å¿trange things which
he had never heard of before. Which, with Å¿ome other aÅ¿Å¿iÅ¿tance, Å¿o far prevail'd with him, that in a Å¿hort time he threw off Father SchiÅ¿m, and ever Å¿ince, like little Loyal John in the Epitaph,
For the King, and Church, and Bloud-Royal,
He went as true as any Sun-Dial.
There are Å¿ome others who have acknowledged to the World in print, the benefit they and the Government received from this firÅ¿t Part.

The Second Part was added by Dr. Bates, after his late MajeÅ¿ties ReÅ¿titution, to inform the World of the manner of his MajeÅ¿ties EÅ¿cape from WorceÅ¿ter, and how things were carried till the depoÅ¿ition of Richard Cromwel, wherein is an excellent account of the bloudy War in Ireland, and the juÅ¿t Judgment of God upon the Scotch Covenanters for joyning with our EngliÅ¿h Parliamentarians, upon pretence of Å¿etting up Presbytery here, but indeed to inrich themÅ¿elves the Å¿econd time with the Spoils of England; the effect of which was, that Presbytery was ruined even in Scotland by O. C. and his victorious Independant Army, and they loÅ¿t at the Å¿ame time all their Civil Priviledges, and were treated, till the Kings return, as a conquered People by their fellow-Rebels.

The Third Part was written by one Dr. Tho. Skynner, another Learned PhyÅ¿ician, to continue
and bring down the Story, and Å¿hew the Joy of our Nation at the ReÅ¿titution of his late MajeÅ¿ty. It is in the Original written in a florid Å¿tile, and full of curious and ingenuous Reflections.

The TranÅ¿lations of all theÅ¿e have been managed with great care, to make them both true to the Originals, and delightful to the Reader; onely the TranÅ¿lator thought fit to Å¿upply Å¿ome Papers which are but hinted at, or wholly omitted in the Author; as the Treaty of the IÅ¿le of Wight, in the FirÅ¿t Part; the Coronation-Oath, in the Third; and others. And alÅ¿o when there are any Papers or ExpreÅ¿Å¿ions mentioned, to publiÅ¿h the original Papers and words, when he could find them; but when not, he hath humoured the TranÅ¿lation as near the Latin as the Å¿ence of the Author and idiome of the two Languages would permit.

There is great hope that this Å¿hort account of our late horrible ConfuÅ¿ions here in England, which is Å¿o acceptable in the Original to all Forreigners and Learned EngliÅ¿h-men, may now tranÅ¿lated be no leÅ¿s acceptable to all thoÅ¿e who either cannot read the Latin, or care not to give themÅ¿elves Å¿o much trouble; and that it may contribute Å¿omething to the interest of the Government, by forewarning men how they betake themÅ¿elves to thoÅ¿e courÅ¿es again which produced Å¿uch dreadful Effects heretofore.

div.head: A Å¿hort HISTORICAL ACCOUNT OF THE RiÅ¿e and ProgreÅ¿s OF THE Late Troubles in England.
div.p: ENgland, The Right of Kings in England, as all the Records of our Antiquity tell us, never was governed but by the authority of a King; and though it hath been divided into Å¿everal Kingdoms, or rather Camps, yet it never had reÅ¿t from inteÅ¿tine Commotions, nor foreign InvaÅ¿ions, till it came under the Obedience and Protection to one Å¿ole Monarch.

Since that,In the perÅ¿on of a Monarch, for above a thouÅ¿and years, it is now above a thouÅ¿and years that Kings in a continued Å¿ucceÅ¿Å¿ion have reigned with Å¿upreme Authority in England. And Å¿o great all along hath been the Love and Reverence that the People have had towards a Prince, that he was always judged the fitteÅ¿t and moÅ¿t worthy of the Government, who was next in Bloud to the King;And he hereditary, Å¿o that no factious Election, but lawful Birthright, could ever warrant a Title to the Crown. The Royal Heir of the laÅ¿t King, though an Infant, is immediately carried to the Throne, even in the Cradle:
And in this kind of immortality in reigning, the Laws glory,
And never dying.
To him all Å¿wear Allegiance
That the King of England never dies.

Nay, and by the ancient common Law, all Subjects above twelve years of age, are bound by Oath to bear a peculiar Faith (by the Laws called Allegiance) to the lawful Prince, to him alone, and for ever, even before he be crowned; and that their Obedience may be confirmed upon a double account, a religious Oath,and Supremacy. that of Supremacy, is likewiÅ¿e to be taken to the King.

I muÅ¿t here beg the Readers pardon, if in the very beginning I Å¿peak of the Kings Prerogative, the Priviledges of Parliament, and Liberties of the People; which to our Country-men who have Å¿tudied the point, perhaps may be tedious, though to the Work we now undertake it be abÅ¿olutely neceÅ¿Å¿ary; Å¿eeing thereby it will appear who have been the Violators, and who the ObÅ¿ervers of the Laws.

The Prerogatives of the K. or chief marks of MajeÅ¿ty, and the Regalia, belong onely to the King.In the firÅ¿t place, what great power the King has over the lives and fortunes of his Subjects, is hereby made manifeÅ¿t, that mediately or immediately they all hold their EÅ¿tates of the King; that is to Å¿ay, that whatever Lands and PoÅ¿Å¿eÅ¿Å¿ions they enjoy in fee or feudal rights, they owe them more to the bounty of the King than to Fortune.

So that all EÅ¿tates and PoÅ¿Å¿eÅ¿Å¿ions are derived from him, and to him return at laÅ¿t. He hath the care of Pupils and Lunaticks.And therefore all EÅ¿tates failing of lawful Heirs, or when the Owners forfeit them by Felony or TreaÅ¿on, flow back to the Kings Exchequer, as to the Ocean from whence they have been derived.

The King, as Father of the Country, has the care of the perÅ¿ons of Pupils and Lunaticks, and enjoys their Rents and Revenues. Nay, by the ancient Laws, it is not lawful for them to contract Marriage without his conÅ¿ent; and if they do, they are to be Å¿everely cenÅ¿ured.

The power of coyning Money.And that what is to be given to CaeÅ¿ar, may be known by the publick Money, the matter, form,
manner, and value of Coyn, is varied according to the will and pleaÅ¿ure of the King.

All Honours, Titles, and Priviledges, He confers all Honours and Offices; all publick Corporations and Societies, flow from and are conÅ¿tituted by the Crown; the Admiral, Chancellor, TreaÅ¿urer, Judges, Sheriffs, JuÅ¿tices of Peace, are onely made by the King;Which are to be adminiÅ¿tred in his name alone. in whoÅ¿e name alone their Writs, Warrants, and Sentences paÅ¿s: nor does any of them enter into Office before he hath taken an Oath of Fidelity to the King, and of faithful adminiÅ¿tration.

None but the King has power of Peace and War, His power in matters of War. who orders Military DiÅ¿cipline according to his will and pleaÅ¿ure, and not by the forms or preÅ¿cripts of Laws; and as he himÅ¿elf thinks fit, diÅ¿poÅ¿es of the Forces both by Sea and Land; it being neceÅ¿Å¿ary that he who watches for the Å¿afety of the Commonwealth, Å¿hould be inveÅ¿ted with Å¿ufficient Power to repreÅ¿s inteÅ¿tine Seditions, and repel foreign InvaÅ¿ions. Upon that account, it belongs onely to him to appoint MuÅ¿ters and Levies of Souldiers, Å¿ecure the CaÅ¿tles and GariÅ¿ons (with which maritim Fortifications England, even in the profoundeÅ¿t time of Peace, is no leÅ¿s Å¿ecured than by the Seas); as often as there is need alÅ¿o to fit out a Fleet, and to Å¿et Governours and Commanders over both.

Nor is the Sword neither to be weilded by any other hand but that which Å¿ways the Scepter: Å¿o that if any one (without the Kings command) take up Arms for the defence of the Kings PerÅ¿on and Rights, he is by Å¿o doing guilty of High-TreaÅ¿on, and liable to the puniÅ¿hment of a Traytor, without a Å¿pecial Pardon from the King.

Nor is his Power more limited in EccleÅ¿iaÅ¿tical than Civil affairs:AlÅ¿o in EccleÅ¿iaÅ¿tical affairs. for Å¿ince the authority of the Pope being Å¿haken off, the Church was made part of the Kingdom, and the Clergy after long reluctancy
began to be contented with the common priviledges of Subjects; the King became at length CuÅ¿tos utriuÅ¿
que tabulae, and (as he ever was in right before, Å¿o was he then) acknowledged and confirmed by Law to be Å¿upreme Head and Governour in Å¿piritual as well as temporal affairs, and owned to be in a manner the BiÅ¿hop of the Kingdom; wherein, in the promotion of BiÅ¿hops, conferring of Dignities, appointing FaÅ¿ts, enjoyning Rites and Ceremonies in the Church, he hath (with the advice of the Fathers and Rulers of the Church) always exerciÅ¿ed a Å¿upreme and Å¿acred Power and Authority.

He moderates the rigour of Laws.He hath alÅ¿o Å¿o great power over the Laws themÅ¿elves (though he obliges himÅ¿elf to govern according to Law) that Å¿ometimes he moderates the rigour of the Law according to Equity, pardons Malefactors;And judges in undecided caÅ¿es. and in caÅ¿es that are not decided by any Law, interpoÅ¿es his Imperial Sentence. LaÅ¿tly, that I may aÅ¿Å¿ert nothing raÅ¿hly, but all upon the credit of Lawyers, the life, force, and authority of every thing that is acted in England, is to be found in the King alone.

But becauÅ¿e the King of England has not, like Briareus, an hundred hands, nor can he, like the Sun, view all things at one glance; he hath been accuÅ¿tomed to create from amongÅ¿t the Nobility, BiÅ¿hops, Judges, He chuÅ¿es his own CounÅ¿ellors. and Commons of the Kingdom, without the envy and emulation of any, Å¿uch and Å¿o many CounÅ¿ellors as he pleaÅ¿es, to aÅ¿Å¿iÅ¿t and eaÅ¿e him in the weighty care of the Government.

He that mounts the Throne is never to be brought to the Bar, Å¿ince the Law Å¿ays he cannot die.Having named theÅ¿e Prerogatives of a moÅ¿t AuguÅ¿t and Imperial Crown, what Å¿hall I call that barbarous and inhumane Principle and PurpoÅ¿e of bringing the King to Judgment before the Kings Tribunal, and then to Å¿mite him with the Sword which he alone is to draw; the King, I Å¿ay, whom
the Law it Å¿elf openly declares can never die? There is no neceÅ¿Å¿ity of curbing arbitrary government by Å¿uch inhumane Tyranny upon the Å¿acred PerÅ¿on of the King, Å¿ince whatever may be done in the adminiÅ¿tration of the Government, either againÅ¿t the Laws of the Country, or inconÅ¿iÅ¿tent with the good and profit of the People, the blame and puniÅ¿hment of it is caÅ¿t upon the publick MiniÅ¿ters: Å¿o that it was not flattery, but the higheÅ¿t JuÅ¿tice which gave ground to this noted maxime,Nor can he err, or do wrong. But as he offends by his MiniÅ¿ters, Å¿o is he puniÅ¿hed. That the King cannot err, nor do any wrong; becauÅ¿e the whole blame and all the puniÅ¿hment is wont, and ought to fall upon the publick MiniÅ¿ters and CounÅ¿ellors, whoÅ¿e duty it is to admoniÅ¿h the Prince, and to deny their concurrence with him in any thing that is unjuÅ¿t; and to reÅ¿igne their place, rather than obey him when he commands any thing contrary to Law.

Nay,The Heir of the Crown is by the death of his PredeceÅ¿Å¿or ipÅ¿o facto cleared from all guilt. the Laws are Å¿o Å¿ollicitous for the Å¿afety of the Prince, as of him who is to maintain and preÅ¿erve the Law, that the next Heir to the Crown, whatÅ¿oever Crime he might be guilty or accuÅ¿ed of whilÅ¿t he was a private perÅ¿on, yet by the death of his PredeceÅ¿Å¿or, as by a certain poÅ¿tliminious AbÅ¿olution, he is freed from all taint and guilt; and his Å¿tepping up into the Throne purges him from all defects. It is enough to curb him that holds the Reins of the Government, That he muÅ¿t expect the Judgment of God.

NevertheleÅ¿s,Yet it is not lawful to rule arbitrarily. it is not lawful for the King to rule arbitrarily in England, oppreÅ¿s his Subjects, or make and abrogate Laws by his Å¿ole Authority. But as the Law allows a decorous adminiÅ¿tration of abÅ¿olute Authority in Å¿ome things to the King, Å¿o does it aÅ¿Å¿igne to the Commons others,VVhat Rights belong to Parliaments. and thoÅ¿e no inconÅ¿iderable Priviledges in the Kingdom, in common with the King, that Å¿o the joynt Authority in Government might the more eaÅ¿ily engage the Subjects to obedience.

To make and repeal Laws.For, for the making and repealing of Laws, and the interpreting and explaining former ambiguous Statutes;ImpoÅ¿e Taxes. for raiÅ¿ing of Money out of the ordinary courÅ¿e,Legitimate BaÅ¿tards. when there is occaÅ¿ion for it; legitimating of BaÅ¿tards; naturalizing of Strangers; altering and Å¿etling the Rights of PoÅ¿Å¿eÅ¿Å¿ions;Enact the VVorÅ¿hip of God. confirming by civil Sanctions the Divine WorÅ¿hip, after it hath by the Convention of the Clergy been formed according to the Word of God; Å¿etting Rates upon Weights and MeaÅ¿ures,Set Rates on VVeights and MeaÅ¿ures. and the like; that the people may not Å¿eem to Å¿uffer any thing without their own conÅ¿ent and concurrence, the Votes of Parliament, which is the Å¿upreme Court of England, and in conjunction with the King, under God, hath a certain Omnipotence in this little World, are neceÅ¿Å¿arily required.

VVhat the Parliament of England is.The Parliament is an AÅ¿Å¿embly of the States of the Kingdom, conÅ¿iÅ¿ting of the BiÅ¿hops, Lords, and RepreÅ¿entatives of the Commons, called by the King who is the Head of it, who meet and Å¿it in two diÅ¿tinct places called the Upper and Lower HouÅ¿es, in reÅ¿pect of dignity not of Å¿cituation. The Upper HouÅ¿e (which is called the HouÅ¿e of Lords) contains two EÅ¿tates,The Æ²pper HouÅ¿e of it. to wit, the Spiritual Lords who are the BiÅ¿hops, and the Temporal who are Dukes, MarqueÅ¿Å¿es, Earls, and Barons; the Judges of the Kingdom aÅ¿Å¿iÅ¿ting to give advice in matter of Law, but not to vote.

The Lower.The Lower HouÅ¿e conÅ¿iÅ¿ts of the third EÅ¿tate of the Kingdom, who are the Commons, and is therefore called alÅ¿o the HouÅ¿e of Commons; they are choÅ¿en by the plurality of Voices of the Freeholders of the Counties, and Freemen of Corporations, two Knights for each County or Shire, and two BurgeÅ¿Å¿es for the moÅ¿t part for every City and Corporation-Town, according to the uÅ¿e and cuÅ¿tom of the place.

The day and place of the meeting of the Parliament is appointed by the King;The time and place appointed by the King. by him alÅ¿o it is prorogued, transferred, and adjourned to another place, or diÅ¿Å¿olved at his pleaÅ¿ure.

The Peers are Å¿ummoned to attend in Parliament by Writs Å¿everally directed to them,They are called by VVrits. and Å¿igned by the King. To the reÅ¿t the Sheriffs of the Å¿everal Counties by virtue of a Writ out of the Chancery, give notice that the King within a certain time orders an Election to be made of Knights and BurgeÅ¿Å¿es, which he commands to be made by the Sheriff in time and place convenient.

div.p:
ReÅ¿criptum Regis ad DynaÅ¿tas Å¿eu Pares Å¿ic Å¿onat: Carolus Dei gratiÃ¢, &c. ReverendiÅ¿Å¿imo in ChriÅ¿to Patri, &c. (Å¿i EpiÅ¿copos compellet) ConÅ¿anguineo noÅ¿tro (Å¿i Duces, Marchiones vel Comites alloquatur) Dilecto & fideli noÅ¿tro (Å¿i Barones.) Quia de adviÅ¿amento Concilii noÅ¿tri, pro quibuÅ¿dam arduis & urgentibus negotiis, Nos, & Statum & defenÅ¿ionem Regni noÅ¿tri Angliae & EccleÅ¿iae Anglicanae concernentibus, quoddam Parlamentum noÅ¿trum ad WeÅ¿tmonaÅ¿t. &c. teneri ordinavimus, & ibidem vobiÅ¿cum & cum caeteris Praelatis, Magnatibus & Proceribus dicti Regni noÅ¿tri Angliae colloquium habere & tractatum; vobis in fide & Dilectione
(Å¿i ad EpiÅ¿copos mittatur ReÅ¿criptum) per fidem & Allegiantiam (Å¿i ad Pares) quibus nobis tenemini, firmiter injungendo mandamus, quod conÅ¿ideratis dictorum negotiorum arduitate & periculis imminentibus, ceÅ¿Å¿ante quacunque excuÅ¿atione, die & loco dictis, perÅ¿onaliter interÅ¿itis NobiÅ¿cum cum caeteris Praelatis, Magnatibus & Proceribus, Å¿uper dictis negotiis tractaturi, veÅ¿trÃºmque ConÅ¿ilium impenÅ¿uri; & hoc, Å¿icut Nos & honorem noÅ¿tram, ac Å¿alutem Regni praedicti & EccleÅ¿iae Å¿anctae, ExpeditionÃ©mque dictorum negotiorum diligitis, nullatenus omittatis, (Å¿i ad EpiÅ¿copos Å¿cribat) praemonere Decanum & Capitulum EccleÅ¿iae veÅ¿trae tolÃºmque Clerum veÅ¿trae DioeceÅ¿eos, quod idem Decanus & Archidiaconi in propriis perÅ¿onis, ac dictum Capitulum per unum, idÃ©mque Clerus per duos Procuratores idoneos, plenam & Å¿ufficientem poteÅ¿tatem ab ipÅ¿is Capitulo & Clero habentes, praedictis die & loco perÅ¿onaliter interÅ¿int, ad conÅ¿entiendum his quae tum ibidem de communi concilio Regni noÅ¿tri (DivinÃ¢ favente clementiÃ¢) contigerit ordinari.

div.head: The ancient form of the Writ to the Peers.
div.p:
The Kings Writ to the Nobles or Peers, runs thus: CHARLES by the grace of God, &c. to the moÅ¿t Reverend Father in ChriÅ¿t (if it Å¿peaks to any of the BiÅ¿hops) to Our CouÅ¿in (if it is addreÅ¿Å¿ed to any Duke, MarqueÅ¿s, or Earl) To our Beloved and Faithful (if to a Baron.) Whereas by the advice of Our Council We have ordained that Our Parliament Å¿hall be holden at WeÅ¿tminÅ¿ter, &c. for the diÅ¿patch of certain difficult and urgent Affairs concerning (or pertaining to) Us, and the State and Defence of Our Kingdom of England, and of the Church of England, and there to hold a Colloquy and Treat with you and with the
reÅ¿t of the Prelates, Great men and Nobles of Our Å¿aid Kingdom of England: Therefore We, by the Fidelity and Love (if the Writ be Å¿ent to the BiÅ¿hops) by the Fidelity and Allegiance, (if to any of the Peers) which you owe to Us, Å¿treightly injoyning, command you, that in conÅ¿ideration of the difficulty of the aforeÅ¿aid Affairs, and of the Dangers impending, laying aÅ¿ide all ExcuÅ¿es, at the day and place aforeÅ¿aid you perÅ¿onally appear to treat with Us, together with the reÅ¿t of the Prelates, Great men, and Nobles, concerning the Affairs aforeÅ¿aid, and thereupon give Us your counÅ¿el. And this you are not to omit, as you love Us, and Our Honour, and the Safety of Our Å¿aid Kingdom, and the expedition of the Å¿aid Affairs.

And if the Writ be directed to a BiÅ¿hop, it goes on further thus: And you are to forewarn the Dean and Chapter of your Church, and all the Clergy of your DioceÅ¿s, that the Å¿aid Dean and the Archdeacons be perÅ¿onally preÅ¿ent; and the Å¿aid Chapter by one, and the Å¿aid Clergy by two Å¿ufficient Procurators, having full and Å¿ufficient power from the Å¿aid
Chapter and Clergy, at the day and place aforeÅ¿aid, to ConÅ¿ent to thoÅ¿e things which then and there (by the favour of the divine Clemency) Å¿hall happen to be ordained by the Common Council of Our Kingdom.

div.head: Ad Communes, Å¿eu Inferioris ConfeÅ¿Å¿us Senatores.
div.p:
Aliud ReÅ¿criptum ad Vicecomites & PraeÅ¿ides Civitatum, Å¿eu Municipiorum, conceptis hiÅ¿ce verbis itÃ Å¿e habet: Rex Vicecomiti Å¿alutem. Quia de adviÅ¿amento & aÅ¿Å¿enÅ¿u Concilii noÅ¿tri, &c. (progreditur ut Å¿uperius) & ibidem cum Praelatis, Magnatibus & Proceribus Regni noÅ¿tri Colloquium habere & tractatum; Tibi praecipimus firmiter injungentes, quÃ²d factÃ¢ Proclamatione in Comitatu tuo, poÅ¿t receptionem hujus Brevis noÅ¿tri, Parliamenti tenendi die & loco praedictis, duos Milites gladiis cinctos, magis idoneos & diÅ¿cretos ComitatÃ»s praedicti, & de qualibet Civitate ComitatÃ»s illius duos Cives, & de quolibet Burgo duos BurgenÅ¿es de diÅ¿cretioribus & magÃ¬s Å¿ufficientibus, liberÃ¨ & indifferenter per illos qui Electioni huic interfuerint, juxta formam Statutorum indÃ¨ edictorum &
proviÅ¿orum, eligi, & nomina eorundem Militum, Civium & BurgenÅ¿ium in quibuÅ¿dam Indenturis inter te & illos qui hujuÅ¿modi Electioni interfuerint conficiendis, Å¿ive hujuÅ¿modi electi praeÅ¿entes fuerint Å¿ive abÅ¿entes, inÅ¿eri, eÃ³Å¿que ad dictum diem & locum venire facies: ItÃ quÃ²d iidem Milites plenam & Å¿ufficientem poteÅ¿tatem pro Å¿e & Communitate praedicti ComitatÃ»s, ac dicti Cives & BurgenÅ¿es pro Å¿e & Communitatibus Civitatum & Burgorum praedictorum diviÅ¿im ab ipÅ¿is habeant, ad faciendum & conÅ¿entiendum his quae tum ibidem de communi Concilio Regni noÅ¿tri (favente Deo) contigerit ordinari Å¿uper negotiis antÃ¨ dictis, itÃ nÃ¨ pro defectu poteÅ¿tatis hujuÅ¿modi, Å¿eu propter improvidam Electionem Militum, Civium aut BurgenÅ¿ium praedictorum, praedicta negotia infecta maneant quovis modo. Nolumus tamen quÃ²d tu nec aliquis alius Vicecomes dicti Regni noÅ¿tri aliqualiter Å¿it electus.

div.head: To the Members of the HouÅ¿e of Commons.
div.p:
Another Writ directed to the Sheriffs and Chief MagiÅ¿trates of Cities and Corporations, runs thus: The King to the Sheriff greeting. Whereas by the Advice and AÅ¿Å¿ent of Our Council, &c. (as before) then and there to hold a Colloquy and Treaty with Our Prelates, Great men, and Nobles of Our Kingdom, &c. We command and Å¿treightly injoyn you that a Proclamation being made in your County (Court) after the receipt of this Our Writ, concerning Our Parliament to be holden at the day and place aforeÅ¿aid; you do cauÅ¿e two Knights of the moÅ¿t fitting and diÅ¿creet of your County aforeÅ¿aid, and of every City in the Å¿aid County two Citizens, and of every Burrow (or Corporation) two BurgeÅ¿Å¿es of the moÅ¿t diÅ¿creet and Å¿ufficient, to be
freely and indifferently choÅ¿en, according to the form of the Statutes in that caÅ¿e made and provided, by thoÅ¿e who Å¿hall be then preÅ¿ent at the Å¿aid Election; and you are alÅ¿o to inÅ¿ert the names of the Å¿aid Knights, Citizens, and BurgeÅ¿Å¿es (whether the perÅ¿ons Å¿o elected be preÅ¿ent or abÅ¿ent) in certain Indentures to be made betwixt you and thoÅ¿e who Å¿hall be preÅ¿ent at the Å¿aid Election, and you Å¿hall cauÅ¿e them to appear at the day and place aforeÅ¿aid: Å¿o as the Å¿aid Knights have full and Å¿ufficient power for themÅ¿elves and the Community of the aforeÅ¿aid County, and the Å¿aid Citizens and BurgeÅ¿Å¿es for themÅ¿elves and the Communities of the Å¿aid Cities and Corporations, Å¿everally to do and conÅ¿ent to thoÅ¿e things which (by the favour of God) Å¿hall by the Common Council of Our Kingdom be ordained concerning the Affairs aforeÅ¿aid; Å¿o that by the want of Å¿uch Power, or by the improvident Election of the Knights, Citizens, or BurgeÅ¿Å¿es aforeÅ¿aid, the Affairs aforeÅ¿aid be not in any way left unfiniÅ¿hed (undiÅ¿patched). Yet We will not that you or any other Sheriff of Our Å¿aid Kingdom be by any means elected.

TheÅ¿e things being punctually performed according to exactneÅ¿s of Law,The manner of meeting. the Members in a Å¿olemn and Å¿plendid ProceÅ¿Å¿ion, Å¿uch as may imprint an Awe and Reverence in the minds of the People, go firÅ¿t to Church, and then to the Parliament-houÅ¿e.The King declares the cauÅ¿es of their meeting in the Æ²pper HouÅ¿e. And at that time the King coming into the HouÅ¿e of Lords, and having called up the Members of the HouÅ¿e of Commons, either Å¿peaks to them himÅ¿elf, or cauÅ¿es the Lord Chancellor to declare to them the weighty cauÅ¿es of their meeting, and what it is he would have them conÅ¿ult and deliberate about for the Publick Good.
The King is not obliged afterward, unleÅ¿s he pleaÅ¿e, to be preÅ¿ent at their ConÅ¿ultations, except at the end of a SeÅ¿Å¿ion, that he may give the Å¿trength and vigour of a Law to their Bills.

The Knights and BurgeÅ¿Å¿es of the Lower HouÅ¿e have Å¿everally the Oath of Allegiance adminiÅ¿tred unto them by one appointed for that effect by the King; which amongÅ¿t other things, contains this clauÅ¿e:All and every one of the Members of the HouÅ¿e of Commons take the Oath of Allegiance to the King. I will bear Faith and true Allegiance to his MajeÅ¿ty, his Heirs and SucceÅ¿Å¿ors, and him and them will defend to the uttermoÅ¿t of my power, againÅ¿t all ConÅ¿piracies and Attempts whatÅ¿oever, which Å¿hall be made againÅ¿t his or their PerÅ¿ons, their Crown and Dignity; and make known unto his MajeÅ¿ty, his Heirs and SucceÅ¿Å¿ors, all TreaÅ¿ons and traiterous ConÅ¿piracies which I Å¿hall know and hoar of to be againÅ¿t him or any of them, &c.

But leÅ¿t any one being advanced to the high Honour and Dignity of conÅ¿ulting with the King, and Å¿haring in Å¿ome part of the Government, Å¿hould forget that he is Å¿till a Subject; the better to keep him within the bounds of duty, he is to take another Oath of Supremacy in theÅ¿e words:And of Supremacy. I A. B. do utterly teÅ¿tifie and declare in my ConÅ¿cience, That the Kings HighneÅ¿s is the onely Supreme Governour of this
Realm, and of all other his HighneÅ¿s's Dominions and Countries, as well in all Spiritual or EccleÅ¿iaÅ¿tical things or cauÅ¿es, as Temporal: and that no foreign Prince, PerÅ¿on, Prelate, State, or Potentate, hath or ought to have any JuriÅ¿diction, Power, Superiority, Preeminence, or Authority EccleÅ¿iaÅ¿tical or Spiritual within this Realm. And therefore I do utterly renounce and forÅ¿ake all foreign JuriÅ¿dictions, Powers, Superiorities, and Authorities; and do promiÅ¿e from henceforth I Å¿hall hear Faith and true Allegiance to the Kings HighneÅ¿s, his Heirs and lawful SucceÅ¿Å¿ors; and to my power Å¿hall aÅ¿Å¿iÅ¿t and defend all JuriÅ¿dictions, Priviledges, Pre-eminences, and Authorities granted or belonging to the Kings HighneÅ¿s, his Heirs and SucceÅ¿Å¿ors, or united or annexed to the Imperial Crown of this Realm. So help me God, and by the contents of this Book.

They chuÅ¿e a Speaker, whom they accompany to the King, beÅ¿eeching his Majesty to approve their Election.Being thus obliged to their duty upon their entry into this auÅ¿picious Honour by the Votes of the Lower HouÅ¿e (according to the Kings deÅ¿ignation or nomination) a Speaker is choÅ¿en, whom they accompany to the King, beÅ¿eeching his MajeÅ¿ty to approve their election; which the King readily grants. This being done, the Speaker in the name of himÅ¿elf and of all the Commons, thanks the King, and begs of his MajeÅ¿ty that they may enjoy their Priviledges, and have the freedom of debating; and that if any one in the heat of diÅ¿courÅ¿e Å¿hould Å¿peak too warmly,And not to be offended with their freedom in speech. his MajeÅ¿ty would not take it ill, nor be offended; and that they may have free acceÅ¿s to his MajeÅ¿ty and the Upper HouÅ¿e Å¿o often as occaÅ¿ion Å¿hall require. Which being granted, they are diÅ¿miÅ¿Å¿ed.

â All may petition, but by the mediation of Deputies.All men heretofore were admitted to petition this AuguÅ¿t AÅ¿Å¿embly, provided their Petitions were preferred within Å¿ix days after the opening of the Parliament, and by the hands of Å¿ome appointed by
the Upper HouÅ¿e; it belonging to them to judge what were fitting to be preÅ¿ented in Parliament, and to reject Å¿uch as were trivial or Å¿editious.

Each HouÅ¿e has power to conÅ¿ult, debate,The way of debating and communicating opinions betwixt both HouÅ¿es. and form Bills about the matters propoÅ¿ed by the King, or concerning the making or abrogating of Laws; Å¿o that what is agreed upon in the one HouÅ¿e, is by MeÅ¿Å¿engers to be Å¿ent to the other: and if both concur in judgment after the matter hath been debated, the AÅ¿Å¿ent is marked over the head of the Bill (if it be in the Lords HouÅ¿e) in this form of words: Les Seigneurs out aÅ¿Å¿entes; The Lords have conÅ¿ented. And in the HouÅ¿e of Commons, thus: Les Communes out aÅ¿Å¿entes; The Commons have conÅ¿ented.

But if they diÅ¿agree, many times both HouÅ¿es, or Committees choÅ¿en by them, meet in conference in a convenient place, which is called the Painted Chamber; where the Lords covered and Å¿itting, in Å¿olemn manner receive the Commons Å¿tanding uncovered, and both argue the matter in debate. If in Å¿uch Conferences opinions diÅ¿agree (as it happens Å¿ometimes) the thing is laid aÅ¿ide; but if they concurr, the Bill is carried to the King: which if he approve of, it is written upon, Le Roy le veut, By the Kings conÅ¿ent the Bills are made Laws; The King wills it; whereby, as by a Soul infuÅ¿ed into the body, it receives life, and paÅ¿Å¿es into a perfect Law, to be afterwards promulgated to the people: If on the contrary the King approve not the Bills brought to him, he uÅ¿es to write over head, Le Roy s'aviÅ¿era, The King will conÅ¿ider of it: Or otherwiÅ¿e rejected. Å¿ometimes he utterly rejects them, and then they are wholly laid aÅ¿ide.

But matters of Religion (which require the Kings more eÅ¿pecial care) are not Å¿o intirely committed by him to the Parliament,Religious matters a â¢
â¢ ommit â¢ ed by the Ki â¢ g to the Clergy. but to the Convocation of the Clergy to be handled, unleÅ¿s for the
Å¿anction of Parliament to give them the authority of a Law, which otherwiÅ¿e they could not Å¿ufficiently have.Which by the Deans, Archdeacons, and Deputies of the Clergy, are holden in the Convocation. The Deans, Archdeacons, two Prebendaries commiÅ¿Å¿ionated by the Å¿everal Chapters, and as many PrieÅ¿ts out of every DioceÅ¿s, meet in an appointed place to conÅ¿ult about affairs of that nature; where having firÅ¿t choÅ¿en a Prolocutor, they Å¿ettle points of Religion, Ceremonies, and other matters belonging to the Church, and the impoÅ¿ition of SubÅ¿idies alÅ¿o, in name of the Clergy: yet in theÅ¿e latter times their Acts bind not the People,Their Acts bind not the People, without the conÅ¿ent of the King and Parliament. until (as we Å¿aid before) they be paÅ¿Å¿ed into a Law by the King, with conÅ¿ent of both HouÅ¿es of Parliament. And Å¿o cautious have our Kings been that Laymen Å¿hould not meddle in Å¿uch affairs, that, as it is recorded in HiÅ¿tory, Queen Elizabeth Å¿everely checked the Parliament for having appointed a FaÅ¿t without â¢ sking her leave; nor would Å¿he be Å¿atisfied, till they begg'd her MajeÅ¿ties pardon for it.

That we may return to the Authority of Parliament, each HouÅ¿e hath its Å¿everal and diÅ¿tinct Priviledges.The Rights & Priviledges of the Æ²pper HouÅ¿e. The HouÅ¿e of Lords not onely concurs in Council and making of Laws, but hath alÅ¿o power of Judicature and giving Judgment, and Å¿o of adminiÅ¿tring an Oath, eÅ¿pecially in weightier CauÅ¿es, as in the corruption of Judges and MagiÅ¿trates, and in higheÅ¿t Appeals: which yet, the Lawyers Å¿ay, cannot lawfully be brought to a tryal, without the conÅ¿ent and warrant of the King; and is never done, unleÅ¿s the Judges of the Law do aÅ¿Å¿iÅ¿t.

Of the Lower.The HouÅ¿e of Commons claims to it Å¿elf the priviledge of petitioning and propoÅ¿ing Laws, or of proÅ¿ecuting, but never of judging, unleÅ¿s within its own walls, and over the Members of their own HouÅ¿e, nor that neither beyond a Fine and ImpriÅ¿onment. By ancient cuÅ¿tom that HouÅ¿e was Å¿o far from pronouncing any Sentence (much leÅ¿s in caÅ¿es of Life
and Death) in the name of the People, againÅ¿t the meaneÅ¿t Servant in England, that it never took to it Å¿elf the power of adminiÅ¿tring an Oath. It is alÅ¿o extant in the Rolls, to this purpoÅ¿e: Æ²pon the humble Å¿upplication of the HouÅ¿e of Commons, that whereas all Parliamentary Judgment belongs to the King and the Peers, and not to the Commons, unleÅ¿s by a Grant and PermiÅ¿Å¿ion from the King, it would pleaÅ¿e the Kings MajeÅ¿ty that they be not, contrary to cuÅ¿tom, obliged to give Judgment; whereupon the King for the future excuÅ¿ed them from that trouble, reÅ¿erving the Parliamentary power of Judging for the time to come to the King and HouÅ¿e of Lords onely, (Å¿ave onely in making Laws, or impoÅ¿ing Taxes and SubÅ¿idies) unleÅ¿s when it Å¿hall otherwiÅ¿e Å¿eem fit to the Kings MajeÅ¿ty to require their particular counÅ¿el and aÅ¿Å¿ent for diÅ¿patching the publick Affairs of the Nation.

Nay, it was of old the cuÅ¿tom alÅ¿o, that if any ControverÅ¿ie or Doubt aroÅ¿e about the validity of the Election of the Members of the HouÅ¿e of Commons, the matter was not determined by the other Members of the Å¿ame HouÅ¿e, but either by the Lords in the Upper HouÅ¿e, or by the Judges in Chancery. And if any of them alÅ¿o departed from the Parliament without leave from the King and both HouÅ¿es, he was brought before the Kings Privy-Council or Kings-Bench, to receive Å¿entence for his faults; but he was never puniÅ¿hed at the will and pleaÅ¿ure of his own HouÅ¿e.
This alÅ¿o is peculiar to the HouÅ¿e of Commons, (that we may again return to their Priviledges) that it belongs to them firÅ¿t to debate and form the Bill for raiÅ¿ing Money from the People.

Such therefore is the wonderful temper of our Monarchy, that the King, Lords, and Commons have their Å¿everal parts in the publick adminiÅ¿tration of Affairs; yet with that harmonious proportion, that
All can help, but none of them hurt the Publick. For the Prerogative of the King that gives him the Å¿upreme power of Government, and of Peace and War, tends to this, that he may have Å¿trength enough to defend the Laws againÅ¿t the Factions of the Nobility, and the Tumults and InÅ¿urrections of the people: whilÅ¿t the Nobles, by the high Authority they have in giving Judgment and making Laws, can on the one hand put a Å¿top to tyrannical attempts, if any Å¿hould be offered by the King; and on the other, curb the inÅ¿olence of a tumultuous and Å¿editious common People. Nor are the Commons, through the priviledge they have of accuÅ¿ing any man, and giving or denying Money, unprovided of means of reÅ¿training the licentiouÅ¿neÅ¿s of the Lords and Privy-CounÅ¿ellors, and of preventing the arbitrarineÅ¿s of the Prince.

The providence of the Law thae the Members might debate freely and without fear.The Laws are very careful that the liberty of Debating and Voting be not obÅ¿tructed through fear and the inÅ¿olence of wicked men; for it is enjoyned under Å¿evere penalties, that no Member of Parliament come to the HouÅ¿e with hidden or open Arms, nor that any other perÅ¿on armed with a Sword or any other Weapon, preÅ¿ume to walk in the Palace-yard or near the HouÅ¿e, thereby to give cauÅ¿e of terrour and apprehenÅ¿ion, or to leÅ¿Å¿en the reverence of the place. Yea, it hath been the cuÅ¿tom, that the Members of Parliament and their menial Servants, Å¿hould during the Å¿itting of Parliament, be protected from arreÅ¿ts for debt, or other Å¿light crimes; but the Priviledge of Parliament excuÅ¿es no man that is guilty of TreaÅ¿on, Felony, or Breach of the Peace, from the ordinary proÅ¿ecution of Law. Yet if by the miÅ¿take either of the MagiÅ¿trate or Officer, any Parliament-man or their Servants happen to be arreÅ¿ted, they cannot be Å¿et at liberty according to Law, but by a Writ (aÅ¿Å¿igning the cauÅ¿e) directed out of the Chancery.

So much heretofore did both HouÅ¿es contain themÅ¿elves within the bounds of modeÅ¿ty,The modeÅ¿ty of the Parliament. that if any one inconÅ¿iderately offended againÅ¿t the received cuÅ¿toms, or Å¿pake any way irreverently of the King, he was Å¿everely puniÅ¿hed for the fault, and that at the Å¿uit and inÅ¿tance of the HouÅ¿e of which he was a Member.

The Kings alÅ¿o did very Å¿eldom,
What honour Kings were wont to Å¿hew the Parliament.
But when occaÅ¿ion required, reduced them into order. unleÅ¿s it were for weighty cauÅ¿es, act any thing that might give offence to Å¿o AuguÅ¿t an AÅ¿Å¿embly: Yet Å¿ometimes, upon high provocations, Å¿ome of our mildeÅ¿t Princes have Å¿everely rebuked the whole Parliament, and cauÅ¿ed Å¿ome Members to be brought to the Bar to anÅ¿wer for their offences; and have puniÅ¿hed others by Fine, ImpriÅ¿onment, or Death, according to the nature of their crimes.

TheÅ¿e were the old cuÅ¿toms, and thoÅ¿e the men that made England for many Ages paÅ¿t to flouriÅ¿h,The happineÅ¿s of the Kingdom under this Government. being happy at home, and renowned abroad; until too much happineÅ¿s (as often happens in humane affairs) with Luxury and all Å¿orts of Vice, brought in amongÅ¿t us Pride, Ambition, and the contempt of the Laws both of God and man; Å¿o that with mutual emulation and envy men began to covet and invade the Rights of one another, to deÅ¿piÅ¿e and Å¿et at nought, rather than to reverence and obey the King, Religion, and Laws, and to gape after Novelties, rather than to acquieÅ¿ce in what was moÅ¿t excellently eÅ¿tabliÅ¿hed.

Of late,VVhat were the beginnings of the Troubles raiÅ¿ed by Å¿ome Members of the HouÅ¿e of Commons. Å¿ome perverÅ¿e men (and they at firÅ¿t but a few) who had Å¿crewed themÅ¿elves into the Lower HouÅ¿e, being deÅ¿irous of changes, and crafty Promoters of publick Debates, began to clamour about the Rights and Liberties of the People, and Power of Parliaments, to arrogate to themÅ¿elves unheard-of Priviledges, to be very buÅ¿ie where they were no ways concerned, take upon them what they were
not capable of effecting, and at length breaking out into inÅ¿olent ExpreÅ¿Å¿ions and Invectives againÅ¿t the the Kings power, calling into queÅ¿tion the Tunnage and Poundage, which the Kings of England in all times enjoyed, and forbidding them to be payed to the King; nay, and to offer violence to their Speaker within the very walls of the HouÅ¿e; and in a word, to Å¿hake off their ancient modeÅ¿ty, all reverence which they ought to bear to the MajeÅ¿ty of their King, and to trample under foot the Å¿acred CuÅ¿toms of the Kingdom and Priviledges of Parliament.

Hence mutual JealouÅ¿ies betwixt the King and Parliament.
And then the diÅ¿Å¿olution of Parliaments. Hence aroÅ¿e mutual Heart-burnings and JealouÅ¿ies, that the King deÅ¿igned to invade the Liberties of the Parliament, and the Parliament to encroach upon the Prerogative of the Crown. For this reaÅ¿on the King put an end to Å¿everal Parliaments much Å¿ooner than many deÅ¿ired, (but not without precedents in former times) and checked the raÅ¿hneÅ¿s of Å¿ome by impriÅ¿onment. Being Å¿ome time afterward Å¿ollicited, he refuÅ¿ed to call new Parliaments, that Å¿o the Heats and AnimoÅ¿ities might be allayed, and that they might learn for the future to bring along with them ModeÅ¿ty and greater Gravity to Å¿o great a Council.

This gave occaÅ¿ion of Å¿tirring the people up againÅ¿t the King.But that gave occaÅ¿ion to crafty and reÅ¿tleÅ¿s men of Å¿preading their poyÅ¿on all over England; Å¿o that every where they gave it out, That Religion was ruined, the publick Liberty oppreÅ¿t, and the Laws in danger of being Å¿ubverted; hoping that it would be no difficult matter to perÅ¿wade credulous people of this, who were greedy of Novelties, and prone to liÅ¿ten to Calumnies and Slanders, eÅ¿pecially of the great men. They reproached the King with bitter Railings, calling him uxorious, imprudent, addicted to the PopiÅ¿h Religion, covetous, and what elÅ¿e they knew to be infamous and hateful to the People. They cenÅ¿ured the beÅ¿t of his actions, and Å¿trained
them to the worÅ¿t Å¿ence. They wonderfully aggravated his Misfortunes and Failings, and were more injurious than ill fortune her Å¿elf in their horrid conÅ¿tructions.

AmongÅ¿t Å¿o many Complaints and Outcries,And yet the Kingdom in a moÅ¿t flouriÅ¿hing condition. if you demand what real calamity happened, Britain was never in a more flouriÅ¿hing condition; Å¿tately Buildings both publick and private every where reared, not onely for conveniency, but even for OÅ¿tentation and Luxury; Trade increaÅ¿ing dayly both in compaÅ¿s and profit, had already enlarged it Å¿elf to both the Indies; onely unhappy in this, that with the Wealth of Strangers, foreign Vices were alÅ¿o imported: Arts of all Å¿orts never look'd gayer in Colledges, Courts, and Shops; nor were the wealthy Inhabitants ever prouder; JuÅ¿tice was adminiÅ¿tred according to Law; nor was any man deprived of Life or Goods, but by the lawful Verdict of a Jury of his Country-men, to whom theÅ¿e things ought to be of higheÅ¿t value: all the parts of Government were Å¿o adminiÅ¿tred, that they Å¿eemed to conÅ¿pire together for the publick good; Å¿ave onely in this, that they could not repreÅ¿s the inÅ¿olency and wantonneÅ¿s that Å¿prung from Å¿o great proÅ¿perity; and (which is not to be diÅ¿Å¿embled) being long unaccuÅ¿tomed to War, we had been unfortunate in Å¿ome foreign expeditions;Though unfortunate in War abroad, and Å¿ome Taxes impoÅ¿ed at home. and the people were incenÅ¿ed at Å¿ome impoÅ¿itions at home, which though very moderate, and countenanced by publick neceÅ¿Å¿ity and good reaÅ¿on in Law, yet gave occaÅ¿ion to the people to pretend that the Right and Property of the Subject was oppreÅ¿t,Some Å¿editious perÅ¿ons are puniÅ¿hed. and to outcries of InjuÅ¿tice; and alÅ¿o the impriÅ¿onment and lopping off the ears of four or five Å¿editious perÅ¿ons, Å¿entenced by the Judges of the Star-Chamber, Å¿eemed to be puniÅ¿hments too Å¿evere for thoÅ¿e halcyon days of Peace and Tranquillity. To this may be added,
that the JuriÅ¿diction and CenÅ¿ures of Spiritual Courts wrought pity in Å¿ome, and indignation in others. BeÅ¿ides, the muÅ¿ter of Malecontents was made greater by Å¿ome Å¿crupulous Puritans who interpreted the enjoyning of Ceremonies and things indifferent in the WorÅ¿hip of God,New Ceremonies Å¿tartle the Puritans. in the Canons of the Church, to be the Fore-runners of Popery.

We may alÅ¿o take along with us the Zeal of the ArchbiÅ¿hop in exempting the Clergie from the Suits and Injuries of Laicks, and preferring them to civil employments; which drew a great deal of envy and ill will not onely upon himÅ¿elf, but upon all the Church-men alÅ¿o:The ArchbiÅ¿hop endeavouring to impoÅ¿e the Liturgy of England upon the Scots, offends them. as alÅ¿o his endeavouring to bring into the Church of Scotland the uÅ¿e of the Service-book of England; which, though his deÅ¿igne was laudable, that theÅ¿e three neighbouring Nations, being under the government of one and the Å¿ame King, might alÅ¿o be joyned in an uniform manner of WorÅ¿hip, was yet unÅ¿eaÅ¿onable and ill timed, as we Å¿hall a little more fully relate.

Æ²pon which pretext, but for other cauÅ¿es, they grow turbulent.Matters in Scotland were then ripe for a Rebellion: for many took it ill that the King denied them the Honours and Titles to which they aÅ¿pired; others were vexed that they were forced to part with Å¿ome portion of the Tythes (though but moderate) which they had, upon the diÅ¿Å¿olution of the MonaÅ¿teries, in the minority of King James, obtained from the Crown, for making a competent Stipend for MiniÅ¿ters, who then Å¿erved the Cures at what eaÅ¿ie rates the Patrons were pleaÅ¿ed to allow them; but moÅ¿t could not digeÅ¿t, that the abÅ¿olute Authority which they had for a long time uÅ¿urped over their VaÅ¿Å¿als and Tenants, Å¿hould be taken from them and annexed to the Crown.

The King reÅ¿olving to reduce thoÅ¿e by Arms, whom he could not reclaim by the milder cauÅ¿es of admonition, being accompanied by the Flower of the Youth, and Nobility of England, who voluntarily, and at their own charge, Å¿et out upon the expedition, marches to the borders; but having by clemency and conceÅ¿Å¿ions brought them over to obedience,
And upon Articles makes Peace with them.
The Scots innovating the Articles, cauÅ¿e a new VVar. which he preferred before HoÅ¿tility and Arms, he condeÅ¿cended to Articles of Peace, and disbanded his Army.

The Scots afterward inÅ¿iÅ¿ting upon Articles different from thoÅ¿e that were agreed upon, occaÅ¿ion new Broils and DiÅ¿Å¿enÅ¿ions; which when neither CommiÅ¿Å¿ioners, MeÅ¿Å¿engers, nor mutual Letters could compoÅ¿e, both Å¿ides prepare afreÅ¿h for a new War.

On the Kings Å¿ide the Earl of Strafford, then Deputy of Ireland, raiÅ¿ed an Army of eight thouÅ¿and men with the aÅ¿Å¿iÅ¿tance of the Parliament of Ireland, being to be paid by them; and being come over again into England, beÅ¿tirs himÅ¿elf in raiÅ¿ing another Army here.

A Parliament is called:A Parliament is called in England, wherein a certain Courtier making bad uÅ¿e of his inÅ¿tructions, did (purpoÅ¿ely, as moÅ¿t believed, that he might confound affairs, and increaÅ¿e AnimoÅ¿ities betwixt the King and Parliament) Å¿omewhat haughtily demand twelve SubÅ¿idies, when the HouÅ¿e of Commons had offered Å¿ix, in lieu of the Ship-money: and this raiÅ¿ed new diÅ¿contents and grievances;And diÅ¿Å¿olved. for putting a Å¿top to which in thoÅ¿e troubleÅ¿ome times, the Parliament
was Å¿ooner diÅ¿Å¿olved than many could have wiÅ¿hed.

The Scots making a Å¿ecret Combination with the Factious, invade England. In the mean time the Scots, whoÅ¿e Forces were not Å¿o diÅ¿perÅ¿ed, but that they might be Å¿peedily drawn together into a body, nicking the opportunity, and by Agents entring into a Combination with the factious of England, under pretext of petitioning the King, came in a hoÅ¿tile manner into England; and having beat Å¿ome Troops that guarded the paÅ¿Å¿age of the River Tine, put all into fear and conÅ¿ternation, took NewcaÅ¿tle and other Towns unprovided for defence, and fortified them.

Having made a Truce, the Judgment of the Parliament is expected.And though Strafford, with the new-raiÅ¿ed Army under his command, had undertaken to drive them out of the Kingdom; yet the moÅ¿t merciful King choÅ¿e rather to refer the matter to a Parliament, than without publick conÅ¿ent to pollute the Kingdom with bloud and Å¿laughter. The Parliament being reduced to Å¿treights,And invite the Scots to their aÅ¿Å¿iÅ¿tance. invite the Scots to their aÅ¿Å¿iÅ¿tance; and that they might revive the expiring and almoÅ¿t extinct opinion of the people which formerly they had enjoyed, and the admiration they were had in for wonderful zeal for the Publick Good and purity of Religion, and at the Å¿ame time time drain the peoples PurÅ¿es of their money, they have recourÅ¿e to their often-practiÅ¿ed tricks.

No inconÅ¿iderable Authors of entering into this Covenant, were the Independents, AnabaptiÅ¿ts, Wherein the Independents are Ring-leaders. and Republicans, and the chief and moÅ¿t Å¿evere in forcing it upon others who were unwilling to take the Å¿ame; though many of themÅ¿elves purpoÅ¿ely refrained from Å¿wearing it, leÅ¿t upon that account they Å¿hould oblige themÅ¿elves to the defence of the Kings perÅ¿on.

TheÅ¿e cruelly perÅ¿ecute all DiÅ¿Å¿enters who will not engage in that holy Covenant,They cruelly perÅ¿ecute DiÅ¿Å¿enters. though they had acted nothing before againÅ¿t the Parliamentary Faction, though they had not refuÅ¿ed to pay any
