And thus they ordered it.To which they make way gradually, Å¿ending PropoÅ¿itions to the K. with a pretence of peace, but in reality to find a cauÅ¿e of accuÅ¿ing him: Conditions of Peace were to be propoÅ¿ed to the King; but Å¿uch, as if he conÅ¿ented to them, he himÅ¿elf would renounce the Crown: and if he refuÅ¿ed, he would be depoÅ¿ed by the Votes of others; and Å¿o be, over and above, reckoned obÅ¿tinate by the people; which would give them a more Å¿pecious pretext for accompliÅ¿hing their deÅ¿igne.

For this end it is contrived and obtained, that the Parliament Å¿hould again Å¿end to the King PropoÅ¿itions, but Å¿uch as were rather imperious and hard Commands, than Conditions of Peace to be treated about, which being granted, he would pluck off his Crown with his own hands.Which, though the Commanders of the Army had procured in Parl. yet in the Camp they perÅ¿wade the K. not to condeÅ¿cend to them. To which, though the Commanders of the Army and Cromwel in the firÅ¿t place, had given their Votes in the Parliament; yet in the Camp they adviÅ¿ed the King not to condeÅ¿cend to them, promiÅ¿ing that they would either obtain or command more reaÅ¿onable Conditions for him; and Å¿eemed to deteÅ¿t thoÅ¿e as proceeding from the hautineÅ¿s and Å¿everity of the Presbyterians.

The K. makes anÅ¿wer to the Parl. propoÅ¿als,His MajeÅ¿ty being deluded by that artifice, makes anÅ¿wer to this purpoÅ¿e: That the PropoÅ¿itions were
Å¿uch, as he could not in honour and conÅ¿cience conÅ¿ent to them, being Å¿uch as could not reconcile all intereÅ¿ts, nor Å¿ettle a laÅ¿ting Peace in the Kingdom: Appeals to the Demands of the Army, as more conducing to peace. He appeals rather to the PropoÅ¿als of the Army, as much more conducing to the Å¿atisfaction of all intereÅ¿ts, and a fit Å¿ubject for a perÅ¿onal conference betwixt himÅ¿elf and the two HouÅ¿es (which he earneÅ¿tly deÅ¿ired;) for which cauÅ¿e his MajeÅ¿ty would have CommiÅ¿Å¿ioners from the Army admitted.

Cromwel and the reÅ¿t of the Commanders of the Army were extreamly well Å¿atisfied with this AnÅ¿wer,Where at Cromwel and the Commanders Å¿eem to rejoyce. as if the King himÅ¿elf gave greater honour to the Army than to the Parliament; and therefore on their parts they promiÅ¿e all good Offices to his MajeÅ¿ty.

In the mean time they take all courÅ¿es to incenÅ¿e the reÅ¿t againÅ¿t the King,But from thence labour to incenÅ¿e the reÅ¿t of the Members againÅ¿t him. pretending themÅ¿elves much aÅ¿hamed that they could not perform all they promiÅ¿ed; and excuÅ¿e themÅ¿elves Å¿ometimes becauÅ¿e of the reverence that was due to the Parliament, and Å¿ometimes again becauÅ¿e of the peremptorineÅ¿s of the Adjutators: They juggle with the K. putting him by turns in hope and fear. at length they began to juggle and quite fall off, to give a contrary Å¿ence to their promiÅ¿es, and to Å¿uggeÅ¿t apprehenÅ¿ions to the King, as if the Adjutators and Republicans deÅ¿igned his MajeÅ¿ties death, whoÅ¿e inÅ¿olent attempts they could not moderate nor at preÅ¿ent repreÅ¿s; mingling with all, promiÅ¿es that if they could cut the combs of the Adjutators, and reÅ¿tore the loÅ¿t DiÅ¿cipline of the Army, they would without delay perform what they had undertaken.

With which his MajeÅ¿ty being moved,At which his MajeÅ¿ty being moved, makes his eÅ¿cape to the IÅ¿le of Wight. (Å¿eeing it was worÅ¿e to diÅ¿truÅ¿t than to be deceived) he privately made his eÅ¿cape from the Army, and (as Å¿ate would have it) fled to the IÅ¿le of Wight, the government of which (as it Å¿eems probable) was juÅ¿t before put into the hands of Colonel Hammond a
dear friend to Cromwel, that there he might play his part in this buÅ¿ineÅ¿s. To this mans protection the King commits himÅ¿elf, running of his own accord into the Snare which the Rebels had long ago laid for him.

From thence he Å¿peedily writes to the Parl. Å¿ending alÅ¿o ConceÅ¿Å¿ions;But that he might not be wanting to the publick whilÅ¿t the Parliament were at a Å¿tand, wondering whither he might have fled, his MajeÅ¿ty wrote to them, Å¿ending therewith ConceÅ¿Å¿ions that were too eaÅ¿ie and great to be expected, or indeed to be wiÅ¿hed for by any; adding thereto invincible Arguments, why he could not conÅ¿ent to the PropoÅ¿als lately Å¿ent him by the Parliament. Æ²pon which he demands a Treaty with the Parl. He propoÅ¿es his own ConceÅ¿Å¿ions and the Demands of the Army, as a fit Å¿ubject for a perÅ¿onal Treaty: and for the Å¿ake of the People and Kingdom, earneÅ¿tly deÅ¿ires it, being willing on his own part to condeÅ¿cend to any thing, that by any means he might procure Peace and Tranquillity to his languiÅ¿hing Kingdoms.

Thus the Rebels oppoÅ¿e and take occaÅ¿ion of asking Demands preliminary to the Treaty.The Republicans of both Å¿orts, as well they that were for a few, as for a many-headed Commonwealth, endeavouring by all means to put a Å¿top to the Peace propoÅ¿ed and offered by the King, take hereby occaÅ¿ion to oppoÅ¿e to his MajeÅ¿ties moÅ¿t juÅ¿t deÅ¿ires, four unreaÅ¿onable Demands, as preliminary cautions; which if his MajeÅ¿ty would conÅ¿ent to, they promiÅ¿e to treat about the reÅ¿t.

I. That the Parliament Å¿hould have power to raiÅ¿e, Å¿ettle and maintain the Forces by Sea and Land, within the Kingdoms of England and Ireland, &c. without the Kings conÅ¿ent; it being declared High-TreaÅ¿on for any others, to the number of thirty, to meet together without the authority of Parliament.
II. That it Å¿hould be lawful to the two HouÅ¿es to Å¿it and adjourn themÅ¿elves when and where they pleaÅ¿ed.

III. That all Oaths, Declarations, Proclamations,
and other proceedings againÅ¿t either HouÅ¿e of Parliament during the War, Å¿hould be declared void and null.

IV. That all Titles and Honour of Peerage conferred on any by the King Å¿ince his MajeÅ¿ty left the Parliament, and Å¿ince the great Seal was carried away, Å¿hould he declared void. All theÅ¿e things they demand that the King would conÅ¿ent might be paÅ¿t into Law; if not, that things muÅ¿t remain as they were.

In the mean time the ScottiÅ¿h CommiÅ¿Å¿ioners who were then at London, Which the Scots oppoÅ¿e both in Parl. and before the King. give in their ReaÅ¿ons in writing againÅ¿t theÅ¿e Demands; and when, nevertheleÅ¿s, they Å¿aw that they were Å¿ent to the King, they proteÅ¿t againÅ¿t them in his MajeÅ¿ties preÅ¿ence, as being flatly oppoÅ¿ite to Religion, the Crown, and the Agreements made betwixt the Kingdoms of England and Scotland.

What can the King do to get out of theÅ¿e Å¿treights? If he grant the Demands, he voluntarily reÅ¿ignes up the Government; and if he refuÅ¿e, he muÅ¿t be depoÅ¿ed with the ignominious brand of ObÅ¿tinacy.

The King though wanted neither greatneÅ¿s of Soul nor WiÅ¿dom,The King anÅ¿wers. and therefore Å¿ends preÅ¿ently back an AnÅ¿wer: That the neceÅ¿Å¿ity of complying with all engaged intereÅ¿ts in theÅ¿e great diÅ¿tempers for a perfect Å¿ettlement of Peace, his MajeÅ¿ty finds to be none of the leaÅ¿t difficulties he hath met with Å¿ince the time of his afflictions; which is too viÅ¿ible, when at the Å¿ame time that the two HouÅ¿es of the EngliÅ¿h Parliament do preÅ¿ent to his MajeÅ¿ty Å¿everal Bills and PropoÅ¿itions for his conÅ¿ent, the CommiÅ¿Å¿ioners for Scotland do openly proteÅ¿t againÅ¿t them: Å¿o that were nothing in the caÅ¿e but the conÅ¿ideration of that difference, his MajeÅ¿ty cannot imagine how to give Å¿uch an anÅ¿wer to what is now propoÅ¿ed, as thereby to promiÅ¿e himÅ¿elf his great end, A Perfect Peace. And when his MajeÅ¿ty farther conÅ¿iders
how impoÅ¿Å¿ible it is (in the condition he now Å¿tands) to fulfil the deÅ¿ires of his two HouÅ¿es, Å¿ince the onely ancient and known ways of paÅ¿Å¿ing Laws, are either by his MajeÅ¿ties perÅ¿onal aÅ¿Å¿ent in the HouÅ¿e of Peers, or by CommiÅ¿Å¿ion under his great Seal of England; he cannot but wonder at Å¿uch failings in the manner of addreÅ¿s which is now made unto him, unleÅ¿s his two HouÅ¿es intend that his MajeÅ¿ty Å¿hall allow of a great Seal made without his authority, before there be any conÅ¿ideration had thereupon in a Treaty; which as it may hereafter hazard the Å¿ecurity it Å¿elf, Å¿o for the preÅ¿ent it Å¿eems very unreaÅ¿onable to his MajeÅ¿ty. And though his MajeÅ¿ty is willing to believe that the intention of very many of both HouÅ¿es, in Å¿ending thoÅ¿e Bills before a Treaty, was onely to obtain a TruÅ¿t from him, and not to take any advantage by paÅ¿Å¿ing them, to force other things from him, which are either againÅ¿t his conÅ¿cience or honour; yet his MajeÅ¿ty believes it's clear to all underÅ¿tandings, that theÅ¿e Bills contain (as they are now penned) not onely the diveÅ¿ting himÅ¿elf of all Soveraignty, and that without poÅ¿Å¿ibility of recovering it either to him or his SucceÅ¿Å¿ors, (except by repeal of theÅ¿e Bills) but alÅ¿o the making his ConceÅ¿Å¿ions guilty of the greateÅ¿t preÅ¿Å¿ures that can be made upon the Subject, as in other particulars, Å¿o by giving an arbitrary and unlimited power to the two HouÅ¿es for ever, to raiÅ¿e and levy, for Land and Sea-Å¿ervice, of what perÅ¿ons (without diÅ¿tinction and quality) and to what numbers they pleaÅ¿e; and likewiÅ¿e for the payment of the Arrears, to levy what moneys, in Å¿uch Å¿ort, and by Å¿uch ways and means (and by conÅ¿equence upon the EÅ¿tates of whatÅ¿oever perÅ¿ons) as they Å¿hall think fit and appoint; which is utterly inconÅ¿iÅ¿tent with the Liberty and Property of the Subject, and his MajeÅ¿ties truÅ¿t in protecting them: Å¿o that if the major part of both HouÅ¿es Å¿hall think it neceÅ¿Å¿ary to put the reÅ¿t of the PropoÅ¿itions into Bills, his MajeÅ¿ty leaves the world to judge how unÅ¿afe
it would be for him to conÅ¿ent thereunto; and if not, what a Å¿trange condition (after paÅ¿Å¿ing thoÅ¿e four Bills) his MajeÅ¿ty and all his Subjects would be caÅ¿t into. And here his MajeÅ¿ty thinks it not unfit to wiÅ¿h his two HouÅ¿es to conÅ¿ider well of the manner of their proceeding; that when his MajeÅ¿ty deÅ¿ires a perÅ¿onal Treaty with them for the Å¿etling of a Peace, they in anÅ¿wer propoÅ¿e the very Å¿ubject matter of the moÅ¿t eÅ¿Å¿ential part thereof to be firÅ¿t granted; a thing which will be hardly credible to PoÅ¿terity: Wherefore his MajeÅ¿ty declares, that neither the deÅ¿ire of being freed from this tedious and irksome condition of life his MajeÅ¿ty hath Å¿o long Å¿uffered, nor the apprehenÅ¿ion of what Å¿hall befal him in caÅ¿e his two HouÅ¿es Å¿hall not afford him a perÅ¿onal Treaty, Å¿hall make him change his reÅ¿olution of not conÅ¿enting to any Act, till the whole be concluded. Yet then he intends not onely to give full and reaÅ¿onable Å¿atisfaction in the particulars preÅ¿ented to him; but alÅ¿o to make good all other ConceÅ¿Å¿ions mentioned in his MeÅ¿Å¿age of the 16th of Novemb. laÅ¿t, which he thought would have produced better effects than what he finds in the Bills and PropoÅ¿itions now preÅ¿ented unto him.

p.hi: And yet his MajeÅ¿ty cannot give over, but now again earneÅ¿tly preÅ¿Å¿eth for a perÅ¿onal Treaty, (Å¿o paÅ¿Å¿ionately is he affected with the advantages which Peace will bring to his MajeÅ¿ty and all his Subjects) of which he will not at all deÅ¿pair, (there being no other viÅ¿ible way to obtain a well-grounded Peace). However, his MajeÅ¿ty is very much at eaÅ¿e within himÅ¿elf, for having fulfilled the offices both of a ChriÅ¿tian and a King; and will patiently wait the good pleaÅ¿ure of Almighty God, to incline the hearts of his two HouÅ¿es to conÅ¿ider their King, and compaÅ¿Å¿ionate their fellow-Subjects miÅ¿eries.

div.p:
The King having delivered this AnÅ¿wer Å¿ealed up, to be carried to the Parliament, the Earl of D. who hankered too much after the Oligarchick Republicans,
deÅ¿ired it to be opened again, that the CommiÅ¿Å¿ioners might be acquainted with what they brought back, as he Å¿aid, was fitting, they being CommiÅ¿Å¿ioners and not PoÅ¿ts or Couriers; (though no Å¿uch thing was contained in their publick inÅ¿tructions) he having paÅ¿t his promiÅ¿e that no prejudice Å¿hould therefrom accrew to the King.

Is confined to cloÅ¿e impriÅ¿onment.But Å¿o Å¿oon as the King, to Å¿atisfie them, had read over his AnÅ¿wer himÅ¿elf, without any reÅ¿pect had to their faith and promiÅ¿e, they confine the beÅ¿t of Princes to cloÅ¿er impriÅ¿onment in
â¢ arisborough-CaÅ¿tle, where then he was: They put from him all his Servants, except Å¿ome new comers and enemies whom they placed about his perÅ¿on rather in deriÅ¿ion, and as a Guard, than for attending and Å¿erving him. And that he might not have the uÅ¿e of the leaÅ¿t bit of Paper Å¿ecretly conveyed to him by any MeÅ¿Å¿enger, they Å¿et Sentinels at all the entries, at the doors and windows of his Chamber.

The Oligarchick Commanders reduce the Democraticks to order, and reÅ¿tore Military DiÅ¿cipline.The Oligarchick Rebels, Cromwel and the other Commanders of the Army being reÅ¿olved to purÅ¿ue their deÅ¿igne, the Kings AnÅ¿wer wrought no good effect in the Parliament; yet the emulation of the Democratick Republicans, and of the Adjutators, for Å¿ome time put a Å¿top to their proceedings. That they might Å¿uppreÅ¿s this Party, of whom they had now enough, a general muÅ¿ter of the Forces is appointed, amongÅ¿t whom one whole Regiment having got the Democratical PropoÅ¿als, which they termed the Ordinance of the People, put into writing, they carried the Paper as a Å¿ignal in their hats; the Oligarchick Republicans by their Å¿ollicitations had gained one or two Regiments; and the reÅ¿t of the Army conÅ¿iÅ¿ted of both Parties promiÅ¿cuouÅ¿ly jumbled together. The chief Commanders who were of the firÅ¿t (as the inferiour were of the other Party) drawing together into a ring, they command
the private Souldiers to throw away their Paper-Å¿ignals; which when they refuÅ¿ed to do, according as they had laid the deÅ¿igne, they break in amongÅ¿t them, and pulling out Å¿ome of the more Å¿awcy fellows of the Regiment, they cauÅ¿e them preÅ¿ently to be Å¿hot to death; which made the reÅ¿t throw away their Badges, and Å¿ubmit to the pleaÅ¿ure of the Generals.

This danger being over,They openly rail againÅ¿t the King, they began to publiÅ¿h the villany they had Å¿o long concealed, to rail openly againÅ¿t the King in the HouÅ¿e, make Speeches, exhort the other Members, and to contrive four Interdicts rather than Votes: whereby,
1. It is reÅ¿olved, And paÅ¿s a Vote of none AddreÅ¿Å¿es to the King. That the Lords and Commons do declare that they will make no further AddreÅ¿Å¿es or Applications to the King.
2. That no Application or AddreÅ¿s be made to the King by any perÅ¿on whatÅ¿oever, without leave of both HouÅ¿es.
3. That the perÅ¿on or perÅ¿ons that Å¿hall make breach of this Order, Å¿hall incur the penalties of High-TreaÅ¿on.
4. That the Lords and Commons do declare, that they will receive no more any MeÅ¿Å¿age from the King to both or either HouÅ¿es of Parliament, or to any other perÅ¿on.

But neither were theÅ¿e carried in the HouÅ¿e of Commons, without tricks and the uÅ¿ual artifices.But Å¿urreptitiouÅ¿ly in the Lower HouÅ¿e; For before any mention was made of theÅ¿e PropoÅ¿itions in the HouÅ¿e, fourty or fifty leading-men, who for the moÅ¿t part would have withÅ¿tood thoÅ¿e attempts, are Å¿ent into their Å¿everal Counties upon pretext of raiÅ¿ing money to pay off the Souldiers, that by their abÅ¿ence, fewer oppoÅ¿ing, and the greater part of the HouÅ¿e being packt, the matter might be eaÅ¿ily carried. NevertheleÅ¿s, this execrable motion (made to the Å¿candal of mankind) of
abjuring their King, was debated to and again, from ten in the morning until Å¿even at night, and had not, after all, found the Votes rather tired out than perÅ¿waded, unleÅ¿s the chief of the Oligarchick Party had given them hopes that they would attempt nothing worÅ¿e againÅ¿t the King. The three laÅ¿t Votes paÅ¿t in the Å¿pace of half an hour with much precipitation, whilÅ¿t the Factious got into the places of the diÅ¿Å¿enting Members, who had withdrawn out of the HouÅ¿e to take a little refreÅ¿hment.

By force and threats in the Æ²pper HouÅ¿e.However, the Æ²pper HouÅ¿e was more hardly brought over to an aÅ¿Å¿ent: for there the Debate laÅ¿ted many days, until CommiÅ¿Å¿ioners coming from the Army upon pretext of thanking the Lower HouÅ¿e for thoÅ¿e Votes, and proteÅ¿ting the Army would protect the Commons therein, threatned the Lords if they perÅ¿iÅ¿ted to oppoÅ¿e them, and Å¿hortly after, whilÅ¿t they Å¿till delayed, forced them out of fear to conÅ¿ent, two Regiments of Souldiers being Å¿ent into WeÅ¿tminÅ¿ter-hall, under colour of a Guard to the Lower HouÅ¿e; but in reality to awe the diÅ¿Å¿enting Lords. This having terrified the three or four Lords that met, who at that time often uÅ¿urped to themÅ¿elves the authority of the Upper HouÅ¿e, (many Å¿tealing out of the way) they agree to the Votes of the HouÅ¿e of Commons. And then CommiÅ¿Å¿ioners were likewiÅ¿e Å¿ent from the Army to thank the Lords for that good Å¿ervice done to the Kingdom, and Å¿olemnly to aÅ¿Å¿ure them in name of the whole Army, That they would maintain and defend the Rights and Priviledges of the Æ²pper HouÅ¿e.

Cromwel excuÅ¿es himÅ¿elf of perfidiouÅ¿neÅ¿s.The Reader may be pleaÅ¿ed to obÅ¿erve what Cloak Cromwel uÅ¿ed for this perfidiouÅ¿neÅ¿s. This Blade, whilÅ¿t he was praying that Almighty God would be pleaÅ¿ed to proÅ¿per his endeavours in raiÅ¿ing again the King to the Throne and MajeÅ¿ty of his AnceÅ¿tors; here the words Å¿tuck between his
teeth, Å¿o that he could not utter one word more; which he interpreting as a Å¿igne of Gods diÅ¿pleaÅ¿ure, concluded the King to be rejected of God. But to others he roundly expreÅ¿Å¿ed himÅ¿elf, That it was lawful to circumvent a wicked deceiver, by craft and deceit.

After this comes out a Proclamation,They publiÅ¿h a Declaration, by authority of the HouÅ¿e of Commons, wherein the Å¿ticklers both for Oligarchy and Democracy, who agreed very well together againÅ¿t the King, declare the ReaÅ¿ons that enclined them to paÅ¿s thoÅ¿e Votes of none AddreÅ¿Å¿es to his MajeÅ¿ty.

This they Å¿tuff with all the Calumnies that were raiÅ¿ed againÅ¿t the King,Which they Å¿tuff with all the Calumnies they can againÅ¿t the King. by the Clubs and Conferences of his lewdeÅ¿t enemies, or by uncertain Rumours Å¿pread abroad by themÅ¿elves; to which they adde other AÅ¿perÅ¿ions, which though they had been bawled over and over again in the HouÅ¿e, yet were found not to have had the leaÅ¿t Å¿hadow of truth, and were onely invented and exaggerated to create greater hatred.

They cauÅ¿e this infamous Libel to be Å¿ent about into all the PariÅ¿hes of the Kingdom, They command it to be read publickly by the MiniÅ¿ters in all PariÅ¿h-Churches, being Å¿ecure that no body durÅ¿t, or indeed could undergo the danger of anÅ¿wering it, Å¿ince all the PreÅ¿Å¿es were narrowly watched. The MiniÅ¿ters are commanded to read it to the people in the Church, and to preach as well as they could in praiÅ¿e of it.

And that they might be the more willing to Å¿erve the end,And Å¿ooth them with promiÅ¿es, that they may comm â¢ nd it in their Å¿ermons. it was at the Å¿ame time voted in the HouÅ¿e of Commons, That the Tythes and Dean and Chapters Rents Å¿hould be paid to the Preachers; Å¿eeming to be very Å¿ollicitous for the CauÅ¿e of God and Religion, when in reality they intended to cheat the Church of them, and to convert them to profane uÅ¿e. Nay, the JuÅ¿tices of Peace are everywhere enjoyned to force the Laicks, who refuÅ¿ed, to pay
them.They endeavour by their EmiÅ¿Å¿aries to procure gratulatory Petitions. They likewiÅ¿e hoped to Å¿tir up the people by EmiÅ¿Å¿aries and Souldiers everywhere diÅ¿perÅ¿ed, by AnabaptiÅ¿ts, SchiÅ¿maticks, and Hereticks, who were moÅ¿t diligent in propagating their affairs, to approve what the Parliament had done by congratulatory AddreÅ¿Å¿es, and to demand Å¿ome Å¿everer puniÅ¿hment to be inflicted upon the King.

But it happened contrariwiÅ¿e: for three AnÅ¿wers and Apologies at leaÅ¿t came out within a Å¿hort time,The K. MajeÅ¿ty is juÅ¿tified by many Apologies. (one of which was written with the Kings own hand) wherein his MajeÅ¿ty was moÅ¿t clearly acquitted from thoÅ¿e reproachful Imputations, and the AccuÅ¿ations retorted upon the Faction it Å¿elf, which was proved to be guilty of all the crimes that it maliciouÅ¿ly and falÅ¿ly faÅ¿tened upon the King; and that with Å¿o great evidence and perÅ¿picuity, that no man durÅ¿t offer Å¿o much as to mutter againÅ¿t it.

The ParÅ¿ons coldly execute their orders: very few congratulate.In the mean time the MiniÅ¿ters coldly obey their commands: and Å¿ome few gratulatory AddreÅ¿Å¿es by the induÅ¿try of Sectarians, are with much ado extorted from a few Counties, and Å¿igned but with the hands of Å¿ome obÅ¿cure and notoriouÅ¿ly malicious Villains.

All the people grumble and fret.Now the people began to grumble and fret, to accuÅ¿e the Sectarians, and eÅ¿pecially the Souldiers of juggling and impoÅ¿ture; and to curÅ¿e them all. Afterwards came Petitions from a great many Counties,Many petition for a perÅ¿onal Treaty with the King, and thoÅ¿e alÅ¿o which always were for the Parliament, earneÅ¿tly intreating that a perÅ¿onal Treaty might be had with the King, that the Army might be paid and disbanded, that aÅ¿Å¿iÅ¿tance in the mean time Å¿hould be Å¿ent over into Ireland, that England might be eaÅ¿ed from OppreÅ¿Å¿ions, and from contributing to the charges of an unneceÅ¿Å¿ary Army, which it was no longer able to bear.

At length it came to that, that a great many of
theÅ¿e humble Petitions Å¿igned with the hands of infinite numbers of men,The Rebels in vain oppoÅ¿ing it. had almoÅ¿t confounded the repugnancy of the Parliament; the Commanders of the Army in the Å¿everal Counties, and the Parliament CommiÅ¿Å¿ioners, who for the moÅ¿t part did all now comply with the victorious Party, in vain uÅ¿ing all their endeavours by threats of Å¿equeÅ¿trations, impriÅ¿onments, baniÅ¿hment, and death, and now and then by flattery and golden promiÅ¿es, to make them deÅ¿iÅ¿t and be Å¿ilent.

Nor can we paÅ¿s over, without a remark,â the changing Tides of Divine Vengeance, or of Popular InconÅ¿tancy; whilÅ¿t the very Å¿ame Parliament, from which the firÅ¿t tumults of petitioning againÅ¿t the King had their riÅ¿e, does now complain that the dignity of the Members are endangered by an undeÅ¿ired confluence of Petitioners.

The firÅ¿t that led the van in petitioning were the EÅ¿Å¿ex-men, in numbers unuÅ¿ual before theÅ¿e times,FirÅ¿t were the EÅ¿Å¿ex-men; who were Å¿o many that they might have compelled thoÅ¿e whom they came to Å¿upplicate.Next, thoÅ¿e of Surrey, who are abuÅ¿ed by the Souldiers. Next came the Surrey-men, who being unarmed, were upon a Å¿light occaÅ¿ion barbarouÅ¿ly treated by the Souldiers near the very door of the Parliament-houÅ¿e; being Å¿everely beaten, forced to flie, Å¿ome killed, more wounded, all plundered, and that by order of the HouÅ¿e, and command of the Officers; nay, the Rioters had the thanks of the Lower HouÅ¿e, and rewards for the fact; that Å¿o the people might for the future beware of licentious petitioning, which heretofore was judged a part of their Right.

But all they get by their Tyranny in labouring to Å¿tifle the Grievances and Complaints of the oppreÅ¿t people,But nevertheleÅ¿s, more Petitions come from other Counties; was to incenÅ¿e the other Counties to ply them more frequently with Petitions: who Å¿eeing they could procure no remedy by complaining, from Prayers and Petitions they betake themÅ¿elves to
Arms. The liberty of the King and People (which heretofore the deluded Rabble thought to be inconÅ¿iÅ¿tent) are again born in colours, by the men of Kent, And the KentiÅ¿h and EÅ¿Å¿ex men with Å¿everal others being repulÅ¿ed, betake themÅ¿elves to Arms. EÅ¿Å¿ex, Suffolk, Norfolk, York-Å¿hire, and other Northern Counties, South and North Wales alÅ¿o, and at length of Surrey, who were inflamed with a greater deÅ¿ire of vengeance; many Nobles (the Earl of Holland, Wiot, and Duke of Buckingham, &c.) who were unluckily diÅ¿covered to have entered into a ConÅ¿piracy at London, joyning them too haÅ¿tily.

The Fleet alÅ¿o falls off from the Parl.The Sea-men alÅ¿o being carried with the Å¿ame tyde of CommiÅ¿eration towards the King, fall off, and Å¿eventeen men of War, having put the Republican Admiral Rainsborough on Å¿hore, come over to Prince Charles.

The Scots riÅ¿e in arms for delivering the K. out of priÅ¿on.The Scots alÅ¿o by order of their Parliament take up Arms for delivering the King out of PriÅ¿on wherein he was baÅ¿ely detained, and make an Irruption into the Northern parts of England, with a numerous army under the command of Hamilton; being joyned by Sir Marmaduke Langdale, with a conÅ¿iderable body of EngliÅ¿h: But whether it was the wonted ill fortune of the King, or of Hamilton himÅ¿elf, or rather the decree and purpoÅ¿e of Almighty God, the EngliÅ¿h firÅ¿t, by intervals, and one after another,The EngliÅ¿h are overcome by the enemy. were routed and killed by the enemy: for it was a matter of Å¿mall difficulty for an old Army provided with Ammunition and all other neceÅ¿Å¿aries of War, commanded by vigilant and expert Generals and Officers, to defeat and put to flight a tumultuary body of raw Country-men rather than Souldiers, deÅ¿titute of Arms and warlike proviÅ¿ions, and for moÅ¿t part without Commanders, whilÅ¿t they come to engage by Parties one after another.

NevertheleÅ¿s, ColcheÅ¿ter in EÅ¿Å¿ex, and Pembrooke the chief Town of that County in Wales, though
they were unprovided for a Siege, gave the Rebels no little work to do. Nor did Pontfract-CaÅ¿tle fall diÅ¿honourably into their hands; out of which about thirty HorÅ¿emen breaking through the Forces that beÅ¿ieged the place, pulled Rainsborough (lately Admiral and now General of the Northern Army, who had brought Å¿ome thouÅ¿ands of Auxiliary Troops to make an end of the Siege) out of his Bed in DuncaÅ¿ter a fortified Tower, twelve miles diÅ¿tant from Pontfract; and becauÅ¿e he refuÅ¿ed to be carried away with them as a PriÅ¿oner, killed him. Nay, the GarriÅ¿on being reduced to the utmoÅ¿t extremity, all had free liberty to depart to their own houÅ¿es, except two Souldiers; to whom it was permitted even by Articles, either to die in the Bed of Honour fighting, or to arm themÅ¿elves and Å¿trive to break through the enemy. Which both of them watching their opportunity, got on horÅ¿eback, and performed almoÅ¿t without a wound.

The Scots through the unskilfulneÅ¿s and cowardiÅ¿e of their Generals,And the Scots. or (which I am not willing to Å¿uÅ¿pect) their treachery, leading the Army in two bodies forty miles diÅ¿tant one from another, are without any trouble routed by Cromwel, who unexpectedly falling upon the main body, Hamilton the General being taken. put it to flight, and all the reÅ¿t into conÅ¿ternation; many being killed and taken, amongÅ¿t whom was Hamilton the General.

The reÅ¿t he purÅ¿ued into Scotland; where Argile with the Forces he had raiÅ¿ed, being no leÅ¿s an Army at home than Cromwel was abroad, reduced them in a Å¿hort time to Å¿uch Å¿treights, that the Army which had been raiÅ¿ed by order of Parliament, was forced to lay down Arms, and Å¿ubmit to the diÅ¿cretion of Argile's Faction. Then was a new Parliament called, all being excluded who had taken up Arms, or voted for engaging in a War for
the delivery of the King. In this the Acts of the laÅ¿t Parliament were recinded, the War declared to have been unlawful, Cromwel had the publick thanks, and Argile privately engaged (as Cromwel himÅ¿elf boaÅ¿ted) that he would concur with the Oligarchicks of England, and root out Monarchy (when occaÅ¿ion offered) in Scotland as well as in England.

The Å¿hips prepare to make a defection from the Prince, matters Å¿ucceeding ill at Land.BeÅ¿ides, many Ships, the Tyde turning, according to the innate levine of Seamen, prepare to make defection from the Prince, caÅ¿ting themÅ¿elves into the protection of the Earl of Warwick, who had won their hearts by frequent LargeÅ¿Å¿es, and who was Å¿et over a new Fleet for a time, that he might draw over the Seamen again to the obedience of the Parliament: but being beÅ¿et with the Spies Of the Oligarchick Rebels, and having done their job, he juÅ¿tly received the uÅ¿ual Reward from theÅ¿e MaÅ¿ters, that is, he was turned out and laid aÅ¿ide.

The Parl. in the mean time think of making peace.WhilÅ¿t the Army is buÅ¿ied in theÅ¿e Wars, the Members of Parliament being a little rid of the yoak of the Army and Cromwel that were now at a diÅ¿tance, and Å¿eriouÅ¿ly conÅ¿idering how ill all the People of the Kingdom would reÅ¿ent the injuries done to the King, and how tickliÅ¿h their own affairs Å¿tood, they begin to think of Peace; and growing wiÅ¿e behind hand,The Act of None AddreÅ¿Å¿es is reÅ¿cinded. againÅ¿t the advice of the Oligarchick Republicans, they reÅ¿cind the Votes of None AddreÅ¿Å¿es, by the unanimous conÅ¿ent of both HouÅ¿es. They appoint a Conference with the K. by CommiÅ¿Å¿ioner in the IÅ¿le of Wight. They appoint a Conferenceâª with the King for compoÅ¿ing Differences; but by CommiÅ¿Å¿ioners, and that in the IÅ¿le of Wight. For this purpoÅ¿e they commiÅ¿Å¿ionate five Lords for the Æ²pper HouÅ¿e, and ten Commoners for the Lower. The PropoÅ¿itions to be debated in that Conference, are preÅ¿cribed to the CommiÅ¿Å¿ioners.

Â¶ That the TranÅ¿lator relates all which verbatim,
though it be contrary to the deÅ¿igne of this Work, and of the Author, who hath onely entred the Å¿hort Articles marked with the numbers I.II.III. I hope the Reader will not diÅ¿like, Å¿ince the Articles at large contain Å¿o excellent a deÅ¿cription of the Changes that were then intended to be made in the Government of England, that it is thought very fit to publiÅ¿h them according to the perfect Copy printed by order of both HouÅ¿es the 29th of AuguÅ¿t, 1648.

WE the Lords and Commons aÅ¿Å¿embled in the Parliament of England, in the name, and on the behalf of the Kingdoms of England and Ireland, and the CommiÅ¿Å¿ioners of the Parliament of Scotland, in the name, and on the behalf of the Kingdom of Scotland; Do humbly preÅ¿ent unto your MajeÅ¿ty the humble deÅ¿ires and PropoÅ¿itions for a Å¿afe and well-grounded Peace, agreed upon by the Parliaments of both Kingdoms reÅ¿pectively; unto which we do pray your MajeÅ¿ties AÅ¿Å¿ent: And that they and all Å¿uch Bills as Å¿hall be tendered to your MajeÅ¿ty in purÅ¿uance of them, or any of them, may be EÅ¿tabliÅ¿hed and Enacted for Statutes and Acts of Parliament, by your MajeÅ¿ties Royal AÅ¿Å¿ent in the Parliaments of both Kingdoms reÅ¿pectively.

div.head: I.
div.p: WHereas both HouÅ¿es of the Parliament of England have been neceÅ¿Å¿itated to undertake a War in their juÅ¿t and lawful defence; and afterwards both Kingdoms of England and Scotland joyned in Solemn League and Covenant, were engaged to proÅ¿ecute the Å¿ame.

That by Act of Parliament in each Kingdom reÅ¿pectively, all Oaths, Declarations, and Proclamations
heretofore had, or hereafter to be had againÅ¿t both or either of the HouÅ¿es of the Parliament of England, the Parliament of the Kingdom of Scotland, and the late Convention of EÅ¿tates in Scotland, or Committees flowing from the Parliament or Convention in Scotland, or their Ordinances and Proceedings; or againÅ¿t any for adhering unto them, or for doing or executing any Office, Place, or Charge, by any Authority derived from them; and all Judgments, Indictments, Outlawries, Attainders, and InquiÅ¿itions, in any the Å¿aid CauÅ¿es; and all Grants thereupon made or had, or to be made or had, be declared Null, Å¿uppreÅ¿Å¿ed and forbidden. And that this be publickly intimated in all PariÅ¿h-Churches within his MajeÅ¿ties Dominions, and all other places needful.

div.head: II.
div.p: That his MajeÅ¿ty, according to the laudable example of his Royal Father of happy memory, may be pleaÅ¿ed to Å¿wear and Å¿igne the late Solemn League and Covenant; and that an Act of Parliament be paÅ¿Å¿ed in both Kingdoms reÅ¿pectively, for enjoyning the taking thereof by all the Subjects of the three Kingdoms; and the Ordinances concerning the manner of taking the Å¿ame in both Kingdoms, be confirmed by Acts of Parliament reÅ¿pectively, with Å¿uch Penalties as by mutual advice of both Kingdoms Å¿hall be agreed upon.

div.head: III.
div.p:
That a Bill be paÅ¿Å¿ed for the utter aboliÅ¿hing and taking away of all ArchbiÅ¿hops, BiÅ¿hops, their Chancellors, and CommiÅ¿Å¿aries, Deans, and Sub-Deans, Deans and Chapters, Arch-Deacons, Canons, and Prebendaries; and all Chaunters, Chancellors, TreaÅ¿urers, Sub-TreaÅ¿urers, Succentors, and SacriÅ¿ts; all Vicars Choril, and ChoreÅ¿ters, old Vicars, and new Vicars of any Cathedral or Collegiate-Church, and all other their under-Officers, out of the Church of England, and Dominion of Wales; and out of
the Church of Ireland, with Å¿uch alterations concerning the EÅ¿tates of Prelates, as Å¿hall agree with the Articles of the late Treaty of the date at Edenburgh, 29 November, 1643. and joynt Declaration of both Kingdoms.

div.head: IV.
div.p: That the Ordinances concerning the calling and Å¿itting of the AÅ¿Å¿embly of Divines, be confirmed by Act of Parliament.

div.head: V.
div.p: That Reformation of Religion, according to the Covenant, be Å¿etled by Act of Parliament, in Å¿uch manner as both HouÅ¿es have agreed, or Å¿hall agree upon, after conÅ¿ultation had with the AÅ¿Å¿embly of Divines.

For as much as both Kingdoms are mutually obliged by the Å¿ame Covenant, to endeavour the neareÅ¿t Conjunction and Uniformity in matters of Religion, That Å¿uch Unity and Uniformity in Religion, according to the Covenant, as after conÅ¿ultation had with the Divines of both Kingdoms now aÅ¿Å¿embled, is or Å¿hall be joyntly agreed upon by both HouÅ¿es of the Parliament of England, and by the Church and Kingdom of Scotland, be confirmed by Acts of Parliament of both Kingdoms reÅ¿pectively.

div.head: VI.
div.p:
That for the more effectual diÅ¿abling JeÅ¿uits, PrieÅ¿ts; PapiÅ¿ts, and PopiÅ¿h RecuÅ¿ants, from diÅ¿turbing the State, and deluding the Laws; and for the better diÅ¿covering, and Å¿peedy conviction of PopiÅ¿h RecuÅ¿ants, an Oath be eÅ¿tabliÅ¿hed by Act of Parliament to be adminiÅ¿tred to them, wherein they Å¿hall abjure and renounce the Popes Supremacy, the Doctrine of TranÅ¿ubÅ¿tantiation, Purgatory, worÅ¿hipping of the ConÅ¿ecrated HoaÅ¿t, Crucifixes and Images, and all other PopiÅ¿h SuperÅ¿titions and Errours; and refuÅ¿ing the Å¿aid Oath, being tendred in Å¿uch manner as Å¿hall be appointed by the Å¿aid Act, to be a Å¿ufficient Conviction of PopiÅ¿h Recu

div.p: That an Act or Acts be paÅ¿Å¿ed in Parliament, whereby the practices of PapiÅ¿ts againÅ¿t the State may be prevented, and the Laws againÅ¿t them duly executed, and a Å¿tricter courÅ¿e taken to prevent the Saying or Hearing of MaÅ¿s in the Court, or any other part of this Kingdom, or the Kingdom of Ireland.

div.head: XV.

And to Å¿uch Act or Acts for raiÅ¿ing of Moneys for the payment and Å¿atisfying of the publick Debts and Damages of the Kingdom, and other publick

And that his MajeÅ¿ty give aÅ¿Å¿urance of his conÅ¿enting in the Parliament of Scotland, to an Act, acknowledging and ratifying the Acts of the Convention of EÅ¿tates of Scotland, called by the Council and ConÅ¿ervers of the Peace, and the CommiÅ¿Å¿ioners for the common Burthens, and aÅ¿Å¿embled the two and twentieth day of June, 1643. and Å¿everal times continued Å¿ince: and of the Parliament of that Kingdom Å¿ince convened.

div.head: XVI.
div.p: That the Lords and Commons in the Parliament of England aÅ¿Å¿embled, Å¿hall, during the Å¿pace of twenty years, from the firÅ¿t of July, 1646. arm, train, and diÅ¿cipline, or cauÅ¿e to be armed, trained, and diÅ¿ciplined, all the Forces of the Kingdoms of England and Ireland, and Dominion of Wales, the IÅ¿les of GuernÅ¿ey and JerÅ¿ey, and the Town of Barwick upon Tweed, already raiÅ¿ed both for Sea and Land-Å¿ervice; and Å¿hall from time to time during the Å¿aid Å¿pace of twenty years, raiÅ¿e, levy, arm, train, and diÅ¿cipline, or cauÅ¿e to be raiÅ¿ed, levied, armed, trained, and diÅ¿ciplined, any other Forces for Land and Sea-Å¿ervice in the Kingdoms, Dominions, and places aforeÅ¿aid, as in their Judgments they Å¿hall from time to time, during the Å¿aid Å¿pace of twenty years, think fit and appoint; and that neither the the King, his Heirs, or SucceÅ¿Å¿ors, nor any other but Å¿uch as Å¿hall act by the authority or approbation of the Å¿aid Lords and Commons, Å¿hall during the Å¿aid Å¿pace of twenty years, exerciÅ¿e any of the Powers aforeÅ¿aid.
And the like for the Kingdom of Scotland, if the EÅ¿tates of the Parliament there Å¿hall think fit.

That Moneys be raiÅ¿ed and levied for the maintenance and uÅ¿e of the Å¿aid Forces for Land-Å¿ervice, and of the Navy and Forces for Sea-Å¿ervice, in Å¿uch Å¿ort, and by Å¿uch ways and means as the Å¿aid Lords & Commons Å¿hall from time to time, during the Å¿aid Å¿pace of twenty years, think fit and appoint, and not otherwiÅ¿e. That all the Å¿aid Forces both for Land and Sea-Å¿ervice, Å¿o raiÅ¿ed or levied, or to be raiÅ¿ed or levied, and alÅ¿o the Admiralty and Navy, Å¿hall from time to time, during the Å¿aid Å¿pace of twenty years, be employed, managed, ordered, and diÅ¿poÅ¿ed by the Å¿aid Lords and Commons in Å¿uch Å¿ort, and by Å¿uch ways and means as they Å¿hall think fit and appoint, and not otherwiÅ¿e. And the Å¿aid Lords and Commons, during the Å¿aid Å¿pace of twenty years, Å¿hall have power,

1. To Å¿uppreÅ¿s all Forces raiÅ¿ed or to be raiÅ¿ed, without authority and conÅ¿ent of the Å¿aid Lords and Commons, to the diÅ¿turbance of the publick Peace of the Kingdoms of England and Ireland, and Dominion of Wales, the IÅ¿les of GuernÅ¿ey and JerÅ¿ey, and the Town of Barwick upon Tweed, or any of them.

2. To Å¿uppreÅ¿s any foreign Forces who Å¿hall invade or endeavour to invade the Kingdoms of England and Ireland, Dominion of Wales, the IÅ¿les of GuernÅ¿ey and JerÅ¿ey, and the Town of Barwick upon Tweed, or any of them.

Provided, that nothing herein before contained Å¿hall extend to the taking away of the ordinary legal power of Sheriffs, JuÅ¿tices of Peace, Mayors, Bayliffs, Coroners, ConÅ¿tables, Headboroughs, or other Officers of JuÅ¿tice not being Military Officers, concerning the adminiÅ¿tration of JuÅ¿tice, Å¿o as neither the Å¿aid Sheriffs, JuÅ¿tices of Peace, Mayors, Bayliffs, Coroners, ConÅ¿tables, Headboroughs, and other Officers, nor any of them, do levy, conduct, employ, or command any Forces whatÅ¿oever, by colour or pretence of any CommiÅ¿Å¿ion of Array, or extraordinary command from his MajeÅ¿ty, his Heirs, or SucceÅ¿Å¿ors, without the conÅ¿ent of the Å¿aid Lords and Commons.

And if any perÅ¿ons Å¿hall be gathered and aÅ¿Å¿embled together in warlike manner, or otherwiÅ¿e to the number of thirty perÅ¿ons, and Å¿hall not forthwith disband themÅ¿elves, being required thereto by the Å¿aid Lords and Commons, or command from
them, or any by them, eÅ¿pecially authorized for that purpoÅ¿e; then Å¿uch perÅ¿on or perÅ¿ons not Å¿o disbanding themÅ¿elves, Å¿hall be guilty and incur the pains of High-TreaÅ¿on, being firÅ¿t declared guilty of Å¿uch offence by the Å¿aid Lords and Commons; any CommiÅ¿Å¿ion under the great Seal or other Warrant to the contrary, notwithÅ¿tanding.

And he or they that Å¿hall offend herein, to be incapable of any pardon from his MajeÅ¿ty, his Heirs or SucceÅ¿Å¿ors, and their EÅ¿tates Å¿hall be diÅ¿poÅ¿ed as the Å¿aid Lords and Commons Å¿hall think fit, and not otherwiÅ¿e.

Provided that the City of London Å¿hall have and enjoy all their Rights, Liberties, and FranchiÅ¿es, CuÅ¿toms and UÅ¿ages in the raiÅ¿ing and employing the Forces of that City, for the defence thereof, in as full and ample manner, to all intents and purpoÅ¿es, as they have or might have uÅ¿ed or enjoyed the Å¿ame at any time, before the making of the Å¿aid Act or PropoÅ¿ition; To the end that City may be fully aÅ¿Å¿ured it is not the intention of the Parliament to take from them any priviledges, or immunities in raiÅ¿ing or diÅ¿poÅ¿ing of their Forces, which they have or might have uÅ¿ed or enjoyed heretofore.

And all Å¿uch of the ScottiÅ¿h Nation as have concurred in the Votes at Oxford, againÅ¿t the Kingdom of Scotland and their proceedings, or have Å¿worn or Å¿ubÅ¿cribed the Declaration againÅ¿t the Convention and Covenant; and all Å¿uch as have aÅ¿Å¿iÅ¿ted the Rebellion in the North, or the InvaÅ¿ion in the South of the Å¿aid Kingdom of Scotland, or the late InvaÅ¿ion made there by the IriÅ¿h and their Adherents, be removed from his MajeÅ¿ties Councils, and be reÅ¿trained from coming within the Verge of the Court; and that they may not, without the advice and conÅ¿ent of both HouÅ¿es of the Parliament of England, or the EÅ¿tates in the Parliament of Scotland reÅ¿pectively, bear any Office, or have any Employment concerning the State or Commonwealth. And in caÅ¿e any of them Å¿hall offend therein, to be guilty of High-TreaÅ¿on, and incapable of any pardon from his MajeÅ¿ty, and their EÅ¿tates to be diÅ¿poÅ¿ed as both HouÅ¿es of the Parliament of England, or the EÅ¿tates of the Parliament in Scotland reÅ¿pectively Å¿hall think fit: And that one full third part upon full value of the EÅ¿tates of the perÅ¿ons aforeÅ¿aid, made incapable of Employment as aforeÅ¿aid, be employed for the payment of the publick Debts and Damages, according to the Declaration.

Branch 1. And in caÅ¿e any of them Å¿hall offend therein, to be guilty of High-TreaÅ¿on, and incapable of any pardon by his MajeÅ¿ty, and their EÅ¿tates to be diÅ¿poÅ¿ed as both HouÅ¿es of Parliament in England, or the EÅ¿tates of the Parliament of Scotland reÅ¿pectively Å¿hall think fit.

Branch 2. That the late Members, or any who pretended themÅ¿elves Members of either HouÅ¿e of Parliament, who have Å¿ate in the unlawful AÅ¿Å¿embly at Oxford, called or pretended by Å¿ome to be a Parliament, and have not voluntarily rendred themÅ¿elves before the laÅ¿t of October, 1644. be removed from his MajeÅ¿ties Councils, and reÅ¿trained from coming within the Verge of the Court; and that they may not, without the advice and conÅ¿ent of both HouÅ¿es of Parliament, bear any Office, or have any Employment concerning the State or Commonwealth. And in caÅ¿e any of them Å¿hall offend therein, to be guilty of High-TreaÅ¿on, and incapable of any pardon from his MajeÅ¿ty, and their EÅ¿tates to be diÅ¿poÅ¿ed as both HouÅ¿es of the Parliament of England Å¿hall think fit.

Branch 3. That the late Members, or any who pretended themÅ¿elves Members of either HouÅ¿e of Parliament, who have deÅ¿erted the Parliament, and adhered to the Enemies thereof, and have not rendred themÅ¿elves before the laÅ¿t of October, 1644. be removed from his MajeÅ¿ties Councils, and be reÅ¿trained from coming within the Verge of the Court; and that they may not, without the advice and conÅ¿ent of both HouÅ¿es of Parliament, bear any Office, or
have any Employment concerning the State or Commonwealth. And in caÅ¿e any of them Å¿hall offend therein, to be guilty of High-TreaÅ¿on, and incapable of any pardon from his MajeÅ¿ty, and their EÅ¿tates to be diÅ¿poÅ¿ed as both HouÅ¿es of Parliament in England Å¿hall think fit.

5 Qualification.
That all Judges and Officers, towards the Law, Common or Civil, who have deÅ¿erted the Parliament, and adhered to the Enemies thereof, be incapable of any place of Judicature or Office towards the Law, Common or Civil: And that all Serjeants, CounÅ¿ellors, and Attorneys, Doctors, Advocates, Proctors of the Law, Common or Civil, who have deÅ¿erted the Parliament, and adhered to the Enemies thereof, be incapable of any practice in the Law, Common or Civil, either in publick or private; and Å¿hall not be capable of any preferment or employment in the Commonwealth, without the advice and conÅ¿ent of both HouÅ¿es of Parliament: And that no BiÅ¿hop or Clergy-man, no MaÅ¿ter or Fellow of any Colledge or Hall in either of the UniverÅ¿ities, or elÅ¿ewhere, or any MaÅ¿ter of School or HoÅ¿pital, or any EccleÅ¿iaÅ¿tical perÅ¿on, who hath deÅ¿erted the Parliament, and adhered to the Enemies thereof, Å¿hall hold or enjoy, or be capable of any preferment or employment in Church or Commonwealth; but all their Å¿aid Å¿everal preferments, places, and promotions, Å¿hall be utterly void, as if they were naturally dead; nor Å¿hall they otherwiÅ¿e uÅ¿e their Function of the MiniÅ¿try, without advice and conÅ¿ent of both HouÅ¿es of Parliament: Provided that no Laps Å¿hall incurr by Å¿uch vacancy, until Å¿ix months paÅ¿t, after notice thereof.

6 Qualification.
That all perÅ¿ons who have been actually in Arms againÅ¿t the Parliament, or have counÅ¿elled or voluntarily aÅ¿Å¿iÅ¿ted the Enemies thereof, are diÅ¿abled to be Sheriffs, JuÅ¿tices of the Peace, Mayors, or other head-Officers of any City or Corporation, CommiÅ¿Å¿ioners of Oyer and Terminer, or to Å¿it or Å¿erve as Members, or AÅ¿Å¿iÅ¿tants in either of the HouÅ¿es of Parliament, or to have any Military employment in this Kingdom, without the conÅ¿ent of both HouÅ¿es of Parliament.

7 Qualification.
The perÅ¿ons of all others to be free of all perÅ¿onal cenÅ¿ure, notwithÅ¿tanding any Act, or thing done in, or concerning this War, they taking the Covenant.

8 Qualification.
The EÅ¿tates of thoÅ¿e perÅ¿ons excepted in the firÅ¿t three precedent Qualifications; and the EÅ¿tates of Edward Lord Littleton, and of William Laud late ArchbiÅ¿hop of Canterbury, to pay publick Debts and Damages.

9 Qualification.
Branch 1. That two full parts in three, to be divided of all the EÅ¿tates of the Members of either HouÅ¿e of Parliament, who have not onely deÅ¿erted the Parliament, but have alÅ¿o voted both Kingdoms Traytors, and have not rendred themÅ¿elves before the firÅ¿t of December, 1645. Å¿hall be taken and employed for the payment of the publick Debts and Damages of the Kingdom.

Branch 2. That two full parts in three, to be divided of the EÅ¿tates of Å¿uch late Members of either HouÅ¿e of Parliament, as Å¿ate in the unlawful AÅ¿Å¿embly at Oxford, and Å¿hall not have rendred themÅ¿elves before the firÅ¿t of December, 1645. Å¿hall be taken and employed for the payment of the publick Debts and Damages of the Kingdom.

Branch 3. That one full moity of the EÅ¿tates of Å¿uch perÅ¿ons, late Members of either of the HouÅ¿es of Parliament, who have deÅ¿erted the Parliament, and adhered to the Enemies thereof, and Å¿hall not have rendred themÅ¿elves before the firÅ¿t of December, 1645. Å¿hall be taken and employed for the payment of the publick Debts and Damages of the Kingdom.

10 Qualification.
That a full third part of the value of the EÅ¿tates of all Judges and Officers towards the Law, Common or Civil, and of all Serjeants, CounÅ¿ellors, and Attorneys, Doctors, Advocates, and Proctors of the Law, Common or Civil: And of all BiÅ¿hops, Clergy-men, MaÅ¿ters and Fellows of any Colledge or Hall in either of the UniverÅ¿ities, or elÅ¿ewhere: And of all MaÅ¿ters of Schools or HoÅ¿pitals, and of all EccleÅ¿iaÅ¿tical perÅ¿ons who have deÅ¿erted the Parliament, and adhered to the Enemies thereof, and have not rendred themÅ¿elves to the Parliament before the firÅ¿t of December, 1645. Å¿hall be taken and employed for the payment of the publick Debts and Damages of the Kingdom.

That a full Å¿ixth part on the full value of the EÅ¿tates of the perÅ¿ons excepted in the Å¿ixth Qualification, concerning Å¿uch as have been actually in Arms againÅ¿t the Parliament, or have counÅ¿elled or voluntarily aÅ¿Å¿iÅ¿ted the Enemies thereof and are diÅ¿abled according to the Å¿aid Qualification, be taken and
employed for the payment of the publick Debts and Damages of the Kingdom.

11 Qualification.
That the perÅ¿ons and EÅ¿tates of all Common Souldiers, and others of the Kingdom of England, who in Lands or Goods be not worth two hundred pounds Å¿terling; and the perÅ¿ons and EÅ¿tates of all Common Souldiers and others of the Kingdom of Scotland, who in Lands or Goods be not worth one hundred pounds Å¿terling, be at liberty and diÅ¿charged.
Branch 1. This PropoÅ¿ition to Å¿tand as to the EngliÅ¿h, and as to the Scots likewiÅ¿e; if the Parliament of Scotland or their CommiÅ¿Å¿ioners Å¿hall Å¿o think fit.

Branch 2. That the 1 of May laÅ¿t, is now the day limited for the perÅ¿ons to come in that are compriÅ¿ed within the former Qualifications. Provided that all and every the Delinquents which by or according to the Å¿everal and reÅ¿pective Ordinances or Orders made by both or either of the HouÅ¿es of Parliament, on or before the 24th day of April, 1647. are to be admitted to make their Fines and CompoÅ¿itions under the rates and proportions of the Qualifications aforeÅ¿aid, Å¿hall according to the Å¿aid Ordinances and Orders, reÅ¿pectively be thereto admitted; and further alÅ¿o, that no perÅ¿on or perÅ¿ons whatÅ¿oever (except Å¿uch PapiÅ¿ts as having been in Arms, or voluntarily aÅ¿Å¿iÅ¿ted againÅ¿t the Parliament, have by concealing their quality, procured their admiÅ¿Å¿ion to CompoÅ¿ition) which have already compounded, or Å¿hall hereafter compound and be thereto admitted by both HouÅ¿es of Parliament, at any of the rates and proportions aforeÅ¿aid, or under reÅ¿pectively, Å¿hall be put to pay any other
Fine than that they have or Å¿hall reÅ¿pectively Å¿o compound for, (except for Å¿uch EÅ¿tates, or Å¿uch of their EÅ¿tates, and for Å¿uch values thereof reÅ¿pectively as have been or Å¿hall be concealed or omitted in the particulars whereupon they compound;) and that all and every of them Å¿hall have thereupon their Pardons in Å¿uch manner and form as is agreed by both HouÅ¿es of Parliament.

That an Act be paÅ¿Å¿ed whereby the Debts of the Kingdom, and the perÅ¿ons of Delinquents, and the value of their EÅ¿tates may be known; and which Act Å¿hall appoint in what manner the ConfiÅ¿cations and Proportions before-mentioned may be leavied, and applied to the diÅ¿charge of the Å¿aid Engagements.
The like for the Kingdom of Scotland, if the EÅ¿tates of Parliament, or Å¿uch as Å¿hall have power from them, Å¿hall think fit.

div.head: XIX.
div.p: That an Act of Parliament be paÅ¿Å¿ed, to declare and make void the CeÅ¿Å¿ation of Ireland, and all Treaties and ConcluÅ¿ions of Peace, or any Articles thereupon with the Rebels, without conÅ¿ent of both HouÅ¿es of Parliament. And to Å¿ettle the proÅ¿ecution of the War of Ireland in both HouÅ¿es of the Parliament of England, to be managed by them; and the King to aÅ¿Å¿iÅ¿t, and to do no act to diÅ¿countenance or moleÅ¿t them therein.

That Reformation of Religion, according to the Covenant, be Å¿etled in the Kingdom of Ireland by Act of Parliament, in Å¿uch manner as both HouÅ¿es of the Parliament of England have agreed, or Å¿hall agree upon, after ConÅ¿ultation had with the AÅ¿Å¿embly of Divines here.

That the Deputy or chief Governour, or other Governours of Ireland, and the PreÅ¿idents of the Å¿everal Provinces of that Kingdom, be nominated by both the HouÅ¿es of the Parliament of England; or
in the intervals of Parliament, by Å¿uch Committees of both HouÅ¿es of Parliament as both HouÅ¿es of the Parliament of England Å¿hall nominate and appoint for that purpoÅ¿e. And that the Chancellor, or Lord Keeper, Lord TreaÅ¿urer, CommiÅ¿Å¿ioners of the Great Seal or TreaÅ¿ury, Lord Warden of the Cinque-Ports, Chancellor of the Exchequer and Dutchy, Secretaries of State, MaÅ¿ter of the Rolls, Judges of both Benches, and Barons of the Exchequer of the Kingdoms of England and Ireland, and the Vice-TreaÅ¿urer, and the TreaÅ¿urers at Wars of the Kingdom of Ireland, be nominated by both HouÅ¿es of the Parliament of England, to continue Quam diu Å¿e bene geÅ¿Å¿erint, and in the intervals of Parliament, by the afore-mentioned Committees, to be approved or diÅ¿allowed by both HouÅ¿es at their next Å¿itting.

The like for the Kingdom of Scotland, concerning the nomination of the Lords of the Privy-Council, Lords of SeÅ¿Å¿ion, and Exchequer, Officers of State, and JuÅ¿tice-General, in Å¿uch manner as the EÅ¿tates of Parliament there Å¿hall think fit.

That the Militia of the City of London and Liberties thereof, may be in the ordering and government of the Lord Mayor, Aldermen, and Commons in Common Council aÅ¿Å¿embled, or Å¿uch as they Å¿hall from time to time appoint, (whereof the Lord Mayor and Sheriffs for the time being to be three:) to be employed and directed from time to time in Å¿uch manner as Å¿hall be agreed on and appointed by both HouÅ¿es of Parliament.

That no Citizen of the City of London, nor any of the Forces of the Å¿aid City, Å¿hall be drawn forth or compelled to go out of the Å¿aid City or Liberties thereof for Military Å¿ervice, without their own free conÅ¿ent.

That an Act be paÅ¿Å¿ed for the granting and confirming
of the Charters, CuÅ¿toms, Liberties, and FranchiÅ¿es of the City of London, notwithÅ¿tanding any NonuÅ¿er, MiÅ¿uÅ¿er, or AbuÅ¿er.

That the Tower of London may be in the government of the City of London, and the chief Officer and Governour thereof from time to time be nominated, and removeable by the Common Council: And for prevention of inconveniencies which may happen by the long intermiÅ¿Å¿ion of Common Councils, it is deÅ¿ired that there may be an Act, that all by-Laws and Ordinances already made, or hereafter to be made by the Council aÅ¿Å¿embled, touching the calling, continuing, directing, and regulating the Å¿ame Common Councils, Å¿hall be as effectual in the Law to all intents and purpoÅ¿es, as if the Å¿ame were particularly enacted by the Authority of Parliament: And that the Lord Mayor, Aldermen, and Commons in Common Council, may adde to or repeal the Å¿aid Ordinances from time to time as they Å¿hall Å¿ee cauÅ¿e.

That Å¿uch other PropoÅ¿itions as Å¿hall be made for the City, for their further Å¿afety, welfare, and government, and Å¿hall be approved of by both HouÅ¿es of Parliament, may be granted and confirmed by Act of Parliament.

That all Grants, CommiÅ¿Å¿ions, PreÅ¿entations, Writs, ProceÅ¿s, proceedings, and other things paÅ¿Å¿ed under the Great Seal of England, in the cuÅ¿tody of the Lords and other CommiÅ¿Å¿ioners appointed by both HouÅ¿es of Parliament for the cuÅ¿tody thereof, be, and by Act of Parliament with the Royal aÅ¿Å¿ent, Å¿hall be declared and enacted to be of like full force and effect to all intents and purpoÅ¿es, as the Å¿ame or like Grants, CommiÅ¿Å¿ions, PreÅ¿entations, Writs, ProceÅ¿s, Proceedings, and other things under any Great Seal of England, in any time heretofore were, or have been; And that for time to
come, the Å¿aid Great Seal now remaining in cuÅ¿tody of the Å¿aid CommiÅ¿Å¿ioners, continue, and be uÅ¿ed for the Great Seal of England; And that all Grants, CommiÅ¿Å¿ions, PreÅ¿entations, Writs, ProceÅ¿s, Proceedings, and other things whatÅ¿oever paÅ¿Å¿ed under or by any authority of any other Great Seal, Å¿ince the 22th day of May, Anno Dom. 1642. or hereafter to be paÅ¿Å¿ed, be Invalid, and of no effect, to all intents and purpoÅ¿es: Except Å¿uch Writs, ProceÅ¿s, and CommiÅ¿Å¿ions, as being paÅ¿Å¿ed under any other Great Seal than the Å¿aid Great Seal in the cuÅ¿tody of the CommiÅ¿Å¿ioners aforeÅ¿aid, on or after the Å¿aid 22th day of May, and before the 28th day of November, Anno Dom. 1643. were afterward proceeded upon, returned into, or put in ure in any the Kings Courts at WeÅ¿tminÅ¿ter: And except the Grant to Mr. JuÅ¿tice Bacon, to be one of the JuÅ¿tices of the Kings-Bench: And except all Acts and proceedings by virtue of any Å¿uch CommiÅ¿Å¿ions of Goal-delivery, AÅ¿Å¿ize, and NiÅ¿i prius, or Oyer and Terminer, paÅ¿Å¿ed under any other Great Seal than the Seal aforeÅ¿aid in cuÅ¿tody of the Å¿aid CommiÅ¿Å¿ioners, before the firÅ¿t of October, 1642.

And that all Grants of Offices, Lands, Tenements, or Hereditaments, made or paÅ¿Å¿ed under the Great Seal of Ireland, unto any perÅ¿on or perÅ¿ons, Bodies politick or corporate, Å¿ince the CeÅ¿Å¿ation made in Ireland, the fifteenth day of September, 1643. Å¿hall be null and void. And that all Honours and Titles conferred upon any perÅ¿on or perÅ¿ons in the Å¿aid Kingdom of Ireland, Å¿ince the Å¿aid CeÅ¿Å¿ation, Å¿hall be null and void.

That the Å¿everal Ordinances, the one intituled, An Ordinance of Parliament for aboliÅ¿hing of ArchbiÅ¿hops and BiÅ¿hops within the Kingdom of England and Dominion of Wales, and for Å¿e â¢ ing of their Lands and PoÅ¿Å¿eÅ¿Å¿ions upon TruÅ¿tees for the uÅ¿e of the Commonwealth;

the other intituled, An Ordinance of the Lords and Commons aÅ¿Å¿embled in Parliament, for appointing the Å¿ale of BiÅ¿hops Lands for the uÅ¿e of the Commonwealth; be confirmed by Acts of Parliament.

TheÅ¿e were the Conditions of Peace propoÅ¿ed by the Parliament as the Å¿ubject matter of that Conference, which all paÅ¿Å¿ionately wiÅ¿hed, and a great many fought for. They were the very Å¿ame that had been heretofore Å¿ent to the King when he was at Hampton-Court, and not onely rejected by his MajeÅ¿ty, but by the Army alÅ¿o, as being too unreaÅ¿onable:
No notice taken of the Scots.
To what Conditions the CommiÅ¿Å¿ioners are tyed. they onely differed in this, that in thoÅ¿e laÅ¿t there was no mention made of the Scots.

In the mean time the Pacificators are inveÅ¿ted with no other authority but that of anÅ¿wering the Royal Arguments, and of returning ReaÅ¿ons to induce the King to aÅ¿Å¿ent: they had no power of Å¿oftening any PropoÅ¿ition, or altering the leaÅ¿t word, nay, nor Å¿o much as of omitting the Preface. Their InÅ¿tructions likewiÅ¿e bear, that they are to acquaint the Parliament with the Kings ConceÅ¿Å¿ions, and the whole progreÅ¿s of the Negotiation, to treat altogether in writing, nay, and to debate the PropoÅ¿itions as they lay in order, not deÅ¿cending to a new PropoÅ¿ition, until the former was adjuÅ¿ted.

The Conference to be held at Newport. Nor was it thought enough that the Conditions and CommiÅ¿Å¿ioners were Å¿o Å¿trictly limited; they confine the Conference alÅ¿o to the Town of Newport in the IÅ¿le of Wight, and the continuance of it to the Å¿pace of forty days.

The King alÅ¿o, who was to be preÅ¿ent at the Conference, was Å¿o far well treated as to be permitted to come out of his PriÅ¿on and have that IÅ¿land allowed him for a larger confinement; but upon promiÅ¿e given, that he would not depart out the
IÅ¿land within forty days after the concluÅ¿ion of the Conference: and the Å¿ly Oligarchick and Democratick Republicans, who had a hand in the Councils, were the Authors of thoÅ¿e Å¿cruples and reÅ¿trictions.The K. is allowed his neceÅ¿Å¿ary Å¿ervants With great caution the Parliament permitted Å¿ome of his MajeÅ¿ties neceÅ¿Å¿ary Servants, by name, Å¿ome Lawyers, Divines, and a Secretary to be preÅ¿ent; but not to be admitted into the Conference, onely to be without behind the Curtain in the Lobby. So that the King alone was Å¿ingly to Å¿uÅ¿tain the perÅ¿on of a Politician and Divine, againÅ¿t the ableÅ¿t Parliamentarian Politicians and Divines of the whole Kingdom.

In managing the Conference, the King alone,The K.'s wonderful prudence in the Conference. with Å¿uch incredible Prudence and Eloquence, Å¿ifted and bafled all their Å¿trongeÅ¿t Arguments, with Å¿o great lenity and readineÅ¿s of condeÅ¿cenÅ¿ion, granted their Demands even when he had made it appear they were unreaÅ¿onable (Å¿o far as with Honour and a Å¿afe ConÅ¿cience he could) that he raviÅ¿hed them all into admiration of him; and, which was an Argument of a Å¿upernatural Wit, he brought over the CommiÅ¿Å¿ioners who were his moÅ¿t inveterate enemies, even againÅ¿t their will, to his Opinion, (though their Employment, and the danger of their heads, obliged them, againÅ¿t their ConÅ¿cience, to continue in oppoÅ¿ition to him.) Without doubt, in this, as in all things elÅ¿e, he gave a glorious proof of his Fatherly goodneÅ¿s, in that with his own loÅ¿s and prejudice onely he would gladly have redeem'd his people from the havock and miÅ¿eries of War.

The Conference had for Å¿ome time been taken up in compoÅ¿ing affairs,In the middle of the Treaty the Parliamentarians require that the MarqueÅ¿s of Ormond's CommiÅ¿Å¿ion be recalled. when of a Å¿udden news is brought to the Parliament, that the MarqueÅ¿s of Ormond was arrived in Ireland to govern that Kingdom in quality of Lord Deputy, by authority from the King; and that he was to Å¿ettle a Peace there,
upon the beÅ¿t conditions he could; as alÅ¿o to levy an Army for delivering the King out of priÅ¿on. Upon this, Letters are Å¿ent to the CommiÅ¿Å¿ioners in the IÅ¿le of Wight, with inÅ¿tructions to demand of the King, that he would recal Ormond's CommiÅ¿Å¿ion, and turn him out of that authority which was Å¿omewhat uneaÅ¿ie to the Pacificators.

In the mean while, report is made to the Parliament by piece-meals of what was tranÅ¿acted in the Conference; where many with a mind as averÅ¿e, as the Kings was inclinable to peace,The K.'s AnÅ¿wers are cenÅ¿ured in Parl. quible at and cenÅ¿ure the leaÅ¿t punctilio of every thing, unleÅ¿s all were condeÅ¿cended to in every tittle according to their own words and preÅ¿cribed form: for they were afraid (which Å¿ome of them openly profeÅ¿Å¿ed) that the PropoÅ¿itions being fully granted, and no more place left for AnimoÅ¿ity or Grievance, they might, if not by force from the people, yet out of Å¿hame be compelled to conclude a Peace in good earneÅ¿t, which they onely deÅ¿ired in Å¿hew. For the the King having,The K. unexpectedly granted many things. contrary to the opinion of all, condeÅ¿cended to many things, had not onely admitted the Å¿ubject matter, but alÅ¿o the Å¿crupuloÅ¿ities and niceties of words.

To the Preface, which aimed not Å¿o much at the publick Peace, as the branding of himÅ¿elf and his party with a note of Ignominy, he would not conÅ¿ent, but with this clauÅ¿e, That nothing in that Conference Å¿hould be taken for granted, unleÅ¿s all were aagreed upon in general.

He agreed to the IÅ¿t PropoÅ¿ition, of recalling the Declarations; to the XVIth, of the Forces; the XIXth, of the government of Ireland; the XVth, of the payment of publick Debts, Provided theÅ¿e Debts were Å¿tated within the Å¿pace of two years; to the XVIIth, of anulling Titles of Honours; the XIXth, of the chief MagiÅ¿trates of the Kingdom; the XIXth, of the
Great Seal; the XIXth, of the Priviledges of London. Of the Court of Wards There is no menÅ¿ion of the Court of Wards in theÅ¿e Articles, thÃ´ it is expreÅ¿Å¿ed both here and in Baker's Chronicle, and perhaps was thought of after theÅ¿e Articles were printed., provided he had an hundred thouÅ¿and pound a year paid him in lieu of it.

In all theÅ¿e points he made himÅ¿elf an eaÅ¿ie prey to the avarice and ambition of others; and that he might render the Kingdom more peaceable to others, he even Å¿uffered it to be Å¿natched out of his own hands.

He gave his conÅ¿ent to all the Articles of the IIId PropoÅ¿ition, except one, concerning BiÅ¿hops and their Revenues; yet in that he was not altogether wanting to the deÅ¿ires of the Parliament: for whatever did not plainly appear to be of Divine InÅ¿titution, he allowed might be abrogated; Å¿o that he Å¿uffered ArchiepiÅ¿copacy to be aboliÅ¿hed, EpiÅ¿copal JuriÅ¿diction alÅ¿o, that is, the exerciÅ¿e of EccleÅ¿iaÅ¿tical JuriÅ¿diction, and the Å¿tate and priviledge of holding EccleÅ¿iaÅ¿tical Courts; but he would not Å¿uffer the power of conferring Orders (and adminiÅ¿tring Church-cenÅ¿ures) as being ApoÅ¿tolical, to be altered and leÅ¿Å¿ened.

But at length the little Rabbies of the AÅ¿Å¿embly and Pacificators interweaving with the other Arguments, which he could better refute, that of invincible NeceÅ¿Å¿ity, and promiÅ¿ing privately, that if he would conÅ¿ent to theÅ¿e at preÅ¿ent, they would hereafter enlarge his Bonds, as alÅ¿o giving him hopes that the Parliament would condeÅ¿cend to him in other matters, provided in this he would remit Å¿omewhat of his Å¿trictneÅ¿s of ConÅ¿cience; he conÅ¿ents that for the Å¿pace of three years, Orders Å¿hall not be conferred by the BiÅ¿hops, without the conÅ¿ent of Presbyters; nay, that the power of Ordaining Å¿hall be Å¿uÅ¿pended, until twenty Divines of his chuÅ¿ing, and an AÅ¿Å¿embly called by the Parliament, do meet, determine, and Å¿ettle the Government of the
Church; to which he promiÅ¿ed to acquieÅ¿ce, if the Parliament would do the like: In the mean time he is not againÅ¿t it, but that Presbytery may be Å¿etled for a tryal.

Abhorring the thought of Sacriledge, he would not Å¿uffer BiÅ¿hops and Church-lands to be divided and alienated from the Church; but permitted them to be let out by leaÅ¿e for ninety nine years, paying a Å¿mall yearly rent for the maintenance of the BiÅ¿hops, and as a token of their Tenure, provided after the expiring of the LeaÅ¿e, they Å¿hould return to the Crown to be employed for the uÅ¿e of the Church: which, in the mean time, he was firmly reÅ¿olved to redeem with his money, and to reÅ¿tore them to the Church-men to whom in right they belonged.
Nor would he (being mindful of his Friends amidÅ¿t his own dangers) conÅ¿ent to the XVIIIth PropoÅ¿ition, concerning Delinquents; but he allowed,
I. That they might be moderately fined.

II. That they may be debarred from the Kings preÅ¿ence and coming to Court: that Å¿ome of them alÅ¿o may be baniÅ¿hed, but not as Traitors, nor yet to loÅ¿e their Lives and EÅ¿tates, if they act to the contrary.
III. That for three years they be excluded from Å¿itting in Parliament.

IV. That they might be brought to tryal, if it were thought fit, and be condignly puniÅ¿hed, if they had acted any thing againÅ¿t the known Laws of England, (which certainly favoured the Kings Party): But he thought it unjuÅ¿t that any man Å¿hould be puniÅ¿hed for his Loyalty to him, according to the dictates of his ConÅ¿cience, and the municipal Laws, by a Law made ex poÅ¿t facto. Yet he condeÅ¿cended to other Articles of the Å¿ame PropoÅ¿ition, upon this condition, that pious and learned Church-men, free
from Å¿candal, might enjoy a third of their Livings, and not be totally deprived of the liberty of preaching.

He could not, as he Å¿aid, recal the Authorities which he had given to the MarqueÅ¿s of Ormond, at the very time when himÅ¿elf was confined to priÅ¿on. The Parliament agreed with him in the reÅ¿t: which Å¿ucceeding, then, according to the ConceÅ¿Å¿ions in the XIXth PropoÅ¿ition, the Parliament Å¿hould have the Å¿ole adminiÅ¿tration of the affairs of Ireland. In the mean time, however, he wrote to the MarqueÅ¿s of Ormond, commanding him to refrain from the execution of his power, Å¿o long as the Conference and any hopes of Peace continued.

WhilÅ¿t the Conference laÅ¿ted, the King, The K. makes Å¿ome PropoÅ¿als. that he might not Å¿till Å¿uffer Å¿o hard uÅ¿age, and that he might try how the Members of Parliament were affected towards him, gave Å¿ome very juÅ¿t and uÅ¿eful PropoÅ¿als to be Å¿ent to the Parliament.

FirÅ¿t, he deÅ¿ires,To which the Parl. in a great part conÅ¿ent. That he may have leave to repair forthwith to WeÅ¿tminÅ¿ter, or any of his houÅ¿es near London, where he may treat with his Parliament at nearer diÅ¿tance, with honour, Å¿afety, and freedom. Which deÅ¿ire, the Parliament having felt the pulÅ¿e of the City, and being encouraged under the hands of the moÅ¿t part and beÅ¿t of the Citizens, promiÅ¿ed, Å¿o Å¿oon as the PropoÅ¿itions were granted, Å¿hould be allowed him.
Secondly, the King demands, That he may be reÅ¿tored to the poÅ¿Å¿eÅ¿Å¿ion of the Lands and Revenues of the Crown.
Thirdly, That he may have compenÅ¿ation for his lawful Rights which the Parliament have thought fit to aboliÅ¿h. To theÅ¿e alÅ¿o the Parliament willingly conÅ¿ent.

Fourthly, That by an Act of Oblivion the memory of all things that had been done in time of the War,
might be aboliÅ¿hed. To this PropoÅ¿al they did not conÅ¿ent, but with cautions and limitations, that gave liberty to the Parliamentarians to bring Actions againÅ¿t any almoÅ¿t of the Kings Party.
