The King having heard this Indictment,He calls into queÅ¿tion the Authority of the Court. with a majeÅ¿ty in his looks and words, that cannot be expreÅ¿t, puts the queÅ¿tion to thoÅ¿e new Judges, By what Authority they brought their King to the Bar, contrary to the publick Faith which was very lately made to him when he entered into a Conference with the Members of both HouÅ¿es. By what lawful Authority, Å¿aid he emphatically. He knew indeed there were many unlawful and powerful Combinations of men in the world, as of Thieves and Robbers by the High-ways. He deÅ¿ires they would tell him by what Authority they had taken that Power, (Å¿uch as it was upon them) and he would be willing to anÅ¿wer; but if they could not, he bids them think well upon it, before they go farther from one Å¿in to a greater: That he had a TruÅ¿t committed to him by God by an ancient and lawful DeÅ¿cent; and that he would not betray it by anÅ¿wering to a new and unlawful Authority.

The PreÅ¿ident replying,Which the PreÅ¿ident affirming to be derived from the People that chuÅ¿e the King, the King denies it That he was brought to anÅ¿wer in the name of the People of England, of which he was elected King. The King made anÅ¿wer, That England was never an Elective Kingdom, but an Hereditary Kingdom for near theÅ¿e thouÅ¿and years. That he did Å¿tand more for the liberty of the People, by rejecting their uÅ¿urped Power, than any of them that came to be his pretended Judges did by Å¿upporting it. That he did not come there as Å¿ubmitting to the Court: That he would Å¿tand as much for the Priviledge of the HouÅ¿e of Commons as any man there whatÅ¿oever; but that he Å¿aw no HouÅ¿e of Lords there, that might, together
with a King, conÅ¿titute a Parliament But then that neither one nor both the HouÅ¿es, nor any other Tribunal upon Earth, had any power to judge the King of England; much leÅ¿s a parcel of pack'd Judges of the Lower HouÅ¿e, who were masked onely with the oppreÅ¿Å¿ed power of that Court.. That if they would Å¿hew him a legal authority, warranted by the Word of God, the Scriptures, or warranted by the ConÅ¿titutions of the Kingdom, he would anÅ¿wer: for that he did avow, that it was as great a Å¿in to withÅ¿tand lawful Authority, as it is to Å¿ubmit to a tyrannical or any ways unlawful Authority. The PreÅ¿ident in the mean time often interrupted him, and at length commanding him to be carried back to PriÅ¿on.

The King is again and a third time brought to the bar.Yet was the good King a Å¿econd and a third time brought before the Bar of the Common People, where the PreÅ¿ident puts him in mind of his Indictment, and commands him to anÅ¿wer to the Articles brought againÅ¿t him, or otherways to liÅ¿ten to his Å¿entence. But the King Å¿till proteÅ¿ted againÅ¿t the Authority of the Court; affirming, That his life was not Å¿o dear to him, as his Honour, ConÅ¿cience, the Laws and the Liberties of the People; which that they might not periÅ¿h all at once, there were great reaÅ¿ons why he could not make his defence before thoÅ¿e Judges, nor acknowledge a new form of Judicature: for what power had ever Subjects, or by what Laws was it granted them, to erect a Court againÅ¿t their King? That it could not be warranted by Gods Laws, which on the contrary command obedience to Princes; not by the Laws of the Land, Å¿ince by them no Impeachment can lie againÅ¿t the King, And being about to alleadge ReaÅ¿ons againÅ¿t the Authority of the Court, they all going in his name: nor do they allow the HouÅ¿e of Commons the power of judging the meaneÅ¿t Subject of England. And that laÅ¿tly, that pretended Power could not flow from any Authority or CommiÅ¿Å¿ion from the People, Å¿ince they had never asked the queÅ¿tion of the tenth man (he might have Å¿aid, of the thouÅ¿andth) of the Kingdom.

The PreÅ¿ident interrupting him again, as before,
takes him up now more inÅ¿olently,The PreÅ¿ident interrupts and takes him up. bids him be mindful of his condition: tells him, that the Court is Å¿ufficiently Å¿atisfied, and do affirm their own JuriÅ¿diction; and that no ReaÅ¿ons were to be heard that declined the Authority of the Court. But Å¿hew me that Court, anÅ¿wered the King, where ReaÅ¿on is not to be heard. We Å¿hew it you here, replied the PreÅ¿ident; and the next time you come, you'll know more of their pleaÅ¿ure. But the King urged, That at leaÅ¿t he might be permitted to give in his ReaÅ¿ons in writing; to which if they could give him Å¿atisfaction, he would not decline their JuriÅ¿diction. Here the PreÅ¿ident, not Å¿atisfied to deny his modeÅ¿t Å¿uit, but falling alÅ¿o into a heat, commanded the PriÅ¿oner to be carried away; who made no other return but this, Remember it is your King whom you refuÅ¿e to hear: it will be in vain for my Subjects to expect JuÅ¿tice from you, when you will not hear your King make his lawful defence.

Now the King is the fourth time brought before this unjuÅ¿t Court of JuÅ¿tice; where the PreÅ¿ident, The King is a fourth time brought to the bar; refuÅ¿es to plead: in his Scarlet-robe, bitterly taxes the King of Contumacy, and runs out in commendation of the Patience of the Court. He bids him at length Å¿ubmit to the Court, or to expect his Sentence. But the King conÅ¿tantly refuÅ¿es to plead before them; telling them however, That he had Å¿omething to Å¿ay that concerned the Peace of the Kingdom, DeÅ¿ires a Conference with the Lords and Commons. and the Liberty of the Subject, wherein he deÅ¿ires to be heard before the Lords and Commons. Yet they refuÅ¿e to grant him that favour, which is not wont to be denied to men of the meaneÅ¿t condition; pretending it would delay and put a Å¿top to JuÅ¿tice. To which the King replied, That it would be better to admit the delay of a day or two, than to haÅ¿ten a Sentence that might bring on that trouble and perpetual inconvenience to the Kingdom, that the Child that is unborn might repent it. For if I had had, Å¿aid he, reÅ¿pect to my Life more than the
Peace of the Kingdom, and the Liberties of the Subject, certainly I Å¿hould have made a particular defence for my Å¿elf: for by that at leaÅ¿twiÅ¿e I might have delayed an ugly Sentence, which I believe will paÅ¿s upon me; and that the Zeal to my Country had not overborn the care that I have of my own preÅ¿ervation, I Å¿hould have gone another way to work than I have done. Now Å¿ince a haÅ¿ty Sentence once paÅ¿t may be Å¿ooner repented than recalled, I deÅ¿ire, that having Å¿omething to Å¿ay more for the Peace of the Kingdom, and the Liberty of the Subject, than for my own particular, I may be heard before Sentence be given.

One of the Judges prickt in ConÅ¿cience.Upon which Colonel Downs, one of the Judges, being prickt in ConÅ¿cience, (contrary to what had been privately agreed upon amongÅ¿t the Judges) deÅ¿ires that they may withdraw and debate that PropoÅ¿al privately. Though this extreamly vexed the PreÅ¿ident, Cromwel, and moÅ¿t of the reÅ¿t, yet that they might not Å¿eem publickly to quarrel among themÅ¿elves, they all withdraw into an adjoyning Chamber; where Downs being paid off with flouts and jeers, intermingled with no Å¿mall threats, they return wonderfully unanimous and agreeing into Court.

The PreÅ¿ident in a Å¿et-Å¿peech makes way for the Sentence. Then the PreÅ¿ident with the Å¿ame inhumane barbarity that he began, proceeds to Sentence; having premiÅ¿ed a long Speech, wherein he aggravates the Contumacy of the King, and the haynouÅ¿neÅ¿s of the Crime; he aÅ¿Å¿erts the Power of Parliaments, producing inÅ¿tances both foreign and domeÅ¿tick, (eÅ¿pecially from Scotland, how aptly the Scots are to look to it) wherein the People have puniÅ¿hed their Kings; and that the Power of the People of England over their King, was not leÅ¿s than that of other Nations; that the King's guilt was greater than that of all others, Å¿eeing that (according to the wiÅ¿h of Caligula) he had endeavoured to have cut off the head of the whole Nation,
by undertaking a War againÅ¿t the Parliament.

Having ended his Harangue,Orders the Sentence to be read. he orders the Sentence to be read, in theÅ¿e words: That whereas the Commons of England in Parliament had appointed them an High Court of JuÅ¿tice for the trying of Charles Steuart King of England; before whom he had been three times convented, and at firÅ¿t time a Charge of High-TreaÅ¿on, and other Crimes and MiÅ¿demeanours, was read in the behalf of the Kingdom of England, &c. Which Charge being read unto him as aforeÅ¿aid, he the Å¿aid Charles Steuart was required to give his AnÅ¿wer, but he refuÅ¿ed Å¿o to do, &c.

For all which TreaÅ¿ons and Crimes, the Court doth adjudge, That he the Å¿aid Charles Steuart, as a Tyrant, Traytor, Murderer, and a publick Enemy, Å¿hall be put to death by Å¿evering his Head from his Body.

The Sentence being pronounced,All the Judges that were preÅ¿ent, Å¿tand up and confirm the Sentence. Å¿ixty Å¿even Judges that were preÅ¿ent, as lifted up by the conÅ¿cience of the Villany they had conÅ¿pired in, at the deÅ¿ire of the PreÅ¿ident, (the thing having been privately concerted) Å¿tand up and confirm the Å¿ame; the reÅ¿t, (amongÅ¿t whom was Fairfax) for the horrour of the Crime, not daring to be preÅ¿ent.

His MajeÅ¿ty behaves himÅ¿elf courageouÅ¿ly and prudently,But he with great preÅ¿ence of mind, whilÅ¿t they cried out, JuÅ¿tice and Execution, turning to thoÅ¿e that were about him, Å¿aid, Alas, poor Souls, for a piece of money they would do Å¿o for their Commanders. Wiping off the Spittle when they Å¿pit upon him, all that came from him was, ChriÅ¿t hath Å¿uffered more for my Å¿ake. He Å¿o convincingly confuted the Commanders, Souldiers, and other impertinent AnabaptiÅ¿ts, who with their cavils and Å¿illy diÅ¿putes came to tempt him, that he put moÅ¿t of them to Å¿ilence. He took Å¿o little notice of their ridiculous mirth, that by contemning it, he diÅ¿appointed their Å¿awcy petulance. Nay, though he was Å¿traitned with time,And prepares himÅ¿elf for his laÅ¿t Å¿ufferings. and diÅ¿turbed with the noiÅ¿e of barbarous Souldiers, yet with a religious and Å¿edate mind, Å¿pending his time in the confeÅ¿Å¿ion of his Å¿ins, forgiving his Enemies, taking the Sacrament, holy reading and meditation, and in all the other duties of
Piety, he finds the favour of God amidÅ¿t the hatred of men, and vanquiÅ¿hes and drives away the terrours of death even before they approach.

WhilÅ¿t theÅ¿e things are done openly in view of the people, the execrable and mercileÅ¿s Judges,The Judges, before the publication of Sentence, conÅ¿ult about the kind, manner, and time of the Murder. in the mean time, in their private Cabals allot every one the part he is to act, what words and GeÅ¿tures they are to uÅ¿e; conÅ¿ulting together about the time, place, kind, and all the manner and Å¿olemnity of the Murder: where, I am aÅ¿hamed to mention, what diÅ¿mal kinds of death were propoÅ¿ed for condemned CaeÅ¿ar, even before the Sentence, according as the wantonneÅ¿s, cruelty, or hatred of the Å¿everal tempers did Å¿uggeÅ¿t, though I have been informed of it by moÅ¿t credible perÅ¿ons. Some vote that his Head and Quarters may be Å¿et up in publick places, a puniÅ¿hment inflicted upon Traytors, as a laÅ¿ting Infamy after their death; Å¿ome would have him hanged after the manner of Murderers, Robbers, and Thieves; others again are of opinion that he Å¿hould Å¿uffer in his Crown and Robes, as a Monument of the Power of the People over their King. At length they agree that it will Å¿uffice, that he loÅ¿e his head upon a Scaffold to be erected before the Banquetting-HouÅ¿e of White-hall, that from the Å¿ame place where he uÅ¿ed to mount the Throne, and appear in the Å¿acred pomp of MajeÅ¿ty, he might paÅ¿s to the Block, and caÅ¿t off the Ornaments of Royalty, where he commonly put them on. This was the Triumph, theÅ¿e the Trophies of a victorious Revenge. And becauÅ¿e they had been told, that the King would not Å¿ubmit his Neck to the Ax of his Subjects, they order iron Rings and Staples to be made upon the Scaffold, that if he reÅ¿iÅ¿ted, he might be drawn down to the Block by the head and hands.

But it is not to be omitted, that amongÅ¿t theÅ¿e
Preliminaries to death,PropoÅ¿als are tendered unto him, upon granting which, he is offered his life. Å¿ome Souldiers, the day before the execution, offered PropoÅ¿als; which if he would at length aÅ¿Å¿ent to, they promiÅ¿ed to grant him life and the name of King. But having heard one or two of them read, he rejected them, Å¿aying to this effect: I had rather Å¿uffer a thouÅ¿and deaths, than Å¿o to proÅ¿titute my Honour and the Liberty of my People.

He is permitted to take his leave of his Children.And, that I may not paÅ¿s by unmentioned the leaÅ¿t piece of humanity Å¿hew'd to him, they give him leave to take his Farewel of his Children; to wit, of the Lady Elizabeth then eleven years old, and the Duke of GlouceÅ¿ter nine.What the King gave them in charge. Here the King charged to tell the Queen, that his thoughts had never Å¿trayed from her, and that his love would be the Å¿ame to the laÅ¿t; that Å¿he Å¿hould command the Prince in his name (if it pleaÅ¿ed God to advance him to the Throne) to pardon his Enemies, &c. withal, he commanded her and her Å¿econd Brother (the Duke of York who Å¿ometime before had made his eÅ¿cape from the Parliament) to be Å¿ubject to the Prince and obey their Mother: he bid her alÅ¿o read BiÅ¿hop Andrews Sermons, Hooker's EccleÅ¿iaÅ¿tical Polity, and BiÅ¿hop Laud's Book againÅ¿t FiÅ¿her, which would ground her againÅ¿t Popery.

Then he Å¿aid to the Duke of GlouceÅ¿ter, Mark, Child, what I Å¿ay; they will cut off my head, and perhaps make thee a King: but mark what I Å¿ay, You muÅ¿t not be King Å¿o long as your Brother Charles and James do live; for they will cut off your Brothers heads (when they can catch them) and cut thy head off too at laÅ¿t: and therefore I charge you do not be made a King by them. To which the Child (looking wiÅ¿hfully upon the King) anÅ¿wered, I will be torn in pieces firÅ¿t.

The K. is led to execution.Now was the fatal day when the King, fortified againÅ¿t death by Innocence and Piety, came out of
St. James's houÅ¿e, (now the Royal PriÅ¿on) and walked afoot through the Park, with a chearful countenance, as if he had been going a hunting. The Souldiers and guard of PartiÅ¿ans marching Å¿lowly, he bid them go faÅ¿ter, Å¿aying, That he now went before them to Å¿trive for an heavenly Crown, with leÅ¿s Å¿ollicitude than he had often encouraged his Souldiers to fight for an earthly Diadem.

Being brought into the Banquetting-houÅ¿e, he Å¿pent an hour in prayer, that having recommended his Soul to God, he might have Å¿ome leiÅ¿ure-time before death to be Å¿pent amongÅ¿t the Souldiers. As he went out from thence upon the Scaffold that was covered with diÅ¿mal black, the firÅ¿t Objects that preÅ¿ent themÅ¿elves to his view, are Executioners in Vizard-maÅ¿ques, a Block and an Ax; which yet do not Å¿o damp his Royal Courage, but that he Å¿hew'd his care for the living to be far greater than his apprehenÅ¿ions of dying: for looking round upon the People, who by numerous Guards of HorÅ¿e were kept at a great diÅ¿tance, and perceiving that he could not be heard by them,He Å¿peaks to Col. TomlinÅ¿on, and the other InÅ¿truments of the Regicide. he waved (as it is probable) the diÅ¿courÅ¿e that he intended to deliver to the Multitude, and addreÅ¿Å¿ed himÅ¿elf to Colonel TomlinÅ¿on, and the other InÅ¿truments of the Regicide, in theÅ¿e following words.

p.hi:
I Shall be very little heard of any body elÅ¿e;His Maj. had not spoken, but that otherwiÅ¿e he might have been thought to Å¿ubmit to the guilt. I Å¿hall therefore Å¿peak a word to you here. Indeed I could have held my peace very well, if I did not think that holding my peace would make Å¿ome men think that I did Å¿ubmit to the Guilt as well as to the PuniÅ¿hment: But I think it is my duty to God firÅ¿t, and then to my Country, to clear my Å¿elf both as an honeÅ¿t man, a good King, and a good ChriÅ¿tian. I Å¿hall begin
firÅ¿t with my Innocency; and in troath, I think it not very needful for me to inÅ¿iÅ¿t long upon this:He did not begin the War. for all the world knows that I did never begin a War with the two HouÅ¿es of Parliament; and I call God to witneÅ¿s, unto whom I muÅ¿t Å¿hortly give an account, that I did never intend to incroach upon their Priviledges: They began upon me;But the two HouÅ¿es. it is the Militia they began upon: They confeÅ¿Å¿ed the Militia was mine, but they thought it fit to have it from me. And to be Å¿hort, if any body will look to the dates of CommiÅ¿Å¿ions, of their CommiÅ¿Å¿ions and mine, and likewiÅ¿e to the Declaration, he will Å¿ee clearly that they began thoÅ¿e unhappy Troubles, not I. So as for the guilt of thoÅ¿e enormous Crimes that are laid againÅ¿t me, I hope that God will clear me on't.His MajeÅ¿ty lays not the the guilt upon the two HouÅ¿es, I will not, (for I am in charity) and God forbid that I Å¿hould lay it upon the two HouÅ¿es of Parliament, there is no neceÅ¿Å¿ity of either, I hope they are free of this Guilt;Ill InÅ¿truments the cauÅ¿e of it. but I believe that ill InÅ¿truments between them and me, have been the chief cauÅ¿e of all this BloudÅ¿hed: So that as I find my Å¿elf clear of this, I hope (and pray God) that they may too. Yet for all this, God forbid that I Å¿hould be Å¿o ill a ChriÅ¿tian, as not to Å¿ay, that Gods Judgments are juÅ¿t upon me; many times he doth pay injuÅ¿tice by an unjuÅ¿t Sentence,One unjuÅ¿t Å¿entence puniÅ¿hed with another. that is ordinary: I will Å¿ay this, That unjuÅ¿t Sentence that I Å¿uffered to take effect, is puniÅ¿hed by an unjuÅ¿t Sentence upon me: So far I have Å¿aid, to Å¿hew you, That I am an
innocent man. Now to Å¿hew you that I am a good ChriÅ¿tian, I hope there is a good man here (pointing to the BiÅ¿hop of London) that will bear me witneÅ¿s,His MajeÅ¿ty forgives all the world, even the CauÅ¿ers of his death. that I have forgiven all the world, and even thoÅ¿e in particular that have been the chief CauÅ¿ers of my death: who they are, God knows, I do not deÅ¿ire to know; I pray God forgive them. But this is not all, my Charity muÅ¿t go further; I wiÅ¿h they may repent, for indeed they have committed a great Å¿in in that particular: I pray God, with St. Stephen, that this be not laid to their charge; and withal, that they may take the way to the Peace of the Kingdom; for my charity commands me not onely to forgive particular men, but to endeavour to the laÅ¿t gaÅ¿p, the Peace of the Kingdom. So (Sirs) I do wiÅ¿h with all my Soul,Prays that they may take the right way to Peace. (I Å¿ee there are Å¿ome here that will carry it further) that they endeavour the Peace of the Kingdom. (Sirs) I muÅ¿t Å¿hew you, both how you are out of the way, and put you in a way. FirÅ¿t, you are out of the way; for certainly all the ways you ever had yet, as far as I could find by any thing, is in the way of ConqueÅ¿t: certainly this is an ill way;ConqueÅ¿t an ill way, Å¿eldom juÅ¿t. for ConqueÅ¿t, in my Opinion, is never juÅ¿t, except there be a juÅ¿t and good cauÅ¿e, either for matter of Wrong, or a juÅ¿t Title; and then if you go beyond the firÅ¿t Quarrel that ye have, that makes it unjuÅ¿t at the end, that was juÅ¿t at firÅ¿t: for if there be onely matter of ConqueÅ¿t, then it is a great Robbery; as a private Souldier Å¿aid to Alexander, That he was a great Robber, himÅ¿elf

was but a petty Robber: And Å¿o, Sirs, for the way you are in, I think you are much out of the way.To give God his due, the K. his due, and the People their due, is the right way. Give God his due in Å¿etling his Church. Now, Sirs, to put you into the way; believe it, you Å¿hall never go right, nor God will never proÅ¿per you, until you give God his due, the King his due, (that is my SucceÅ¿Å¿our) and the People their due; I am as much for them as any of you. You muÅ¿t give God his due, by regulating rightly his Church, according to the Scripture, (which is now out of order) and to Å¿et you in a way particularly, now I cannot; but onely this: A National Synod freely called,As to the K. it concerning himÅ¿elf, his MajeÅ¿ty waves it. freely debating among themÅ¿elves, muÅ¿t Å¿ettle this, when every Opinion is freely heard. For the King, indeed, I will not, the Laws of the Land will clearly inÅ¿truct you for that; therefore, becauÅ¿e it concerns mine own particular,Peoples liberty conÅ¿iÅ¿ts in having government, not in Å¿haring it. I onely give you a touch of it. For the People, truly I deÅ¿ire their liberty and freedom as much as any body whomÅ¿oever: But I muÅ¿t tell you, that their liberty and freedom conÅ¿iÅ¿ts in having government under thoÅ¿e Laws, by which their lives and theirs may be moÅ¿t their own; it is not in having a Å¿hare in the government, that is nothing pertaining to them: A Subject and a Soveraign are clean different things; and therefore until you do that, I mean, that you put the People into that liberty, as I Å¿ay, certainly they will never enjoy themÅ¿elves.

Sirs, it was for this that now I am come hither: for if I would have given way to an Arbitrary way, for to have all Laws changed according
to the power of the Sword, I need not have come here; and therefore I tell you (and I pray God it be not laid to your charge) that I am the MARTYR of the People.His MajeÅ¿ty the Martyr of the People. In troth, Sirs, I Å¿hall not hold you any longer; I will onely Å¿ay this to you, That I could have deÅ¿ired Å¿ome little time longer, becauÅ¿e I would have put this, what I have Å¿aid, a little better digeÅ¿ted than I have done; and therefore I hope you will excuÅ¿e me. I have delivered my ConÅ¿cience: I pray God you take thoÅ¿e courÅ¿es that are beÅ¿t for the good of the Kingdoms and your own Å¿alvation.

div.p: Being thus about to conclude his moÅ¿t innocent and meek Speech, the BiÅ¿hop of London gave him a hint, That if his MajeÅ¿ty thought fit, he would Å¿ay Å¿omewhat as to his Religion; not that any man living Å¿uÅ¿pected that, of which he had given Å¿o clear proofs during the whole courÅ¿e of his life, but that he might, according to cuÅ¿tom, Å¿atisfie the People.

To which the King replied, He profeÅ¿Å¿es he dies a ChriÅ¿tian of the Church of England.
I thank you very heartily, my Lord, for I had almoÅ¿t forgotten it. In troth, Sirs, my ConÅ¿cience in Religion, I think, is very well known to all the World; and therefore I declare before you all, That I die a ChriÅ¿tian, according to the ProfeÅ¿Å¿ion of the Church of England, as I found it left me by my Father, and that honeÅ¿t man I think will witneÅ¿s it.

Then turning to the Officers, he Å¿aid, Sirs, excuÅ¿e me for this Å¿ame; I have a good CauÅ¿e, and I have a gracious God, I will Å¿ay no more.
But a little after, I go from a corruptible to an incorruptible Crown, where no diÅ¿turbance can be, no diÅ¿turbance in the World.

He is beheadedAfterwards kneeling down by the Block, as at a Desk, and having Å¿aid a Å¿hort Prayer, he moÅ¿t humbly reÅ¿igned his Å¿acred head to his Maker to be Å¿truck off by a masked Executioner; which was quickly done at one blow. So fell CHARLES; and Å¿o with him expired the Honour and Soul of Great Britain.

Barbarous Cruelty againÅ¿t him dead. AgainÅ¿t his body.Nor are they Å¿atisfied to have exerciÅ¿ed their Rage and Cruelty againÅ¿t him, whilÅ¿t he was alive: they diÅ¿honour his martyred Body; waÅ¿h their hands and dip their Å¿ticks in his Bloud; Å¿et to Å¿ale the Block cut into pieces, and the Sand underneath it moiÅ¿tened with Royal Bloud; and make money alÅ¿o of his Hair. All which were by the Spectators bought up upon different motives: Å¿ome as dear Pledges and Relicks of a Prince whom they adored; others, that they might never want a Cure for the Kings Evil, a Prerogative which our Kings are believed to enjoy; but many alÅ¿o, that they might have and Å¿hew in triumph the Spoils of their Enemy. Cromwel, that he might to the full glut his traiterous eyes with that Spectacle, having opened the Coffin wherein the Body was carried from the Scaffold into the Palace, curiouÅ¿ly viewed it, and with his fingers Å¿evered the head from the Å¿houldiers, as we have been informed by Eye-witneÅ¿Å¿es.

Afterwards they give the Body to be embowelled by a raÅ¿cally Quack-PhyÅ¿ician, and Å¿ome Surgeons of the Army, moÅ¿t inveterate Enemies to the very name of a King, (his MajeÅ¿ties own Servants being removed) who had orders carefully to enquire (which was the Å¿ame to them as if they had been
commanded poÅ¿itively to affirm) whether he had not the Venereal DiÅ¿temper, or any Å¿igns of Frigidity; with a deÅ¿igne to take an occaÅ¿ion from thence of branding either himÅ¿elf or PoÅ¿terity with Infamy. But that Villany was cruÅ¿hed in the Egg by the preÅ¿ence of an honeÅ¿t PhyÅ¿ician, who getting to be admitted to the DiÅ¿Å¿ection, overawed them by his reverence and authority: the Å¿ame perÅ¿on having alÅ¿o reputed that by the healthfulneÅ¿s and vigour of his ConÅ¿titution, he might have outlived moÅ¿t men; Å¿o that all who conÅ¿ider the humourous temper both of his body and mind, are fully now Å¿atisfied of it.

Nay,AgainÅ¿t his Å¿oul. that they might Å¿train their Malice to the higheÅ¿t pitch of Cruelty, they make no leÅ¿s Å¿cruple to murder the Soul of the King, and as eaÅ¿ily damn him to the flames of Hell, as they are wont to canonize all their own for Saints.

They make it their buÅ¿ineÅ¿s alÅ¿o to blacken his Memory amongÅ¿t men;AgainÅ¿t his fame and memory to poÅ¿terity. they cauÅ¿e his Statue that Å¿tood over the Porch of St. Paul's Church, and another that was placed amongÅ¿t the Statues of his PredeceÅ¿Å¿ors in the Royal Exchange of London, to be thrown down, putting theÅ¿e words into the empty Nich, The Tyrant the laÅ¿t of Kings is gone. Exit Tyrannus regum ultimus; moÅ¿t falÅ¿e both in the preÅ¿age and crime. They employ the mercenary Pen of the Son of a certain S â¢ rivener one Milton, from a muÅ¿ty Pedant, â¢ ampt into a new Secretary, whoÅ¿e Talent lying in Satyrs and Libels, and his Tongue being dipt in the blackeÅ¿t and baÅ¿eÅ¿t venome, might forge an ã in non-Latin alphabet ã , or Image-breaking; and by his livid and malicious Wit, publiÅ¿h a Defence of the Kings Murder againÅ¿t SalmaÅ¿ius.

They rob the BiÅ¿hop of London, They carry away all the Royal Writings that they might not be publiÅ¿h'd who was long kept a PriÅ¿oner, of all the Papers which his MajeÅ¿ty had delivered unto him, and ranÅ¿aking all Clothes,
Trunks, and Boxes, they Å¿earch into every corner, that they might hinder any Paper written with the Royal hand, from coming into the publick; by which indeed they deprived mankind of many rare Monuments of Prudence and Piety.

NevertheleÅ¿s, a golden book of the Kings Meditations Å¿aw the light.NevertheleÅ¿s, by the extraordinary providence of Almighty God, to their eternal Å¿hame and confuÅ¿ion, and the everlaÅ¿ting praiÅ¿e of the boundleÅ¿s and Royal Virtue of the King, a Book of MEDITATIONS or SOLLILOQÆ²IES, Å¿aw the light, a poÅ¿thumous work of which, whoÅ¿oever impartially conÅ¿iders the weight of matter, the quaintneÅ¿s of Å¿tile, the Å¿trength of ReaÅ¿ons, and the ardour of Piety, muÅ¿t, in Å¿pight of Envy, acknowledge that amongÅ¿t Writers he deÅ¿erved the Kingdom, and that thoÅ¿e ill minds that wreÅ¿ted from him the Civil Government, muÅ¿t render him the dominion of Letters.

The extraordinary grief of the people.No King, not onely of Britain alone, but that ever Å¿ate upon the Throne, left the World more bewailed and lamented. For the news of his death being Å¿pread over England, made women miÅ¿carry, caÅ¿t both men and women into Fits, ConvulÅ¿ions, and Melancholy; nay, Å¿ome were Å¿o Å¿urprized, that they outlived not the Å¿uddenneÅ¿s of the ConÅ¿ternation: The Pulpits in all places uttered nothing but Sighs and Groans: The Å¿ame perÅ¿ons with uÅ¿eleÅ¿s grief bewailing him now he was gone, who becauÅ¿e of difference of Opinion concerning Church-government, had no great kindneÅ¿s for him whilÅ¿t he was alive. The very little Children (who Å¿eldom mind Å¿uch things) burÅ¿ting out into Tears, could hardly be comforted. Men of all Å¿orts, and almoÅ¿t of all Sects, enlarged in his praiÅ¿es, comparing him to Job, David, and Solomon, for Patience, Piety, and WiÅ¿dom. Nor can I my Å¿elf forbear in this place to hoiÅ¿t Å¿ail, and with all the skill I have, launch out into the Ocean of his Virtues; though the nature of an Abridgment
I am now about, does lay an embargo upon my liberty. I Å¿hall therefore by a few, and thoÅ¿e clouded beams, give you what Å¿ight I can of that Sun.

He was indeed a Prince to be reckoned amongÅ¿t the beÅ¿t of all paÅ¿t Ages,The Character of the late King. whoÅ¿e great endowments of mind, and greater Virtues, rendered him in the opinion of all, even his greateÅ¿t Enemies, Worthy of Government, if he had not governed: who by all mens confeÅ¿Å¿ion, attained to that height of perfection, that he was the Å¿ame in all places, and at all times; that the courÅ¿e of his Virtues was even and Å¿teddy, his countenance and looks the Å¿ame in the moÅ¿t different kinds of fortune that he had tried; as if from the Torrid he had removed into the Frigid Zone, without the leaÅ¿t alteration in his temper. Who pleaÅ¿ed even the unwilling, and as by a kind of Charm, mitigated the hatred of many, won his enemies to FriendÅ¿hip, and turned Railings into PraiÅ¿es. Who Å¿o excelled in Prudence and all Heroick Virtues, that through Calumnies and Reproaches he Å¿hone out with greater luÅ¿tre.

His Enemies feigned him to be a man of weak Judgment, but found him to be a match, if not Å¿uperiour, to the choiceÅ¿t Politicians and Divines: They reviled him as cowardly and fickle, without faith, and of feminine inconÅ¿tancy; but in Battels they felt him to be valiant, perceived him undaunted in Threats, Dangers, and DiÅ¿graces, and unÅ¿haken in PriÅ¿on and at Death. They Å¿landered him as a PapiÅ¿t, but Å¿aw him in his Writings to be a Champion for the Reformed ApoÅ¿tolical Religion; defending it not onely by his Pen, but with his Bloud. They who maligned him as cruel and bloud-thirÅ¿ty, advanced to that licentiouÅ¿neÅ¿s of calumniating, onely through the clemency of their King, â to which the Rebels promiÅ¿ed themÅ¿elves a
too eaÅ¿ie retreat, until by the favour of fortune, being tranÅ¿ported beyond the bonds of pardon, they chuÅ¿e rather to deny mercy to a Prince of Å¿o much clemency, than to ask it of him when he was diÅ¿armed.

If any thing could be objected to him, it was Å¿o far from being a fault in Å¿o rare a Prince, that it was the height of an unÅ¿eaÅ¿onable Virtue, inconÅ¿iÅ¿tent with Å¿o vitious and corrupt an Age; that is, too much Lenity to the cruel, Candour to the diÅ¿ingenuous and crafty, a Å¿trict JuÅ¿tice and Certitude, which is not commonly the Virtue of Kings, a ModeÅ¿ty that diÅ¿truÅ¿ted his own Abilities, and a Mind Å¿o far from pride, that he was more apt to comply with the worÅ¿e CounÅ¿els of others, than to Å¿tick to the beÅ¿t of his own; as if he had indeed believed the Calumnies of his Enemies to be true.

The Rebels exerciÅ¿e Arbitrary Dominion over the Lives and EÅ¿tates of others.The great Defender of the Laws being now cut off, and the Government unhinged, the new Æ²Å¿urpers thought it time to turn all topÅ¿ie-turvy, and to make Laws according to their own pleaÅ¿ure. They order CHARLES the Second, by the name of CHARLES STEÆ²ART, and the Duke of York, whereÅ¿oever they could be found, to be put to death.They forbid any man to call Charles the II. King, or to pray for him, his Brother, or any of the Royal Family. Out comes preÅ¿ently an Ordinance, under pain of High-TreaÅ¿on, That no man Å¿hould preÅ¿ume to declare CHARLES STEUART, commonly called Prince of Wales, King: And as if this had been but a Å¿mall matter, That no man Å¿hould pray for CHARLES the Second, under the name of Prince of
Wales, King of Scotland, or eldeÅ¿t Son of the King, or for the Duke of York, or any of the Royal Family, under pain of SequeÅ¿tration.

Monarchy and the HouÅ¿e of Lords being both aboliÅ¿hed, the firÅ¿t under pretext of change,
The Monarch being cut off, th â¢ y preÅ¿ently murder Monarchy; they alÅ¿o abrogate the HouÅ¿e of Lords.
Turns out the Lord Mayor of London.
uÅ¿eleÅ¿neÅ¿s and danger, and the other both of uÅ¿eleÅ¿neÅ¿s and danger; they make an Ordinance for changing the moÅ¿t ancient Government of England into a Democraty or Popular Commonwealth: and becauÅ¿e the Mayor of London refuÅ¿ed to publiÅ¿h the Ordinance, they turn him out of his Office, fine him in two thouÅ¿and pounds, and commit him to the Tower; notwithÅ¿tanding his alleadging, That Å¿uch an act was to be performed by the Sheriffs, and not the Mayor of London, and that being bound by Å¿o many Oaths, he could not in conÅ¿cience do it. A dull blockhead, one of the Kings Judges, was forthwith put into his place, and that others upon account of conÅ¿cience, might not boggle at any of their commands, they aboliÅ¿h the Oath which all men upon their entry into publick place, were obliged to take to the Kings MajeÅ¿ty. They alter the Common Council of the City alÅ¿o. They purge the Common Council of the City, which was wont to conÅ¿iÅ¿t of the richer and graver Citizens, and turn out many Aldermen; making this their colour for it, that the year before (though at the deÅ¿ire of the major part of the Parliament) They had Å¿igned the Petition for a perÅ¿onal Conference with the King; and filled their places with the abject Riff-raff of the Rabble, many of them very young, and moÅ¿t of them broken fellows.

They alÅ¿o turn out the Recorder, Town-Clerk, and other Officers of the City, who had refuÅ¿ed to attend the Mayor at the publiÅ¿hing of the Ordinance for aboliÅ¿hing of Monarchy; other factious Villains of their own Gang, being preferred to their places; who leading the other Citizens by the noÅ¿es, the City of London in a trice became obedient to the
Orders of the Mock-Parliament.
And repeal all Laws againÅ¿t HereÅ¿ies and SchiÅ¿ms.
They engage the Preachers to themÅ¿elves by the Kings Rents.
PuniÅ¿h the Gain-Å¿ayers. With one Å¿ingle Vote they repeal all the ancient Laws made againÅ¿t Sects and SchiÅ¿ms. They deprive the MiniÅ¿ters of the promiÅ¿ed Revenues, I mean, of Deans and Chapters Lands: They alÅ¿o make profeÅ¿Å¿ion of eaÅ¿ing tender ConÅ¿ciences from the burthen of Tythes, aÅ¿Å¿igning Å¿ome thouÅ¿ands a year out of the Kings Revenue, for Stipends and Salaries for the Preachers; that Å¿o they might be at the beck of the Republicans, and be at length by Office conÅ¿trained with mutual AÅ¿Å¿iÅ¿tance and Pay to conÅ¿pire againÅ¿t Monarchy. Nay, it was debated, whether they Å¿hould not for Å¿ome time Å¿hut the Church-doors, and reÅ¿train the licentiouÅ¿neÅ¿s of Presbyterians: but milder Councils prevailing, Å¿ome having been impriÅ¿oned, & others threatned with death, all are commanded upon pain of SequeÅ¿tration to refrain from Invectives, and to comply with their Rulers in keeping FaÅ¿ts and Thanksgiving-days, and whatever elÅ¿e concerned the affairs of the Church. They break down the Kings Arms and Statues that were Å¿et up in publick places, and put up their own inÅ¿tead of them. They coyn new money with the impreÅ¿Å¿ion of a CroÅ¿s and Harp, as the Arms of England and Ireland. In a word, as by Law, and in full right, they invade and appropriate to themÅ¿elves all the Regalia, which as by way of SequeÅ¿tration they had before uÅ¿urped.

Sparing no body.From henceforward, without any regard to JuÅ¿tice and HoneÅ¿ty, they Å¿pare neither Sex nor any Order of men. The Kings Children who remained in England, to wit, the Lady Elizabeth and Henry Duke of GlouceÅ¿ter, Princes of Å¿ingular accompliÅ¿hments of Nature, are many ways baÅ¿ely uÅ¿ed by them. AmongÅ¿t the Regicides it was moved oftener than once, whether they had not better put her out Apprentice to a Trade, that Å¿he might get
her living, than to breed her up in a lazy life at the charge of the Publick. From the gentle tuition of the Earl of N. Å¿he is turned over to the Å¿everer diÅ¿cipline of another, with orders, that when there was no occaÅ¿ion for it, Å¿he Å¿hould not be treated as the Daughter of a King: Afterward Å¿he was confined to Carisborough-CaÅ¿tle in the IÅ¿le of Wight, under the cuÅ¿tody of one Mildmay, an inÅ¿pired fool, but implacable enemy to the Royal Family; that Å¿he poor Lady, thus put in mind of her Fathers ImpriÅ¿onment and Murder, being already conÅ¿umptive, might the Å¿ooner be brought to her end. And indeed, when through the irkÅ¿omneÅ¿s of PriÅ¿on, Grief, and SickneÅ¿s, Å¿he viÅ¿ibly and daily decayed and pined away, the inhumane Traytors deny her the aÅ¿Å¿iÅ¿tance of a PhyÅ¿ician; nay, the PhyÅ¿ician whoÅ¿e preÅ¿ence Å¿he earneÅ¿tly deÅ¿ired, they Å¿o frighten from his duty, that he durÅ¿t not wait upon her. She being dead, they Å¿end the Duke of GlouceÅ¿ter into baniÅ¿hment, having allowed him a Å¿mall piece of money (that I may not omit any act of their humanity) to carry him over into Flanders.

They baÅ¿ely treat the CounteÅ¿s of CarliÅ¿le, by an uÅ¿age unworthy of her Sex and Quality, as being one who of too much a friend before, was now become an Enemy, and commit her to the Tower of London. Duke Hamilton and the Earl of Holland, who now too lately repented their having been the firÅ¿t of the Lords and chief of the Factious, who for their own Å¿afety, had too much Å¿erved the times againÅ¿t the King, and of the Royal Party, the heroick Lord Capel, a prime Champion both for his King and Country, are by the Å¿ame PreÅ¿ident BradÅ¿haw, who dyed red with Royal bloud, knew not what it was to Å¿pare the bloud of other men, in the Å¿ame Court of JuÅ¿tice Å¿entenced to loÅ¿e their heads. Whom the Rebels thought fit they baniÅ¿hed, and
Å¿eized all EÅ¿tates and Inheritances, how large Å¿oever, at their own diÅ¿cretion. There was a debate amongÅ¿t them about making a Law, that whoÅ¿oever was by them Å¿uÅ¿pected to be an ill willer to the Commonwealth, or an enemy to the Army, might be brought to a tryal before a Council of War, and Å¿entenced by them as they thought fit.

Nay, they order the Å¿tately Fabricks of the Royal HouÅ¿es and Palaces, to be thrown down, that Kings for the future might not have a houÅ¿e of their own to cover their heads under; God any Å¿tately Temples wherein he might be worÅ¿hipped, or the Kingdom any publick Structures to Å¿hew its magnificence. St. Paul's Church in London, that of Salisbury, and the Kings houÅ¿e of Hampton-Court, Fabricks that may compare for Å¿tatelineÅ¿s with the beÅ¿t of Europe, with much ado eÅ¿caped the fury of their deÅ¿olating hands.

The Government committed to the Council of forty men.A Council of forty perÅ¿ons is erected, which by a gentle name to the common people, they call the Keepers of the Liberties, who altogether, or at leaÅ¿t Å¿even of the number, had the full adminiÅ¿tration of the Commonwealth. AmongÅ¿t theÅ¿e were three or four contemptible Lords, Slaves to the Republican Faction admitted, of whom BradÅ¿haw was made Head, with the Title of Lord PreÅ¿ident, and a yearly Salary of two thouÅ¿and pounds, as the price of Regicide.

A Å¿ubÅ¿cription is enjoyned.Moreover, a Writing is commanded to be taken by all, whereby they were bound to approve whatÅ¿oever the Rebels had acted againÅ¿t the King and Kingdom. Yet when many had refuÅ¿ed to take it, they were nevertheleÅ¿s admitted upon this condition, That with their lives and fortunes, they Å¿hould maintain and defend for the future, the State and Mock-Parliament in the Å¿ame condition they were. Henceforward none of the Å¿ecluded Members, nor of
thoÅ¿e who had withdrawn, were admitted into the HouÅ¿e, unleÅ¿s they approved underhand the late Villanies. NevertheleÅ¿s, they command all to appear againÅ¿t a certain day, or otherways to be excluded for ever, and others choÅ¿en in their places. So that Å¿ome for fear of SequeÅ¿tration, and I know not what hurt and damage they were apprehenÅ¿ive of, others out of hopes of profit to be got in publick changes, by a baÅ¿e temporizing, Å¿trike in with the Republican Æ²Å¿urpers, and are admitted into a Å¿hare of the labour and danger, but not of the Government.

About the Å¿ame time the Å¿ecluded Members meet in Lincolns-Inne to conÅ¿ult together, S. inveighs bitterly againÅ¿t the Regicides. and take the advice of S. a Lawyer, what was fitteÅ¿t to be done in the preÅ¿ent Å¿tate of affairs. But he readily gave his opinion, that the late changes were made againÅ¿t the tenor of the Laws, the CuÅ¿toms and IntereÅ¿t of the Country, and the Dictates of right ReaÅ¿on; and that no commerce could be kept with the UÅ¿urpers, without the guilt and horrid crime of TreaÅ¿on: and indeed he frightened many of the Members from coming to the HouÅ¿e, who could never afterward be brought to joyn in council with the Regicides. NevertheleÅ¿s,By and by falls off to the Å¿ame Party. within a few days he himÅ¿elf became a leading-man in the Rebel-Parliament, and the Council of the Keepers of the Liberties, and Å¿ubmitted to their Authority: nay, and did not reject the place of Lord Chief JuÅ¿tice of the Common Pleas, conferred upon him by the Å¿ame men, though the King before the Troubles had honoured him with the title of his Attorney-General.

TheÅ¿e things are carried on under pretext of Å¿peedy Å¿etling the State;
They labour to eÅ¿tabliÅ¿h an Oligarchy.
The Democraticks oppoÅ¿e it. but in reality with deÅ¿igne to Å¿ecure the Government to themÅ¿elves: to whom all the reÅ¿t almoÅ¿t being cow'd into a Å¿ubmiÅ¿Å¿ion, the Popular Republicans onely reÅ¿iÅ¿t. TheÅ¿e demand
that the RepreÅ¿entative Å¿o often deÅ¿ired and Å¿o often promiÅ¿ed, might be eÅ¿tabliÅ¿hed by a free and equal election of the people, the Rump of the Mock-Parliament being diÅ¿miÅ¿Å¿ed.Inveigh, In Writings and Conferences they inveigh againÅ¿t the arbitrary dominion of the Æ²Å¿urpers, the High Court of JuÅ¿tice, Council of State, â or of the Keepers of the Liberties, as onely the Å¿ofter names of a harder Tyranny; nay, they cry out againÅ¿t the Kings murder as unjuÅ¿t, and committed againÅ¿t all Law and juÅ¿t Authority; that the People had changed but not Å¿haken off the Yoke; that they had rather live ten years under the government of the worÅ¿t of Kings, than one year under their dominion; that the loins of King Charles were lighter than their little finger. So great force has truth, as that it draws Å¿uch ExpreÅ¿Å¿ions even from the unwilling. At length they flie to Arms,ReÅ¿iÅ¿t with Arms. and the private Souldiers, eÅ¿pecially the Troopers, who formerly conÅ¿ented with them in moÅ¿t things, being everywhere Å¿tirred up, they at length begin to gather together in form of an Army.

But the Æ²Å¿urpers who were never wanting to occaÅ¿ion, obviate the beginnings; and under pretext of compoÅ¿ing Differences amongÅ¿t honeÅ¿t men, who minded the Å¿ame things, though they mutually entertained bad opinions one of another, having corrupted and gained Å¿ome of them to their Party, they Å¿uddenly fall upon the reÅ¿t and defeat them,They are defeated by the Æ²Å¿urpers. diÅ¿arm the PriÅ¿oners, and having cauÅ¿ed the chief Authors of the Stirs to be Å¿hot, and others to be puniÅ¿hed more mildly, they terrifie all the reÅ¿t from diÅ¿turbing for the future the Rulers, either with cutting Truths, or Å¿harper Arms.

Th â¢ y publiÅ¿h a Proclamation, that no man Å¿hould accuÅ¿e them of Tyranny.The Æ²Å¿urpers being fixed in the Saddle, publiÅ¿h a Proclamation, forbidding all men to accuÅ¿e them of Tyranny, to object any thing againÅ¿t them by word or in writing, or to attempt any alteration, under pain of
High-TreaÅ¿on. Appoint a Thanksgiving. They appoint a Å¿olemn ThankÅ¿giving-day to render publick thanks to God for their proÅ¿perous Å¿ucceÅ¿s againÅ¿t the Democraticks, that Å¿o by mocking of God, they might the more eaÅ¿ily make the Å¿illy people rejoyce in their Calamities. And the Å¿ame day they are Å¿umptuouÅ¿ly feaÅ¿ted by the Mayor and Aldermen of London, Are feaÅ¿ted by the City. not without the Reproaches and CurÅ¿es of almoÅ¿t all the Spectators; where amidÅ¿t the tears and miÅ¿eries of a great many that periÅ¿hed by a famine that then raged, they junket it deliciouÅ¿ly. Fairfax and Cromwel are complemented with Å¿plendid PreÅ¿ents of Gold and Silver. And that the wretched Citizens might not Å¿eem to have loÅ¿t all their labour in feeding theÅ¿e Ravens, they beÅ¿tow upon them the Kings new Park, Which they recompence. under colour of making them Å¿ome recompence for their late Magnificence; but in reality, that the diÅ¿tracted men being allured by the Å¿weetneÅ¿s of that morcel, might be won over to their Party, and wiÅ¿h well to the new Government.

Henceforward there is nothing to them Å¿acred or holy: They either diÅ¿tribute amongÅ¿t themÅ¿elves, or Å¿ell at eaÅ¿ie rates the Kings HouÅ¿hold-furniture,They Å¿ell the Kings HouÅ¿es, HouÅ¿hold-furniture, &c. Lands and HouÅ¿es, the Revenues and Lands of the Church, which belonged to the Deans and Chapters, and which remained intire till now by the Votes of both HouÅ¿es of Parliament, for the uÅ¿e of the new Clergy, or Presbyterian MiniÅ¿try: That by theÅ¿e arts they might both glut their own Avarice, and by involving many in the Å¿ame guilt with themÅ¿elves, make them firmer to their Faction.

Nor being yet Å¿atiated by the Crown and Church-lands, and the EÅ¿tates of the Noblemen and Gentlemen, who diÅ¿agreeing from them, made up the far greater part of the Kingdom, which they had Å¿eized long ago by way of SequeÅ¿tration; nor by the Goods and Chattels of thoÅ¿e aforementioned
whom they had plundered, and the vaÅ¿t Å¿ums of money which thoÅ¿e that had been for the King dayly paid for redeeming their EÅ¿tates, and purchaÅ¿ing favour; they daily raiÅ¿e an incredible quantity of money from the CuÅ¿toms and the ExciÅ¿e, (a Tax which before would not have been endured in England):They burden the people with moÅ¿t heavy Taxes. Not to mention the Å¿ecret Veins of Wealth, I mean Bribes and Gifts, which thoÅ¿e that Å¿tood for Places or had buÅ¿ineÅ¿s and Law-Å¿uits, Å¿lipt privately into their pockets. Nay, they were not aÅ¿hamed to flea the Å¿o-often fleeced people by a moÅ¿t heavy ImpoÅ¿ition of ninety thouÅ¿and pounds a month to pay the idle Souldiers.

Invade Ireland;However, the Å¿poils and government of one Kingdom was not enough to Å¿atisfie them; they invade the IriÅ¿h alÅ¿o that were ready to Å¿ubmit to the King, (whom whilÅ¿t they were Rebels, moÅ¿t part of them praiÅ¿ed, few at leaÅ¿t did hoÅ¿tilely aÅ¿Å¿ault them) promiÅ¿ing themÅ¿elves certain victory over them; and hoping that Ireland being Å¿ubdued, they might eaÅ¿ily reduce Scotland and France, as being divided at home;And threatned the whole world. and many of them had the confidence openly to glory, that they would break that Yoke wherewith the Kings of the Earth oppreÅ¿s the People. Nor truly could any man have told where the fierceneÅ¿s of this Scourge would have ended, and where that Floud would have Å¿pent it Å¿elf, unleÅ¿s the divine MajeÅ¿ty, which hath hollowed a channel for the Sea, Å¿et bounds and limits to it, and Å¿aid, Hither Å¿halt thou come, and no further, had not oppoÅ¿ed the over-Å¿welling pride of theÅ¿e Waters, and commanded his Angel to Å¿ound the Retreat.

list.head: MDCXI.

list.head: MDCXLI, MDCXLII.
list.item: January 3.The King accuÅ¿es five Commoners, and one Lord of High-TreaÅ¿on.

list.head: MDCXLIII.

list.head: MDCXLIII, IV.

list.head: MDCXLIV, V.

March.The MarqueÅ¿s of Ormond, Lord Lieutenant of Ireland, delivers up Dublin to the EngliÅ¿h.
June 4.The Army take the King out of PriÅ¿on.
And march againÅ¿t the Parliament.
The Speakers of both HouÅ¿es, with fifty other Members,July 29. flie to the Camp.
The Souldiers attend the Members that fled to WeÅ¿t-minÅ¿ter. AuguÅ¿t 6.
Æ²njuÅ¿t Conditions of Peace are propoÅ¿ed to the King at Hampton-court. September 7.
The King makes his eÅ¿cape to the IÅ¿le of Wight. Novemb. 11.
From thence writing Pacificatory Letters,Decemb. 24. they propoÅ¿e to him four Demands as preliminary to a Conference.
The King is made cloÅ¿e PriÅ¿oner.

list.head: MDCXLVII, VIII.
list.item: The Parliament votes no more AddreÅ¿Å¿es to the King. January 17.
The Counties everywhere Å¿tir; the KentiÅ¿h, EÅ¿Å¿ex-men,May. June. and Å¿ome others, take up Arms.
The Duke of Buckingham, Francis his Brother,July 5: and Earl of Holland, in vain take up Arms.
The Fleet comes over to the Prince of Wales. July.
The Scots commanded by Duke Hamilton, advance into England.
They are defeated by Cromwel, and Hamilton taken.AuguÅ¿t 17.
Fairfax takes ColcheÅ¿ter upon Å¿urrender.AuguÅ¿t 28.
Rainsborough, a Commander of the Parliament Army,October 29. killed at DuncaÅ¿ter.
A Conference appointed with the King in the IÅ¿le of Wight. Sept. Octob.
The MarqueÅ¿s of Ormond returns Lord Lieutenant into Ireland. November.
The RemonÅ¿trance of Ireton is approved in a Council of War.Novemb. 16.
And is preÅ¿ented to the Parliament in name of the Army and People of England. Novemb. 20.
The King is carried from the IÅ¿le of Wight to HurÅ¿t-CaÅ¿tle.Decemb. 1.
NevertheleÅ¿s, the Parliament votes,Decemb. 5. That the Kings ConceÅ¿Å¿ions are a Å¿ufficient ground for a Peace.

list.head: MDCXLVIII, IX.
list.item: January 4.The reÅ¿t amongÅ¿t other and unheard things, vote, That all Power is originally in the People.
January 6.Then, That the King himÅ¿elf is to be brought to a tryal.
January 20.22, 23, 27.The King therefore is brought to the Bar.
The King is brought a fourth time, and condemned.
January 30. CHARLES the beÅ¿t of Kings, by unparallel'd Villany is beheaded.
March 9. James Duke of Hamilton, Henry Earl of Holland, and the generous Arthur Lord Capel, are beheaded.
March 17.LaÅ¿tly, Monarchy it felf is aboliÅ¿hed by the Regicides.
May 30.The Act is proclaimed by the mock-Mayor of London.
May.The Democratical Republicans Å¿tirring in Arms, are routed.
June 7.Solemn Thanksgivings appointed for the Victory, and the Conquerours feaÅ¿ted by the Londoners.

div.head: A Å¿hort HISTORICAL ACCOUNT OF THE RiÅ¿e and ProgreÅ¿s OF THE Late Troubles IN ENGLAND: AND ALSO Of the KING's Miraculous EÅ¿cape after the Battel at WorceÅ¿ter.
The Second Part.
div.p:
NOW are the Cruel Regicides MaÅ¿ters of England, The Å¿tate of Affairs after the Regicide, in England, Scotland, but of England alone. The Scots were in Å¿uÅ¿pence, not being, as yet, fully reÅ¿olved, whether they Å¿hould Å¿ettle Charles the Second in his Fathers Throne, or, uÅ¿urping the Soveraignty, Å¿hould Govern Scotland as a Common-wealth themÅ¿elves. Ireland, Ireland, almoÅ¿t entirely for the King, was ready utterly to Å¿hake off the Yoke
of the Mock Parliament. And the IÅ¿lands belonging to England. The IÅ¿lands belonging to England, not only the adjacent, as JerÅ¿ey, Man, and Silly, but the more remote alÅ¿o in America, to wit, Bermudos, the Caribbe IÅ¿lands, Virginia, and New-England, upon the Continent, which had been heretofore planted with EngliÅ¿h Colonies, refuÅ¿e to obey the UÅ¿urpers.

The Regicides reÅ¿olving the worÅ¿t againÅ¿t Ireland, Forbid Trading with the IÅ¿lands and Plantations, and for what end. Ireland was to be the firÅ¿t Seat of War, Å¿hortly to be Å¿ubdued, whilÅ¿t the Scots were for Å¿ome time left to themÅ¿elves. They think it enough at preÅ¿ent, to diÅ¿charge all Trading with the IÅ¿lands and Plantations; that no Sugar, Indico, Tobacco, and Cotton Å¿hould be from thence imported into England; nor any Cloaths, and other neceÅ¿Å¿ary ProviÅ¿ions for Life, be tranÅ¿ported from England thither; hoping, by this Fetch, that either being glutted with their own Commodities, or at leaÅ¿t pinched through the want of ours, they would be forced to comply: Nor was it doubted, but Å¿ome time or other, as occaÅ¿ion offered, they would bring them under the Yoke.

Now there was one thing mainly neceÅ¿Å¿ary for their future DeÅ¿igns, which (as they were pleaÅ¿ed to flatter themÅ¿elves) was eaÅ¿ie to be obtained.They Å¿ooth the Dutch. The FriendÅ¿hip and Alliance of no Nation, nor People, Å¿eemed more commodious and neceÅ¿Å¿ary to them, than that of the Dutch, both in reÅ¿pect of Neighbourhood and Situation of the Country, and of the Humour and Inclination of the People; nor did they want a pretext of making application to them. For Strikland, who, from the beginning of the Troubles, had been AmbaÅ¿Å¿adour, or Envoy with the States of the Æ²nited Provinces, being kindly treated by them: DoriÅ¿laus being Å¿ent AmbaÅ¿Å¿adour, They thought fit to Å¿end over DoriÅ¿laus, who had had a chief hand
in framing the Kings Indictment, as their AmbaÅ¿Å¿adour,And for what purpoÅ¿e: to Complement and Thank them in their Name, aÅ¿Å¿ure them of mutual good Offices, juÅ¿tifie to them by ReaÅ¿ons their Proceedings againÅ¿t the King, and to colour the Villany by the Å¿pecious Authority of what Laws he could Å¿crape together. BeÅ¿ides, he had it in InÅ¿tructions (if he found it convenient) to let fall Å¿ome mention of a Coalition, or Conjunction, and to offer and preÅ¿s it; Å¿eeing if it could be effected by the ConÅ¿ent of both Nations, they might laugh at all DeÅ¿igns and Attempts of Foreigners, and Å¿hare betwixt themÅ¿elves the Trade of the whole World.

But that Negotiation proved unÅ¿ucceÅ¿sful,But without Å¿ucceÅ¿s: the Prince of Orange being Stat-holder, and the People deteÅ¿ted the Murder of the King. Some Scots alÅ¿o, who, though at a diÅ¿tance, had Å¿peedy notice of his Arrival, entering his Lodgings before he had had Audience,For the AmbaÅ¿Å¿adour is killed by Å¿ome Scots, with many Wounds killed DoriÅ¿laus, and made their eÅ¿cape before they could be apprehended. Thus the Å¿hedding of Royal Blood is puniÅ¿hed by Bloody hands, and by the juÅ¿t Judgment of God,And that with Å¿afety. whatever may be the InjuÅ¿tice of Men, the Crime is brought home to the Author. The Regicides often demanded of the States Reparation for the Fact, but without any Å¿ucceÅ¿s.

But the Democratical Party in England, A Petition preÅ¿erved to the Regicides by the Democratical Party; managing things now Å¿omewhat more cautiouÅ¿ly, laid not aÅ¿ide their diÅ¿contents. Walwin, Prince, Lilburn, Overton, and others of that Gang, prefer a Petition to the Rump Parliament, wherein they propoÅ¿e many good things, which might be uÅ¿eful to the Publick,They are committed to P â¢â¢
Å¿on for it. mingling with them Reproaches that were not altogether falÅ¿e: For which they were committed
to PriÅ¿on, there to lye by it, till the fierceneÅ¿s of their tempers were allayed.

Another from the private Souldiers,NevertheleÅ¿s, the private Souldiers of IngoldÅ¿by's Regiment grow Seditious at Oxford, under pretence of Petitioning; That the Rump-Parliament might be diÅ¿Å¿olved, a lawful RepreÅ¿entative choÅ¿en in place of it; that the Laws might be rendered into the vulgar Language; and thoÅ¿e that were Å¿uperfluous aboliÅ¿hed; that there might be a RegiÅ¿ter kept of all Mens Lands and EÅ¿tates; that every one might know what Title they had to what they poÅ¿Å¿eÅ¿Å¿ed; that the ExciÅ¿e, and all unlawful Exactions might be aboliÅ¿hed. To which they added over and above, (to increaÅ¿e their Party, not that they repented for the Kings Murder,) that Charles the Second might be chief MagiÅ¿trate of the Kingdom. But the Collonel haÅ¿tening thither,Is Å¿uppreÅ¿t in the Birth. and having cauÅ¿ed Å¿ome few to be Å¿hot to death, by a timely remedy Å¿tifled the Tumult in the Birth.

A third and Å¿marter Petition from the Officers of the Army;Yet from theÅ¿e Embers a new Flame broke out; for Å¿ome Officers in Fairfax his Army, preÅ¿ent a Å¿marter Petition to the Å¿ame purpoÅ¿e, though in different words.

To the former they add, That the Tithes being aboliÅ¿hed, or converted to another uÅ¿e, the MiniÅ¿ters might have more certain Stipends; that the publick Money might be more Å¿paringly diÅ¿tributed amongÅ¿t the Parliament Men; and that the Souldiers Å¿hould have their pay. Which the Regicides elude, The Rump-Parliament durÅ¿t not Å¿light this; but gives them good words, and being conÅ¿cious to themÅ¿elves, how often they, by Declarations, had promiÅ¿ed, and how many times they had been reproached with unfaithfulneÅ¿s and breach of PromiÅ¿e, they Å¿et apart a day weekly for deliberating about theÅ¿e PropoÅ¿als. FirÅ¿t, Concerning the Government
and RepreÅ¿entative, where having examined and conÅ¿idered the Nature of all States and Republicks, from that of Rome, even to RaguÅ¿a, they pretend to Å¿earch out a kind of Government, which might be beÅ¿t and moÅ¿t Å¿uitable for England. But they could find none that was exquiÅ¿it enough, nor that Å¿eemed adapted to the Genius of this People. And Å¿o, like Penelope, By doing much to no purpoÅ¿e. weaving and unweaving their Web, they put off the time, until the matter might be forgotten, or Å¿omething of greater moment intervene.

I know not whether it be worth the while here to mention the Prohibition made by the French at that time,Some Trade with us, Prohibited by the French: of any Trade with us in Wollen and Linen Manufacture; which drew from the Regicides a reciprocal Prohibition, that no Wine, nor Silk Stuffs Å¿hould from thence be Imported into England. With the French by us. It was likewiÅ¿e to our advantage, Ordered in Flanders, that no Ships nor Goods taken by Privateers, Å¿hould be Condemned or Sold in their Harbours.

But it is worth taking notice of, that a Å¿everer InquiÅ¿ition was appointed againÅ¿t the MiniÅ¿ters all England over,The MiniÅ¿ters of the Church of England are PerÅ¿ecuted, under pretext of Reforming the Church, and introducing the Orthodox Religion; and all were cruelly perÅ¿ecuted, not only they who Å¿tuck cloÅ¿e to the Doctrine and DiÅ¿cipline of the Church of England; but even they who wiÅ¿hed well to it, or had any ConverÅ¿ation with Men of that PerÅ¿waÅ¿ion: Ignorant men in the mean time (I Å¿peak of the generality) Laicks, Shepherds, and men void of all Learning, being put into the MiniÅ¿try, and Å¿ome of them preferred to two or three Livings at a time, which before they cryed out againÅ¿t as abominable.

EÅ¿pecially the
â¢ elch. Let North-Wales be one InÅ¿tance for all of that Reformation; where, about Å¿ome hundreds, and of theÅ¿e not a few Good, Grave and very Learned Divines, were turned out of their Livings: And Powell, Cradock, Floid, and a few other Ignorant Vagabonds that had no certain Habitation, going about in the mean time as Itinerant EvangeliÅ¿ts, Preaching, or rather Canting from the Pulpit, devoured vaÅ¿t Revenues; for the CommiÅ¿Å¿aries let out for a trifle, the remnant of the Tythes for feeding Å¿uch Ravens, who were to be accountable to the Rump-Parliament for them at NeverÅ¿maÅ¿s.

The reÅ¿t are cheriÅ¿hed.Moreover, the Regicides diÅ¿tribute amongÅ¿t their own Clergy the Augmentations, which were the reÅ¿idue of the Tythes, and of BiÅ¿hops and Deans Rents, that could find no PurchaÅ¿ers, eÅ¿pecially amongÅ¿t thoÅ¿e who had not an hundred Pounds a year. But that only during pleaÅ¿ure, and for a time, that they might have them at their beck, and buy the Endeavours, Voices, and Affections of Å¿o many men; and that they alÅ¿o being more vigilant Spies, over Å¿uÅ¿pected PerÅ¿ons, might pry into their Faults, their ExpreÅ¿Å¿ions and Councils, and inform them of all.

An Expedition into Ireland, under the Command of Cromwell. And now England is wholly taken up in preparations for a War in Ireland, whither Cromwell is Å¿ent as General of the Army. He having MuÅ¿tered his Men, haÅ¿tens his March to the CoaÅ¿t, and filling BriÅ¿tol, CheÅ¿ter, and Milford-Haven with Souldiers, prepares for his Expedition. The Reader therefore muÅ¿t paÅ¿s over with me into Ireland, that he may be able to give a Judgment of the Inhabitants, and how to diÅ¿poÅ¿e them into their Å¿everal
Ranks, that he may diÅ¿cover their various diÅ¿poÅ¿itions, and the ends they drove at.

The Inhabitants of Ireland are either Natives or Planters:The IriÅ¿h are ranked into Å¿everal claÅ¿Å¿es. The Native IriÅ¿h. And theÅ¿e laÅ¿t either Ancient or Late. ThoÅ¿e I call Natives, who firÅ¿t of all Inhabited the IÅ¿land, or were deÅ¿cended from them; and are either Noblemen and Gentlemen: Yeomen and Husbandmen, the Roman Catholick Clergy and BiÅ¿hops; with other Free Denizens. The Native Nobles, either wholly enjoy their Ancient Lands; or, being Å¿ubdued by the Kings of England, and for their Rebellion forfeiting part of their Lands, enjoy what remains, and Rent the reÅ¿t of the Proprietors for a Å¿mall matter. TheÅ¿e live in the Mountains and Woods, where they imperiouÅ¿ly domineer over their Tenants and VaÅ¿Å¿als; and know exactly the Bounds and Limits of their Lands; truÅ¿ting to this, that in future Revolutions, whatÅ¿oever they challenge for their own, will again, as by a PoÅ¿tliminous Right, return to them as to the lawful Proprietors and MaÅ¿ters.

The Titular Clergy and BiÅ¿hops (for we muÅ¿t know that thoÅ¿e of the Roman Communion have their own Clergy, PrieÅ¿ts and BiÅ¿hops, Å¿ecretly appointed by the Pope, who live only upon Charitable Contributions) privately perform the Duties of Religious WorÅ¿hip, after the manner of the Church of Rome, in the Å¿ame manner as if they were authoriÅ¿ed by Law, and were not contrary to our CuÅ¿toms; His MajeÅ¿ty conniving at the Errours of an obÅ¿tinate and Å¿tiff-necked Nation. But for all this, we muÅ¿t know, that there is an Orthodox Clergy alÅ¿o all over Ireland, conÅ¿iÅ¿ting not only of EngliÅ¿h, but of IriÅ¿h men born, who every where
enjoy the Tythes. But after the firÅ¿t breaking out of the Rebellion, both, as well the EngliÅ¿h as Natives, were forced to flye and withdraw.

The greateÅ¿t part are Strangers, but Free Denizens, who, though they are Å¿prung from EngliÅ¿h Race, yet partly by Marriage, partly being Naturalized, through long ConverÅ¿ation and CuÅ¿tom having forgot their Original Stock, are in Cloaths, Humour, and Carriage, tranÅ¿formed into the Manners of the Natives.

The Pope's Nuncio head of the Rebels.The Chief and Head of all theÅ¿e, though a Stranger, was John BaptiÅ¿ta Renuncio, Prince and BiÅ¿hop of Firma, the Popes Nuncio; who paÅ¿Å¿ing through France on his Journey to Ireland, did not wait upon the Queen of England being then there, and openly threatned, that he would Å¿uffer no man to remain in Ireland that wiÅ¿hed well to the King, or who Å¿hould be found to favour the EngliÅ¿h or their Affairs.

TheÅ¿e kindled, and in all places blew the Coals of Rebellion, and, that the Breach might not be made up again, uÅ¿ed all means by Rapine, Murder, and all Å¿orts of Villany to put things into confuÅ¿ion; to overthrow the Government, renounce the King, chuÅ¿e a King of the Ancient Race, or of Å¿ome new Family, whether the Pope or King of Spain, or to erect a new Common-wealth of the Clergy and Deputies of the Nobles. Yet I muÅ¿t except Clanricard, Taff, and Å¿ome few more; who though they were zealous Roman-Catholicks,Some Catholick Nobles Loyal to the King. yet perÅ¿evered in their Loyalty and Obedience to the King.

IriÅ¿h Planters.
Planters I call all thoÅ¿e, who being of the Roman Catholick Religion, from the time of Henry II. went over from England into Ireland, and in a continued SucceÅ¿Å¿ion, continued there until the
Reign of Queen Elizabeth. TheÅ¿e alÅ¿o being privy to the ConÅ¿piracy, whether that they might maintain the Roman Catholick Religion in Å¿ecurity,Why they fell off, and at the Å¿ame time increaÅ¿e their civil JuriÅ¿dictions and Immunities, or carried away with the Tide of Rebellion; or, in a word, that they might Å¿ecure themÅ¿elves and their EÅ¿tates in a common Rapine, had already joyned with the other PapiÅ¿ts, Being before moÅ¿t Loyal. who nevertheleÅ¿s, before that time could never be endured to pollute themÅ¿elves with Å¿uch barbarous Cruelty, and Å¿o many unparallell'd Murders, or to fall off from the Government of England.

They who lately went over into Ireland about the latter end of the Reign of Queen Elizabeth, either for the Wars, or for Planting and Setling there, were for moÅ¿t part faithful to the King, except thoÅ¿e who were deluded by the Authority of Parliament, or infected with Presbytery by the Neighbouring Scots.

A Colony of Scots tranÅ¿ported into Æ²lÅ¿ter, The IriÅ¿h Scots, by Authority from King James, had encreaÅ¿ed to the number of forty thouÅ¿and Families. TheÅ¿e in the beginning of the Troubles, following the Ceremonies of their Countrymen, Å¿ided with the Parliament. But King Charles being beheaded, and the EngliÅ¿h Monarchy quite overturned,Now fight for the King. they changed their minds, and Å¿et themÅ¿elves valiantly upon revenge, under the Command of the Earl of Ards, Collonel Monro, Audley Mervin, and Sir Robert Stewart.

Coot Governour of Derry, Monck of Dundalk,
Coot, Monck, and Jones, Å¿tand for the Rump-Parliament, and Principally Jones Governour of Dublin, Å¿tood for the Rump-Parliament. But O-brian Earl
of Inchiqueen Governour of MunÅ¿ter,
Inchiqueen for the King. with that whole Province, and all his Forces, who had Å¿worn to be true to the King and Parliament jointly, after the Murder of the King renouncing the Rump-Parliament, declare now for the King alone, Hitherto we have taken pains to deÅ¿cribe the various Inclinations, DeÅ¿igns, and PurpoÅ¿es of the IriÅ¿h, now let us Å¿ee by what Orphean Harp or Charm, they were united into one.

In the firÅ¿t Part we told you, how the MarqueÅ¿s of Ormond was forced by the treachery of the IriÅ¿h, How the RoyaliÅ¿ts joyned together. to deliver up to Jones, Dublin with the whole GarriÅ¿on, and all that continued in their Duty. From that time the Pope's Nuncio Commanded in Chief, except in thoÅ¿e places which were under Jones, Coot, and Monck, which eÅ¿pouÅ¿ed the Party of the Rump-Parliament. He took to himÅ¿elf the whole Power, made Laws, pronounced Judgments,The arrogance of the Pope's Nuncio was his ruine, drew up and muÅ¿tered Armies, managed the War, and impoÅ¿ed money, with an abÅ¿olute and deÅ¿potick Authority. But by this means he became both hated and deÅ¿piÅ¿ed, Å¿o that having received one blow after another (eÅ¿pecially PreÅ¿ton's Forces being defeated by Jones,
And the cauÅ¿e of PreÅ¿ton's defeat.
The Æ²nion of the IriÅ¿h in favour of the King.
Who humbly dedeÅ¿ire the Queen and Prince of Wales to Å¿end over the MarqueÅ¿s of Ormond with Å¿upplies and Authority. he grew weak both in Men and Authority. This opportunity was laid hold upon by Clanricard, who Commanded one Army in Æ²lÅ¿ter, and Taff who Commanded another in MunÅ¿ter, who having conÅ¿ulted with Inchiqueen, reÅ¿olved upon it as the moÅ¿t expedient courÅ¿e, to implore the Royal AÅ¿Å¿iÅ¿tance again, Unite together into one, and to Å¿end forthwith to the Queen and Prince of Wales to acquaint them with what they had done; confeÅ¿Å¿ing that the Truce was not faithfully obÅ¿erved, and diÅ¿covering thoÅ¿e by whoÅ¿e fault and
inÅ¿tigation it was broken: They moreover moÅ¿t humbly beg, that the MarqueÅ¿s of Ormond may be Å¿ent over with Authority and Supplies, and engage upon conditions which were not diÅ¿liked by the King, to fight under his Banner, till the broken Forces of the Rump-Parliament Å¿hould be utterly deÅ¿troyed, and his MajeÅ¿ty and they themÅ¿elves fully reÅ¿tored to their former peace.

The Popes Nuncio Å¿uÅ¿pecting that matters would fall out Å¿o,The Nuncio frets, and that the Å¿torm which his Government had raiÅ¿ed, would break over his own head, forbids any farther Treaty, threatens the Contraveeners with dire PuniÅ¿hments; and at length Å¿trikes thoÅ¿e that perÅ¿iÅ¿ted in their purpoÅ¿e, with the uÅ¿ual Weapon of Excommunication. But that blunt Thunderbolt Å¿cared no body;And being beÅ¿ieged, for they march againÅ¿t him, and beÅ¿iege him in the Town of Galloway: WhilÅ¿t, in the mean time, the Lord O-brian diverts the Succours that Ouen-Ro-Oneal deÅ¿igned to bring to his Party.Capitulates for a departure. Then the Pope's Nuncio deÅ¿pairing of relief, capitulated for a diÅ¿honourable Retreat, and departed. WhilÅ¿t theÅ¿e matters were acting, the Glorious King Charles the FirÅ¿t, Murdered by the Hands of Rebel Parricides, Crowned his Death with Martyrdome.

NevertheleÅ¿s, the MarqueÅ¿s of Ormond being rid of that difficulty, Ormond coming to Kilkenny, where a general meeting of the IriÅ¿h was held, they come to Articles of agreement. and having a new CommiÅ¿Å¿ion and InÅ¿tructions from King Charles the Second, repairs to Corke, and Å¿hortly after to Kilkenny, where a Parliament, or Convention of the States of Ireland was then kept; and after long Debates on each Å¿ide, they came to a great many Articles of Agreement; of which, this was the Å¿ubÅ¿tance.

After a Recognition, whereby they owned his MajeÅ¿ty for Soveraign, and lawful King of Ireland, and that they would to the utmoÅ¿t defend him with their Lives and Fortunes; they agree, That the King Å¿hould give the IriÅ¿h free liberty of their Religion. That if it Å¿eemed fit to the Deputies or CommiÅ¿Å¿ioners, (who were appointed to the number of eighteen) a Parliament Å¿hould be called within two Months, wherein PapiÅ¿ts as well as others Å¿hould have liberty of free Voting; and that the King Å¿hall confirm their Acts, provided they be not grievous to ProteÅ¿tants. All Acts and Decrees paÅ¿t Å¿ince AuguÅ¿t 1641, that might be diÅ¿honorable to the IriÅ¿h Nation, Å¿hall be repealed. That all Law Suits, Sentences, Actions, or ProceÅ¿Å¿es commenced or determined Å¿ince that time, be wholly aboliÅ¿hed, and that the IriÅ¿h be reÅ¿tored to the Lands and EÅ¿tates whereof they had been diÅ¿poÅ¿Å¿eÅ¿Å¿ed. That all Impediments be removed, that were wont to barr the IriÅ¿h PapiÅ¿ts from Å¿itting in Parliament. That all Debts be reckoned to be in the Å¿ame Å¿tate as they were in, in the Year 1641, and that no body be moleÅ¿ted nor troubled upon that account. That the Lands of the Barons and Nobles in the Counties of Toumond, Clare, Tipperrary, Limmerick, Kilkenny, and Wicklo, be adjudged to the ancient PoÅ¿Å¿eÅ¿Å¿ors, and their Titles made good by new Acts. That Inns be Erected for the Students in Law, wherever the Lord Lieutenant Å¿hall think convenient; and where Degrees alÅ¿o in the Law may be taken, as well as in England. That Places and Titles of Honour, and beneficial Offices, may be free both to PapiÅ¿ts and ProteÅ¿tants. That the uÅ¿e and ExerciÅ¿e of Arms, Commands, and Governments, may be in the power of the Å¿ame; and that during the War, five thouÅ¿and IriÅ¿h Foot, and two thouÅ¿and HorÅ¿e be kept in pay. That the Court
of Wards be aboliÅ¿hed, and in lieu of it, twelve thouÅ¿and pounds a year payed into the Kings Exchequer. That no Peer have liberty to Vote by Proxy: That the Nobles be obliged within five years to purchaÅ¿e Lands, a Baron to the value of two hundred pounds a year, a ViÅ¿count four hundred, an Earl Å¿ix hundred, a MarqueÅ¿s, eight hundred, and a Duke a thouÅ¿and. That they may be free to treat of the independance of the Parliament of Ireland, upon that of England. That thoÅ¿e of the Kings Privy-Council Å¿hall meddle with no Affairs, but the Publick: That Suits about Titles be referred to the Judges of the Kingdom, to whom it belongs to try them. That the Acts againÅ¿t the Exportation of IriÅ¿h Wool, Tallow, and other Goods out of the Kingdom, be repealed. That they who have been under any pretext, Fined, or PuniÅ¿hed, in the County of UlÅ¿ter, Å¿ince the firÅ¿t of King James, Å¿hall be relieved according to Equity. That the Inhabitants and Citizens of Corke, Youghal, and Dungarban, be reÅ¿tored to their PoÅ¿Å¿eÅ¿Å¿ions, that they were turned out of in the beginning of the War, provided they give Security for their Loyalty, and that they Å¿hall not be troubleÅ¿ome to the GarriÅ¿ons. That an Act of Oblivion be paÅ¿t, of all things before committed, thoÅ¿e excepted, who Å¿tand guilty of Barbarous and Inhumane Crimes. That it be lawful to none of the Nobles to Farm the CuÅ¿tomes. That Laws be made againÅ¿t Monopolies. That the JuriÅ¿diction of the Court called, CaÅ¿tle-Chamber, âbe moderated. That the Law be abrogated, which ordained, That HorÅ¿es Å¿hould not draw the Plow by the Tail, and that the Straw Å¿hould not be burnt to Å¿eparate the Corn from it. That Law Suits about Sea Matters, Å¿hall be decided in the Chancery of Ireland. That, for the future, all Actions, about the want of Title, Å¿hall be Å¿uppreÅ¿Å¿ed, if the
owners have from ancient times poÅ¿Å¿eÅ¿Å¿ed the Lands by any Right. That alÅ¿o all IntereÅ¿t for Moneys, Å¿ince the beginning of the Troubles, be diÅ¿charged, and that, for the following years, it exceed not five per Cent. a Year. That the Deputies or CommiÅ¿Å¿ioners Å¿hall impoÅ¿e Å¿ufficient Taxes, for carrying on the War, both by Sea and Land; either by way of ExciÅ¿e, or any other way, that they Å¿hall judge moÅ¿t convenient for the Publick. That JuÅ¿tices of the Peace Å¿hall have Power to determine Suits, under the value of ten Shillings. That the Governours of the PopiÅ¿h PerÅ¿waÅ¿ion, enjoy the Governments and Commands that they are at preÅ¿ent in poÅ¿Å¿eÅ¿Å¿ion of. That the Tenths of taken Ships, and ImpoÅ¿itions upon Commodities, Å¿hall remain in the hands of thoÅ¿e to whom they have been granted, until further order be taken about all theÅ¿e things. It was about the beginning of May,

The death and character of Ireton. Is taken. Nor

knew not as yet, what it was to AÅ¿Å¿ociate, and they had no opportunity of riÅ¿ing; the Regicides having a watchful Eye over all the Countries, and their Spies and EmiÅ¿Å¿aries wreÅ¿ting all the Actions and Sayings of HoneÅ¿t men into the worÅ¿t SenÅ¿e.

AÅ¿cham, who he was:About that time AÅ¿cham, whom I named a little before, a Fellow of obÅ¿cure Birth, deÅ¿iring to Å¿how his Gifts and get himÅ¿elf a Name, by writing againÅ¿t the King, and for the abominable change of Government, which the leÅ¿s it beeame him to do, for that heretofore (under the Earl of Northumberland) he had had the inÅ¿titution of the Young Duke of GloceÅ¿ter, is therefore in quality of Envoy with Ribera an Italian, An envoy from the Rump-Parliament to the King of Spain, as his Interpreter Å¿ent into Spain to treat of Affairs. But he had got himÅ¿elf Å¿o much hatred by his Writings that were publiÅ¿hed, and the Employment he now undertook, that Å¿ome conÅ¿pired a revenge, and Å¿uddenly breaking into his Chamber at Madrid,
againÅ¿t all Law and Equity killed both him and Ribera his Interpreter.He is privately killed with his Interpreter. One of the Murderers taken, making his eÅ¿cape Å¿uffers for it. The AmbaÅ¿Å¿adour of Venice gave Sanctuary to one of the Murderers; another being taken making his eÅ¿cape, publickly Å¿uffered for it. The reÅ¿t to the number of three took Sanctuary in a Church till the EccleÅ¿iaÅ¿ticks Å¿hould have time to take cogniÅ¿ance of the CauÅ¿e. It is fit we Å¿hould alÅ¿o mention the good Offices of the emulous King of Portugal, The King of Portugal offends the Regicides, becauÅ¿e he would not force Prince Rupert and Prince Maurice cut of his Harbours, when Blake deÅ¿ired to fight them. But a terrible Hurricane which is frequent
in the Torrid Zone, Where Maurice was unhappily caÅ¿t away, having Å¿eparated Maurice from his Brother, he was caÅ¿t away with his Ship and Men in the dreadful Storm. Unhappy EngliÅ¿h, who with blind rage have conÅ¿umed the Relicts of the Palatinat! and accurÅ¿ed Broils of Britain, that Å¿hipwrack't that Life which eÅ¿caped the Sword of AuÅ¿tria! I Å¿hould give way to lamentations, if our Å¿hame could add Glory to the Dead, or give comfort to the Å¿urviving Family. Let us only then, which is all we can do, with our Tears waÅ¿h out the Å¿tain of our unlucky Age; to which Crime it is no Å¿mall acceÅ¿Å¿ion, that the Ocean and other World are alÅ¿o polluted with the deÅ¿truction of the Royal Family. I return to Portugal, from whence the Å¿team of Sugar attracted an AmbaÅ¿Å¿adour to London. Now would God the Supreme diÅ¿poÅ¿er of all things,The PortugueÅ¿e Ships are reÅ¿tored. Å¿uffer that Å¿o remarkable conÅ¿tancy of Å¿o good a King, Å¿hould turn to the dammage of his Subjects. I mention
not the Glory of aÅ¿Å¿iÅ¿ting diÅ¿treÅ¿Å¿ed Princes, a rare thing amongÅ¿t Kings. But after all, he himÅ¿elf has no cauÅ¿e to fear, but that his kindneÅ¿s Å¿hew'd to a King, heretofore in diÅ¿treÅ¿s, will, by the Å¿ame Prince, who never forgets thoÅ¿e that have deÅ¿erved well of him, now raiÅ¿ed to the Throne of his AnceÅ¿tours, and joyned to him in Affinity, be repayed to him and his Subjects with plentiful intereÅ¿t.

But now we have affairs nearer home, Strickland, the AmbaÅ¿Å¿adour, being Å¿lighted in Holland, returns home. and with the Dutch again to conÅ¿ider. But that the Parricides might repay one Affront with another, they command Jacobin Vanodenskirk, the Dutch AmbaÅ¿Å¿adour to depart the Kingdom of England, The Dutch AmbaÅ¿Å¿adour is commanded to depart England, upon pretext that the King being dead, the Negotiation with the States was now at an end. But Å¿oon after, as if they repented what they had done, Schaepie is Å¿ent to treat of Peace, who, though he was but an Agent, and empowred only by one City, to wit, AmÅ¿terdam, to treat, yet, by the Rump-Parliament,
To whom another preÅ¿ently Å¿ucceeds from AmÅ¿terdam.
St. Jones and Strickland are Å¿ent into Holland with great Equipage. he is honoured with the Title of AmbaÅ¿Å¿adour, who take occaÅ¿ion, on the other hand to Å¿end two AmbaÅ¿Å¿adours with Royal and Magnificent Equipage, to wit, Oliver St. Jones, one of the Members of the Rump-Parliament, and Lord Chief JuÅ¿tice of the Common-Pleas, and Walter Strickland. TheÅ¿e have InÅ¿tructions, To clap up a Peace, and that by a Coalition of both Nations into one, they might live under the Å¿ame Government, have the mutual Priviledges of Habitation, Trading and Harbours of each Country indifferently: But theÅ¿e were not to be divulged, but piece and piece, and by degrees, if they found

Who nevertheleÅ¿s being fooled by the States,But the States had no inclination to Å¿ettle a Peace, until they found the Å¿ucceÅ¿s of the affairs in Scotland. But after much adoe, having at length given Audience to the AmbaÅ¿Å¿adours, they put them off from day to day, till they propoÅ¿ed, at long run, Å¿ome long winded Articles of Peace, drawn up in the time of Henry VII, to be conÅ¿idered; which, Å¿o Å¿oon as the AmbaÅ¿Å¿adours had rejected, they deviÅ¿e others to drive away time, until the AmbaÅ¿Å¿adours, finding themÅ¿elves fooled, might haÅ¿ten their departure. But, during their Å¿tay in Holland, the States were neceÅ¿Å¿itated to place a Guard at their Door;And expoÅ¿ed to continual dangers; nor was that Å¿ufficient to Å¿ecure them from Affronts, but that their Windows were every night broken, or they themÅ¿elves diÅ¿turbed by I know not what Bug-bears and Apparitions.
