This enraged the Parricides, But great were the DiÅ¿orders that this Affront occaÅ¿ioned, and Å¿evere was the Revenge which the Parricides hatched in their Hearts; being reÅ¿olved, that if the affairs in Scotland Å¿ucceeded according to their wiÅ¿hes, they would never reÅ¿t nor Å¿heath their Sword, before they had forced by Arms the Conditions, which by
AmbaÅ¿Å¿adours they could not obtain. In the mean time they thought it enough at preÅ¿ent, to give out Letters of RepriÅ¿al, And made them give out Letters of RepriÅ¿al. and by other mens hands, revenge the Injuries done to themÅ¿elves; and to make an Act, that no MerchandiÅ¿e, of what Country Å¿oever it were, Å¿hould be brought into England, unleÅ¿s imported in EngliÅ¿h Bottoms by EngliÅ¿h Sea-men, or fraighted by EngliÅ¿h Merchants.

Let us make a trip over to Sweden,
Whitlock Sails to Sweden with a Å¿plendid EmbaÅ¿Å¿y for the Que â¢ n the Queen whereof had lately Å¿ent an Envoy to Compliment and Congratulate the Regicides: To her therefore Whitlock is Å¿ent in a Å¿plendid EmbaÅ¿Å¿ie, to return the Honour and Compliment, and alÅ¿o to make Peace with her, to which Å¿he very willingly conÅ¿ented. But the Queen being Å¿horttly after removed, or, to uÅ¿e a Å¿ofter expeÅ¿Å¿ion, having reÅ¿igned the Crown,Who reÅ¿igning the Crown, the King Å¿ends ov â¢ r Bond AmbaÅ¿Å¿adour to Cromwell. the King of Sweden Å¿ends over a Reciprocal, and no leÅ¿s Honourable EmbaÅ¿Å¿y, by the Lord ChriÅ¿topher Bond, a Senator of the Kingdom, to Cromwell, who then had the chief adminiÅ¿tration of the Government.

The IÅ¿les of Silly lay very convenient for moleÅ¿ting the Trade of the EngliÅ¿h. An expedition for reducing the IÅ¿les of Silly. There the RoyaliÅ¿ts cruiÅ¿ing too and again with four or five Å¿mall VeÅ¿Å¿els, did no little hurt to the Regicides, and would have done much more, could they have been morgaged to the Dutch, as it was commonly reported. For plucking out of this Thorn, great preparations are made at Plimouth, not above fifteen Leagues diÅ¿tant from the IÅ¿lands. Where Blake and Popham having provided Å¿ome Å¿mall VeÅ¿Å¿els and Boats, they take the opportunity, and Å¿et Sail from thence in the night time, with three hundred Souldiers, beÅ¿ides Sea-men, and having had a fair Wind,
next morning they come to the Land. There are in all ten adjacent IÅ¿lands, divided only by narrow PaÅ¿Å¿ages of an Eddy Sea, and on all Å¿ides Å¿ecured by Shelves and Rocks. In three hours time they take ThreÅ¿coe and Briari, Of which two, after a conflict of three houres continuance, are taken. with the loÅ¿s of fifteen Men: but of the GarriÅ¿on, a Boat being Å¿unck, about fourty were drowned, one hundred and twenty made PriÅ¿oners, and about fourty Guns taken, which the RoyaliÅ¿ts out of two Friggats, had planted upon the Å¿hoar. The raging of the Sea appeaÅ¿ing the Fury of the Souldiers, made for two days time a CeÅ¿Å¿ation, not unlike to a Peace. But on the third day, when it was Calm, they began to thunder on both Å¿ides with their great Guns, on the one hand from ThreÅ¿coe, and the other IÅ¿lands, and on the other, from St. Mary's Grimsby Haven, being betwixt them.The reÅ¿t at length Å¿urrender upon articles. But the Governour Greenvill, now Earl of Bath, wanting Å¿upplies, at length, upon pretty good Conditions, Å¿urrenders the IÅ¿land.

As alÅ¿o upon Barbadoes, an IÅ¿land in America. He, with eighteen or twenty Sail of Men of War, had Å¿teered his CourÅ¿e to the WeÅ¿t Indies, to reduce thoÅ¿e IÅ¿lands once more under the yoak of England; and Å¿etting upon them unexpectedly, he took twenty or thirty Dutch Ships, who in contempt of two Acts, drove a Trade with them; cruiÅ¿ing off and on in Å¿ight of the IÅ¿land, he blocked it up for the Å¿pace of Å¿ix Months, and at length, a Sedition ariÅ¿ing amongÅ¿t the Planters, he forced the Lord Willoughby,
whom the King had made Governour of it, to Å¿urrender.

WhilÅ¿t theÅ¿e things are acting in the Indies, they erect of new in England, a High Court of JuÅ¿tice, as they were pleaÅ¿ed to call it,A high Court of JuÅ¿tice is again erected, and that a Å¿tanding Court. not upon the account of a preÅ¿ent Emergent; but to continue for Å¿ix Months, which if it could paÅ¿s without the envy of Tyranny and OppreÅ¿Å¿ion, might be adjourned de die in diem. Keeble is by the Rump-Parliament made PreÅ¿ident of this Court, being aÅ¿Å¿iÅ¿ted by others, and fifty AÅ¿Å¿eÅ¿Å¿ors of the popular Faction. MoÅ¿t of theÅ¿e being Souldiers, were ready at the beck of the General, to Å¿mite the PriÅ¿oner as an Enemy; all the reÅ¿t were Creatures of the new Common-wealth, whoÅ¿e hopes and whole EÅ¿tates depended upon the favour of the Parricides; except, perhaps, one or two, who had more Zeal than Judgment. And this horrid Violence, unheard of under the Government of our Kings paÅ¿t in all Ages, is impoÅ¿ed upon the ignorant multitude, under the Å¿pecious name of JuÅ¿tice. TheÅ¿e Men had Power to bring before them, try and puniÅ¿h without appeal, any that had held CorreÅ¿pondence with the King, Queen, Duke of York, the RoyaliÅ¿ts, or IriÅ¿h, that had aÅ¿Å¿iÅ¿ted them by Word, or Deed, or received them into their HouÅ¿es, or that had delivered up any CaÅ¿tle, Town, or Ship, or had attempted any Å¿uch Surrender; beÅ¿ides many other Crimes of the Å¿ame nature. Now if you inquire into the conÅ¿titution of the Court, and whence it derived its Authority, you muÅ¿t know, that it was firÅ¿t appointed againÅ¿t the Kings MajeÅ¿ty, by thoÅ¿e who were Å¿o far from having any Power of adminiÅ¿tring JuÅ¿tice, that, by our Laws, and CuÅ¿toms, they had not the Power to condemn the meaneÅ¿t Slave; then againÅ¿t the Nobles;

If any man was Å¿uÅ¿pected of plotting and contriving againÅ¿t the Publick, he was preÅ¿ently dragged before this Å¿upreme Tribunal, and expoÅ¿ed to the Calumnies of pettifogging Lawyers, who for a little Reputation and Profit Å¿old their Souls in pleading againÅ¿t him; who having none to defend his CauÅ¿e, and being terrified or Å¿hamed out of Countenance, without the Evidence of two WitneÅ¿Å¿es, or the Verdict of a Jury of twelve men, (which has onely force in England) he is Condemned, and why Å¿hould not I Å¿ay Murdered?

A lively deÅ¿cription of the Å¿ad faee of affairsIt was, indeed no Å¿mall matter of terrour, to Å¿ee a drawn Sword hanging as by an Hair over all mens naked Heads, at every minute ready to fall upon them. About that time eÅ¿pecially, and afterward when Cromwell had got the chief adminiÅ¿tration of the Government, whole Å¿warms of informers wandered about in all places,Informers Å¿warm in all places. both publick and private, Å¿acred and prophane. They liÅ¿tned in Churches, Å¿neaked into companies in Taverns and AlehouÅ¿es, and went to wreÅ¿tling in the Rings. Noblemen and Gentelmens Servants were corrupted, that they might diÅ¿cover what their MaÅ¿ters talked at Table; the chief Vintners or their Drawers at leaÅ¿t were feed, to hearken to the free diÅ¿courÅ¿es of their CuÅ¿tomers over their Wine, either in the room or skulking behind the Hangings, or thin partition Walls. Such kind of Spies and eave-droppers,Nothing Å¿ecure from Spies. Hiero the Tyrant of SyracuÅ¿a uÅ¿ed to employ, who were called ã in non-Latin alphabet ã and ã in non-Latin alphabet ã , In a word, PriÅ¿ons were full of accuÅ¿ers that they might accuÅ¿e; Å¿o that there was no Village free from Å¿narlings nor Å¿nares. The
Cities themÅ¿elves were filled with Å¿olitude, Å¿ilence, trembling and fear. All flocked into the Countrey, not for pleaÅ¿ure or the Society of their Neighbours, but where they could find Å¿olitude and retreat; where the BarrenneÅ¿s and deÅ¿ertneÅ¿s of the place might neither allure Soldiers nor Å¿ecure Informers; where they might neither be known, nor have acquaintance, and where avoiding the company of men, they might have the Å¿atisfaction of being Å¿ecure, without the pleaÅ¿ure of the Countrey or company. All Neighbourhood, Society, and intimacy were Å¿uÅ¿pected. ThoÅ¿e who where naturally averÅ¿e from ill things, yet often deceived, becauÅ¿e they had been deceived before. Into Å¿uch confuÅ¿ion had the Rout, the diÅ¿turber of common Peace, put all things.Who had a thouÅ¿and tricks to do miÅ¿chief, With obÅ¿ervant eyes do curious Spies run about, and were not idle when they had nothing to do. They tope it Å¿toutly that by a gentle rack they may pump out the Å¿ecrets of the heart. They pry into words and actions, but much more into mens looks, the interpreters of the mind. It is their buÅ¿ineÅ¿s to hanker about for Rumors, and Å¿pread reports, to rouze the drooping hopes of the credulous, and to foment them with Å¿trange Å¿tories, which afterwards vaniÅ¿hing into Å¿moak, they might be cowed and rendered more puÅ¿illanimous for the future.

The Noblemen and Gentlemen who had been of the contrary Å¿ide, are purÅ¿ued with Å¿ecret whiÅ¿pers and calumnies wherever they could be pickt up, onely to vex them; the more moderate are obnoxious to SuÅ¿picions: ThoÅ¿e who were found any way to have aÅ¿Å¿iÅ¿ted or correÅ¿ponded with the King, were either forced to bribe luÅ¿tily or to Å¿tand a Tryal. There were
alÅ¿o a kind of Duckoys and Trapans, A New Å¿et of Trapans come in play, of all men the moÅ¿t accurÅ¿ed, whoÅ¿e chief Å¿tudy was to teaze the more hot-headed and cholerick, and draw them thereby into Capital Å¿nares; and when they had thus caught them, inform againÅ¿t them that they might be brought to a Tryal, or oppreÅ¿s them with Å¿ecret Calumnies.Who amongÅ¿t others, are fatal to Colonel Andrews.
Colonel Andrews thus circumvented loÅ¿t his Head. Nor was the preÅ¿ident BradÅ¿haw aÅ¿hamed openly to declare in Court, that by counterfeit Letters he had correÅ¿ponded with him in the name of the King. Thus was the EÅ¿tate of the Lord Craven confiÅ¿cated;By the craft of theÅ¿e, the Lord Craven is forfeited. though being no way obnoxious, but for a large EÅ¿tate which he poÅ¿Å¿eÅ¿Å¿ed in England, he lived beyond Seas in Holland. Whither one Faulkner of that Gang, a turn-coat to the Kings Party, being Å¿ent, (but for what end I dare not affirm,) laid a Å¿nare for him. One Å¿ingle evidence, and he infamous too, was Å¿ufficient to the partial and mercenary Judges, for the fellow was afterwards for the Å¿ame depoÅ¿ition convicted of perjury, who having given under his hand contrary to what he had Å¿worn, to the Judges eyes bely'd his venal Tongue. TheÅ¿e are the counterfeiters of CommiÅ¿Å¿ions, of the King's Signet, forgers of writings and hands, and the Cony-catchers of Novices. They of their own accord give men Authority to raiÅ¿e Soldiers,And others brought into the danger of their lives. and then turn that Authority to their ruine, Deliver Letters, which they venture to do, though (as they Å¿ay) upon the Peril of High TreaÅ¿on, and then inform the Soldiers that they might Å¿eize the Parties with the Letters, bring them before the new Court, and point blank condemn them to Death. In the mean time there was no accuÅ¿ing of the clandeÅ¿tine authors of the Villany,WhilÅ¿t the accurÅ¿ed authors are Å¿ecure, and far leÅ¿s bringing them to JuÅ¿tice. So that it clearly appeared
that theÅ¿e were not the crimes of private men, but publickly deliberated,As being put upon theÅ¿e tricks by the Regicides. forged in the Å¿hop of the Politicians, and committed to the Myrmidons, who as Jackcalls to the Lyons, might make it their buÅ¿ineÅ¿s, to hunt out for Crimes, which the High Court of JuÅ¿tice might run down.

The Scots being long uncertain what to do,The Scots conÅ¿ent to Monarchy, and that in the perÅ¿on of Charles the Second, thoÅ¿e that were of a contrary opinion not daring to reÅ¿iÅ¿t: Yet they diÅ¿agree about the conditions. and divided into divers Factions, at length reÅ¿olve upon Monarchical Government, and proclaming CHARLES the Second King. A few who reliÅ¿hed a Republick, being of the Å¿ame mind with the Regicides, concealed their rancour, not daring to diÅ¿cover themÅ¿elves, nor reÅ¿iÅ¿t. But upon what Conditions he Å¿hould be admitted to the Throne is Å¿eriouÅ¿ly debated; nor never well agreed upon. MoÅ¿t of the Highlanders, firmly maintain that no other Articles are to be demanded of his MajeÅ¿ty but the ancicient promiÅ¿es which the Laws injoyned at the inauguration of Kings. Others, to wit the Covenanters, would have him firÅ¿t to Å¿ubÅ¿cribe the Solemn League and Covenant, give Å¿igns of Å¿orrow and repentance for his Father and Mother's Å¿ins; and all baniÅ¿hed and turned out of Court who had carried Arms for his Father, or had not as yet taken the Covenant. I mention not the reÅ¿t; as being but a few, whoÅ¿e minds were either corrupted by Bribes and PenÅ¿ions from the Regicides,, or were infected with the contagion of their Friends the Democraticks;At length CHARLES the Second is proclaimed King of Scotland England, and Ireland; and who urged Å¿everer terms, that they might raiÅ¿e new Å¿cruples, and cut off all way for the King's admiÅ¿Å¿ion. At length, the middle party prevailing, CHARLES the Second is by Heralds, in all publick Place, proclaimed King of Scotland, England and Ireland.

And Windram is Å¿ent to the King from the Convention of EÅ¿tates,In the mean while the debate growing long in the Convention of EÅ¿tates, and Committee of the Kirk, who were to conÅ¿ider of the matter and to draw it up into Form, they themÅ¿elves at length reÅ¿olve to Å¿end Windram, Laird of Libberton, to try the Kings mind; who having delivered him Letters full of Å¿orrow, and regret, for the horrid and unparallelled Murder of his Father,That he might inform him upon what conditions he was to be admitted. aÅ¿Å¿ures him that the Scots were ready to obey him, had proclaimed him King and SucceÅ¿Å¿our to the Crown, and that upon the following Conditions, they would admit him to the Supreme adminiÅ¿tration of the Government.

The PropoÅ¿als were to this effect. That the King Å¿hould Å¿ubÅ¿cribe the Solemn League and Covenant, Which were to this purpoÅ¿e. and conÅ¿ent by act of Parliament that all his Subjects Å¿hould take it, confirming all that they had done for that purpoÅ¿e. That he Å¿hould confirm the acts of the two laÅ¿t SeÅ¿Å¿ions of the Parliament; which condemns Duke Hamilton's late engagement and irruption into England. That he Å¿hould recal his CommiÅ¿Å¿ion to MontroÅ¿s, whereby he had Power to raiÅ¿e Souldiers in Scotland, or bring them into Scotland from abroad. That he would renounce his right of Negative Vote. That he would Å¿uffer no PapiÅ¿t about him, and laÅ¿tly, that he would appoint a place in Holland, where CommiÅ¿Å¿ioners might wait upon his MajeÅ¿ty, for adjuÅ¿ting of theÅ¿e propoÅ¿als and of other things that might be previous to his voyage.

The King having read the Letters writes back to the Scots by Fleeming. TheÅ¿e PropoÅ¿als were made in the IÅ¿le of JerÅ¿ey, where the King with many of his Courtiers then was, who, having received the Letters, made Windram very welcome; and not long after Å¿ent Sir William Fleeming to the ScottiÅ¿h Nobility and Committee of the Kirk with Letters of reciprocal congratulation. At length he writes
to them by Windram.
Afterwards by the Å¿ame Windram;
And appoints Breda in Holland for a Treaty.
That he was well pleaÅ¿ed with their obedience and indignation againÅ¿t the Regicides, exhorts them, that they would Å¿eriouÅ¿ly endeavour the reÅ¿toring of Peace and Concord; that for that end he Å¿hould not be wanting in any thing; and bids them for that purpoÅ¿e Å¿end CommiÅ¿Å¿ioners to Breda, with whom he would treat about the re-eÅ¿tabliÅ¿hing of Peace.

The King being willing to deliberate about theÅ¿e matters more Å¿eriouÅ¿ly,Then deliberates with his Friends. privately demands the Opinions of his Friends, writing to thoÅ¿e whoÅ¿e Affairs hindered them from waiting PerÅ¿onally upon him. But Å¿o many Heads, Å¿o many Minds; yet the Opinions were divided chiefly into two.Of whom Å¿ome dread all concord with the Scots: Some perÅ¿wade him not at all to liÅ¿ten to the Scots, there being treachery hid under the Å¿pecious Cloak of obedience. They repreÅ¿ent to him his Father as an InÅ¿tance of it, who had been long gull'd with fair promiÅ¿es, until he was forced to be Å¿evere to his moÅ¿t faithful Subjects; and then afterward was delivered up to the pleaÅ¿ure of the Faction. That they would cloath him with the Name and Title of a King, but keep all the Power and real Authority in their own hands. And that if he offered for the future to reÅ¿iÅ¿t, and get his neck from under the Yoke, they would deliver him up to the EngliÅ¿h Regicides, or kill him with their own hands. That he would do better to Å¿tick by MontroÅ¿s, than by the united Forces of Scotland, whom he had found to be faithful and brave in doubtful and difficult times, and magnanimous and fortunate at a pinch; that with his own, and the Forces of his Friends, Å¿uccours from abroad, and the aid of the EngliÅ¿h, IriÅ¿h, and Scots, he might mount his Throne in Å¿pight of all the attempts and endeavours of his Enemies.

Others again magnified the Authority of Parliament,

In the mean time Straughan falls in Å¿uddenly and briskly upon the Cromwellians, He falls upon the EngliÅ¿h. and puts their Out-Guards into DiÅ¿order, but with no

The Commanders are angry; The MiniÅ¿ters pray him to withdraw:The Council of War was very angry at theÅ¿e things; and the MiniÅ¿ters coming, earneÅ¿tly beg of him, that he would withdraw, and not expoÅ¿e himÅ¿elf to the dangers of War: They pretend to be in Covenant with God, as no King was; and that That Life, which was to be preferred before the Lives of ten thouÅ¿and private Souldiers, was not to be expoÅ¿ed to the Enemy; with many things of that nature. Cromwell returning to his Camp,From thence he marches to MuÅ¿Å¿elbrough to hinder its being Å¿urpriÅ¿ed, and preÅ¿ently after to Haddington, on Pentland Hills, has intelligence that the Enemy was about to Å¿urpriÅ¿e MuÅ¿Å¿elbrough, and intercept the ProviÅ¿ions, which he uÅ¿ually received in Boats from Dunbar. Cromwell marching back victorious, during the general ConÅ¿ternation, takes, Leeth,

Cromwell purÅ¿ue, Ker: Cromwell now deÅ¿pairing of the inteÅ¿tine diÅ¿Å¿entions amongÅ¿t the Scots, purÅ¿ues Ker; and having ordered Lambert and Whaley with five Regiments of Foot, and an hundred Dragoons, to keep along the South Å¿ide of the River Clide, he himÅ¿elf advances on the North Å¿ide. and knowing that Cromwell was abÅ¿ent, with fifteen hundred HorÅ¿e,Who unexpectedly falls upon Lambert, he Å¿uddenly falls upon Lambert in the night time, and that very Å¿ucceÅ¿sfully at firÅ¿t, till by chance a Tree being laid croÅ¿s the Å¿treet in the middle of the Town, which a Captain with a Company defended, put a Å¿top to their ProgreÅ¿s, whilÅ¿t Lambert drew up his Men, and, Å¿urrounding the Enemy, charged them on the Rear. And having made a conÅ¿iderable Å¿laughter of them, and Ker himÅ¿elf, who was Å¿hot through the hand, being taken,But unfortunately. he purÅ¿ued the reÅ¿t to Air, which Town being preÅ¿ently taken, was Å¿ecured with a GarriÅ¿on. And Å¿o thoÅ¿e of the old Army that hitherto remained, are quite broken and diÅ¿perÅ¿ed, whether more to the grief or Å¿atisfaction of the King, I cannot tell.

About the Å¿ame time a great ConÅ¿piracy of Presbyterians, A ConÅ¿piracy diÅ¿covered at London. both MiniÅ¿ters and Lay-men is diÅ¿covered at London; which took vent firÅ¿t in Scotland, and was by Cromwell, upon Å¿ome Å¿uÅ¿pitions he had not without ground conceived, recommended to the Regicides of England to be Å¿ifted. A Ship bound for the IÅ¿le of Man, to acquaint the Earl of Derby with the whole Scheme of the matter was, by Å¿treÅ¿s of weather, accidentally forced into Air: The Souldiers Å¿earching the Ship, detect the Å¿ecret, afterwards the ConÅ¿piratours are brought to Examination at London; and by the mutual accuÅ¿ations one of another, the whole Intrigue was laid open. That at the inÅ¿tigation of MaÅ¿Å¿ey, and Å¿ome Scots, they had deÅ¿igned to raiÅ¿e Money and Arms,For raiÅ¿ing an Army in Scotland, to invade England. and therewith levy an Army in Scotland, which being joyned to Ker, the Duke of Buckingham, Lord Wilmot, and MaÅ¿Å¿ie, Å¿hould invade England; Of this are accuÅ¿ed, Jenkins, CaÅ¿e, Drake, Love,
and many other MiniÅ¿ters, beÅ¿ides Lay-Men, Gibbons, Cook, Potter, &c. Another ConÅ¿piracy in Norfolk, Suffolk, and Cambridge-Å¿hire, Scarcely was that ConÅ¿piracy Å¿tifled, but a new Sedition aroÅ¿e amongÅ¿t the Norfolk, Suffolk, and Cambridge-Å¿hire men, which was nevertheleÅ¿s Å¿mothered in the birth, all the undertakers being diÅ¿perÅ¿ed; of whom, in Norfolk alone, fifty Men, by Sentence of the High Court of JuÅ¿tice,But in vain; were hanged for that attempt. And that we may inÅ¿iÅ¿t no longer upon theÅ¿e Tragedies,The WelÅ¿hmen with like Å¿ucceÅ¿s. a great many WelÅ¿h in Cardigan-Å¿hire gathered together, which in a Å¿hort time might have looked like an Army, had not the Forces, who were ready in all places round about, drawn together, and quenched that Fire with Blood.
But this is only a digreÅ¿Å¿ion, which may Å¿omewhat Å¿erve to excuÅ¿e the ScottiÅ¿h InvaÅ¿ion, that happened this year.

But let us return again to Scotland, The King is Crowned at Scoon, where now the Å¿olemn Coronation of the Kings MajeÅ¿ty is appointed to be at Scoon, Å¿eaven and fourty Kings having heretofore put on the Crown of Scotland in that place; where it was performed with as much Pomp, conÅ¿idering the times, and the diminution of their Å¿trength, as it had been celebrated in more flouriÅ¿hing ages. The King Å¿ets up his Standard at Aberdeen;The King Å¿ets up his Å¿tandard, to which from all places about, Volunteers, and Honorary Souldiers

Cromwell viÅ¿its Torwood Not daring to attempt it. Cromwell being informed of theÅ¿e Å¿ucceÅ¿Å¿es,

The King, in the mean time marches Å¿treight to England,

Å¿o that from CarliÅ¿le to WorceÅ¿ter, about two hundred Miles diÅ¿tant from one another, no man, much leÅ¿s any houÅ¿e received the leaÅ¿t injury; if you'l except the breaking of one Orchard, and the taking of four or five Apples; for which, notwithÅ¿tanding, the Soldier that committed it was preÅ¿ently Å¿hot to Death.In the chief Towns he is pr â¢
claimed King of England, &c. In all places on their march, the GarriÅ¿ons are Å¿ummoned in the Kings name to Å¿urrender, but without any Å¿ucceÅ¿s: And in the more eminent places, by Heralds CHARLES the Second is proclaimed King of England, Scotland, France and Ireland; the people

So Å¿oon as the news of this expedition was by PoÅ¿t brought to the Rump-Parliament, The Parricides quaking at the news of it, and the report flying that the King having mounted his Soldiers on HorÅ¿es which he found upon the Rode, haÅ¿tened his March towards London, as it is common to fear, to make dangers far greater than they are, Å¿uch Horror and ConÅ¿ternation invaded the minds of the Parricides and Rebels, that in deÅ¿pair they began to caÅ¿t about for lurking holes and places of eÅ¿cape, and accuÅ¿ed Cromwell of raÅ¿hneÅ¿s and precipitancy: Until they had notice that the King had diverted to WorceÅ¿ter, and received freÅ¿h comforts from Cromwell's Letters, who bad them be of good cheer, and uÅ¿e their utmoÅ¿t force, to obviat that laÅ¿t danger, and wholely deÅ¿troy the Enemy.

HarriÅ¿on on the left hand with three thouÅ¿and HorÅ¿e, waited the motion of the King's Army, HarriÅ¿on and Lambert wait the motions of the King, and in vain oppoÅ¿e him at Warrington Bridge. being for that end left behind on the Borders of England; after followed Lambert, with two thouÅ¿and; both as occaÅ¿ion offered, haraÅ¿Å¿ing and hindering them in their March. with one repulÅ¿e from Å¿ome of the Paliament Souldiers that were there by chance,The King eaÅ¿ily poÅ¿Å¿eÅ¿Å¿es himÅ¿elf of WorceÅ¿ter. they poÅ¿Å¿eÅ¿s the City, but were much weakened and impaired in Å¿trength by the tediouÅ¿neÅ¿s and length of the march.

He kindly invites the Londoners to his aÅ¿Å¿iÅ¿tance,From hence, the Kings MajeÅ¿ty, by Letters, invites the Lord Mayor and Common-Council of London, to Arm for his Defence, and for their own juÅ¿t Liberties; promiÅ¿ing Pardon to all for what was paÅ¿t, except the Murderers of his Father. Cromwel with a vaÅ¿t Army BeÅ¿ieges WorceÅ¿ter. animates with new Vigour the Forces of the Rebel-Parricides; and preÅ¿ently joyning his Men with Lambert, HarriÅ¿on, Gray and Fleetwood, and thoÅ¿e who from all parts came flocking in partly voluntarily, and partly by compulÅ¿ion, he made up an Army (if Å¿ome be not miÅ¿taken in their reckoning) of fourÅ¿core thouÅ¿and Men, and more, whom he poÅ¿ts round the City of WorceÅ¿ter.

But the brave,The Earl of Derby with a handful of new raiÅ¿ed Men, though unfortunate attempts of the Earl of Derby which happened about that time, are not to be paÅ¿t over in Å¿ilence. He with a Å¿mall handful of two hundred and fifty Men, from his own IÅ¿le of Man, arrived at a little Town in LancaÅ¿hire, and in that Countrey raiÅ¿ed almoÅ¿t fif â¢ n hundred Men; with whom he marches to
â¢ cheÅ¿ter, there to joyn five hundred more; b â¢ to his misfortune he met with Lilburn a Colonel of the Rump-Parliament Forces, with Å¿ixteen hundred Men. For coming
preÅ¿ently to blow up the Town of Wigan, Is defeated by Lilburn. after a Å¿mart conflict the Earl is defeated, who having received two wounds, by By-ways croÅ¿s the Countrey he flies to Worcester, the Lord Widderington, Sir Thomas TilÅ¿ley, Matthew Bointon and Trollop, Colonels, with Lieutenant Colonel Galliard being kill'd, and Sir William Throgmorton, Colonel Richard Leg, with four other Officers, and fourty Private Souldiers taken.

Cromwell in the mean time views the Kings Camp, MaÅ¿Å¿ey is beat out of Upton, which the Cromwellians poÅ¿Å¿eÅ¿s themÅ¿elves of. uncertain as yet in what part to fall on: He thought it, however, fit to make his firÅ¿t attempt at Æ²pton, Å¿eaven Miles above WorceÅ¿ter to the South, where there is a Stonebridge over the Savern. But the Cromwellians laying hold of the occaÅ¿ion, Å¿tradling upon the Plank, paÅ¿s over one after another; and encreaÅ¿ing in number, they poÅ¿Å¿eÅ¿s themÅ¿elves of Æ²pton Church, and for Å¿ome time defend it, until more Swimming over the River on HorÅ¿eback, and croÅ¿Å¿ing the Bridge that was now in Å¿ome manner repaired, came up to their AÅ¿Å¿iÅ¿tance. And now the third of September came, a Day fatal to, and never to be forgot by the Scots for the overthrow they received at Dunbar the year before; when the King with a Council of War, viewing the Enemies from the high Steeple of the Cathedral-Church, perceived them upon their March towards the Town. The King was Å¿carcely got back into the Town, when Montgomery who defended the Bridge, being dangerouÅ¿ly wounded, and deÅ¿titute of Gunpouder, Kreth alÅ¿o another Commander being taken, returns to the City. Whil'Å¿t theÅ¿e things were acting, the Kings MajeÅ¿ty turning towards the EaÅ¿t-Å¿ide of the Town, reÅ¿olves to hazard a Battel.There is a Å¿harp engagement at Perry-wood, where the King behaved himÅ¿elf moÅ¿t valiantly: Therefore with a conÅ¿iderable Body of Foot, but a Å¿mall number of HorÅ¿e (for the ScottiÅ¿h Cavalry Å¿carce budg'd) he marches againÅ¿t the Enemy at Perry-wood with a moÅ¿t undaunted and preÅ¿ent Mind, being followed by the Dukes of Hamilton and Buckingham, and Sir Alexander Forbes, at the Head of his Foot.But being over-powered by number, At the firÅ¿t charge he beat the Van and made himÅ¿elf MaÅ¿ter of the Artillery; but afterwards, though with wonderful Sagacity he gave orders in the heat and
confuÅ¿ion of the Fight, fac'd the greateÅ¿t dangers with a High and Steady Mind, not to be matched by others; and with his own Hand did many brave Actions, though at that time he gave illuÅ¿trious proofs of his PerÅ¿onal Valour even in the Judgment of his Enemies; yet being overpowred by freÅ¿h Men, whom Cromwell in great numbers Å¿ent in, he deÅ¿paired not, but that he might reÅ¿erve himÅ¿elf for better Fortune,He returns into the Town. thought it beÅ¿t to retreat in time, and Å¿ave himÅ¿elf in the Town; but he was for Å¿ome time Å¿topt by a Wagon laden with Ammunition, which the Wheel being accidentally broken, lay croÅ¿s Sudbury-Gate. He exhorts the HorÅ¿e to renew the Fight; but they are deaf to all entreaties. he uÅ¿ed all manner of perÅ¿waÅ¿ions to encourage the Souldiers who now were giving over to renew the Engagement; till the danger growing greater and greater, by St. Martins-gate he went out to the HorÅ¿e, Commanded by David LeÅ¿lie, being almoÅ¿t whole entire, and directed his courÅ¿e towards Barbon-bridge, earneÅ¿tly entreating the HorÅ¿e that they Å¿hould take Courage, and haÅ¿ten to the AÅ¿Å¿iÅ¿tance of the Foot, who were put to utmoÅ¿t extremity. But many refuÅ¿ed, Å¿ome threw away their Arms, all Å¿lunk away and choÅ¿e rather to decline the danger, than by fighting Å¿toutly, either make that the laÅ¿t day of their Life, or the firÅ¿t of their Victory. broke into the Town through the Suburbs of St. John; and Cromwel, The Town is taken, and the Fort Royal, the Soulders that kept it being put to the Sword. having thrown down Sudbury-gate, beat off the Earl and the reÅ¿t. From thence he marched on victorious to the Fort Royal, maintained by Colonel Drummond with fifteen hundred Soldiers; who having refuÅ¿ed to Å¿urrender it, was Attacked on all Hands, and cut off with all his Men. Deplorable and Å¿ad was the Countenance of the Town after that: The Victorious Souldiers on the one Hand, Killing, breaking into HouÅ¿es, Plundering, Sacking, Roaring and Threatning; on the other hand, the Subdued flying, turning their backs to be cut and Å¿laÅ¿ht, and with Å¿tretched out hands begging Quarters; Å¿ome in vain reÅ¿iÅ¿ting Å¿old their lives as dear as they could; whil'Å¿t the Citizens, to no purpoÅ¿e, prayed, lamented and bewailed. Here were to be Å¿een Å¿ome that begg'd Relief; and there again others weltering in their own gore, who deÅ¿ired that at once an end might be put to their lives and miÅ¿eries. Three thouÅ¿and and five hundred Private Souldiers were Å¿lain.The number of the Å¿lain, Duke Hamilton having his Thigh broken, lived but four or five days after the Battel. Å¿ome Towns-people, but moÅ¿t Scots; amongÅ¿t whom were the Earls of Rothes, Karnewath, Kelly, the Lord Sinclare, Montgomery, the General of Artillerie, as alÅ¿o of EngliÅ¿h, Colonel Graves, and FanÅ¿haw Secretary to the King, with the Officers of the Scots Army, all the Baggage, and an hundred and five and fifty Colours.

The King leaving the ScottiÅ¿h HorÅ¿e, betakes himÅ¿elf to By ways,The Kings MajeÅ¿ty having a little beyond Barbon-bridge left LeÅ¿lie, who reÅ¿olved to march with the HorÅ¿e that were almoÅ¿t entire, by Newport Å¿treight into Scotland, and being attended by the Duke of Buckingham, the Earls of Derby and Lauderdale, the Lords Wilmot, Talbot and other PerÅ¿ons of Qualitie, with about fifty HorÅ¿e, followed By-ways; partly that he might refreÅ¿h himÅ¿elf with Å¿leep, and partly that he might diÅ¿appoint thoÅ¿e that purÅ¿ued him.And at the perÅ¿waÅ¿ion of the Earl of Derby, goes towards BoÅ¿cobel. One Gifford that was well acquainted with the Ways, leaving KedderminÅ¿ter on the Left-hand,When they came to the HouÅ¿e called Whitladies. conducted him by Stonebridge; and at Whiteladies an old MonaÅ¿terie of CiÅ¿tertian Nuns in the midÅ¿t of the Woods, about a Mile from BoÅ¿cobel, having knockt up another Pendrel about midnight, he and his Company are let in. The honeÅ¿t Countrey-men promiÅ¿ing to do what lay in their Power, Richard by a back door led him out into the next Wood; Wilmot having been before ordered to go on HorÅ¿eback to London,
Wilmot being before Å¿ent to London. where at the Å¿ign of the Green Dragon by the Vintry in Thames-Å¿treet, the King had reÅ¿olved to meet him; John Pendrell promiÅ¿ing to Å¿hew him a way which he might more Å¿ecurely follow.

After that the Nobles had taken the beÅ¿t care they could of the King,WhilÅ¿t the Nobles eÅ¿Å¿ay to overtake LeÅ¿ly. they conÅ¿ult about their own Å¿afety, and think it Å¿afeÅ¿t to follow, and if they could overtake LeÅ¿lie, becauÅ¿e of the number of men he had with him, that might Å¿ecure them from a few Å¿tragling Soldiers, and becauÅ¿e they were got Å¿o far on their way, that a conÅ¿iderable body of the Rebels could hardly overtake them. They were not far from thence, when they protected the Lord LivingÅ¿tone, Captain of the King's Troop of Guards, from the Enemies that purÅ¿ued him; but that good fortune laÅ¿ted not long: For Å¿oon after, when they had advanced beyond Newport, They are diÅ¿perÅ¿ed by Lilburn's men, Derby and others being taken. they fall in amongÅ¿t Lilburn's men, who eaÅ¿ily rout and put them to Å¿light, being quite Å¿pent with fatigue; the Earl of Derby (whom the impious Rebels afterwards condemned in a Council of War, and put to Death), Lauderdale, (who for his Loyalty Å¿uffered a tedious ImpriÅ¿onment, until the King's ReÅ¿tauration) and others, whom it would be long to name, being taken. Nay LeÅ¿ly was not got far beyond Newport,

A full account where the King lurked in England. But now what befel the King, the Care of Providence, Hopes of the EngliÅ¿h Race, and Defender of the Church, Å¿ince the EngliÅ¿h, I know, are inÅ¿atiably deÅ¿irous to be informed of it, and
that hardly in any Age a more remarkable adventure hath happened, I Å¿hall, according, as I have heard it from the King's own Mouth, relate with Å¿ome exactneÅ¿s and curioÅ¿ity.

Towards the Evening, Richard brings him into his HouÅ¿e that Å¿tood hard by,In the Evening he comes to Richard Pendrell's HouÅ¿e; where he prepares for a New Journey, that he was to take that Night. For the King amongÅ¿t other things had asked, If he knew any Faithful,

At Madely he is lodged in a Barn,At length they come to Madely, where Pendrell knocking at the Door, is preÅ¿ently let in. The GueÅ¿t is kindly received by Wolfe, who being acquainted with the deÅ¿ign, lodges him in the Barn, becauÅ¿e in the day time his HouÅ¿e was Å¿eldom free from Souldiers. therefore it would be very difficult and unÅ¿afe to paÅ¿s the River.The River being Å¿trictly guarded, he returns into the Wood from whence he came. Being come back before Day, he tarried in the Wood, till Richard went to Å¿ee if any Souldiers were in BoÅ¿cobel HouÅ¿e; but he finds none there Å¿ave Colonel Carlos, whom we mentioned before to have, with others, kept the Cromwellians in Play at Sudbury-gate, who being born thereabouts, was juÅ¿t come to a Friends HouÅ¿e, to beg a little Bread.Early in the Morning he is by Carlos brought into BoÅ¿cobel-houÅ¿eâª

Humphrey, another of the five Brothers of the Pendrells, who kept a Mill hard by, had gone
to Sheffual to pay his AÅ¿Å¿eÅ¿Å¿ment; where, in the HouÅ¿e of Captain Broadway Collector of the Money, he accidentally met with an Oliverian Colonel, who very earneÅ¿tly Å¿ought after the King; and hearing that this Countrey-man lived near the Abbey of Whitladies, he asked him if he knew any thing of the King, or of the Abbey: Pendrell the Miller being asked concerning the King, adding, That if any would diÅ¿cover him, he might gain a thouÅ¿and pounds Sterling; but that if he were found to have concealed, or hid him, he would undoubtedly Å¿uffer death for it. In the mean time John Pendrell, when he was Å¿hewing the Lord Wilmot his way to London, found it every where Å¿o peÅ¿tered with Souldiers, that he thought it Å¿afeÅ¿t to hide him and his HorÅ¿e in a Marle-pit, Wilmot coming out of a Marle-pit, is committed to the care of Whitgrave. until he could find out a more commodious lurking place; and at length he happily committed him to the truÅ¿t of Whitgrave and HudleÅ¿tone, (though both Roman Catholicks) HudleÅ¿tone being Tutor in the HouÅ¿e to Mr. Whitgrave's three Sons. The Å¿ame day Soldiers make a new Å¿earch in the Abbey, The King is again Å¿earched after in the Abbey. having been informed by an EnÅ¿ign who was made PriÅ¿oner, that the King certainly abÅ¿conded there; for that he had Å¿een him with
Å¿ome other Company arrive there, and that he had obÅ¿erved no Å¿uch perÅ¿on depart from thence. The night following his MajeÅ¿ty having drawn a Bill of Exchange upon a Merchant in London, for Money to be payed to his Landlord, that if it Å¿hould come to the knowledge of the Parricides, that he had been harboured in that houÅ¿e, he with the reÅ¿t concerned might have wherewithal to Å¿hift for themÅ¿elves, and get beyond Sea, took his leave of Whitgrave, his Wife, and HudleÅ¿tone; and committed himÅ¿elf and Wilmot to the protection of Colonel Lane, to be conducted to Bently. He removes to Bently, from thence to go to BriÅ¿tol as the Å¿ervant of Jane Lane. Where his Å¿iÅ¿ter Jane Lane undertook to carry him to BriÅ¿tol where he hoped he might have a paÅ¿Å¿age; having in this manner laid her deÅ¿ign. She procured from a certain Colonel of the Rebels, a paÅ¿sport for her Å¿elf, a Gentleman and his Wife, with one Servant, mounted upon two HorÅ¿es, that they might Å¿afely and without moleÅ¿tation travel to the houÅ¿e of one Norton near BriÅ¿tol, whoÅ¿e Wife was ready to lye in. Her Å¿iÅ¿ter Jane muÅ¿t needs be at her Labour; and could not have better Company to go along with her, than her CouÅ¿in and
her Husband; which was a Scheme very well contrived. Without more delay, the King mounts on HorÅ¿e-back, riding before Jane as her Servant. LaÅ¿Å¿els, her CouÅ¿in,He Å¿ets forth upon his journey, accompanied with LaÅ¿Å¿els and Wilmot, with his Wife follows after: Wilmot rides before with a Hawk on his FiÅ¿t, as a Å¿tranger who had accidentally met them on the Rode; reÅ¿olving Å¿o Å¿oon as they came near BriÅ¿tol, to Å¿trike off to the houÅ¿e of his friend Sir John Winter, there to expect the IÅ¿Å¿ue of things. The firÅ¿t remarkable accident that happened,At BromÅ¿grove he falls in diÅ¿courÅ¿e with a Smith about himÅ¿elf. was at BromÅ¿grove; for the King's HorÅ¿e loÅ¿ing a Shoe, His MajeÅ¿ty was to carry him to a Smith to be Å¿hod. When they were come near to Stratford, they had a mind to foard over the River of Avon, about a mile below the Town: But drawing nearer, they perceived Soldiers HorÅ¿es feeding in the Meadows, and the Troopers lying upon the ground, on the other Å¿ide. There they conÅ¿ult what was beÅ¿t to be done. The King was for going confidently on; but LaÅ¿Å¿els, thinking Å¿till on the Injury which he had lately received from the Soldiers, thought it Å¿afer to

On the third day, leaving BriÅ¿tol three Miles to the left,Then at Marsfield, and the third day at Norton, where he pretends himÅ¿elf Å¿ick. they arrived at Norton's houÅ¿e; where Jane cauÅ¿ed a Bed to be made in a private Chamber for the King, who Å¿he Å¿aid, was the Son of one of her Father's Tenants, and was Å¿ick of an Ague, getting Doctor Gorge to give him Å¿omewhat for his DiÅ¿temper.

But withal begs leave to impart the Å¿ecret not only to his Mother and Wife, but alÅ¿o to four Servants, of whoÅ¿e faithfulneÅ¿s both to his Majesty and himÅ¿elf he was fully aÅ¿Å¿ured. VVilmot

They go to Carew-CaÅ¿tle, The appointed hour of their coming drawing nigh, VVindham and his Wife, as if to take a walk, went out to meet them; and Å¿end the King privately into the houÅ¿e, by one whom they had choÅ¿en for that purpoÅ¿e:And next day to Trent, where VVindam lived. He readily liÅ¿tened to it, and preÅ¿ently went to Chayermouth, near to Lime; Elden freights a Ship at Chayermouth. where having Å¿ent for the MaÅ¿ter of a Ship, he asked him, under promiÅ¿e of Å¿ecreÅ¿ie, if he durÅ¿t venture to carry VVilmot and his Å¿ervant Å¿afely over to France. Hitherto all things Å¿ucceeding according to their expectation; there only wanted a pretext of Å¿taying in Lodgings, till all things might be made ready for their paÅ¿Å¿age. Leaving therefore Trent, the King Å¿ets out towards Chayermouth, with Juliana Conisbey his pretended Bride, who was privy to the matter,The King goes thither, carrying Juliana Conisbey with him as his Bride. riding behind him upon the Å¿ame HorÅ¿e. From thence the Merchant goes to Lime, that he might give notice to the MaÅ¿ter of the Ship, to be in readineÅ¿s to put to Sea at the appointed time; The King with the reÅ¿t went to their Lodgings at Chayermouth; and Peters to Å¿tay for the Boat. But having waited till it was almoÅ¿t day, he returned without any News of the arrival of the Boat.But loÅ¿ing hopes of a Ship, he preÅ¿ently departs This put them all into diÅ¿order; and made them think of taking other meaÅ¿ures, there was no Å¿afe place here to Å¿tay in; and the King was reÅ¿olved not to loyter a moment.

After a Å¿hort conÅ¿ultation, the King with Juliana, and the Colonel accompanying them, advance towards Bridport, there to expect the coming of the Lord VVilmot and Peters in an appointed Inn. But Elden the Merchant, who thought
that by this time they had made half their Voyage, could not imagine the reaÅ¿on of the breach of promiÅ¿e, nor could he attribute it to any thing elÅ¿e, Å¿ave that the man taking his leave of his Friends, it being then the Market-day at Lime, had drank Å¿o much as to make him forget the prefixed time.Why the MaÅ¿ter of the VeÅ¿Å¿el failed Å¿o foully. But it was known afterward, that the MaÅ¿ter of the VeÅ¿Å¿el being come home, to take clean Cloaths and other neceÅ¿Å¿aries for his Voyage with him, was locked up in his Chamber, and bolted in by his Wife: For that very day a Proclamation had been made in the Town, whereby it was declared Death for any PerÅ¿on to aid or conceal the King; and a thouÅ¿and Pounds promiÅ¿ed to any that could apprehend him. EÅ¿pecially in Sir Hugh Windham's houÅ¿e. The IÅ¿le of Mann alÅ¿o tak â¢ n. Next follows the IÅ¿le of Mann, this place, though defended by Feminine Valour, to wit, by the CounteÅ¿s of Derby, yet vied Å¿o much in honour with men, that it was doubtful, whether, in the Royal CauÅ¿e, Sir George Cartright, or Å¿he, fell the laÅ¿t Victim under the Hands of the Traytors.

An Act of Oblivion paÅ¿Å¿esAll the Provinces thus Å¿ubdued, an Act of Oblivion paÅ¿Å¿es, whereby the memory of what was paÅ¿t being aboliÅ¿hed, all Crimes whatÅ¿oever are pardoned. But this was hampered with Å¿o many Limitations, ReÅ¿trictions, Exceptions, and enÅ¿naring ClauÅ¿es, that there was little hopes for true Penitents to expect any good from it. But Å¿uch,But not without the inÅ¿tance of Cromwell. however, as it was, Cromwell alone was to be thanked for it, by him chiefly it was propoÅ¿ed, and by his means and endeavours it paÅ¿t in the Rump-Parliament, that, by Å¿o doing, he might by a Å¿hew of kindneÅ¿s claw the Å¿uffering and vanquiÅ¿hed People, and at the Å¿ame time heap hatred and indignation upon the Heads of his fellow Traytors. The Soldiers diÅ¿pleaÅ¿ed with the Rump. But the hatred and animoÅ¿ities betwixt the Rump and the Soldiers, the Seeds whereof had been long ago Å¿own, though during the common danger they appeared not, began now to Å¿how
themÅ¿elves, and, after long and mutual grudges, to break out into Flames, and to devour one another. So rare a thing it is for Thieves and Robbers, to agree long together. The Soldiers object,Which with theÅ¿e Crimes they load, that theÅ¿e men did for ever appropriate to themÅ¿elves and their Friends all places of Honour and Command, barring all others from any Å¿hare with them; and that under colour of the publick good, they divided amongÅ¿t themÅ¿elves all profitable Offices, without any regard to the Publick. For what end had they taken Arms againÅ¿t the King? expoÅ¿ed their lives to Å¿o many dangers, ript up the bowels of their Country-men and friends? Did they bring the King to the Block, (for in that execrable Villany they triumphed) that they might only Å¿ettle them in their Seats, Å¿o as they might Å¿ecurely live at their eaÅ¿e for ever, and, right or wrong, domineer over all without any diÅ¿tinction, and Murder and Sacrifice to their own private LuÅ¿t or Revenge, as many Subjects as they pleaÅ¿ed? Away with it, Å¿ay they, it were better to return to the old way of Government, RaiÅ¿e King CHARLES from the Dead, and Å¿ubmit to his Rule, Å¿eeing it was known that he followed the Laws, and accordingly Å¿quared the adminiÅ¿tration of his Government. They therefore earneÅ¿tly deÅ¿ire, That at length an end might be put to the Parliament, a new and fair RepreÅ¿entative choÅ¿en by the good people, and that the Laws might be reformed; beÅ¿ides the many other things which had already Å¿o often cloyed them with Petitions.

The goodly Warriours made theÅ¿e Å¿pecious demands,As minding onely their own advantages, not out of a pure zeal for the Publick good; but that having baulked them, by determining their Authority, they themÅ¿elves might have their turn in the Government;
hoping that by branding them with theÅ¿e reproachful Characters, they would at length be fain to put the Power into their hands.

The Objections are boldly enough anÅ¿wered.On the other hand the Rump-Members, MagiÅ¿terially grave, by a long poÅ¿Å¿eÅ¿Å¿ion of Authority, bid the Soldiers mind their own Affairs, look to their Arms, and obey Orders, that they, to whom the care of the Common-wealth was committed, and the buÅ¿ineÅ¿s of Å¿ettling a new Government, having long laboured in the Affair, with no Å¿mall ProgreÅ¿s, would at length by the help of God bring it to perfection. They bid them have a care, in the mean time, that they make no Tumults, Å¿eeing they who had pulled a King from his Throne, wanted neither ReÅ¿olution nor Force to reduce into order licentious Souldiers, though milder courÅ¿es were more pleaÅ¿ant to them.

The Soldiers reply.But the Soldiers diÅ¿daining that they Å¿hould be thought pragmatical, and medlers in Affairs that did not belong unto them, anÅ¿wer thoÅ¿e State-AdviÅ¿ers, That they were not Mercenary Soldiers, nor had not taken up Arms only in ProÅ¿pect of pay, but for maintenance of the Publick Liberty, neither would they lay them down till they found the common Fruit of their endeavours. That they ought not to boaÅ¿t of putting the King to Death, (Å¿o they mutually gloried in that Horrid Villany) Å¿ince they onely Å¿tood by, as in DiÅ¿guiÅ¿e and MaÅ¿querade; but that they by their Valour, and at their own Peril, accompliÅ¿hed the thing, at the mention of which they would have Å¿tarted, had they not been encouraged, and Å¿et on by men of the Sword.

The Rump, therefore, being now more afraid of their Servants and idle Soldiers, than formerly of the Royal Enemy, endeavour by all ways to reduce them to Obedience, or at leaÅ¿t
fairly to diÅ¿miÅ¿s and disband them,Of whom therefore the Rump, under another pretence, order a great part to be disbanded. but Å¿till under another pretence, alledging that the Commonwealth was not able to entertain Å¿o many idle and lazy Soldiers. Wherefore, under colour of leÅ¿Å¿ening the Charges of the Publick, they paÅ¿s an Act for Disbanding part of the Army, and the reÅ¿t to have but half pay, and to be divided and Å¿eparated in Å¿everal Countries; that at once they might Å¿ecure themÅ¿elves againÅ¿t the attempts of the Cavaliers, and take from their own Souldiers all opportunity of making Innovations.

The Soldiers Å¿mell out the deÅ¿ign, and it prickt them to the heart, that they were now to be caÅ¿t down from that height, from whence they received plentiful incomes, and almoÅ¿t Å¿hared in the Government: They take it very ill to be cut Å¿hort of their pay, of their domineering, after their accuÅ¿tomed manner, in the Countries, and of making their own advantages in Å¿uppreÅ¿Å¿ing the beginnings of Sedition. Therefore the Officers refuÅ¿e to be disbanded, reciprocally pretending the Publick good.The Soldiers refuÅ¿ing, and demanding a new RepreÅ¿entative, They alÅ¿o frame a Petition, Å¿uch as they had formerly preÅ¿ented, with propoÅ¿als much to the Å¿ame effect, and deÅ¿ire a Å¿peedier anÅ¿wer; nor would they lay down their Arms, before the remnant of the old Parliament being aboliÅ¿h'd, a RepreÅ¿entative were lawfully choÅ¿en, and that for the greater expedition, An equal numb â¢ r of both conÅ¿ult in common, Å¿ome of the Officers of the Army, as CommiÅ¿Å¿ioners, Å¿hould be admitted into the HouÅ¿e, or at leaÅ¿t Å¿it and debate about the PropoÅ¿als with the Members of Parliament. The Rump condeÅ¿cending to this, twelve of each party meet and conÅ¿ult in common: Where, Oliver St Johns, more skilful than the reÅ¿t in the Common Law,But without any Fruit. raiÅ¿ing Å¿cruples, and perplexing matters that were clear in themÅ¿elves, Å¿o confounded the Rude Soldiers,
that about one word, they Å¿pent above two Months.

TheÅ¿e PropoÅ¿als were alÅ¿o debated in the Rump:The Rumpers are divided about the manner of the RepreÅ¿entative, but Å¿ince it would be tedious to mention all of them, I Å¿hall briefly, onely relate with what Å¿harpneÅ¿s and quite oppoÅ¿ite Opinions they claÅ¿hed about the RepreÅ¿entative. Some were for Å¿haping it after this manner, Å¿ome after another, and Å¿ome after none at all. The Presbyterians, who were but few in number, are for having it conform to the Solemn League and Covenant, a Å¿trict and previous InquiÅ¿ition being made into the Manners and Religion of the men. The Æ²topians dreamt of, I know not what Olygarchy made up of the Godlier Party, winnowed and Å¿ifted to the higheÅ¿t Purity. Others were for a kind of Circulation, that every one Å¿ucceÅ¿Å¿ively and in courÅ¿e might have their turns in the Government.And about the Time; BeÅ¿ides there was no leÅ¿s Å¿trife about the Time. Some thought it very dangerous, nay, without doubt fatal, to aÅ¿Å¿ign any day of diÅ¿Å¿olution, and to introduce a new RepreÅ¿entative.Not willing to give the Power raÅ¿hly out of their own hands. Others would have no Å¿uch change to be made, but every third, fourth, or fifth year. But thoÅ¿e who were in Power, think it Å¿afeÅ¿t, that new Members Å¿hould be choÅ¿en in place of thoÅ¿e that died or were turned out. And moÅ¿t Votes agreed in this; which they forthwith enacted, though the night before they had privately promiÅ¿ed the contrary to the Officers, to wit that they would model a new RepreÅ¿entative.

Cromwell flying to the HouÅ¿e, and objecting to them MiÅ¿demeanours and other horrid Crimes,So Å¿oon as Cromwell heard of that, he haÅ¿tens to the Parliament HouÅ¿e, ordering ten or twelve Soldiers to follow him, and Å¿tay for him at the door. He himÅ¿elf, accompanied only with Fleetwood, entring in: To this purpoÅ¿e
Å¿pake to the Speaker: You have Å¿ufficiently impoÅ¿ed upon the People, and provided for your Å¿elves and Relations; you have long cheated the Country, by your Å¿itting here under pretext of Å¿ettling the Commonwealth, reforming the Laws, and procuring the Common Good; whilÅ¿t in the mean time you have onely invaded the Wealth of the State, Å¿crewed your Å¿elves and Relations into all Places of Honour and Profit, to feed your own Luxury and Impiety. Then Å¿tamping with his Foot, which was the Signal to the Soldiers without, For Å¿hame, Å¿aid he, get ye gone, give place to honeÅ¿ter Men, Commands all to be gone. and thoÅ¿e that will more faithfully diÅ¿charge their TruÅ¿t. But whilÅ¿t all, Å¿urpriÅ¿ed by this Å¿udden ConÅ¿ternation, held their tongues, one had the boldneÅ¿s to tell him, It Å¿uits ill with your Excellencies JuÅ¿tice, to brand us all promiÅ¿cuouÅ¿ly and in general, without any Proof of a Crime. At which being a little more heated, taking hold of one by the Cloke, Thou art a WhoremaÅ¿ter, Å¿ays he; to another, Thou art an Adulterer; to a third, Thou art a Drunkard and Glutton; to a fourth, Thou art an Extortioner: And the MuÅ¿quetiers ruÅ¿hing in, he excludes them all,And they delaying, by the aÅ¿Å¿iÅ¿tance of the Soldiers he expelled them the HouÅ¿e, and commands the Parliament to be diÅ¿Å¿olved; whilÅ¿t HarriÅ¿on gently pulled the Speaker out of his Chair, being unwilling to riÅ¿e, and Å¿ent him going. So that that vaÅ¿t, horrid, and many-headed MonÅ¿ter, whoÅ¿e Bellowing had made all Europe to Å¿hake, is by one Å¿ingle Puff of Cromwell's Breath diÅ¿perÅ¿ed and Å¿cattered, no body regretting, but rather all the People rejoycing at it. So, Government baÅ¿ely got, is baÅ¿ely loÅ¿t. Nay, to compleat their PuniÅ¿hment,And makes them ridiculous. they were ridiculed, a Bill being Å¿et upon the Door, with, This HouÅ¿e is to be Let. They were alÅ¿o Lampoon'd by the Ballad-Å¿ingers about Town, who cried
publickly about the City, Twelve Parliament-men for a Peny. Next day the Council of State, and Privy Council, are in the Å¿ame manner Å¿ent packing by Cromwell, leÅ¿t, if any remained, the Rooks might breed again.

By this Å¿o acceptable an Action, he Å¿o blotted out the Memory of his paÅ¿t Villanies, that for a time he was rather look'd upon as a Saviour;The People rejoycing, the Shouts and Bonfires that were made, Å¿ufficiently expreÅ¿Å¿ing the Joys of the People, for being delivered from Å¿o cruel a Yoke. They praiÅ¿e the Freedom the General took,And much applauding him. in not fearing to charge his Impotent MaÅ¿ters to their Faces, with the Vices that were publickly talked of; Å¿ome few in the mean time obÅ¿erving, that whilÅ¿t he himÅ¿elf now accuÅ¿ed thoÅ¿e whom before he had commended, he had then preferred Å¿uch as he might afterwards moÅ¿t juÅ¿tly accuÅ¿e. For he had Å¿o purged the Parliament, as caÅ¿ting away the Flower, he had for his own purpoÅ¿e reÅ¿erved the Bran, to be likewiÅ¿e thrown away when he had a mind to it. The Rump-Members loaded with publick Hatred, and Å¿ad Hearts, departed home, as they were commanded; for there was a NeceÅ¿Å¿ity that they muÅ¿t fall at the PleaÅ¿ure of thoÅ¿e, at whoÅ¿e PleaÅ¿ure they choÅ¿e to Å¿tand; and Å¿ince they could not thrive in their Trade, without obeying their Guardians, the Injuries of the Soldiers were to be born with, and onely whiÅ¿pered. But they find no other Patron. The Publick, indeed, grieved not at their DiÅ¿aÅ¿ter, as if the Office of the Laws had been Å¿hut; but triumphantly inÅ¿ulted over them, as a Den of Thieves now broken up and diÅ¿perÅ¿ed.

But the Commonwealth was Å¿till reÅ¿erved to Å¿adder Bondage, Cromwell now, as General of the
Army, arrogating to himÅ¿elf the Supreme Authority. Yet that he might remove all Å¿uÅ¿picion of any Å¿uch ambitious DeÅ¿ign, and render the Å¿ame more Å¿ecure and Å¿table by gradual and crafty InÅ¿inuations; as alÅ¿o that he might gull the Demotratical Republicans, They conÅ¿ult, in the mean time, what is fitteÅ¿t to be done. it is decreed in a Council of the Officers, That the Supreme Power Å¿hould be committed to Godly and Pious Men, to the number of an hundred and forty four, during the Å¿pace of Å¿ix Months; who Å¿hould have power to moderate, and with Å¿uch Prudence Å¿ettle all things, that all Sin and Vice being rooted out, Peace and Concord might flouriÅ¿h in the Nations. Therefore the Officers of the Army,The Officers advance the Godly to the Government, with ConÅ¿ent of Cromwell, call out of every County and Corporation a proportionable number of the holieÅ¿t Men whom either they knew, or could find out, (the civiller, or rather moÅ¿t pragmatical Å¿ort of the Private Soldiers being permitted to name Å¿ome) whom they place at the Helm of Government, to conÅ¿ult about the difficult Affairs of Three Kingdoms: Illiterate Men for the moÅ¿t part,ChoÅ¿en from among the Off-Å¿cowrings of the People, and out of all Sects: and the Off-Å¿cowrings of the People; and theÅ¿e alÅ¿o Bigots, AnabaptiÅ¿ts, Fifth-monarchy-men, Democraticks, Fanaticks, and, in a word, the moÅ¿t villanous Incendiaries of all the Sects. But with thoÅ¿e were mingled Cromwell's cunninger Adherents, whom, being moÅ¿t obnoxious, he had endeared to himÅ¿elf by Favour, that as occaÅ¿ion offered they might Å¿way the reÅ¿t, and check their mad CounÅ¿els.

TheÅ¿e being met in the Parliament-houÅ¿e,
Who having choÅ¿en a Speaker,
Take the Name of The Parliament of England;
their firÅ¿t Care is to chuÅ¿e one Rous, a Smatterer in Letters, for Speaker; and then, to give themÅ¿elves a Title; which, after much Preliminary DiÅ¿pute, was at length concluded to be, The Parliament of England. This done, they
Å¿et to work. But, Good God! what Å¿trange ConfuÅ¿ion preÅ¿ently aroÅ¿e? Which Cromwell and the other cunning Rogues foreÅ¿eeing would undoubtedly happen, laughed in their Sleeve, that they being hampered and entangled in Difficulties, would with univerÅ¿al ApplauÅ¿e and Gratulation deliver up to Cromwell alone the Å¿ole AdminiÅ¿tration of Government.

They reÅ¿olved to make way for the Monarchy of ChriÅ¿t upon Earth, propheÅ¿ying his PerÅ¿onal PreÅ¿ence to be at hand: Therefore they pronounce PrieÅ¿thood to be Popery;And preÅ¿ently Å¿hew their madneÅ¿s, in falling Å¿oul of the MiniÅ¿ters, Colleges, and Nobility. paying of Tythes, JudaiÅ¿m; the Laws of England, the Remains of the Norman Yoke; Schools and Colleges, HeatheniÅ¿h Seminaries of curious and vain Learning; Nobility, laÅ¿tly, and Honours, contray to the Law of Nature, and ChriÅ¿tianity: all which they would have wholly aboliÅ¿hed, and pluck'd up by the Roots; and without doubt had done Å¿o, had not the few of SenÅ¿e that were amongÅ¿t them put a Å¿top to it.

They aboliÅ¿h all Courts of JuÅ¿tice.However, in effect they aboliÅ¿h the Court of Chancery, and all the Judicatures that were wont to be kept in WeÅ¿tminÅ¿ter-hall. By one or two Acts was that prodigious Parliament renowned:Appoint JuÅ¿tices of Peace to celebrate Marriage. For, Marriage, which from the very Birth of the Church of England was never celebrated but by Church-men, they commit to the Care of JuÅ¿tices of the Peace; as if in an Affair of Å¿o great moment, there were no need of Solemn Prayers, nor of the Benediction of the Church. They leave alÅ¿o the Publication of the Bans of Matrimony, which uÅ¿ed always thrice to be made in time of Divine Service, to the choice of the Parties, either to have it made in the Church or Market-place. A RegiÅ¿ter alÅ¿o is appointed to be kept, not of the
ChriÅ¿tnings, but of the Birth of Children: Å¿o that from hence you may gueÅ¿s what a kind of new Reformers theÅ¿e were.

But when Cromwell had Å¿uffered them to give the People Å¿ufficient Proofs of their MadneÅ¿s, and to work Fear and Hatred alÅ¿o in their Fellow-Subjects, Å¿ome of them who had more Å¿enÅ¿e,The Å¿ounder part deliver up the Government to Cromwell, who with reluctancy accepts it; upon a day appointed went with their Speaker to attend him, earneÅ¿tly beÅ¿eeching him to take upon himÅ¿elf the Supreme Authority, now again fallen at his Feet. Cromwell made a Å¿hew of wonder, denying utterly and rejecting it; but at length, with much ado, Å¿uffered himÅ¿elf to be prevailed upon; but with this Condition, That an InÅ¿trument or Form of the Thing, under Hand and Seal, Å¿hould be given him.

This being done, though the Inferiour Officers of the Army and the Republicans were againÅ¿t it, who promiÅ¿ed to themÅ¿elves profitable Places under that Government, and a Licencious Liberty of domineering, or at leaÅ¿t conÅ¿tant and Å¿tanding Commands in the Army; yet Lambert,
Lambert chiefly, and by his perÅ¿uaÅ¿ion the reÅ¿t of the Officers conÅ¿enting. who at preÅ¿ent promiÅ¿ed himÅ¿elf the Second Place in the Government, and afterterwards the FirÅ¿t, hiding a proud Ambition under a Cloke of Humility, by Words, and by his Example, perÅ¿uaded the other Officers not onely to comply with that Monarchy, but alÅ¿o to Å¿tickle for and deÅ¿ire it. So now the Name of a Commonwealth Å¿tinks, and the Popular State, which heretofore they gloried in, is deÅ¿piÅ¿ed. The Single Government of One PerÅ¿on onely pleaÅ¿es them; and, what heretofore they had curÅ¿ed with Å¿o many private and publick Imprecations, after a ConÅ¿ultation with the Officers, is declared to be the Government of this Nation.
Yet Cromwell would not accept of it by the Title of KING, But he would be called Protector, not King. though he was perÅ¿uaded to it by many, leÅ¿t he might Å¿eem to make Shipwrack of all ModeÅ¿ty, and too openly to prevaricate: But joyning together a Commonwealth, and Single Government, which formerly were inconÅ¿iÅ¿tent, under the Title of Protector he takes into his Hands the Reins of Government, modelled according to the Conditions of an InÅ¿trument, which here we Å¿hall inÅ¿ert.

div.head: THE InÅ¿trument of Government.
div.p: THat the Supreme LegiÅ¿lative Authority Å¿hould be in a Single PerÅ¿on and the People in Parliament; but the AdminiÅ¿tration thereof to be left to the Lord Protector and to his Council, whereof the Number was not to be above Twenty and one.

That all Charters, Patents, Writs, and CommiÅ¿Å¿ions, Å¿hould be paÅ¿Å¿ed by the Protector: All Power of MagiÅ¿tracy, Honours, and Titles, to be deriv'd from him. LikewiÅ¿e the Pardon of all Offences, excepting TreaÅ¿on and Murder. He alÅ¿o to have the AdminiÅ¿tration of all things, with the Advice of his Council, and according to the Tenor of this InÅ¿trument.

That the Militia, Å¿itting the Parliament, Å¿hould be in the diÅ¿poÅ¿al of the Protector and the Parliament; but in the Intervals, in the Protector and his Council. The Power alÅ¿o of making Peace and War with Foreign Princes, to be in the Protector and his Council: but he to have no Authority of Repealing or Making any Laws, without the ConÅ¿ent of Parliament.

That the Parliament Å¿hould be called before the end of Six Months then next enÅ¿uing, and afterwards once in Three years, or oftner if need require; and that it Å¿hould not be in the Protector's Power to DiÅ¿Å¿olve the Å¿ame for the firÅ¿t Five Months, without the ConÅ¿ent of the HouÅ¿e.

That the Number of Members for England Å¿hould conÅ¿iÅ¿t of full Four hundred, Elected according to an equal DiÅ¿tribution: for Scotland Thirty, and for Ireland the like Number; the Number for each County and City to be alÅ¿o aÅ¿Å¿igned.

That the Calling of Å¿uch Parliament Å¿hould be under the Seal of the Commonwealth, by Writs to the Sheriff in the Protector's Name. But if the Protector Å¿hould not call the Å¿ame within the times limited, the Chancellor then to do it, under the Penalty of High TreaÅ¿on; and if he Å¿hould fail therein, then that the Sheriffs Å¿hould peform it. And after Å¿uch Election Å¿hould be made, to be tranÅ¿mitted by the Chief MagiÅ¿trate, by Indenture, to the Chancellor, Å¿igned with his Hand, Twenty days before the Sitting of the Å¿ame Parliament. AlÅ¿o if the Sheriff or Mayor Å¿hould make a falÅ¿e Return, that he be fined in Two thouÅ¿and Marks.

That none Å¿hould be capable to Elect, who had ever born Arms againÅ¿t the Parliament, or been Actors in the IriÅ¿h Rebellion. Nor that any PapiÅ¿t Å¿hould ever be capable to give his Voice. And that all Elections against theÅ¿e Rules Å¿hould be void, and the TranÅ¿greÅ¿Å¿ors fined at Two years Value of their Revenues, and a third part of their Goods.
That no PerÅ¿on under the age of One and twenty years, Å¿hould be capable of being Elected; nor any other than of known Credit, fearing God, and of good Behaviour.
No Man likewiÅ¿e to have Power of Electing, whoÅ¿e EÅ¿tate Å¿hould not be worth 20 l. per An. Sterling.

That the Return of the PerÅ¿ons Elected Å¿hould be tranÅ¿mitted by Prothonotary in Chancery, unto the Council of State, within two days after they Å¿hould come to his Hands, to the end that Judgment might be made of the PerÅ¿ons, if any QueÅ¿tion Å¿hould ariÅ¿e touching the LawfulneÅ¿s of the Choice.
That Sixty Members Å¿hould be accounted a Parliament, in caÅ¿e the reÅ¿t be abÅ¿ent. NevertheleÅ¿s, that it Å¿hould be lawful to the Protector to call a Parliament when he Å¿hall Å¿ee cauÅ¿e.

That the Bills agreed on in Parliament Å¿hould be preÅ¿ented to the Protector, for his AÅ¿Å¿ent thereto; and if he Å¿hould not give his AÅ¿Å¿ent to them within Twenty days, that then they Å¿hould have the force of Laws without it.

That if any CounÅ¿ellor of State Å¿hould die, or be outed of his Place for Corruption, in the Intervals of Parliament, the Protector, with the reÅ¿t of the Council, to Å¿ubÅ¿titute another in his Å¿tead.

That a certain Annual Tax Å¿hould be made throughout the Three Commonwealths, for the Maintenance of Ten thouÅ¿and HorÅ¿e, and Fifteen thouÅ¿and Foot; which Tax Å¿hould alÅ¿o Å¿upply the Charge of the Navy: And that this Rate Å¿hould not be leÅ¿Å¿ened or altered by the Parliament, without the ConÅ¿ent of the Protector and his Council. But if it Å¿hould not be thought neceÅ¿Å¿ary hereafter that any Army Å¿hould be maintained, then whatÅ¿oever SurpluÅ¿age of this Tax Å¿hould be, to be kept in the TreaÅ¿ury for Å¿udden Emergencies.

That if there might happen to be occaÅ¿ion of making extraordinary Choices, and to raiÅ¿e new Forces, it Å¿hould not be done without ConÅ¿ent of Parliament; but that in the Intervals of Parliament it Å¿hould be lawful for the Protector and his Å¿aid Council, both to make new Laws, and to raiÅ¿e Monies for the preÅ¿ent Exigencies.

That all the Lands, ForeÅ¿ts, and JuriÅ¿dictions, not then Å¿old by the Parliament, whether they had belonged to the King, Queen, Prince, BiÅ¿hops, or any Delinquents whatÅ¿oever, Å¿hould thenceforth remain to the Protector.
That the Office of Protector Å¿hould thenceforth be Elective; but that none of the King's Line Å¿hould be ever capable thereof; and that the Election Å¿hould belong to the Council.
That for the preÅ¿ent Oliver Cromwell Å¿hould be Protector.

That the Great Offices of the Commonwealth, viz. Chancellor, Keeper of the Seal, Governour of Ireland, Admiral, TreaÅ¿urer, in caÅ¿e they Å¿hould become void in Parliament-time, to be filled up by the approbation of Parliament; and in the Intervals, by the like approbation of the Council.

That the ChriÅ¿tian Religion, as it is contained by Holy Scripture, Å¿hould be the Publick ProfeÅ¿Å¿ion of the Nation; and that thoÅ¿e who were to have the Care thereof, Å¿hould have their Support from the Publick; Å¿o that it be with Å¿ome other more convenient Maintenance, and leÅ¿s Å¿ubject to Envy, than by Tythes.
That no Man Å¿hall be by any Fine or Penalty whatÅ¿oever, forced to Comply with the Å¿aid Publick ProfeÅ¿Å¿ion, otherwiÅ¿e than by PerÅ¿uaÅ¿ions and Arguments.

That no man ProfeÅ¿Å¿ing Faith in ChriÅ¿t, Å¿hould be prohibited the ExerciÅ¿e of his own Religion, Å¿o that he diÅ¿turb not any other: but that neither Popery or Prelacy Å¿hould be permitted the leaÅ¿t Favour or Licence; and that all Laws to the contrary Å¿hould be void.
That all Agreements made by Parliament Å¿hould be firm and Å¿table; All Articles of Peace made with DomeÅ¿tick Enemies, made good.

That all Protectors, in their Order, Å¿hould be obliged by Oath, at their firÅ¿t taking upon them the Government, by all means to procure the Peace, Welfare, and Quiet of the Commonwealth; by no means to violate the preÅ¿ent Agreements; and laÅ¿tly, to his Power to adminiÅ¿ter all things according to the Laws, Statutes, and Customs of England.

Cromwell Å¿wears to his own Conditions, and preÅ¿ently chuÅ¿es CounÅ¿ellors out of every Sect.To theÅ¿e Conditions Cromwell Å¿wears, and then cunningly chuÅ¿es his Privy-CounÅ¿ellors; which he Å¿o dexterouÅ¿ly pack'd, that though they differed in Quality and Inclinations amongÅ¿t themÅ¿elves, yet all were equally at his devotion. Of every Sect he chuÅ¿es Å¿ome Leading Men, by whoÅ¿e means he might gain the reÅ¿t of the Å¿ame Stamp: Officers alÅ¿o of the Army, eÅ¿pecially the Higher, and thoÅ¿e who were moÅ¿t in Favour and Authority with the People. AmongÅ¿t them were AnabaptiÅ¿ts, Independents, and Presbyterians; IriÅ¿h and Scots; all Å¿orts of Republicans; and, until all Liberty of Ingenuous Minds was reÅ¿trained, Å¿ome RoyaliÅ¿ts alÅ¿o. The Reins of theÅ¿e Å¿o many and different Opinions, Factions, Nations, and Sects, the skilful Driver, being himÅ¿elf of no Faith nor certain ProfeÅ¿Å¿ion, took into his Hands, and turned them at his pleaÅ¿ure; now inclining to one Å¿ide, now to the other; Å¿ometime approving the greater, and Å¿ometime the Å¿maller number of Votes; being ready at every turn to diÅ¿miÅ¿s thoÅ¿e that were head-Å¿trong. And thus aÅ¿Å¿iÅ¿ted by his CounÅ¿ellors, he takes upon him the AdminiÅ¿tration of the Commonwealth.

What were the thoughts of men in this great Revolution.Out of fear, few withÅ¿tand this Å¿o great a Change in Affairs, and many applaud it: ThoÅ¿e who are of a contrary Opinion, Å¿tand in amaze, and conceal their Thoughts. Presbyterians, Independents,
RoyaliÅ¿ts, NeutraliÅ¿ts, and all, chuÅ¿e rather to acquieÅ¿ce under his Government, than eternally to be enÅ¿laved to the PleaÅ¿ure of mad Fanaticks. The exulting Soldiers are cock-ahoop: Now Colleges are freed from the fear of Ruine; the Common-Laws are Å¿ecured from danger; the Nobility, though maimed, yet Å¿till Å¿eemed to be in being; the Presbyterians, Å¿ecure of their Tythes and DiÅ¿cipline, though not coactive, triumph: nor are the RoyaliÅ¿ts much grieved, being now Å¿ure of a Single PerÅ¿on, and hoping that the Scepter and Crown, after one or two Turns more, would at length be Å¿etled upon the right BaÅ¿is, the Royal Family. Every Commander of the Army talks of Golden days, as if now their Places were to laÅ¿t for ever; nor does the meaneÅ¿t Soldier deÅ¿pair, but that by degrees he may mount to the top of the Government. But Lambert and other Chief Officers, beÅ¿ides the plentiful EÅ¿tates wherewith they are enriched at preÅ¿ent, skip for joy that they are admitted into a Å¿hare of the Government, hoping within a little after the death of the aged Protector, to be raiÅ¿ed higher.

AmidÅ¿t theÅ¿e DomeÅ¿tick Revolutions at home, England wanted not a Foreign Enemy;A War with Holland. they had a heavy War with Holland upon their Shoulders, which being begun two years before, and till then continued, Å¿eemed like to terminate in the Ruine of one of the two Nations, had not God othewiÅ¿e decreed. The Dutch were netled at the Letters of RepriÅ¿al, The uÅ¿e of it. which being promiÅ¿cuouÅ¿ly granted, Pyrats from all Places, who liked better to live by Rapine, than by honeÅ¿t CourÅ¿es, infeÅ¿ting the Seas, had taken above FourÅ¿core Sail of Ships; as alÅ¿o at the Order of Parliament, That no Goods Å¿hould
be Imported from abroad, unleÅ¿s in EngliÅ¿h Bottoms, or Ships of the Country where the Commodities were originally to be had. The laÅ¿t Opinion prevailing,The middle Opinion prevailing, EmbaÅ¿Å¿adors for Pacification are Å¿ent into England. The EmbaÅ¿Å¿adors Brother, Don Pantaleon Sa,But I muÅ¿t not here paÅ¿s over the EmbaÅ¿Å¿adors Brother, Don Pantaleon Sa, who had not the luck to return again into his own Country. However, next morning Don Pantaleon Sa was carried out of his Brother's HouÅ¿e,For a Murder committed in London, to be tried for the Murder of one Greenway, an innocent PerÅ¿on, who was unexpectedly and unfortunately killed in the Scuffle; and was Å¿hortly after brought to the Bar before Rolls Chief JuÅ¿tice of England, having Å¿ome Doctors of the Civil Law for AÅ¿Å¿eÅ¿Å¿ors; where the PriÅ¿oner having pleaded and

At the Å¿ame time, and upon the Å¿ame place,And Gerard at the Å¿ame time alÅ¿o, for Å¿tanding up for the Kings IntereÅ¿t â¢

Vowell, a School-maÅ¿ter, Vowell hanged for the Å¿ame CauÅ¿e. was hanged for the Å¿ame CauÅ¿e; who bravely upbraiding the Judges to their Faces with InjuÅ¿tice, he cited the Judges and Cromwell to appear before the Judgment Seat of God, who will render to every one according to their Works.

But let us return to our King, who having an Appartment in the Louvre, did not lazily lament his Misfortunes, but tried all ways whereby he might better his croÅ¿s Fortune, and Å¿et things to rights again: He uÅ¿es all Endeavours to procure the Favour of the King, the Cardinal, and Princes. And

London, Kent, and the other Counties,And all diÅ¿appointed of their Hopes. taking warning from the Misfortunes of their Brethren, forbore at preÅ¿ent to make any DiÅ¿turbance; but yet they could not eÅ¿cape the Intelligence

Cromwell's Arts of DiÅ¿covery.Now the Reader is to know how Cromwell came to the knowledge of the matter. He gained a conÅ¿iderable and topping Traytor, one Manning, EÅ¿pecially one Manning that lived at Court, whoÅ¿e Father died in defence of the Royal CauÅ¿e, as he himÅ¿elf had formerly Å¿erved the King, and received a Wound in the Foot; being a Gentleman of a good Family, and by Religion a Roman Catholick: who notwithÅ¿tanding, that he might be the more acceptable, and make way for his future Treachery, daring in a manner to mock God, took the Sacrament, after the manner of the Church of England. Cromwell calls a Parliament of Commoners onely,But a Parliament is now called at London, though not after the ancient manner: The Commons are onely called to Å¿it and conÅ¿ult in Parliament; nor theÅ¿e neither freely elected by all the People. Lenthall being again choÅ¿en Speaker,But they, on the contrary, nibble at the InÅ¿trument of Government, The Officers and Courtiers oppoÅ¿ing it, they fall firÅ¿t upon the New InÅ¿trument of Government; all the ClauÅ¿es and Articles whereof they thorowly Å¿ift and examine. But the Republicans Å¿tood Å¿tiff to the contrary, making anÅ¿wer, That the Government was uÅ¿urped by Craft and Force, not procured by Right, nor confirmed by the Free Votes of the People; that it laid Snares for the Liberty of the Commonwealth, and made way for a moÅ¿t grievous Tyranny. But Cromwell Å¿everely checks theÅ¿e Debates, Cromwell being informed of theÅ¿e Debates, comes in great rage to the Parliament, and tells them to this effect: That they were not called together that they might confound and turn all things again into the former Chaos, but that they Å¿hould build upon the Foundation and Ground-work already laid down, and not to be altered: That his Authority could not be called in queÅ¿tion, unleÅ¿s at the Å¿ame time they invalidated their own Power; Å¿ince the preÅ¿ent Parliament was called by him, and by him had liberty to conÅ¿ult: That he alone had the Right of Å¿etling Fundamentals, upon which they had power to raiÅ¿e and beautifie SuperÅ¿tructures: That he was reÅ¿olved to maintain the Government and Supreme Power in a Single PerÅ¿on, to call a Parliament once in Three years, not to Å¿it above Five months without his ConÅ¿ent, &c. And obliges all that would enter the HouÅ¿e to own the Government.But becauÅ¿e Admonition might not be Å¿ufficient, he thinks fit to apply Force. Many who could not Å¿wallow that Bit, are debarred from the Privilege of Sitting. In the mean time Cromwell having received a Å¿plendid EmbaÅ¿Å¿ie from Sueden, He makes Peace with Sueden, with equal Magnificence, he concluded a Peace with that Crown, and diÅ¿miÅ¿Å¿ed the EmbaÅ¿Å¿adors with hopes of a nearer Alliance. He makes Peace alÅ¿o with France,

But all this while, the Å¿pecious Pretext of Supreme Authority was wanting to theÅ¿e Attempts. The Parliament had denied their Collective

Then from the Officers in England, But amongÅ¿t the EngliÅ¿h Officers there was a neceÅ¿Å¿ity of a wheadling Pretext; to wit, That the Malignants and Enemies of the Country now triumphed, as if the Army breaking into DiÅ¿cords and DiviÅ¿ions, would preÅ¿ently renounce their General Cromwell: That therefore a Petition of that nature muÅ¿t needs be framed, wherein by applauding the Protector, they would convince thoÅ¿e that were of a contrary Opinion. The Army thus leading the Dance,And afterwards from Å¿ome Corporations. Å¿ome Corporations and Counties follow; and theÅ¿e, poÅ¿Å¿eÅ¿Å¿ed by what Spirit I know not, heap Å¿o many and Å¿o great Elogies upon the Man, that Å¿triving to outdo others in Hyperbolical Cant and Flattery, they fall into BlaÅ¿phemy, and bluÅ¿h not moÅ¿t profanely to attribute to this Man, Titles that are peculiar to God Almighty.

He affected to be a Promoter of JuÅ¿tice,In the mean time (to give the Devil his Due) he reÅ¿tores JuÅ¿tice, as well DiÅ¿tributive, as Commutative,

Mens Manners alÅ¿o,And a rigid CenÅ¿urer of Manners, at leaÅ¿t outwardly, Å¿eemed to be reformed to the better, whether by really Å¿ubÅ¿tracting the Fewel of Luxury, or through fear of the Ancient Laws, now revived and put in execution. He Å¿tudied alÅ¿o to gain an Opinion of extraordinary Sanctity among the Church-men;And a Favourer of the Clergy, for no Man affected to Å¿eem more tender of the Clergy than he, though he would not liÅ¿t himÅ¿elf in any particular Sect, nor eÅ¿pouÅ¿e particular Opinions: He was, indeed, more inclined towards the Independents, his Affairs Å¿o requiring; but a Å¿evere Enemy to all the Orthodox Clergy of England. Though the Publick UÅ¿e of the Service-Book was denied to the EpiÅ¿copal Party, yet in Private HouÅ¿es he allows them the UÅ¿e of their

The Independents get into the Chief Places of Honour and Profit,He hugged the Independents: whom he countenanced with his own Familiarity; and at length gave them liberty to call an AÅ¿Å¿embly at the Savoy, that the Preachers or Prelates of the Independent Churches in all Counties meeting there, might make a ConfeÅ¿Å¿ion of their Faith, and juÅ¿tifie themÅ¿elves from abÅ¿urd Opinions, with which they were branded by Å¿ome: but eÅ¿pecially, and indeed, that they might Å¿hew their Numbers and Strength, and by knowing one another, aÅ¿Å¿ociate together into a Å¿tricter Union. Though this Meeting was not celebrated till Richard was poÅ¿Å¿eÅ¿s'd of the Government, yet the Grant of it was obtained in Oliver's time.Nor was he an enemy to Fanaticks, He allows a Toleration of Religion to all Å¿orts of Fanaticks.
Though publickly he deteÅ¿ted,And Roman-Catholicks. and Å¿eemed an implacable Enemy to the PapiÅ¿ts; yet he was very familiar with Å¿ome of them, and very obliging towards them: Nay, once he Å¿et afoot a Treaty with them, about a general Toleration of Religion, converting the third part of their Rents, wherein by our Laws they are fined, into a certain Sum of Money. He creates CenÅ¿urers of the Preachers out of every S â¢ ct;He appointed a Convention of Lay-men and Church-men, as well Presbyterians and Independents, as alÅ¿o AnabaptiÅ¿ts, who had power to judge of Promotions, and the Collation of EccleÅ¿iaÅ¿tical Benefices, vacant by Death or DepoÅ¿ition; to call before them, and examine Competitors, put QueÅ¿tions to them concerning their Manners and Learning, and eÅ¿pecially about the Marks of the In-dwelling of the Holy Spirit; and Å¿ometimes about Civil Matters, as, If they liked a Popular State. the Men, by Sollicitations, PromiÅ¿es, Gifts,Who baÅ¿ely minded their own Profit. and Bribes, things were Symoniacally tranÅ¿acted in that kind of Office, Lay-men, Soldiers, Bankrupt TradeÅ¿men, and Shop-keepers, being alÅ¿o admitted into the MiniÅ¿try, and mingled with Å¿ome skilful Preachers who had been Ordained.

He endears and obliges to himÅ¿elf Seculars, He Å¿tudies to ingratiate himÅ¿elf with all men, according to their various Humours: With the Nobility, by Å¿pecious Offices, Å¿uch as were accommodated to the different Humours of the Men. But the Godly, The Godly, and thoÅ¿e that profeÅ¿Å¿ed much Piety, he would humour with holy Conferences, Prayers alÅ¿o (when it was needful), and Expounding of Sacred Scripture. When he was in the Country,Country People, he uÅ¿ed once or oftner a Year, to give the Neighbours about, a Buck, to be run down in his Park, and Å¿ome Money to buy Wine to make merry with.And alÅ¿o the Soldiers. Always glancing at his own Profit:He was rich in PromiÅ¿es, but at the Å¿ame time very Å¿paring of Gifts; for he never beÅ¿towed a Place or Office, till firÅ¿t he weighed it exactly in the Scales of his own Profit, that he might thereby reap conÅ¿iderable Advantage to himÅ¿elf; as, when he advanced his Countrymen, the more Å¿agacious, or Å¿uch as were ready to undertake any thing, to Preferments. A moÅ¿t cunning Diver into the Manners of Men.No Man dived more cunningly into the Manners of Men, and into the Tempers of thoÅ¿e with whom he had BuÅ¿ineÅ¿s to do, nor Å¿ooner
diÅ¿covered their Talent; no Man knew more of Men; nay, if there was any Man in all England that was Å¿ingular in any Art or Faculty, he could not be hid from him.And moÅ¿t prodigious Hypocrite.
