Where the BiÅ¿hop of Avignon, that he might gain Credit to AÅ¿trological Predictions, Å¿ent him out of France a Scheme calculated by one Oneal a Mathematician, wherein he predicted, That in the Year One thouÅ¿and Å¿ix hundred and Å¿ixty, the King Å¿hould certainly enter England in a triumphant manner; which Å¿ince, to our wonder, we have Å¿een fulfilled, all the People triumphantly rejoycing. In the mean time, whilÅ¿t He with great tranquillity of Mind Å¿uffered greateÅ¿t AdverÅ¿ity, Cromwell had neither ReÅ¿t nor Security in his ProÅ¿perity, Cromwell continually dogg'd with anxious & biting Cares, Å¿ince the time the laÅ¿t Whirlwind had blown with Å¿o much fury and force; whether he was laÅ¿hed by the Furies of an ill ConÅ¿cience, or terrified with growing Dangers, he never was at eaÅ¿e. PiÅ¿tols;Thinks himÅ¿elf Å¿afe no where. never coming back the Å¿treight Publick Rode, or the Å¿ame way, nor never paÅ¿Å¿ing but in great haÅ¿te and with Å¿peed. How many Locks and Keys are for the Doors of his HouÅ¿e? Let us here mention one PaÅ¿Å¿age, which tho' indeed ridiculous, had nevertheleÅ¿s almoÅ¿t coÅ¿t him his Life. Of new he oppreÅ¿Å¿es the RoyaliÅ¿ts, whom he Å¿poils of the tenth part of their Goods, Cromwell now growing bare of Money, diÅ¿perÅ¿ed his Souldiers over the Countrey, allowing them free Quarters inÅ¿tead of Pay; taking a pretext from a late InÅ¿urrection, without any accuÅ¿ation or proof of a Crime, to plunder all thoÅ¿e who had been Å¿equeÅ¿trated for the Royall CauÅ¿e, commanding them to pay the tenth part of their Goods, and of their yearly Rents; unleÅ¿s they could compound for it, by laying down a Sum of Money, as had been often done before. The Publick Faith, and Act of Oblivion Å¿tood them in no Å¿tead; though it had coÅ¿t vaÅ¿t Sums of Money,Withot any diÅ¿tinction. or had been Å¿tipulated by Articles upon the Å¿urrender of GarriÅ¿ons and Å¿trong places: Nor did the innocence of many, who had not meddled in theÅ¿e Affairs, in the leaÅ¿t excuÅ¿e them; all are equally involved in the Guilt, and muÅ¿t all alike part with their Money.

He Å¿ets Major Generals over Provinces,New Major Generals are appointed to raiÅ¿e the Moneys in all Counties, to the number of fourteen, each having their Province, which perhaps reached three or four Counties, over which, as amongÅ¿t the Romans, the Military Tribunes, Å¿o theÅ¿e were appointed with almoÅ¿t an abÅ¿olute Power.Who had great power given them over Å¿uÅ¿pected perÅ¿ons. And that they might not Å¿eem thus to domineer onely for Money, they are impowered to make inquiry into all thoÅ¿e who had carried Arms for the King, or had favoured that CauÅ¿e; thoÅ¿e who had heretofore bought up Arms, or had hired or let out PoÅ¿t-horÅ¿es; into Privat AÅ¿Å¿emblies; thoÅ¿e who

To theÅ¿e were joined AÅ¿Å¿eÅ¿Å¿ors in the Å¿everal Counties, Towns and Provinces, for moÅ¿t part choÅ¿en out of the very Sink of the People, though others of better note were Å¿ometimes mingled with them; theÅ¿e had Power upon common Fame, proper Knowledge, or bare Conjecture, to inform againÅ¿t others, make them appear, and accuÅ¿e them before the Major General of the Army, with whom they Å¿at as AÅ¿Å¿eÅ¿Å¿ors in giving Judgment. Good God! how Princely theÅ¿e fellows carry it!EÅ¿pecially over MiniÅ¿ters turned out of their Livings, who are not permitted Å¿o much as to teach little Children. how big and proud do they look, deÅ¿piÅ¿ing and Å¿lighting all others of what rank and quality Å¿oever? Nothing pleaÅ¿ed them more than to inÅ¿ult over, and oppreÅ¿s the MiniÅ¿ters of the Church of England, Å¿ufficiently already born down; who being long ago turned out of their HouÅ¿es and Livings, theÅ¿e Blades would not Å¿o much as Å¿uffer them to teach little Children, thereby to get Bread to themÅ¿elves and Families, unleÅ¿s Å¿ome Fanatick interceded for them, which happened rarely, and but to a few. The RoyaliÅ¿ts being right or wrong before Å¿equeÅ¿tred, muÅ¿t now Å¿uffer a Decimation; and be threatned with ImpriÅ¿onment, Bonds, and TranÅ¿portation, which Å¿ometimes were actually inflicted. Licentious indeed was the Rule of
theÅ¿e Men, they carry all things Arbitrarily, and with DeÅ¿potick Authority; making themÅ¿elves Judges of ControverÅ¿ies, (though they were ignorant of, and deÅ¿piÅ¿ed all Forms and Methods of ProceÅ¿s,) which they conÅ¿tantly decided in favours of the Faction and their Party. They impoÅ¿ed new and unuÅ¿ual PuniÅ¿hments; nay, and made new Laws: RaiÅ¿ed People out of their Beds at Midnight, and committed them to Goals; nay, and cauÅ¿ed ConÅ¿tables, who have the power of keeping the Peace in Countrey Villages, to be whipt, and put in the Stocks; compelled PerÅ¿ons of Quality, who had appeared for neither Party; nay, Å¿uch as had been for the Parliament, and others alÅ¿o, who heretofore by hereditary right had Å¿i â¢ ten in the HouÅ¿e of Lords, to come and give their Votes in the Elections for Parliament-Men. At length their Exorbitant Power being Å¿uÅ¿pected to Cromwell himÅ¿elf, they are wholly aboliÅ¿hed. Being at length drunk with that Exorbitant Power, they hardly acknowledged the Protector himÅ¿elf, and begun to Å¿purn againÅ¿t the mighty Tyrant; which made him by degrees leÅ¿Å¿en their Power, and upon the approach of a Parliament wholly aboliÅ¿h it.

About the Å¿ame time Cromwell Å¿ends one of his Bedchamber Envoy into Poland, there to Congratulate the Victories of the King of Sweden; with a preÅ¿ent of four brave HorÅ¿es, as a TeÅ¿timony of his Affection.

Whether or not, Private Affairs be worth the relating, may be a doubt; yet, that the inclinations of the People may be known, I Å¿hall mention Å¿ome PaÅ¿Å¿ages.Some ImpriÅ¿oned for the Royal CauÅ¿e, DaviÅ¿on, Holder, and Thorold, are brought into Å¿uÅ¿pition of acting for the King, and of uÅ¿ing endeavours to bring him in; therefore they are committed to a ProvoÅ¿t MarÅ¿hal, to be Å¿hortly brought to
Tryal before the High Court of JuÅ¿tice. In the mean time, having obtained leave from him to walk abroad, they wheadled the Soldier into a by place, whom, becauÅ¿e he refuÅ¿ed to conÅ¿ent to their eÅ¿cape, they PiÅ¿tolled.For a Murder afterward committed, are brought to a Tryal, and acquitted by a Jury. But being afterwards apprehended, they are brought to their Tryal for Murder before the Lord Chief JuÅ¿tice of the Kings Bench, in WeÅ¿tminÅ¿ter-hall, and Å¿ubmitted themÅ¿elves to the Verdict of a Jury of Twelve Men; a Tryal that onely pleaÅ¿es our Countrey-men, as being according to Law. NevertheleÅ¿s, though they were taken in the fact, and that the Judge himÅ¿elf had promiÅ¿ed to uÅ¿e his endeavours to have theÅ¿e Men Condemned; yet, I know not what Å¿cruples being Å¿tarted, the Jury brought them in, Not guilty; which thing vexed Cromwell, who had reÅ¿olved with himÅ¿elf that they Å¿hould certainly die for it.

This inÅ¿tance made him inveigh bitterly againÅ¿t the ancient way of Tryal;After the Å¿ame manner Lilburn eÅ¿caped Death; and Stawell thrice. reflecting alÅ¿o how Lilburn two years before, by the Å¿ame means eÅ¿caped his fury; and as luckily alÅ¿o, one Stawell, who was a Knight, notwitÅ¿tanding the Capitulation he had made upon the Å¿urrender of his GarriÅ¿on, being thrice brought to a Tryal of his Life, (a barbarous thing, and contrary to Law, to be again tried for one and the Å¿ame crime) was thrice acquitted by the Jury. This, though the Å¿trongeÅ¿t Bulwark againÅ¿t Tyranny, he affirms ought to be taken away, as a hindrance to JuÅ¿tice; complaining,The Tyrant objects againÅ¿t the Ancient CuÅ¿tom of a Jury of twelve Men. That Sacred JuÅ¿tice was raÅ¿hly put into the Hands of the Profane, Common People; that the weightieÅ¿t matters of Law did not depend upon the Sentences of the Learned in the Law, but upon the PleaÅ¿ure and Prejudices of a Company of Men, deÅ¿titute
of all Ingenious Learning, nay, and almoÅ¿t of Common SenÅ¿e. That it was more conÅ¿onant to JuÅ¿tice, that fifty Men choÅ¿en out of the flower of the whole Nation, Å¿hould determine of Lives and Fortunes. Under theÅ¿e Colours and Pretexts, he Å¿ubverted the wholÅ¿om ConÅ¿titutions of our Fore-fathers, and invented a new way of Butchery of his own.

But I deÅ¿ire that both our Countrey-men and Foreigners would take notice,This wholeÅ¿om CuÅ¿tom is juÅ¿tied. that this CuÅ¿tom of Tryal by a Jury of Twelve Men, founded on ReaÅ¿on and Equity, granted us by the Å¿ingular favour both of the Saxon and Norman Kings, and practiÅ¿ed amongÅ¿t us time out of mind, though it was in this Age for a Å¿hort time intermitted, yet it was approved by the Publick deÅ¿ires of all. The trueÅ¿t Judges of the Commons, are the Commons; as of the Nobles, their Peers; Å¿ince Men of the Å¿ame Rank and Quality are apteÅ¿t to love, and not to envy one another. BeÅ¿ides, if the Sheriff empannel any who bear you a grudge, you may challenge and reject them. How are they to be accuÅ¿ed of ignorance, Å¿ince the matter of Fact is known by Evidence, who alledge, and by their Oath prove it in open Court? and the point of Law they are to be directed by the Judges who are verÅ¿ed therein. The Fact is better examined by a plain and uncorrupted ConÅ¿cience, than cunning, that Å¿erves the ends of another. The Judges and Bench have onely their Duty to mind, ConÅ¿ult for the common IntereÅ¿t, and with the publick good procure the favour of their Princes. On the other hand, thoÅ¿e whom the offended Conquerour appoints as Arbiters of your Life and Fortune, obeying the pleaÅ¿ure of one MaÅ¿ter, and obÅ¿equiouÅ¿ly oppreÅ¿s you. AccuÅ¿ed Subjects, whom before they looked
upon as Servants, they now Å¿ternly frown upon as Publick Enemies; and without more ado, find them guilty of TreaÅ¿on, and condemn them to Å¿uffer accordingly. It is a Compendious and rare way of JuÅ¿tice, indeed, to have the Å¿ame Men to be the AccuÅ¿ers, WitneÅ¿Å¿es, Informers, Judges; nay, and plainly, the Executioners, and very often alÅ¿o the Authors of the Crimes.

Another greater into America. But the other Expedition required greater preparatives; as being carried on by the remains of the DiÅ¿Å¿enting and Disbanded Souldiers, to wit, of EÅ¿Å¿ex, Waller, and MaÅ¿Å¿ey's Armies, &c. Å¿ome RoyaliÅ¿ts and Republicans alÅ¿o, but Å¿paringly joyned with them.The firÅ¿t reaÅ¿on of it. For theÅ¿e being for the moÅ¿t part indigent and dangerous at home, watched all opportunities of innovation; and therefore buÅ¿ineÅ¿s is found out for them abroad, that they might not be troubleÅ¿ome to others, but eaÅ¿e England a little by the departure of Å¿o many Men.The Å¿econd. The Protector made his brags openly, that by a War with Spain, the Nation would attain to much Glory, Wealth, and large Dominions in the WeÅ¿t-Indies:The third. And not only cut off the Sinews of War whereby the Spaniards infeÅ¿ted Europe, but alÅ¿o hinder the Influx of the Spirits and Life of it, by intercepting their Riches. Nor did he doubt of an eaÅ¿ie and cheap Victory.The fourth. For the Spaniards were but few, and thoÅ¿e diÅ¿perÅ¿ed over the vaÅ¿t Territories of America; and that it was credible, that the Natives, weary of their hard and tedious Bondage, would upon the firÅ¿t glimpÅ¿e of liberty, riÅ¿e up againÅ¿t the Tyranny of the Spaniards. That though the Towns were well fortified, yet they were unprepared for making a reÅ¿iÅ¿tance, the Souldiers
being unaccuÅ¿tomed to War; nay, though GarriÅ¿oned by Å¿uch as had been inured to fighting, yet all relief by Sea being Å¿topt, and the Land not affording ProviÅ¿ions either for the EngliÅ¿h, or the Inhabitants, they muÅ¿t in a Å¿hort time be Å¿tarved out.The fifth. The neighbouring Plantations of our Countrey-men, beÅ¿ides, accuÅ¿tomed to the Climat and Diet, could yearly furniÅ¿h Å¿upplies; Å¿o that there could neither be any want of Souldiers for Å¿ubduing the Provinces, nor of People to be TranÅ¿ported into better Plantations. N â¢ y, (and which went a great way,) there was not wanting a certain Divine, that gave vent to the Ambition which flamed Å¿ufficiently of it Å¿elf, and who well underÅ¿tood the EnthuÅ¿iaÅ¿tick humour of Cromwell. This Man bid him, Go, and proÅ¿per; calls him, A Stone cut out of the Mountains without Hands, that Å¿hould break the Pride of the Spaniard, cruÅ¿h AntichriÅ¿t, and make way for the Purity of the GoÅ¿pel over the whole World. Swollen therefore with this hope, he Å¿ends for Officers and Commanders from all Places, Å¿ollicits, wheadles them with good words and with fair PromiÅ¿es of their paÅ¿t Arrears, and I know not what Mountains of Gold perÅ¿wades them to undertake the Voyage. He raiÅ¿es alÅ¿o private Souldiers, and fits out a conÅ¿iderable Fleet; he makes Penn Admiral at Sea, Penn Admiral at Sea, and Venables General at Land. and Vennables General of the Land Forces, Men that could not Å¿et their HorÅ¿es together; joining with them CommiÅ¿Å¿ioners, who were acquainted with the Humours, and Language of the Inhabitants, and skilful in the Harbours and advantages of Places, with whoÅ¿e advice the Generals were to manage all matters; and preÅ¿ently orders them to make Å¿ail to the Caribbee IÅ¿lands, there Å¿hortly to expect all neceÅ¿Å¿ary ProviÅ¿ions from England.

The Spaniard being afraid.Whil'Å¿t theÅ¿e things are carrying on in England, the Neighbouring Princes were at a Å¿tand what to think on't; but the Spaniard was moÅ¿t Å¿tartled, who from Dunkirk Å¿ent the MarqueÅ¿s of Leda to learn if he intended to keep the Peace with him. But he from the AnÅ¿wers conjecturing the DeÅ¿ign, Å¿peedily returns, and repented too late of his too early honouring an UÅ¿urper.

They arrive firÅ¿t at Barbadoes; In Å¿ix or Å¿eaven weeks time, with a fair Wind, they arrived at Barbadoes, the moÅ¿t flouriÅ¿hing of all the IÅ¿lands; from thence Å¿ailing to St. ChriÅ¿tophers, and other Circumjacent IÅ¿lands, they raiÅ¿e nine or ten thouÅ¿and Men, not Å¿o much Souldiers, as Porters, Slaves, and Rogues, who in hopes of Booty, not with deÅ¿ign to undergo the Perils and Toils of a Military Life, engaged in the Service; fitter to make up a number, than to Å¿ight. TruÅ¿ting to this Army (though I muÅ¿t confeÅ¿s Å¿ome old Souldiers were mingled with them) Arms and Ammunition not being as yet brought from England, (Å¿o that inÅ¿tead of Pikes many were fain to make uÅ¿e of Poles) they Å¿ail to the IÅ¿land of HiÅ¿paniola, Afterwards they Å¿aile to HiÅ¿paniola, with a deÅ¿ign to proceed to Carthagena after they had taken St. Domingo. that Å¿urpriÅ¿ing and making Å¿ure of St. Domingo the chief Town, and leaving there a Magazine with as many Souldiers as they could Å¿pare, they might proceed to Carthagena; but when they came in view of St. Domingo, having landed part of the Souldiers near the Town, whilÅ¿t the reÅ¿t fetched a compaÅ¿s about, that they might attack it on the other Å¿ide, the Å¿ignal is expected. But theÅ¿e having fatally Å¿ailed ten Leagues beyond the place appointed for the landing, put aÅ¿hoar in another place, and marching through a Sandy and thick Woody Country,But they are firÅ¿t overcome by the heat and thirÅ¿t, they were Å¿o Å¿corched and burnt up with heat and thirÅ¿t, that Å¿ome being
quite Å¿pent, fell dead by the way; many Å¿tragling to find Å¿omewhat to aÅ¿Å¿wage their thirÅ¿t, were killed by the Enemy: the reÅ¿t hardly able to go or Å¿tand upon their Legs, at length joyn their Companions. There, Orders were publiÅ¿hed, which were as grievous to their Minds as the drought had been to their Bodies, whereby They are commanded upon pain of Death to bring all the Gold, Silver, and Rich Goods that they Å¿hould find, into a Common TreaÅ¿ury. The hope of booty had hitherto kept up their Spirits; but now being deÅ¿titute of all comfort, and Å¿enÅ¿ible of their preÅ¿ent and paÅ¿t fatigues, they were Å¿etting forward on their march towards St. Domingo; when after a Å¿udden volley of Å¿mall Å¿hot,Then by the Inhabitants, three hundred Cow-hunters armed with Lances break out of the Woods upon them, and having put them into diÅ¿order killed them till they were weary. But next Day, the Army being refreÅ¿hed as well as they could, their deÅ¿ign Å¿ucceeded Å¿omewhat better.

At length drawing off their Forces, they bid adieu to that unhappy Land, having loÅ¿t Å¿ix hundred Men or more. Then they Å¿et Å¿ail towards Jamaica, to the WeÅ¿tward, a pleaÅ¿ant IÅ¿land, and, as it were, a Garden of Delights; which they eaÅ¿ily become MaÅ¿ters of, the Spaniards Capitulating to be gone;And at length by a Plague in Jamaica, whither they had betaken themÅ¿elves. but there a direful Plague, the avenger of WickedneÅ¿s, raged amongÅ¿t the EngliÅ¿h, which within Å¿ix Months infected and Å¿wept away the whole Army except two Souldiers. Afterwards new Souldiers, and freÅ¿h Å¿upplies coming by little and little to their refreÅ¿hment, they drive all the Spaniards out of Jamaica, which extends in length threeÅ¿core Leagues, and thirty in breadth, and bravely
repulÅ¿ed thoÅ¿e that attempted to come back again; becoming MaÅ¿ters of the whole IÅ¿land, and raiÅ¿ing Forts in Å¿everal places for their defence. Thus Divine WiÅ¿dom baffles the Pride and Vanity of Man.

The Spaniard declaring War, Cromwell aÅ¿Å¿iÅ¿ts the French upon theÅ¿e Conditions.The Spaniard to be revenged Proclaims War againÅ¿t Cromwell: And he on the other hand makes a League with the French, that at the Peril and Charges of others, he might give the Spaniard his Hands full on't. It was therefore agreed, That Cromwell Å¿hould Å¿end Å¿ix thouÅ¿and Men over into Flanders, to be payed by the French; and that the Å¿econd Town that Å¿hould be taken, Å¿hould belong to the EngliÅ¿h; and that CHARLES King of England, with all His Court and Family, Å¿hould be BaniÅ¿hed France, leÅ¿t he might any way be aiding and aÅ¿Å¿iÅ¿ting to the Enemy. The Duke of York, the Kings Brother, forÅ¿eeing that, renounces the French Service, wherein he had hitherto bravely behaved himÅ¿elf under MarÅ¿hal Turen;King CHARLES and the Duke of York being invited, go into Flanders, and Å¿hortly after both the King and He, are by Don John of AuÅ¿tria and others invited to come into Flanders, having a PenÅ¿ion of Nine thouÅ¿and pounds EngliÅ¿h a year Å¿ettled upon them, which his MajeÅ¿ty after his return into England fully repaid.Where the Duke Å¿erves the Spaniard. They came firÅ¿t to BruÅ¿Å¿els; and there the Duke is made General of the EngliÅ¿h, Scots and IriÅ¿h, who left the French Army at the Kings Command, and now Å¿erved the Spaniard.

ManaÅ¿Å¿es Ben IÅ¿rael, a Jew, deÅ¿ires liberty for his Nation to live and Trade in England. At that time one ManaÅ¿Å¿es Ben IÅ¿rael, a JewiÅ¿h Rabbi, came from Holland, and deÅ¿ired leave of the Protector that the Jews might be Å¿uffered to live in England, and enjoy a Free Trade, uÅ¿ing many Arguments for obtaining that Favour; as, in the firÅ¿t place, The Innocence of their Lives, and the Gain that would accrue from their
Trade; and others eaÅ¿ie to be deduced from the Native Genius and Qualities of that People: But the advantage he moÅ¿t boaÅ¿ted of, was, their Art in giving the beÅ¿t Intelligence, Å¿eeing they knew the Å¿ecret DeÅ¿igns and CounÅ¿els of all Princes; theÅ¿e he promiÅ¿es to diÅ¿cover to him, and at the Å¿ame time to defeat the CounÅ¿els that might be prejudicial to his IntereÅ¿ts. LaÅ¿tly, which was the Å¿trongeÅ¿t Argument of all, he promiÅ¿es a great Sum in ready Money, and Å¿ome ThouÅ¿ands of Pounds yearly to be paid into the Exchequer. To which Cromwell liÅ¿tens, in hopes of gain: Such golden PromiÅ¿es, with the Å¿weet Å¿mell of Gain, Å¿oon prevailed, the Exchequer eÅ¿pecially at that time being exhauÅ¿ted, much Debt contracted, and Cromwell caÅ¿ting about all ways how he might have Money to defray the Publick Charges. But a fair and honeÅ¿t Pretext was wanting: Therefore, on a day prefixed,But having firÅ¿t conÅ¿ulted Divines, Divines are called to meet, and give their Judgments about this Matter; Why, Å¿ince we pray to God for the ConverÅ¿ion of the Jews, we Å¿hould baniÅ¿h them our Society; as if we, who are enlightned by the bright Beams of the GoÅ¿pel, ought to be afraid of our Religion becauÅ¿e of Jews? He being aÅ¿Å¿ured of a great many Votes, made no doubt but that they would comply with him: But, alas! what a Tide of Contradiction had he to Å¿tem?Of whom Å¿ome, contrary to his expectation, are of a contrary Opinion. Some Divines on the day appointed diÅ¿puting to the contrary, not without Å¿ome inward heat and anger, Å¿o that they Å¿eemed rather to decline than promote the Determination of the ControverÅ¿ie, by oppoÅ¿ing this rapid Motion. However, he reÅ¿olved to connive, and allow them liberty to trade in England, with an Indulgence of their Religion according to the Rites of MoÅ¿es, without any publick Examination going before, or (as it is uÅ¿ual amongÅ¿t Catholicks)
coming yearly after, and without teaching or catechiÅ¿ing them.

The EngliÅ¿h Fleet, Commanded by Montague and Blake, But this Year was famous for the Actions of Mountague, Å¿ince Earl of Sandwich, and of Blake: For they with a Joynt-CommiÅ¿Å¿ion commanding the Fleet, whilÅ¿t they were cruiÅ¿ing upon the CoaÅ¿t of Spain, without the Straits Mouth, met with Eight great SpaniÅ¿h Ships, whom Stainer preÅ¿ently engages with Three Frigats onely; for the reÅ¿t could not come up becauÅ¿e of the Wind: but with Å¿o much Bravery and ReÅ¿olution he plied them with his BroadÅ¿ides, that within three or four Hours Å¿pace he maÅ¿tered them all;Defeats eight SpaniÅ¿h Ships richly laden; whereof two were taken. one being Å¿unk, another burnt, two eÅ¿caping into Cadiz, and two more forced aÅ¿hore and broke to pieces, wherein were loÅ¿t Sixty thouÅ¿and Wedges of Silver, beÅ¿ides other rich Goods of vaÅ¿t Value. However, two of them fell into the hands of the Victorious, with a great deal of Coyned Gold, to the quantity of Six hundred thouÅ¿and Pieces, much Silver, curiouÅ¿ly-wrought Plate, and other things of value, together with two Sons of the MarqueÅ¿s de Baydexio, Don JoÅ¿eph de Savega, and Don FranciÅ¿co de Lopes; the MarqueÅ¿s himÅ¿elf, with his Lady, and Daughter, who was to be married to the Son of the Duke of Medina Sidonia, being burnt. The two Brothers that remained alive, were by Cromwell diÅ¿charged without any RanÅ¿om.

England now being Å¿ufficiently plagued by thoÅ¿e petty Tyrants whom they called Major-Generals, A Å¿econd Parliament, c â¢ nÅ¿iÅ¿ting onely of Co â¢ moners, wherein Scots and IriÅ¿h are admitted, who (as we Å¿aid before) began to be uneaÅ¿ie to all, another Parliament is called; but not after the ancient manner, but onely made up of the Commoners or People; Thirty being called out of Scotland, and as many from
Ireland; Cromwell tampering with many, and the Major Generals hindring the Elections and Votes of Å¿everal, that the HouÅ¿e might not be filled with Republicans. In the mean while no Man is Å¿uffered to enter the HouÅ¿e, till firÅ¿t he Å¿ubÅ¿cribed to the Authority of the Protector; Å¿o that by that means moÅ¿t of the Republicans of either Å¿ort are excluded from Å¿itting.Suits better with Cromwells IntereÅ¿ts Sir Thomas Widdrington is choÅ¿en Speaker. Many things paÅ¿Å¿ed here in favour of Cromwell: as, That it Å¿hould be TreaÅ¿on to conÅ¿pire his Death: and, That the Royal Family Å¿hould be renounced. Nor is it in this place to be omitted, that about this time many things were publickly talked of to the prejudice of the King: as, That he was ConÅ¿umptive, and could not live long; That he was alÅ¿o Melancholy, and inclinable to a MonaÅ¿tick Life, laying aÅ¿ide all deÅ¿ire of Government; and that the Duke of York was a ProfeÅ¿Å¿ed PapiÅ¿t; that by that means they might wheadle over the credulous and unwary to their Party, by removing every thing that might curb and keep them in awe. The CuÅ¿toms are renewed; a vaÅ¿t Triennial Tax alÅ¿o impoÅ¿ed upon all HouÅ¿es built upon new Foundations in London, and witbin Ten miles round, that every one of them Å¿hould pay a years Rent.

At length,Since they would have made him King, at the Motion of a certain Citizen of London, the Parliament reÅ¿olves to give Cromwell the Title of King, with moÅ¿t of the EnÅ¿igns of Royalty, which he had already long ago uÅ¿urped; and many Members apply themÅ¿elves to him, beÅ¿eeching him that he would vouchÅ¿afe to accept of it: which he Å¿ometimes made a Å¿hew as if he would embrace; but by and by again appeared doubtful, and at length Å¿hifted it off.

I think it will not diÅ¿pleaÅ¿e the Reader if I give in this place a Å¿hort hint at the main ReaÅ¿ons whereby the Members of Parliament endeavoured to incline Cromwell to accept of the Title of King, which inwardly he was moÅ¿t ambitious of, though outwardly he affected a reluctancy. This Affair was by the Parliament committed to the diligent management of Å¿ix or Å¿even of their number.Alledging theÅ¿e ReaÅ¿ons for it: TheÅ¿e Men urg'd, That the name of King had always been in vogue from the very beginning in this Nation, for the Å¿pace of above thirteen hundred years; that the PerÅ¿on of the King had Å¿ometime diÅ¿pleaÅ¿ed the People; but that the Title was never before abrogated; that moreover the Å¿ame was fitted to our Laws, and the Humour of the People, and approved not onely by the Votes of the preceding, but of this preÅ¿ent Prarliament alÅ¿o. To which he anÅ¿wering, Cromwell anÅ¿wers, That theÅ¿e were perÅ¿uaÅ¿ive, but no cogent Arguments; that the Title of Protector might be adapted to the Laws; that Providence was againÅ¿t them, which hath now altered the Name; and that he could not without a Crime diÅ¿pleaÅ¿e Å¿o many Godly and Religious Men. But the CommiÅ¿Å¿ioners reply,They Å¿trongly reply. That the Title ought to be fitted to the Laws, not the Laws to Titles; nay, that the Innovation of Titles is Å¿uÅ¿pected as a Cloak for Æ²nderhand Tyranny, and that the diÅ¿advantages of Å¿uch a kind of change are never felt in in the Å¿ame Age; for which very ReaÅ¿on, when King James came to the Crown of this Kingdom, the Parliament would not give way that in his Title, inÅ¿tead of England and Scotland, he Å¿hould inÅ¿ert Great Britain. That by refuÅ¿ing the Title of King, he does not derogate Å¿o much from himÅ¿elf, as from the Nation; whoÅ¿e Honour it is to be governed by a King. That the Å¿upreme MagiÅ¿trate was never deÅ¿igned by the Name of Protector, unleÅ¿s for a
time, during the Nonage of the King, for the AdminiÅ¿tration of the Government, and a Title for the moÅ¿t part unfortunate. That that Name at preÅ¿ent having its Original from the Souldiers, Å¿ounded Victory, and might be lawfully reÅ¿cinded by another Parliament. That the Title of King being once aboliÅ¿hed, the Government would become mutable and unÅ¿afe, not durable, if the Foundation tottered; that in the Å¿pace of five years it had been three or four times altered, and was yet as wavering, as heretofore the alteration of Title was ominous to the Roman People, who neither could endure the Name of Prince, nor of Perpetual Dictator, nor of the Prince of the Senate, till at length the PleaÅ¿ure of CaeÅ¿ar went for Law. The chief Argument. But the Å¿trongeÅ¿t Argument of all was, The Statutes of the Ninth of Edward the Fourth, and of the Third of Henry the Seventh, wherein it was enacted, That no Man carrying Arms, though unjuÅ¿tly, for the King in being, Å¿hall be puniÅ¿hed for it; and that in the late Wars, more truÅ¿ting to that Law, were in Arms for the King, than of thoÅ¿e who loved his CauÅ¿e. That as to Providence, it was no leÅ¿s conÅ¿picuous in changing the Government again into Monarchy, for avoiding confuÅ¿ion, and quelling a tumultuous People, than in changing the Name of a Monarch into that of Protector. That, laÅ¿tly, Good and Godly Men would Å¿ubmit to a Decree of Parliament, though perhaps they might Å¿eem to differ in private. A great deal of time is Å¿pent betwixt Cromwell and the Committee in mutual AnÅ¿wers and Replies; but after much affectation of Words, they Å¿till fell upon the Å¿ame Heads again.

There was no leÅ¿s to do with the private AddreÅ¿Å¿es of different Parties;Who they were that would have had him take the Title of King. moÅ¿t of the Pettyfogging Lawyers, the CommiÅ¿Å¿ioners for the Great Seal, the Judges, and Å¿ome of the Officers of
the Army, relying upon the former ReaÅ¿ons, entreat, urge, and earneÅ¿tly importune him, That he would conÅ¿ent to take upon him the Name of King. And who on the other hand as fiercely oppoÅ¿ed it. On the other hand, the AnabaptiÅ¿ts, Sectarians, and Democratical Republicans, by Letters, Conferences, and Monitory Petitions, wearied him with their importunities to the contrary. Many alÅ¿o of the Soldiers and inferiour Officers, laying their Heads together, frame a Petition to the Å¿ame purpoÅ¿e. But he, during the whole tranÅ¿action, diÅ¿miÅ¿Å¿es all with the Å¿ame uncertainty and doubts; however he Å¿everely chid the Soldiers, biding them mind their own buÅ¿ineÅ¿s, for what had they to do with the ReÅ¿olutions of Parliament? that they Å¿hould look to their Arms, and keep themÅ¿elves modeÅ¿tly within their own bounds, not medling in Civil Affairs; but that if they did forget their Duty and Obedience, neither God Almighty, nor he himÅ¿elf would be wanting to reduce them into order.

The Cavaliers for Å¿everal reaÅ¿ons were for the firÅ¿t Advice.The Cavaliers are Tooth and Nail for his complying with the firÅ¿t Advice, as being a Matter which they thought would not a little contribute to the reviving of their CauÅ¿e, whilÅ¿t continual jangling and and diÅ¿Å¿entions would thereby ariÅ¿e betwixt the Republicans and Cromwell; and the Office of King being again introduced, the onely Quarrel would then be betwixt two Families, which of the two had the better Title, the one having it by undoubted right, and the other by none at all. And beÅ¿ides, thereby it would be made manifeÅ¿t for what cauÅ¿e the War was in a great part begun, to wit, the Å¿ole Ambition of Cromwell. But he having taken time to weigh with himÅ¿elf all their Opinions, thought it more modeÅ¿t and
Å¿uitable to his IntereÅ¿t, to retain his more than Regal Authority, circumÅ¿cribed by no Laws, under the Å¿ubmiÅ¿Å¿ive Title of Protector,
Cromwell rejecting the Crown which be Å¿o earneÅ¿tly coveted, than by coveting an AuguÅ¿t Name, render himÅ¿elf ridiculous to the World. At length having called the Parliament unto him, He tells them, That at preÅ¿ent he durÅ¿t not take upon him the AdminiÅ¿tration of the Government with the Title of King; though he was reÅ¿olved in future Parliaments to introduce it by degrees, how humbly Å¿oever at preÅ¿ent he carried himÅ¿elf, and utterly rejected the Å¿ame.

I cannot tell whether or not it be worth the mentioning, what many interpreted as a bad preÅ¿age. WhilÅ¿t the Members of Parliament were going up to the Banqueting-HouÅ¿e in Whitehall, to have the laÅ¿t Debate with Cromwell about that Affair, his eldeÅ¿t Son Richard being in company with them, the old Stairs by which they mounted being overcharged with weight broke with them, Å¿o that many fell to the ground; of whom not a few had bruiÅ¿es in their Legs and Arms, and amongÅ¿t the reÅ¿t Richard being grievouÅ¿ly wounded, lay by it a long time.

But Å¿ince Cromwell refuÅ¿ed the Title of King, With much ado, he obtained from the Parliament the Title of Protector, the Parliament, by the Å¿uperiority of two Voices onely, confirmed to him that of Protector, which he had taken before; and that they might not Å¿eem to have done nothing at all, they agreed about reforming the InÅ¿trument of Government, and added a HouÅ¿e of Peers, or Lords, to be choÅ¿en by him, That theÅ¿e Men might as occaÅ¿ion offered, be a check Å¿ometimes to the Commons when they proceeded too haÅ¿tily. They give him likewiÅ¿e Power of appointing his SucceÅ¿Å¿our or next Heir. That no Man, however
lawfully elected according to the above-mentioned Conditions, Å¿hould under any pretext whatÅ¿oever, be excluded from Å¿itting in Parliament.

And is Å¿olemnly Inaugurated by the Speaker.On a day appointed the Members march to WeÅ¿tminÅ¿ter-hall, there Å¿olemnly to Inaugurate Cromwell, and to receive his conÅ¿ent. So Å¿oon as he had mounted a Stage erected for that purpoÅ¿e, round which the Members of Parliament Å¿at, Widdrington the Speaker reaching to him the EnÅ¿igns of MajeÅ¿ty, to wit, a long Purple Robe lined wtth Ermin, the Holy Bible, a Sword and Scepter, thus he Å¿peaks to him, Å¿tanding near him under a Canopy of State. This Robe of Purple is an Emblem of Magistracy, and imports RighteouÅ¿neÅ¿s and JuÅ¿tice; when you have put on this VeÅ¿tment, I may Å¿ay, you are a Gown-man. This Robe is of a mixt Colour, to Å¿hew the mixture of JuÅ¿tice and Mercy. Indeed a MagiÅ¿trate muÅ¿t have two Hands, Plectentem & Amplectentem, to cheriÅ¿h and to puniÅ¿h. The Bible is a Book that contains the Holy Scriptures, in which you have the happineÅ¿s to be well verÅ¿ed. This Book of Life conÅ¿iÅ¿ts of two TeÅ¿taments's, the Old and New: The firÅ¿t Å¿hews ChriÅ¿tum Velatum; the Å¿econd, ChriÅ¿tum Revelatum; ChriÅ¿t Vailed and Revealed: It is a Book of Books, and doth contain both Precepts and Examples for good Government. Here is a Scepter not unlike a Staff, for you are to be a Staff to the weak and poor: It is of Ancient uÅ¿e in this kind. It's Å¿aid in Scripture, That the Scepter Å¿hall not depart from Judah. It was of like uÅ¿e in other Kingdoms; Homer the Greeek Poet calls Kings and Princes, Scepter-bearers. The laÅ¿t thing is a Sword, not a Military, but Civil Sword: it is a Sword rather of Defence than Offence; not to defend your Å¿elf
onely, but your People alÅ¿o. If I might preÅ¿ume to fix a Motto upon this Sword, as the Valiant Lord Talbot had upon his, it Å¿hould be this, Ego Å¿um Domini Protectoris, ad protegendum Populum; I am the Protectors, to protect his People. Then having given him his Oath, and read over the Articles of Government, with Å¿ound of Trumpet he is Proclaimed Protector of the Commonwealth of England, Scotland, and Ireland, &c. but with faint Acclamations from the People. Hence you may underÅ¿tand what, and how great things the Power of a Tyrant, counterfeit Virtue, Lawyers fetches, fawning hope, anxious fear, love of novelty, and Å¿pecious pretexts, could, againÅ¿t all right and reaÅ¿on, bring to paÅ¿s, amongÅ¿t Men in all things elÅ¿e, for moÅ¿t part, very Prudent and WiÅ¿e: That in the like caÅ¿e I may uÅ¿e the Words of another. TheÅ¿e things being thus performed, the Parliament Å¿hortly after were diÅ¿miÅ¿Å¿ed for three or four Months, and Cromwell has time to make choice of his Peers for the other HouÅ¿e.

But we muÅ¿t not omit to take notice in this place of that unbridled licentiouÅ¿neÅ¿s of Hereticks, which grew greater and greater daily.The Å¿ink of Hereticks of theÅ¿e times: BeÅ¿ides ArrianiÅ¿m againÅ¿t the Divinity of our Saviour JeÅ¿us ChriÅ¿t, and other abominable Errours, which one Biddle profanely and yet Å¿afely maintained before the Parliament; the BlaÅ¿phemies alÅ¿o of Copps againÅ¿t the Holy Name of God; and Fry, who heretofore Å¿cattred his PoiÅ¿ons in the Parliament-HouÅ¿e; beÅ¿ides Erbury, who as with impunity he Å¿owed the monÅ¿trous Seeds of HereÅ¿ies amongÅ¿t the Souldiers, and in the City, whilÅ¿t he was in health, Å¿o dying he breathed out his laÅ¿t in BlaÅ¿phemy; SaltmarÅ¿h alÅ¿o, and other Sectarians, whoÅ¿e Fanatical Errours,
by the EnthuÅ¿iaÅ¿m of Cromwell, and the other Officers of the Army, were again conjured from Hell; a new and unheard-of Generation of Quakers Å¿prung up, of whom the Parliament brought before them a conÅ¿iderable Ring-leader, that I Å¿hall now briefly diÅ¿courÅ¿e of.

Sundercome a Republican plots againÅ¿t Cromwell. About that time Cromwell's Life was in danger from one Sundercome a Republican. It was Å¿aid, that he was Å¿uborned by AlonÅ¿o de Cardenas, formerly EmbaÅ¿Å¿adour in England from the King of Spain, and then living in Flanders, to kill him. He had often taken a HouÅ¿e fit for committing the Fact; but his Hopes always
failing him, he got him a BlunderbuÅ¿s that could diÅ¿charge twelve Bullets at a time, reÅ¿olving with that, out of an Arbor upon the Å¿ide of the Rode, where the Way grows narrow, at HammerÅ¿mith near London, to Å¿hoot Cromwell as he paÅ¿t in his Coach to Hampton-Court, and forthwith mounting a fleet HorÅ¿e, make his EÅ¿cape on the oppoÅ¿ite Å¿ide. But becauÅ¿e there was a neceÅ¿Å¿ity of having another privy to the DeÅ¿ign, when the time that he was to go drew near, one Toop belonging to the Guards is engaged in the Plot.Who being betray'd by another ConÅ¿pirator, is brought to a Tryal, and condemned: But one AÅ¿Å¿aÅ¿Å¿ine betrays another; Toop, Sundercome: who that he might be the firÅ¿t that Å¿uffered for TreaÅ¿on under this Government, by a new Statute is arraigned, and condemned for conÅ¿piring the Death of the Protector. However, Å¿ome few hours before the time of his deÅ¿igned Execution,But he prevented the Executioner by a Å¿udden Death. he was found dead in his Bed, though his Body appeared found, there being no Marks of Violence either inwardly or outwardly to be diÅ¿covered. Of which thing, according to the diverÅ¿ity of Humours, People might Å¿everally judge as they pleaÅ¿ed.

In the mean while the fiercer Fifth-Monarchy-men and Republicans, making all the Preparations they could for a Å¿udden InÅ¿urrection againÅ¿t the new Monarchy in the Bud, are diÅ¿covered,The Republicans riÅ¿ing are apprehended. and preÅ¿ently Å¿eiÅ¿ed; amongÅ¿t other things, a Standard being taken, bearing a Lion Couchant, with this InÅ¿cription, Quis Å¿uÅ¿citabit eum? Who Å¿hall rouÅ¿e him? This RiÅ¿ing then being wholly defeated, LawÅ¿on a Sea-Commander, Colonel HarriÅ¿on, Rich, and Å¿everal Officers of the Army, with Danvers, and others, who could not endure the Regal Authority of Cromwell, are clapp'd up in PriÅ¿on. Lambert alÅ¿o, when he
perceived that all his Hopes of SucceÅ¿Å¿ion were cut off by an Ordinance of Parliament, began to tack about, and Å¿trike in with the Republicans:
Lambert being Disbanded, Which Å¿o Å¿oon as Cromwell had notice of, he preÅ¿ently recalled his CommiÅ¿Å¿ion, and diÅ¿banded him, Fleetwood is put in his place. appointing Fleetwood to be next to himÅ¿elf in Power; for he thought it neither Å¿afe nor fit, that he Å¿hould have the Chief Command in the Army, who profeÅ¿Å¿ed himÅ¿elf an open Enemy to the Civil Government.

Cromwells Lords of the very dregs of the People, Cromwell, in the mean time, that he might by fair and gentle means draw over more of the Republicans, and endear them to himÅ¿elf, promoted many of them into the HouÅ¿e of Lords, that they might Å¿eem to Å¿hare with himÅ¿elf in the Government; but Å¿uch mean Fellows, of no Birth nor Merit, raiÅ¿ed out of the Dregs of the Rabble, who were contemptible and ridiculous to the real Lords and Peers, could neither give nor receive any Splendour or Nobility. Would ye have a LiÅ¿t of Å¿ome of them? Let Pride then lead the Dance; a moÅ¿t abject RaÅ¿cal, who had Å¿erved a Brewer; and that he might now with greater Å¿ecurity cheat the Publick, he purchaÅ¿es a Grant for Brewing Beer for the Protector's Family, and for Å¿erving the Fleet at Sea. HuÅ¿on was another, who not long before cobbled old Shoes in a Stall. BerkÅ¿tead, who heretofore Å¿old Needles, Bodkins, and Thimbles, and would have run on an Errand any where for a little Money; but who now by Cromwell was preferred to the Honourable Charge of Lieutenant of the Tower of London. Cooper, who had been a HaberdaÅ¿her of Small-wares in Southwark. Berry, a Woodmonger; and Whaley, a broken Clothier, who had removed into Scotland until the breaking
out of the Wars. I Å¿hall name no more of them, that I may not turn the Readers Stomach. In the mean time,Some of the Nobility being mingled with them who diÅ¿dain, Å¿uch companions: he joyns to them for Companions five or Å¿ix of the Ancient Nobility, and gives them place in the HouÅ¿e of Lords; who nevertheleÅ¿s refuÅ¿e to herd with the reÅ¿t, and all refrain the HouÅ¿e, that they might not pollute their Blood by Å¿uch a Contagion. Others called out of the HouÅ¿e of Commons to this Other HouÅ¿e, prefer their own Seats, and will not be reckoned amongÅ¿t thoÅ¿e Peers. The two Sons, and one Son-in-Law of Cromwell,
Falconberge alÅ¿o his Son-in-law, and both his own Sons. are brought into this HouÅ¿e: For it is to be obÅ¿erved, that he had lately married his two younger Daughters (the eldeÅ¿t having formerly married to Cleypole) the one to Mr. Rich, Nephew to the then Earl of Warwick, who lived not long after; and the other to the Lord Falconberge, of whom now we Å¿peak; Henry Cromwell his younger Son, whom he made Deputy of Ireland, and Richard the elder: of whom, Å¿ince I am to mention him in the Sequel, it will be fit I Å¿peak a little at preÅ¿ent, before I leave this HouÅ¿e of Lords.

That Cromwell might remove all Å¿uÅ¿picion of arrogating to himÅ¿elf and Family the Supreme Authority,Of whom he Å¿ends Richard to lead a Countrey Life, he Å¿ends his eldeÅ¿t Son Richard into the Country, to take his PleaÅ¿ure in Hunting and Hawking: Where he, a Man of a good Nature, courteous and affable, far from the Tricks of his Father, receiving the Common People hoÅ¿pitably, diverting himÅ¿elf with the Gentry, and behaving himÅ¿elf civilly to all, beÅ¿ides many good Offices that he did at Court and elÅ¿ewhere, not onely gained the ApplauÅ¿e of the People, but obliged a great many PerÅ¿ons of Note and Quality. But at length his
Father took him off of theÅ¿e Toys, and by degrees inured him to Publick BuÅ¿ineÅ¿s; ordering him firÅ¿t to Å¿it in the Committee of Trade, then in the HouÅ¿e of Commons, and now at laÅ¿t having called him, as we have juÅ¿t now Å¿aid, up to the HouÅ¿e of Lords. Who at length is made Chancellour of the Æ²niverÅ¿ity of Oxford, and one of his Father â¢ s Privy Council. BeÅ¿ides, he made him Chancellor of the UniverÅ¿ity of Oxford, one of his Privy-Council, and a Colonel of the Army; that he might Å¿hew him not onely to the People, but to the Soldiers; and that he might inÅ¿inuate with all, and as much as he could make himÅ¿elf Friends by ConverÅ¿ation.

A Parliament of two HouÅ¿es, who agree ill betwixt themÅ¿elves, the BaÅ¿tard Peers being deÅ¿piÅ¿ed by the Lower-HouÅ¿e.And now the day was come when the whole Parliament was to meet, as well the Republicans, who in the beginning of the Parliament had been excluded by Cromwell, for refuÅ¿ing to Å¿ubÅ¿cribe to the Condition required, as the Lords or Peers who by Oliver's Writ filled the Upper HouÅ¿e. But the Reader cannot but wonder, how diÅ¿dainfully the Members of the Lower HouÅ¿e looked upon thoÅ¿e new Lords, asking them with Å¿corn, By what Authority they Å¿ate? to what end? and for what purpoÅ¿e were they called hither? Nay, they could not refrain from ridiculing and Å¿coffing at them, nor be induced to have any thing to do, or conÅ¿ult in common with theÅ¿e Men. On the contrary, the Lords (as they were inÅ¿tructed by Cromwell) fawned, complied, wheadled, and courted their FriendÅ¿hip, leaving no means uneÅ¿Å¿ayed whereby they might Å¿often and make them more gentle. But they continue to be moroÅ¿e, untractable, and refractory to every thing: Which Cromwell obÅ¿erving, and eÅ¿pecially becauÅ¿e he underÅ¿tood that the Cavaliers were hatching new DeÅ¿igns; that the King was in a readineÅ¿s, with I know not how many thouÅ¿and Men, to invade England;
and that the MarqueÅ¿s of Ormond was really in the Land, Å¿ecretly labouring to raiÅ¿e the Country; for theÅ¿e ReaÅ¿ons he forthwith diÅ¿Å¿olved that fictitious, and, as I may Å¿ay,And therefore that Parliament is diÅ¿Å¿olved. New DeÅ¿igns of the Cavaliers are diÅ¿appointed by Cromwell, they being diÅ¿covered by Å¿ecret Spies. Comical Parliament.

It was not long before the Stirs began more clearly to appear; one Corkar, a ParÅ¿on in SuÅ¿Å¿ex, who nevertheleÅ¿s had heretofore had a hand in killing Rainsborough at DoncaÅ¿ter, Sir Richard Willis, and many others, who had Å¿erved and been well rewarded by the King, and had opportunity of paÅ¿Å¿ing to and again betwixt Cromwell and His MajeÅ¿ty, and diÅ¿covering all Å¿ecret Intrigues, having baÅ¿ely betrayed the DeÅ¿ign. A General InÅ¿urrection was deÅ¿igned almoÅ¿t all over England, eÅ¿pecially in Hull, London, SuÅ¿Å¿ex, Surrey, and many other Places; which the King himÅ¿elf, with Foreign Forces commanded by MarÅ¿in, intended to Head. But all proved in vain; the Matter, as we have Å¿aid, having been diÅ¿covered to Cromwell by treacherous and clandeÅ¿tine Spies.

The MarqueÅ¿s of Ormond with much ado made his EÅ¿cape, having by the AÅ¿Å¿iÅ¿tance of Doctor Quarterman procured a Boat in SuÅ¿Å¿ex:Many are brought to Trial for their Life. And now a vaÅ¿t number of PerÅ¿ons apprehended, are loaded with the Å¿uÅ¿picion of guilt: and therefore the High Court of JuÅ¿tice, a true Object of DeriÅ¿ion, had it not been polluted with Blood, is again appointed, LiÅ¿le being PreÅ¿ident. Before this Court are brought Mordant Son to the Earl of Peterborough, two Stapleys, Woodcock, Sir Henry Slingsby, Hewet Doctor of Divinity, Mallory, Rivers, Dyke, and many more. Hewet is condemned for Contumacy, in not acknowledging the Authority of the Court. Slingsby, becauÅ¿e being formerly a PriÅ¿oner in
Hull, he had treated with Waters about the Delivery of Hull-Fort into the hands of the King. Mordant is abÅ¿olved by the Majority onely of one Voice; when within a quarter of an hour after Pride came in, who would certainly have voted to the contrary: Å¿o near he Å¿eemed to the very Jaws of Death. Woodcock defended himÅ¿elf Å¿o ingeniouÅ¿ly, that he came off. The reÅ¿t were either not found Guilty, or obtained Cromwell's Pardon for accuÅ¿ing of others, or, in Å¿hort, were condemned of High TreaÅ¿on. Hewet and Slingsby were both beheaded.Two of the more remarkable are beheaded: Four others drawn, hanged, and quartered But four others were drawn, hanged, and quartered, their Privy Members and Bowels burnt, their Heads Å¿et up upon London-Bridge, and their Quarters upon four Gates of the City. The Common Å¿ort being Å¿afe by their Number, after a long ImpriÅ¿onment, at length denying the Fact upon Oath, are diÅ¿miÅ¿Å¿ed. Thus they who for attempting to Å¿lay a Tyrant deÅ¿erved a Triumphal Arch, and higheÅ¿t Honours, falling into the bloody Hands of their Enemies, Å¿uffer a cruel and ignominious Death.

Cromwell for greater Å¿ecurity levies new Troops of H â¢ rÅ¿e, conÅ¿iÅ¿ting of Voluntiers.But that he might provide againÅ¿t Å¿uch Stirs for the future, and more Å¿ecurely Å¿ettle his illgot and unÅ¿afe Government, beÅ¿ides the Soldiers of the Army, he levies Troops of HorÅ¿e in the Å¿everal Counties, which for the moÅ¿t part were made up of Voluntiers, whom either ambition of domineering, hope of Preferment, proÅ¿pect of Booty, or at leaÅ¿t the tediouÅ¿neÅ¿s of an idle and lazy Life, allured into the Service. Of theÅ¿e he gave the Command to Å¿ome of his Relations and faÅ¿t Friends. Though at preÅ¿ent their Pay was but Å¿mall, Eight pound a year, yet by getting into profitable Places, and plundring the Cavaliers upon all occaÅ¿ions, they
were in good hopes of feathering their NeÅ¿ts. Their Duty was to watch over the Counties, to be preÅ¿ent at Publick Fairs and other numerous Meetings, to hinder private AÅ¿Å¿emblies and ConcourÅ¿es of People, to exact the Taxes from thoÅ¿e who were either Å¿low or unwilling to pay them, by Free-Quarters, and Fines impoÅ¿ed upon them; to Å¿eiÅ¿e, beÅ¿ides, Å¿uÅ¿pected PerÅ¿ons, Å¿earch their HouÅ¿es, take from them the Arms which they might have for defending themÅ¿elves againÅ¿t Thieves in the Night-time, and, in a word, to Å¿uppreÅ¿s inÅ¿tantly all Stirs, if any hapned, in the bud.

Blake is again, but now the laÅ¿t time, to appear upon the Stage. He being this year Å¿ent to cruiÅ¿e in the Atlantick Ocean, had Intelligence that the SpaniÅ¿h Fleet, richly laden with Silver and Plate, had out of fear put into the IÅ¿land of Tenariff, reÅ¿olving to keep in the Port of Sancta Cruce, until Blake Å¿hould be forced to return home, either by the Winter Weather, or the want of Victuals and ProviÅ¿ions. Wherefore Å¿teering his CourÅ¿e thither, he found the Harbour in Å¿hape of a CreÅ¿cent, defended by Å¿even Forts lying round it, and two CaÅ¿tles placed at the Points, with Å¿eventeen Ships riding therein, their Heads Å¿tanding towards the Mouth of the Harbour, that they might fire with greater certainty upon thoÅ¿e that offered to enter: nor could the Governour forbear to jear and Å¿lout at the EngliÅ¿h.
Blake with unparallell'd boldneÅ¿s burns the SpaniÅ¿h Fleet in the very Harbour of Sancta Cruce.
Blake therefore entring the Mouth of the Harbour with his Frigats, thunders BroadÅ¿ides and Å¿mall Shot againÅ¿t the CaÅ¿tles, till the Soldiers flying from thence, he Manned his Boats with Seamen, and Å¿ent them in, who deÅ¿troyed and burnt all the SpaniÅ¿h Ships that were there. Which being
done, he made uÅ¿e of a favourable Wind, which as it had brought him thither, Å¿o carried him off again, more Å¿atisfied with his Revenge than Booty.

His Death, Character; and Actions.But farewell to Blake, who in that Expedition died of a Scurvey and DropÅ¿ie: A Man deÅ¿erving PraiÅ¿e even from an Enemy; who having heretofore diligently plied his Studies, took his Degree of MaÅ¿ter of Arts in Wadham-College in Oxford, and lived long a quiet and Country-life in SomerÅ¿etÅ¿hire; till afterward, the Civil War breaking out, he was engaged into the Service by Å¿ome Parliamentarians, and defended Lime and Taunton even to a Miracle againÅ¿t the King. Then being advanced to a Command at Sea, he Å¿ubdued the IÅ¿les of Silly at home; after which, being honoured with the Title and Place of Admiral, he became famous by many Actions abroad: For he humbled the Pride of France, reduced Portugal into order, broke the Strength of the Dutch, and drove them off of the Sea, Å¿uppreÅ¿Å¿ed the Pyrats, and, laÅ¿tly, triumphed twice over Spain: In this alone to be blamed, that he Å¿tuck to the Side of the Parricides.

The Dane makes War againÅ¿t the Swede,
â¢ ow victorious in Poland. About that time a dreadful War broke out betwixt two Northern Nations. Frederick the Third, King of Denmark, egg'd on by his Confederates the King of Poland and Elector of Brandenburg, invades the Territories of Carolus GuÅ¿tavus King of Sweden, then Victorious in Poland;The Swede haÅ¿tning his return, invades Denmark, revenges himÅ¿elf on the Dane, and reduces him to extremity. and breaking the Truce, beÅ¿ieges Bremersford, and other Å¿trong Places in Bremen. Which Å¿o Å¿oon as Carolus GuÅ¿tavus had Intelligence of, leaving Poland the beÅ¿t way he could, he marched his Forces through GaÅ¿Å¿ue, Pomerania, and the Dutchy of Mecklenbourg, into HolÅ¿tein,
recovers what he had loÅ¿t, and drives Frederick, who was unable to give him Battel, into the IÅ¿lands; then he over-runs all Jutland and HolÅ¿tein; and having the opportunity of a hard Winter, (not without danger to himÅ¿elf and Army,) he boldly marched over the Sea, upon the Ice, into Fuinen; and having Å¿ubdued it, and the IÅ¿lands about, one after another, in the Å¿ame manner he enters Zeeland, divided from them by a narrow Frith, where, by the Å¿ame Storm of a Å¿udden War, he had overwhelmed Copenhagen, had not a Peace been made at RoÅ¿child, by the Mediation of Medows, (who with JepÅ¿on was by Oliver Å¿ent from England as Mediators of Peace, he to the Swede, and the other to the Dane) and the Intervention of the EmbaÅ¿Å¿adors of other Princes: for which timely Service King Frederick made Medows Knight of the Elephant, and a Nobleman of Denmark: And King Charles the Second of England, as a TeÅ¿timony of His Favour for the good Offices done to his KinÅ¿man, honoured him likewiÅ¿e with Knighthood.

The War breaking out again afterward betwixt the Kings, the Swede having poÅ¿Å¿eÅ¿Å¿ed himÅ¿elf of Croneberg, and the greateÅ¿t part of Denmark, and blocked up Copenhagen by a long and obÅ¿tinate Siege, both Parties implore the AÅ¿Å¿iÅ¿tance of Neighbouring Nations;Afterward he demands AÅ¿Å¿iÅ¿tance from the EngliÅ¿h, and the Dane from the Dutch.
Carolus GuÅ¿tavus, of the EngliÅ¿h; and Frederick, of the Dutch. The Swede wanted Ships and Seamen; the Dane, all kind of Relief, to wit, Soldiers, Ships, and Ammunition. The Swede offered the EngliÅ¿h for their Security, and a Reward of their Pains, Gluckstadt, with a Å¿mall Territory on the other Å¿ide of the Elbe (which nevertheleÅ¿s was not in his power), and Leth-Fort upon
the River WeÅ¿e. But the EngliÅ¿h demanding either Gottenberg on the Baltick Sea near the Sound, or ElÅ¿enburg that lies in the Mouth of the Baltick, Cromwell and the Swede diÅ¿agree about the Terms. Cromwell Å¿ends thither a Fleet, and two Mediators. NevertheleÅ¿s, Oliver fits out a pretty conÅ¿iderable Fleet in England; and, that he might watch all Opportunities of advantage for the EngliÅ¿h, Å¿ends it into Denmark, under the Command of GoodÅ¿on; but the Ice and Winter-Colds hindred it from advancing beyond Scagen: and at length Richard Å¿ent a greater, under the Command of Admiral Montague, who was afterwards made Earl of Sandwich, and Knight of the Garter. But the Dutch being Å¿ecure that the EngliÅ¿h would not interfere and moleÅ¿t them, that they might maintain a Free Trade through the Sound, and at the Å¿ame time aÅ¿Å¿iÅ¿t the King of Denmark, The Dutch likewiÅ¿e aÅ¿Å¿iÅ¿t the Dane, having fought the Swedes at Sea. reduced to the utmoÅ¿t extremity, fitted out a Fleet, under the Command of General Opdam, provided with all NeceÅ¿Å¿aries; which having engaged in a Sea-fight with the Swedes, with equal LoÅ¿s on both Sides, they Å¿upplied Copenhagen with Ammunition, and plenty of all ProviÅ¿ions.

The French by the aÅ¿Å¿iÅ¿tance of the EngliÅ¿h take Montmidy; and preÅ¿ently after Mardyke Fort, which is given to the EngliÅ¿h to be defended.To Flanders now the Å¿eries of this Å¿hort HiÅ¿tory calls me, where the Affairs of the Spaniards began to decline and grow daily worÅ¿e and worÅ¿e. A well appointed Army of Å¿ix thouÅ¿and EngliÅ¿h under the Command of Reynolds is landed at Calis; of which Å¿ome aÅ¿Å¿iÅ¿t the French in taking Montmidy, and being afterwards all joyned with the French, they take Mardyke Fort two Miles diÅ¿tant from Dunkirk, which was given to the Engl â¢ Å¿h to be kept during the Winter, who fortifie it round with PaliÅ¿adoes, beÅ¿ides a Wall and Ditch, and render it impregnable. NevertheleÅ¿s the moÅ¿t illuÅ¿trious Duke of York reÅ¿olved
to attaque it, bringing therefore about four thouÅ¿and Men before it, partly EngliÅ¿h, Scots, and IriÅ¿h, and partly Spaniards, The Duke of York in vain attempts it. he attacks it in the Night-time by an AÅ¿Å¿ault. It was moreover repreÅ¿ented to him, That he had Å¿till a Å¿afe refuge under the Mercy of the King, if he would expiate his Fathers Crime by his own Allegiance; that it was the part of a King to keep his Word; that the Lord Petcombe, the DaniÅ¿h ReÅ¿ident, had promiÅ¿ed to Å¿end over Letters Å¿afe to the Soundt, that a MeÅ¿Å¿enger might be more Å¿ecurely Å¿ent afterward to the Admiral to acquaint him with theÅ¿e Affairs; and that he would likewiÅ¿e give Å¿ecurity on the Kings part, that the Articles Å¿hould be fulfilled: That that was no Å¿uch difficult thing to be done, Å¿ince the Fleet was as yet free from Contagion, the Admiral ready to Å¿erve the King, and both hating and hated by the Parricides; that beÅ¿ides, PortÅ¿mouth and other Å¿trong Holds would joyn with him in a Å¿trict Confederacy; that moÅ¿t part of the People alÅ¿o, for the Å¿ake of the King, and to revenge the injuries done to himÅ¿elf, and the Parliament, abruptly
diÅ¿Å¿olved, would riÅ¿e in Arms; and laÅ¿tly, that all Ireland was as yet Å¿ubject to his Government. Being Å¿ollicited by theÅ¿e and Å¿uch like Arguments, he was in Å¿uÅ¿pence, not knowing what to do; he was toÅ¿Å¿ed betwixt hope and fear, having miÅ¿Å¿ed or abuÅ¿ed the occaÅ¿ion of doing his buÅ¿ineÅ¿s, Å¿ometimes preferring the CounÅ¿els of Å¿ome, and by and by again of others, and Å¿ometimes ready to run for it: till at length being adviÅ¿ed by Fleetwood and other Republicans (whoÅ¿e Opinions he had privately asked) That it would be much Å¿afer for him to enjoy certain and Å¿ure Priviledges,
â¢ eetwood di
â¢ wading him. than dangerouÅ¿ly make tryal of new Experiments, with fear and aÅ¿toniÅ¿hment he keeps in Whitehall.

In the mean time a Council being called, the Officers that had Å¿tood for Richard, Ingoldsby, Coff, Whaley, Fal â¢ onberge, and Howard, are â¢ aÅ¿heered; the old Republican Colonels, whom his Father had formerly turned out, Lambert, HarriÅ¿on, Rich, Parker, Ok â¢ y and others, being again brought into play. Then the Officers of the Army, with Å¿ome five or Å¿ix Members of the MuÅ¿ty Old Rump, The Officers agan raiÅ¿e the Rump from the Dead, meeting together in the HouÅ¿e of the Old Speaker Lenthall, require him, that he would reaÅ¿Å¿ume his Chair, after a long intermiÅ¿Å¿ion, in Parliament, and again Å¿it at the Helm of the Government. Which at firÅ¿t he refuÅ¿ed, alledging invincible Arguments to the contrary; but afterwards, partly through the threats and deÅ¿ires of Vane, and chiefly of Lambert, partly through his own PuÅ¿illanimity, and partly through his own ambitious deÅ¿ire of Rule, he is prevailed upon, and condeÅ¿cends. The Officers having acknowledged the injury they had done to the Rump, and having publickly declared their Å¿orrow for it, and the Members
obliging themÅ¿elves of new, by mutual engagements, the Speaker with his Mace before him enters the HouÅ¿e of Commons, being attended by as many as could be got together out of the Streets, Ale-houÅ¿es, Taverns,(And what Å¿ort of Men they were:) even the Army and PriÅ¿ons; which nevertheleÅ¿s being computed, hardly made up two and fourty Men: by Å¿o Å¿mall a Thread the Affairs of England then hung. Yet theÅ¿e Varlets made no Å¿cruple to repreÅ¿ent three States, make and unmake Laws, ProÅ¿ â¢ ribe, Forfeit, and take to themÅ¿elves the abÅ¿olute Power over the Lives and Fortunes of all.

The Articles or Engagements that they entered in, were to this purpoÅ¿e;And bound to theÅ¿e Articles, That all Å¿hould enjoy their Liberties and Properties. That there be a fixed and determinate proceeding in Law. That all Crimes relating to the change of Government be aboliÅ¿hed. That all Statutes and Ordinances remain in force, until the contrary be Enacted. That Publick Debts be punctually paid. That no Man believing in the Father, Son, and Holy GhoÅ¿t, and acknowledging the Holy Bible for the Word of God, be debarred from the profeÅ¿Å¿ion of his Religion, except EpiÅ¿copal-Men and PapiÅ¿ts. That a Zealous and Powerful MiniÅ¿try be by all means cheriÅ¿hed. That Colledges and Schools be reformed. That at preÅ¿ent Fleetwood have the chief Command of the Forces both by Sea and Land. That for the future, the Parliament have the LegiÅ¿lative Power, and the Council of State the Executive. That the Protectors Debts be paid: and that he have a Liberal PenÅ¿ion of Ten thouÅ¿and pounds yearly, during Life, and ten thouÅ¿and more in Inheritance. And that his Mother alÅ¿o, during Life, have eight thouÅ¿and pounds yearly out of the Exchequer.

Send them into the Parliament-houÅ¿e.The Parricides being bound to theÅ¿e Articles, take their Seats again in the Parliament-HouÅ¿e; but how much they valued them, they make it quickly manifeÅ¿t. In the mean time, many of the old Members, to the number of above three hundred, who had been Å¿ecluded heretofore by the Officers of the Army, though they believed the Parliament to be diÅ¿Å¿olved by the Death of Charles the FirÅ¿t, and the Abrogation of the HouÅ¿e of Lords, yet, that they might avoid other Inconveniencies, deÅ¿iring to be readmitted, are carefully kept out. Some few Days after, they Å¿end CommiÅ¿Å¿ioners to Richard, to ask him the QueÅ¿tion, How he liked the change of Government, and what Debts he owed? that wheadling him with the hopes of kind uÅ¿age, they might draw from him a voluntary renunciation of the Authority. He makes anÅ¿wer, That he thought it reaÅ¿onable that he Å¿hould Å¿ubmit to their Authority, from whom he muÅ¿t expect protection: that his Steward Å¿hould give them an account of his Debts.
Richard out of fear having reÅ¿igned up his Authority, But nothing but a formal and expreÅ¿s reÅ¿ignation would pleaÅ¿e them; to which he Å¿eemed chearfully to give his aÅ¿Å¿ent. And now at length he is commanded to deliver up all the Goods and HouÅ¿hold Furniture, not Å¿o much as reÅ¿erving to himÅ¿elf any Gold or Silver, Jewels or Hangings, Linnen, or any other Goods that might have been pack'd up in a Å¿mall bulk; all are adjudged to the Exchequer.Stript of all, departs out of Whitehall. Thus Å¿tript of all, he is commanded to depart out of Whitehall, liable to the Actions of all his Creditors, and perhaps to have been tried for his Life, had they not had other FiÅ¿h to fry.

Behold the perfidiouÅ¿neÅ¿s of Mortal Men, and a wonderful inÅ¿tance of Divine Providence,
which preÅ¿ides over, and alters Humane Affairs and Governments, as it Å¿eemeth Good to the Amighty! He who juÅ¿t now Å¿wayed the Scepter of three Kingdoms, forced by the Calamities of a tedious Civil War to truckle under his Vicegerents, three old Commanders, to wit, his Brother, Brother-in-law, and a third, whom Cromwell had obliged by many and great Favours; he, I Å¿ay, in the Å¿hort Å¿pace of one year, is craftily turned out of all, and now Å¿tript of his borrowed Plumes, he becomes the object of the Raillery of Poets and Painters,And being made a laughing Å¿tock, betakes himÅ¿elf again to a Country Life. and being Å¿ufficiently laÅ¿ht with the giibes and reproaches both of the Parricides, and Rabble, as of old the Dictator was called from the Plough, Å¿o now the Protector is Å¿ent back to the Plough.

div.head: Part the Third: OR, THE HISTORY OF THE CompoÅ¿ing the Affairs of England By the ReÅ¿tauration of King CHARLES II. And the PuniÅ¿hment of the Regicides, And the Settlement of the Church and State as they were before the Rebellion.
div.p: THE Civil War of England, begun by a pernicious and fatal Parliament, A Recapitulation of things paÅ¿t. raged for the Å¿pace of eight years with various Å¿ucceÅ¿Å¿es of Battels; till the RoyaliÅ¿ts being in all parts worÅ¿ted, and not able to keep the Field, Charles the FirÅ¿t, the beÅ¿t of Kings, a Prince of moÅ¿t exalted but perÅ¿ecuted Virtue, to avoid the victorious Arms of the EngliÅ¿h Independants, moved by ill fate or bad counÅ¿el, caÅ¿t himÅ¿elf into the arms of the Presbyterian Scots, by whom he was, for a round Å¿um of money, treacherouÅ¿ly delivered up into the hands of EngliÅ¿h Traytors.

Nor was it long before he was a Å¿ad inÅ¿tance, that
the PriÅ¿ons of Kings are but little diÅ¿tant from their Graves.

For (what the flagitiouÅ¿neÅ¿s of paÅ¿t Ages never attempted, and future Will hardly believe) the unfortunate Prince, to make way for the UÅ¿urpation of the Traytor Cromwel, January 30. 1648. was forced by a Å¿cenical and mock-form of Law and JuÅ¿tice, to lay down his Å¿acred head to be Å¿truck off upon a Block. The boldeÅ¿t Villany that ever any Nation Å¿aw; and a Parricide that all the World was aÅ¿toniÅ¿hed at.

But this Villany Å¿ucceeding Å¿o proÅ¿perouÅ¿ly, and Britain at length,September 3. 1650. and Sept. 3. 1651. and Ireland being Å¿ubdued by victorious Rebels, as the Forces of Charles the Second were entirely routed by the defeats at Dumbar and WorceÅ¿ter; Cromwel the Traytor delayed no longer the execution of his long-projected WickedneÅ¿s. He knew full well, that the name of the Parliament was grown odious to the people, through the uneaÅ¿ineÅ¿s of their flagitious and uÅ¿urped Dominion. Turning therefore his Arms againÅ¿t his hauty MaÅ¿ters,April 20. 1653. he turned them out of the HouÅ¿e, as Objects firÅ¿t of his own contempt, and then of the peoples Å¿corn. The onely grateful action he did to the Kingdom.

Cromw. takes upon him the ProtectorÅ¿hip.And now Cromwel being MaÅ¿ter, and impatient of a Å¿low progreÅ¿s to UÅ¿urpation, graÅ¿ps the Scepter, with the lofty Title of Protector. In the mean time he ruled more arbitrarily than a King, though he Å¿eemed to refuÅ¿e the Title which he paÅ¿Å¿ionately aÅ¿pired to. Whether he was more remarkable for FalÅ¿hood or Valour, the Reader may judge, Å¿ince Courage he had by turns and intervals, but was never without HypocriÅ¿ie and native Treachery.

Richard Å¿ucceeds to his villanous UÅ¿urpation,Richard Å¿ucceeds. a Son in all things unlike to his Father, and unfit for daring ReÅ¿olutions. His judgment and actions were managed by the direction and Å¿uggeÅ¿tions of others; and was Å¿o eaÅ¿ily impoÅ¿ed upon by their knavery, that by what followed Å¿hortly after, Æ²nfit for the dignity. it appeared that onely the late Cromwel had a mind able to Å¿upport Å¿uch a weight.

For the Colonels of the Democratical Faction heretofore turned out,He is deÅ¿piÅ¿ed by the Democratical Colonels. who were more addicted to the government of the Parliament, than to that of a Protector, when they perceived the turn of Affairs, and their old hopes revived, revenged by the ruine of the Son, the injuries they had received from the Father. And abuÅ¿ing the eaÅ¿ineÅ¿s of Richard to inÅ¿olence and contempt, they induÅ¿triouÅ¿ly Å¿et about the changing again of the Protectordom into a Commonwealth.

Whether the Relations and CounÅ¿ellors of Richard were privy to the Plot, or deluded, I cannot Å¿ay, Richard's Relations combine with them but at length they fatally deluded him. And being Complices of the Treachery of the Democraticks, they were made a Cloak for the Ambition of others. Richard therefore being adviÅ¿ed by his Friends to diÅ¿Å¿olve the Parliament which he had lately called, the onely Å¿upport of his own hopes, and terrour of the Rebel-Colonels; too late he was Å¿enÅ¿ible of the treachery or ignorance of his Friends, and too late condemned his own credulity. Richard's
affairs being then in their declenÅ¿ion, and his Relations Fleetwood and Desborough Å¿educed either by vanity or knavery; The power of Lambert formerly laid aÅ¿ide, became now paramount, and by joynt Councils in appearance,Lambert, &c. returns to the Army. they managed the Affairs of the Government with equal care, though different deÅ¿ignes; but what Fleetwood more openly, Lambert more cunningly carried on.

And now the Officers whom old Cromwel had heretofore turned out of the Army, being reÅ¿tored, they invaded the Forces, as before they did the government of Richard. But that the matter might be brought about in the uÅ¿ual forms, they appoint Prayers, the common prelude of Traytors, to be made in St. James's; where many Independant Preachers of great note in their long-winded Prayers, call upon God as a WitneÅ¿s of their Treachery. And the very Å¿ame who lately prayed for the health of Cromwel on his Death-bed, now baÅ¿ely and craftily conÅ¿ult about the excluÅ¿ion of his Son.

The Rump-Parliament is reÅ¿tored by the Colonels.But whilÅ¿t they haÅ¿tned the execution of their late deÅ¿ignes, they gave a remarkable and foul inÅ¿tance of their inconÅ¿tancy, by reÅ¿toring to Supreme Power, the Rump-Parliament, which Cromwel by their own hands Å¿ix years before, had dragg'd out of the HouÅ¿e: that Å¿ink of ill men, I mean, who were infamous by the Spoils of the publick, foully Å¿tained with all Å¿ort of Knavery, Impudence, and Avarice; and for their Crimes Å¿o univerÅ¿ally hated of the People, that it was a very eaÅ¿ie matter to have raiÅ¿ed or depreÅ¿Å¿ed again theÅ¿e Phantoms of Government, by the like wantonneÅ¿s of the giddy Mobile.

To be turned out again i â¢ time.
Which depoÅ¿es Richard
And now theÅ¿e Parliament-Robbers being again admitted to the Government, they take their known places, and being above all things mindful of Cromwel's Treachery, they turn out Richard, wavering,
as yet, and tottering in his Throne; and lay the quaking ProteÅ¿toral Youth flat upon the ground. As if by turning the infamy upon the Cromwels they might thereby wipe off their own Reproach.

They demand an account of the Funeral-charges of his dead Father,Then expoÅ¿es him. (wherein that prodigal Villain had outdone the burials of Kings) and of his own Creditors; but with no deÅ¿igne, in the mean while, to pay his Debts, onely to expoÅ¿e him to contempt, becauÅ¿e of his Poverty, or to Å¿corn, for his Luxury.

The Members of Parliament that were more innocent than themÅ¿elves,And excludes many of the Members. or more adverÅ¿e to bad Councils, by Guards Å¿et at the door, they exclude out of the HouÅ¿e; and preÅ¿ently declare the Secret and MyÅ¿tery of the Government, which with no leÅ¿s vanity than impudence, they Å¿tiled, THE GOOD OLD CAÆ²SE.

From the meeting of this fatal Rump again,May 8. I Å¿hall begin my work. The firÅ¿t thing they now do, is to conÅ¿ult how they may Å¿ecure themÅ¿elves, and undo the Publick. That they had been formerly thruÅ¿t out by the Souldiers,The Rump prevents the power of the Colonels. Å¿truck deep in their minds; and that they might therefore prevent future Snares from the Colonels, they reÅ¿erve to themÅ¿elves the Supreme Authority in the Army; making their Speaker Lenthal General in the Chair. And having turned out the Officers of the Army that were for a Protectoral Dignity, they create new ones out of the Sink of Democraticks.
But before I proceed any farther, it will be neceÅ¿Å¿ary both for my Å¿elf and the Reader, to give a more accurate account of the Å¿tate of the EngliÅ¿h Affairs at that time.

The fate of the Cromwels was now come: for
Richard being laid aÅ¿ide at London,
Henry Cromwel Deputy of Ireland, Å¿ubmits to the Rump. his Brother Henry, whom his Father had made Deputy of Ireland, imitating his Brothers weakneÅ¿s, at the command of the Rump, delivers up the Army and Government to Colonel Ludlow, a Å¿tern man, and truÅ¿ty to the Faction, who Å¿ucceeded him.

And Monk, Governour of Scotland; and the Fleet under LauÅ¿on.
Monk, Governour of Scotland, a man often to be mentioned in our Annals, promiÅ¿ed to be true to the Rump-Parliament; as alÅ¿o did the Fleet, and Vice-Admiral LauÅ¿on.
