And Å¿o with bitter Invectives they reckon up the ImpriÅ¿onments, SequeÅ¿trations, continual Taxes, and the other Å¿everities they had been obnoxious to.

That they had long enough born the burden of the accurÅ¿ed Parliament, and groaned under the Yoke of an enraged Enemy: That the Power of both was abominable, and their Bondage grievous: That wicked Parricides laughed at their MiÅ¿eries, whilÅ¿t they falÅ¿ly call Slavery, Peace; Cruelty and Slaughter, DiÅ¿cipline: That Å¿ince whether they be overcome or do Å¿ubmit, they muÅ¿t periÅ¿h; how much more honourably would they periÅ¿h in the embraces of their Liberty and Country? That Å¿lavery is leÅ¿s ignominious to thoÅ¿e who attempt their freedom, and that they had already Å¿inned enough through cowardiÅ¿e: That they Å¿hould Å¿hake off the Yoke of the Jangling Traytors, and put an end to Å¿o many years bondage: That the raÅ¿h attempts of the daring have often been favoured by fortune: That Å¿ecret hopes in Monk, wealth in the City, the fortune of London, and God their Protector, were Å¿till in being: That it would be glorious to themÅ¿elves and PoÅ¿terity, to have expiated the civil Troubles wantonly begun by their AnceÅ¿tors, and the Royal Bloud of Charles the Martyr, by reÅ¿toring his Son with no other helps than the Loyalty of his own Subjects.

AmidÅ¿t theÅ¿e diÅ¿contented Speeches and City-tumults,The tumult of the London-Prentices. a vaÅ¿t croud of Prentices and Serving-men got together: a bold Å¿ort of men, accuÅ¿tomed to an inÅ¿olent kind of City-liberty, who tired out by long Å¿lavery, with a licentious freedom, run about in all places in a tumultuary and confuÅ¿ed manner, demanding a new and full Parliament, as the onely Remedy to their Evils.

But Colonel HewÅ¿on, formerly a Cobler, Is Å¿uppreÅ¿Å¿ed by HewÅ¿on. Decemb. 3. being by Fleetwood Å¿ent into the City with a Party of brisk Souldiers, in a moment Å¿uppreÅ¿Å¿ed the defenceleÅ¿s anger of the Rabble, and the headleÅ¿s Multitude, and uÅ¿ed many Å¿everities againÅ¿t the Citizens.

The Grievances of the City increaÅ¿ing daily,The GarriÅ¿on of PortÅ¿mouth riÅ¿es for the Rump. Wetham Governour of PortÅ¿mouth admitted into the place three Members of the late excluded Rump, and Colonels in the Army, to wit, Hazelrigg, Walton, and Morley: againÅ¿t whom Fleetwood having Å¿ent Forces, they deÅ¿pairing of the Å¿trength of their Friends, and having neither money nor credit, revolted to the Enemy.

Nor was this all the misfortune that befel Fleetwood and the Committee of Safety: The Navy endeavours the Å¿ame. for Vice-Admiral LawÅ¿on with a Fleet of Ships true to the CauÅ¿e, Å¿topt the mouth of the River of Thames, threatning to Å¿uffer none to eÅ¿cape by Sea, if they did not again reÅ¿tore the Rump to the power of Government.

All things everywhere growing worÅ¿e and worÅ¿e, Fleetwood yields to the Rump. the Committee of Safety was Å¿tartled; and Fleetwood unfit for adverÅ¿ity, who never could bear proÅ¿perity, and growing daily more contemptible and cheap, neither conÅ¿tant in his ReÅ¿olution, nor reÅ¿olute in his Treachery; having Å¿ent a fawning MeÅ¿Å¿enger to Lenthal the Speaker, he prays and beÅ¿eeches, more Å¿laviÅ¿hly than became a General, that
the Members being forthwith called together, they would take upon them the Government, and receive them into favour who confeÅ¿Å¿ed their errour. And indeed many of the Committee of Safety,
The Committee of Safety wavers. though they were very deÅ¿irous of retaining their Power, yet conÅ¿ulted about the reÅ¿toring of the Rump, knowing very well that their Government would not be long, if Lambert returned victorious from the North.

Fleetwood's Å¿ouldiers make defection to the Rump.And now General Fleetwood's Regiments Å¿elling their Å¿ouls and bloud for Eight pence a day, under Colonels of the Democratical Faction, return under the power of the Rump, forgetting their yeÅ¿terdays-Commander, who carried the empty Title of General. Nor was there any publick Commodity Å¿o Å¿aleable as the Treachery of the Souldiers.
The Committee of Safety is diÅ¿Å¿olved. This was the Exit of the two months-whirlegig of Government; the very names of Fleetwood and Lambert grew contemptible, and Safety forÅ¿ook the Committee.

So Å¿oon as Monk underÅ¿tood that the Fleet were for the Rump, and that the GarriÅ¿on of PortÅ¿mouth was of the Å¿ame mind, having Å¿peedily recalled his CommiÅ¿Å¿ioners, he broke off the Conference and Overture of Peace with Lambert. In the mean time he wrote to him, Monk breaks off the Conference of Pacification. That Å¿ince he underÅ¿tood that the Parliament by their own authority had choÅ¿en PortÅ¿mouth for their SeÅ¿Å¿ion, he thought it not conÅ¿onant to his truÅ¿t and modeÅ¿ty, by private Debates to conÅ¿titute a private Commonwealth; but rather Å¿etting aÅ¿ide the Quarrels of the two Armies, to refer the adminiÅ¿tration of publick Affairs to their prudence and care.

The Rump reÅ¿tored to the Government. Decemb. 6. The Reverend Rump now Å¿trikes in again, in the laÅ¿t year of their government, and probably the beÅ¿t for the Publick; though reinÅ¿tated more by the beggary than the good will of the Souldiers. And this was the reaÅ¿on that their chief care was for
money, and that the Souldiers might be paid by the Å¿poils of the State.Recals Lambert's Army. Lambert's forces are imperiouÅ¿ly commanded back to their GarriÅ¿ons, and forthwith to leave the Field, upon pain of diÅ¿obeying the Supreme Power, and forfeiting their Duty. And at the Å¿ame time news was brought to Monk's Camp, that the Committee of Safety was broken, and the Rump again in power.

What could Lambert now between hawk and buzzard do? he was forÅ¿aken by Fortune, deluded by Fleetwood's confidence, over-reached by Monk under a colour of Peace, and deÅ¿piÅ¿ed by the Rump. Should he return to London, it was a long and difficult march; and perhaps as late for the Å¿uccour of his friends as dangerous to himÅ¿elf, having Å¿uch an Enemy in the rear. Should he engage Monk in a Country improper for HorÅ¿e, the ground being covered over with Ice and Snow, it would be very uncertain, if not in vain, Å¿ince in the dead of Winter his HorÅ¿e could do no feats: What to do he could not tell.

Nor were Lambert's men truer to their TruÅ¿t than Fleetwood's had been at London: The treachery of Lambert's men towards him. for Å¿o Å¿oon as they heard of the defection of the London-Regiments, baÅ¿ely, without conÅ¿ulting their General, nay, and Å¿lighting his authority, they Å¿ubmit to the Rump.

Few now were to be Å¿een at Lambert's door, and fewer within; nothing but Å¿ilence, and Å¿eldom any Guards: He was no more General nor cauÅ¿e of the War; but where he hoped for Laurel and Triumph, he was fain to Å¿earch a hiding place: Å¿o that without any attendance, he Å¿peedily and Å¿ecretly betook himÅ¿elf to London. So fallacious and uncertain a thing is Power, when it is too great.

A certain kind of Triumviral Power now exerted it Å¿elf in Britain under Monk, Fleetwood, and
Lambert, not much unlike to that Roman Triumvirat of CaeÅ¿ar, Pompey, and CraÅ¿Å¿us.

With almoÅ¿t the Å¿ame gallantry Monk behaved himÅ¿elf in Scotland, as CaeÅ¿ar heretofore governed in Gallia; but out of their Governments Monk out-did CaeÅ¿ar: for the Roman being come into the City, offered violence to the Senate, and unjuÅ¿tly uÅ¿urped the DictatorÅ¿hip. The other entering London, under colour of reÅ¿toring the Parliament, by a rare inÅ¿tance of Loyalty and ModeÅ¿ty, reÅ¿tored the King.

Nor were the emulous and competing CraÅ¿Å¿us and Pompey more Å¿ollicitous in drawing in CaeÅ¿ar, than Fleetwood and Lambert were in endeavouring to aÅ¿Å¿ociate Monk into the Government: for though they contributed their mutual aÅ¿Å¿iÅ¿tance in overturning the Rump-Parliament, yet it is certain, they hardly conÅ¿pired in any thing, but in the fear that both of them had of Monk. Fleetwood was jealous of Lambert's ambition; and Lambert could not brook Fleetwood's authority: the one could not admit of an Equal, nor the other of a Superiour.

Monk therefore was courted by Letters from both, as having it in his power to give the Government to what Party he pleaÅ¿ed. Nor could Fleetwood have expected better Conditions from Lambert, had he prevailed againÅ¿t Monk; which thoÅ¿e who favoured Fleetwood in his Army perceiving, avoiding all opportunity of fighting with Monk, leÅ¿t Lambert, perchance, getting the victory, might turn out his Rival Fleetwood. Lambert can hardly be compared to Pompey, unleÅ¿s it be in boundleÅ¿s ambition, and the unhappy iÅ¿Å¿ue thereof; and Fleetwood not at all to CraÅ¿Å¿us.
But without doubt it was the intereÅ¿t of the Publick that both were undone, Å¿eeing Monk getting the better, reÅ¿tored at length Britain to it Å¿elf.

Lambert's Forces in all places having either run away or Å¿ubmitted, Monk divides his Army,1659, 60. Monk marches into England, January 1. 1659, 60. and under his own and Morgan's conduct, marches Å¿treight to London; a march that will be famous in all future Ages, and memorable to PoÅ¿terity.

On New-years-day, having Å¿ent before the Foot, he moved from CaldÅ¿tream, and the day after he himÅ¿elf followed with the HorÅ¿e, and took his Quarters at Wellar: the next day,At Morpet he receives Letters from the Mayor of London. when he was come to Morpet, he received Letters from the Lord Mayor and Court of Aldermen of London, Å¿ent by the City-Sword-bearer, wherein they earneÅ¿tly entreat him, That according to the great TruÅ¿t and Power he had, having now found an occaÅ¿ion, than which, Providence had never offered a greater, he would relieve the diÅ¿treÅ¿Å¿ed State, and call a new and full Parliament, as the onely Å¿upport of their tottering Country; freely offering him the aÅ¿Å¿iÅ¿tance and concurrence of the City in the affair.

And now on the fourth of January,
He comes to NewcaÅ¿tle, Jan. 4. Monk having marched his Army over deÅ¿ert Mountains in deep Winter-Snow, arrived at NewcaÅ¿tle, and the day following Å¿ets forward to Durham;Jan. 5. from thence directing his march to York; near Allerton he was honourably received by the Sheriff of the County.

Being next day come to York, He enters York. he was met by a multitude of Citizens and PerÅ¿ons of Quality, and by them Å¿plendidly conducted into the City. Having performed Å¿o great a march in Å¿o Å¿hort a time, he reÅ¿ted here five days, either that he might let the news of his coming flie before him to London, or that having allowed Å¿ome time, he might by his Agents, of whom he had a great many in the City, be early informed of the Councils of the Rump, and inclinations of the Citizens.

Here Monk met with Fairfax, a famous Souldier,
and his old Companion in the Wars; who now following his own humour,Monk meets with Fairfax at York. had riÅ¿en in Arms againÅ¿t Lambert, and was with no contemptible Forces, but far greater reputation, come over to the right Å¿ide, being now with more honour an Enemy, than he had heretofore been General of the Å¿ame Army.

He Å¿ends part of his Army under Morgan back into Scotland. During this Å¿tay at York, Monk received into his Å¿ervice Å¿ome Regiments of Lambert's Army, having changed the Colonels and Officers; and no Enemy now appearing anywhere, he muÅ¿tered his Army, and Å¿ent back part of it under the command of Morgan into Scotland.

He himÅ¿elf, with four thouÅ¿and Foot, and eighteen hundred HorÅ¿e, marches forwards towards London. Such was the Army of Monk, the leaÅ¿t and yet moÅ¿t renowned body of men that ever marched through England, which being hardly a third part in number to the enemy, buoyed up the fate of tottering Britain, and the fortune of Charles the Second.

Monk meets Clarges at Nottingham. Jan. 19.The Army marching from hence, and being come to Nottingham, he was met by Clarges, who came poÅ¿t from London, a man deÅ¿ervedly of great intereÅ¿t and authority with him. He Å¿ecretly informed him of the deÅ¿ignes of the Rump, the Å¿trength of the City-Forces, the Å¿uÅ¿picions and jealouÅ¿ies of the Sectarians, and that the hopes of the Citizens depended wholly on him.

The CommiÅ¿Å¿ioners of the Rump meet Monk at LeiceÅ¿ter. Jan. 22. Upon his march he was met at LeiceÅ¿ter, and congratulated by Scot and RobinÅ¿on, CommiÅ¿Å¿ioners from the Rump, upon pretext of doing honour to the General, and civilly waiting upon him in his march; but in reality as Spies to dive into his Å¿ecrets, and diligently to obÅ¿erve his words and actions.

Nor was Monk leÅ¿s circumÅ¿pect, but being a
great concealer of his thoughts, and Å¿paring in words, accommodating all his diÅ¿courÅ¿e to occaÅ¿ion, and Å¿hewing the CommiÅ¿Å¿ioners all imaginable reÅ¿pect in the Army, he confirmed them in the opinion of his Å¿incerity.

In this long and triumphant march,The people everywhere petition Monk for a new Parliament. he advanced amidÅ¿t the ApplauÅ¿e and Congratulation of all men, and everywhere was met by the people, who, to the grief of the CommiÅ¿Å¿ioners, petitioned him for a full and free Parliament, as the onely Remedy to their Evils. The Å¿ame the CommiÅ¿Å¿ioners from the City of London deÅ¿ired, upon their meeting the General at Harborough. At Northampton he met with the like. And moÅ¿t part of the neighbouring and more remote Counties of England, Å¿ent him Deputies and Petitions to the Å¿ame effect: all which, Monk that kept his own counÅ¿el, civilly received, but cautiouÅ¿ly anÅ¿wered.

Now was Monk arrived at St. Albans, From St. Albans he Å¿ends to the Rump, Jan. 28. within twenty miles of London, wholly intent upon his entering the City. Therefore by Colonel Lidcolt he prudently wrote to the Rump to acquaint them with his approach; And that Å¿eeing he had brought with him an Army true to the Parliament, and moÅ¿t obÅ¿ervant of DiÅ¿cipline, he intimated to them, that it would be unÅ¿afe to mingle his honeÅ¿t and faithful Souldiers with the treacherous Forces in London,DeÅ¿iring Fleetwood's Forces to be Å¿ent out of Town. who were Å¿o lately endeavouring changes, and their fierceneÅ¿s not as yet wholly laid aÅ¿ide: that therefore for the Å¿afety of the Parliament, he earneÅ¿tly intreats them, that Å¿ending forthwith Fleetwood's Forces out of Town, they would order them Quarters to be appointed by the Quarter-MaÅ¿ter-General. This was the reaÅ¿on alleadged in publick, but in Å¿ecret there was another.

The Rump conÅ¿ented to Monk's deÅ¿ire,The Rump conÅ¿ented. whether cordially, or rather out of fear, I Å¿hall not determine. And therefore Fleetwood's men are ordered
to leave the City, and to go and quarter in the Country at a diÅ¿tance.

Fleetwood's men march angrily out. Feb. 2. But the Pretorian Bands being long pampered in London, angrily, and with a threatning carriage, left the City; rage being mingled with their obedience, and the hatred of the Parties Å¿till remaining after the War.

Monk enters London. Monk in the mean time came from St. Albans to Barnet, and the day following being the third of February, marched into London in order. He himÅ¿elf in military pomp lead the HorÅ¿e through the Å¿treets of London, and, not without a preÅ¿age, took his Lodgings in Whitehall.

The Parliament had been Å¿o often garbl'd and curtail'd, that it was then by the People in deriÅ¿ion called the Rump: But theÅ¿e Senatorian ConÅ¿pirators, the Å¿hame and Å¿corn of all honeÅ¿t men, being of inÅ¿olent tempers, and now the third time got into power, blown up with proÅ¿perity, began more and more daily to inÅ¿ult over the Publick; and being in fear on both hands, from their friends as well as foes; and knowing that their Å¿trength conÅ¿iÅ¿ted more in Fame than in Force, they reÅ¿olved to eÅ¿tabliÅ¿h their Tyranny by a new Oath, The Rump by Oath abjures Monarchy. and that the deÅ¿peration of all Pardon might adde Å¿trength to this Bond of Iniquity, to compel the People to Å¿wear not onely, that they Å¿hould bear Faith and true Allegiance to the Commonwealth of England, and the preÅ¿ent Parliament; but that they Å¿hould alÅ¿o renounce and abjure all Allegiance to Charles the Second, and the whole Royal Family: Which was the laÅ¿t effort of their expiring Fortune.
In the mean time the Rumpers, being themÅ¿elves employed in perpetrating the higheÅ¿t Crimes, let thoÅ¿e of Booth's Party, and of the revolting Regiments, paÅ¿s unpuniÅ¿hed, as below their notice.

And now the Council of State, conÅ¿iÅ¿ting of the moÅ¿t villanous Republicans,
The Council of State offers Monk the Oath.
He delays. He goes to the Rump. Feb. 6.
renders the Oath to Monk; which he, as taking time rather to conÅ¿ider than refuÅ¿ing it, prudently avoided.

The third day after Monk had entred the City, being attended by Scot and RobinÅ¿on, he went to the HouÅ¿e, where the Speaker Lenthall, a mighty man at words, and nothing elÅ¿e, having commended his fidelity and good Å¿ervices rendred to the Parliament, in reÅ¿toring them by his Arms to their Authority, gave him the publick Thanks of the HouÅ¿e.
And now what Speech he again made to the Rump, I Å¿hall in his own words relate.

body.p:
AMongÅ¿t the many Mercies of God to theÅ¿e poor Nations, your peaceable ReÅ¿titution is not the leaÅ¿t; it is (as you Å¿ad) his work alone, and to him belongs the glory of it. And I eÅ¿teem it as a great effect of his goodneÅ¿s to me, that he was pleaÅ¿ed to make me, amongÅ¿t many worthier in your Å¿ervice, Å¿ome way inÅ¿trumental in it. I did nothing but my duty, and deÅ¿erve not to receive Å¿o great an honour and reÅ¿pect as you are pleaÅ¿ed to give me at this time and place; which I Å¿hall ever acknowledge as a high mark of your favour to me. Sir, I Å¿hall not now trouble you with large Narratives; onely give me leave to acquaint you, That as I marched out of Scotland hither, I obÅ¿erved the People in moÅ¿t Counties in great and earneÅ¿t expectations of a Settlement; and Å¿everal Applications were made to me, with numerous SubÅ¿criptions to them. The chiefeÅ¿t heads of their DeÅ¿ires were, for a free and full Parliament, and that you would determine your Å¿itting; a GoÅ¿pel-MiniÅ¿try; encouragement of Learning and Æ²niverÅ¿ities; and for admittance of the Members Å¿ecluded before the year 1648. without any previous
Oath or Engagement. To which I commonly anÅ¿wered, That you are now in a free Parliament; and if there be any force remaining upon you, I would endeavour to remove it; and that you had voted to fill up your HouÅ¿e, and then you would be a full Parliament alÅ¿o; and that you had already determined your Å¿itting: and for the MiniÅ¿try, their maintenance, the Laws, and Æ² niverÅ¿ities, you had largely declared concerning them in your laÅ¿t Declaration; and I was confident you would adhere to it. But as for thoÅ¿e Gentlemen Å¿ecluded in the year 1648. I told them, you had given judgment in it, and all people ought to acquieÅ¿ce in that judgment; but to admit any Members to Å¿it in Parliament without a previous Oath or Engagement to Å¿erve the Government in being, it was never done in England. But although I Å¿aid it not to them, I muÅ¿t Å¿ay (with pardon) to you, That the leÅ¿s Oaths and Engagements are impoÅ¿ed (with reÅ¿pect had to the Å¿ecurity of the common CauÅ¿e) your Å¿ettlement will be the Å¿ooner attained to. I am the more particular in theÅ¿e matters, to let you Å¿ee how grateful your preÅ¿ent ConÅ¿ultations about theÅ¿e matters will be to the people. I know all the Å¿ober Gentry will cloÅ¿e with you, if they may be tenderly and gently uÅ¿ed; and I am Å¿ure you will Å¿o uÅ¿e them, as knowing it to be the common concern, to accompliÅ¿h and not leÅ¿Å¿en our intereÅ¿t; and to be careful that neither the Cavalier nor the Fanatick Party have yet a Å¿hare in your Civil or Military Power; of the laÅ¿t, whoÅ¿e impatience to Government you have lately had Å¿o Å¿evere experience of. I Å¿hould Å¿ay Å¿omething of Ireland and Scotland: indeed Ireland is in an ill Å¿ettled condition, and made worÅ¿e by your interruptions, which prevented the paÅ¿Å¿ing an Act for the Å¿ettlement of the EÅ¿tates of Adventurers and Souldiers there, which I heard you intended to have done in a few days; and I preÅ¿ume it will be now quickly done, being Å¿o neceÅ¿Å¿ary at this time, when the wants of the Commonwealth call
for Å¿upplies: and people will unwillingly pay Taxes for thoÅ¿e EÅ¿tates, of which they have no legal aÅ¿Å¿urance. I need not tell you how much you were abuÅ¿ed in the nomination of the Officers of your Armies there; their malice that deceived you hath been Å¿ufficiently manifeÅ¿ted. I do affirm, that thoÅ¿e now who have declared for you, will continue faithful; and thereby convince, that as well there as here, it is the Å¿ober intereÅ¿t muÅ¿t eÅ¿tabliÅ¿h Dominion. As for Scotland, the People of that Nation deÅ¿erve to be cheriÅ¿hed much; and I believe your late Declaration will much glad their Å¿pirits: for nothing was more dreadful to them, than a fear to be over-run with Fanatick Notions. I humbly recommend them to your affection and eÅ¿teem, and deÅ¿ire the intended Æ²nion may be proÅ¿ecuted, and their Taxes made proportionably to thoÅ¿e in England; for which I am engaged in promiÅ¿e to become a Suiter to you. And truly, Sir, I muÅ¿t ask leave to entreat you to make a Å¿peedy proviÅ¿ion for their Civil Government there, of which they have been deÅ¿titute near a year, to the ruine of many Families: and except CommiÅ¿Å¿ioners for managing of the Government, and Judges to Å¿it in Courts of Judicature, be Å¿peedily appointed, that Country will be very miÅ¿erable. I directed Mr. Gumble (whom I lately Å¿ent to you, to give you an account of the affairs of the ScottiÅ¿h Army, and to make certain PropoÅ¿als in their names) to preÅ¿ent Å¿ome perÅ¿ons to you, both for CommiÅ¿Å¿ioners and Judges, which he did; but by reaÅ¿on of your great affairs, they were not diÅ¿patched: but I humbly now offer them to your conÅ¿ideration.

div.p:
If what the General Å¿pake was unpremeditated, Monk's Speech Å¿uÅ¿pected by the Members. certainly it was well his upon: but how the Rump were Å¿atisfied with his Speech, the Å¿equel will make it appear. BeÅ¿ides, his declining to take the Oath of Abjuration the day before, the freedom of his Å¿peech mightily netled the Rump-Abjurors, who
looked upon him as a Dictator rather than an Orator, commanding rather than petitioning; and who had Å¿eemed as much diÅ¿Å¿atisfied with the treachery of Fanaticks, as the contumacy of the Cavaliers.

The Abjurors in the mean time, thoÅ¿e Piles in the Rump, who had the Å¿ole power in carrying of things, began to have jealouÅ¿ies of the Å¿incerity of Monk's intentions, and of the extraordinary affection of the people towards him; and having found an opportunity, they delayed no longer to make a tryal of his thoughts and hidden deÅ¿ignes.

The Londoners refuÅ¿e to pay Taxes.The Government of this Rump-Parliament was grown Å¿o contemptible and loathÅ¿ome to the Londoners, that an Order paÅ¿t in Common Council, That unleÅ¿s they had a free and full Parliament, they would not pay one farthing of Taxes: which Å¿o Å¿tartled and incenÅ¿ed the guilty and timerous minds of the Members, that Monk hath forthwith Å¿evere orders to march into the City, Monk is Å¿ent into the City in Arms. Feb. 9. commit twelve of the more Å¿awcy Citizens to the Tower of London, and by pulling down the City-PoÅ¿ts and Chains, Gates and Portcullices, in a military manner quell the boldneÅ¿s of the People: which if he did, then the diÅ¿grace and hatred would equally fall upon all; and that by that means they would prove Monk's friendÅ¿hip, as if he refuÅ¿ed, they might conclude him an Enemy.

To which he offers violenceThough Monk abhorred thoÅ¿e cruel Orders of theÅ¿e Rulers, yet he marched into the City with armed Forces, and contrary to his own inclination, puts in execution the hateful Orders of the Rump.

This unexpected AggreÅ¿Å¿ion of Monk aÅ¿toniÅ¿hed the City, and the People were in conÅ¿ternation at it, appearing firÅ¿t by a profound Å¿ilence, then Å¿ecret murmurings, and amazed looks; but there was more Å¿adneÅ¿s than fury in the caÅ¿e, and the Town
Å¿eemed rather Å¿urrendred than Å¿tormed. In the mean time the Souldiers had the chief command, Å¿lighting the Authority of the Mayor, and Dignity of the City.

q.l: âEt nullos Comitatu eÅ¿t Purpura faÅ¿ces.
âAnd no Scarlet nor Gold-Chain appeared.

div.p: Now did the Londoners bewail their own credulity, and the falÅ¿e hopes they had conceived of Monk; and deÅ¿paring of humane aÅ¿Å¿iÅ¿tance, they directed their eyes to Heaven, preÅ¿aging no leÅ¿s than a perpetual Bondage to the City.

This odious obedience performed by Monk to the Rump, put the Spectators to a plunge,The action of Monk is variouÅ¿ly interpreted. and Å¿uffered various interpretations. But for what he Å¿o far hazarded his own Reputation in obeying the Rumpers after this manner, or why, by Å¿o Å¿udden a change of counÅ¿el and conduct, he endeavoured to regain their favour again, I Å¿hall not venture to determine. The truth is,And is preÅ¿ently diÅ¿pleaÅ¿ed with himÅ¿elf for it. being either conÅ¿cious to himÅ¿elf of the injury and affront done to the City, or having too much experienced the Arts and Treachery of the Rump, and being no leÅ¿s prevailed upon by the Prayers of his Friends, and the Complaints of all, he was Å¿enÅ¿ible that his too great compliance with the Rumpers reflected upon his own Honour, and that the Indignity offered to the City, had raiÅ¿ed him too much Envy.

The Å¿ame night being come back to Whitehall, and caÅ¿ting about what was to be done in this tickliÅ¿h Å¿tate of affairs, he called to Council privately Å¿ome of the Officers who were his greateÅ¿t Confidents, and privy to his Å¿ecret deÅ¿ignes, and having formed a Letter,He Å¿ends an angry Letter to the Rump. Feb. 11. he therein angrily complaining of Å¿everal things to the Rump, as, That his Å¿ervices done to the HouÅ¿e were Å¿lighted, whilÅ¿t the late Traytors,
who were not much leÅ¿s Enemies to them than to the Commonwealth, had with them now much more credit and eÅ¿teem than he. From whence elÅ¿e proceed your new kindneÅ¿s to Lambert and Vane? and your new offences againÅ¿t me? If the perfidy of the Fanaticks had Å¿till diÅ¿pleaÅ¿ed you, why did you with Å¿o much reÅ¿pect receive yeÅ¿terday that Leering Heretick Barebones? and the inÅ¿olent Rabble of Sectarians, which lewdly in his company approached you with a diÅ¿honeÅ¿t Petition?

p.hi: This kindneÅ¿s of the HouÅ¿e Å¿hewn to a Rabble of Hereticks, is not Å¿imple (Å¿incere). It is the common deÅ¿ire of the whole Commonwealth, the general requeÅ¿t of the People, Citizens, Souldiers, of every one, and all, That the number of the Members being fill'd up within a week, and then your Å¿itting determined, you Å¿hould give place to a new Parliament.

div.p: TheÅ¿e Letters he Å¿ent the next morning by Lidcot and Clobery, two Colonels to the HouÅ¿e.

Monk returns into the City. Feb. 12. In the mean time he himÅ¿elf haÅ¿tens into the City, that he might make amends for his fault, and wipe off the infamy of the foregoing day. Having Å¿ent a MeÅ¿Å¿enger before to acquaint the Lord Mayor with his coming, and muÅ¿tered his Army in Finsbury-fields, he is entertained at a Å¿plendid Dinner in the Lord Mayor's houÅ¿e. After Dinner the Mayor conducted the General to the Common-Council of the City, where in a full AÅ¿Å¿embly of the Citizens in their formalities,Makes a Speech to the Citizens: He declared to them his trouble to Å¿ee what affronts were offered to them by Orders from the Council of State, which he obeyed; yet diÅ¿liked that he was neceÅ¿Å¿itated to comply with thoÅ¿e Commands; but with a reÅ¿olution always to run through the greateÅ¿t dangers to Å¿erve them: That he had not forgot their kind Letter at Morpeth, wherein he affectionately concurred, but was forced to retire backwards, like a Fencer, to make the better ground, and the more advantageous
aÅ¿Å¿ault. That he had Å¿ent to the HouÅ¿e that morning,And promiÅ¿es a new Parliament. that they Å¿hould iÅ¿Å¿ue Writs for a full Parliament; and to this end he was come to Å¿tay with them, and Å¿ee his deÅ¿ires fulfilled; and that they Å¿hould put a period to their Å¿itting by the Å¿ixth of May.

Monk's Speech was with delight and univerÅ¿al applauÅ¿e heard by the Citizens;The Citizens rejoyce. and the name of a New Parliament Å¿o pleaÅ¿ed the minds of the People, that the City which appeared deÅ¿olate and dejected in the morning, Å¿eemed tranÅ¿ported with joy at night, by the ringing of Bells and Bonefires.

But the old CommiÅ¿Å¿ioners, Scot and RobinÅ¿on, being Å¿ent into the City to the General, they offered him the hypocritical Thanks of the Rump for his quelling of the City; and concealing their diÅ¿pleaÅ¿ure at his Letter, they promiÅ¿e a fuller Parliament: and that their diÅ¿Å¿imulation might be the more Å¿pecious, they invite Monk again to WeÅ¿tminÅ¿ter to aÅ¿Å¿iÅ¿t them with his counÅ¿el.

The General and his Friends gave them a doubtful
anÅ¿wer, as well knowing that the civility of the proud Rumpers was not for nought: However, it was the intereÅ¿t of both Parties to continue their diÅ¿Å¿imulation.

But the CommiÅ¿Å¿ioners upon their return, having brought advice of the joyful familiarity that was betwixt the General and the Citizens, the Rump Å¿melt out Monk's deÅ¿igne, and were diÅ¿tracted in their thoughts. Wherefore they forthwith Å¿et about the leÅ¿Å¿ening of his power in the Army;The Rump weakens Monk's authority. appointing a Committee of five for ordering the affairs of the Forces; which if they could have gone through with, the EngliÅ¿h Army being altogether averÅ¿e from Monk, they had certainly ruined his fortune.

So Å¿oon as Monk heard that he was made one of five Generals, being unaccuÅ¿tomed to affronts, and equally Å¿lighting the baÅ¿eneÅ¿s and treachery of the Rumpers, He takes it in indignation. he took greater care of his affairs: And that he might not make uÅ¿e of the counÅ¿el of Enemies and Traytors onely, he deÅ¿ires a Conference with the old Å¿ecluded Members; upon whoÅ¿e Å¿enÅ¿e and inclinations when he found there was more to be grounded,And Å¿ends the Å¿ecluded Members to the houÅ¿e. Feb. 21. and perceived them to be fit men for qualifying matters, and not averÅ¿e from his own deÅ¿ignes in time, he Å¿ent them to the Parliament attended by a guard of Souldiers.

The Å¿ecluded Members in the mean time entring the HouÅ¿e again,The Abjurators depart. the baÅ¿er and viler Å¿ort of the Abjurors being now in deÅ¿pair, left the HouÅ¿e. The reÅ¿t being more moderate, continued to joyn with their reÅ¿tored fellow-Members in the adminiÅ¿tration of the affairs of the Publick.

The Votes of the fuller Parliament. The Parliament being now increaÅ¿ed in number, and the Vote of their own excluÅ¿ion being in the firÅ¿t place repealed, they appoint Monk General of all the Forces in Britain and Ireland, and order money
Å¿treight to be levied for the Pay of the Souldiers. They appoint Montague Admiral of the Fleet; give liberty to Booth's PriÅ¿oners, and the Captive Citizens; in whoÅ¿e place Lambert was afterwards clapt up in the Tower.

WhilÅ¿t the Parliament was buÅ¿ied in the affairs of the Commonwealth,
Monk acquaints the diÅ¿tant Forces, with the reÅ¿tauration of the Parliam. Feb. 21.
Monk in the mean time wholly taken up about the care of the Forces, having called a Council of his Colonels, diÅ¿patched Letters to all the Regiments of the Army and their Officers, that were quartered up and down Britain and Ireland, to certifie them of the reaÅ¿on of the readmiÅ¿Å¿ion of the Members, with large aÅ¿Å¿urances of their conÅ¿tancy to their old ProfeÅ¿Å¿ion and Principles; and that without this Expedient there was no way to Å¿atisfie the Nation, or raiÅ¿e money for the Å¿ubÅ¿iÅ¿tance of the Army or Navy.

The diÅ¿tant Regiments in the mean time wanting Money and NeceÅ¿Å¿aries,They conÅ¿ent to him. and having tried the experience of both fortunes, choÅ¿e rather to comply, and have their certain Pay, than to Å¿tand it out, and truÅ¿t to uncertainties.

But Monk, to make Å¿ure of the Forces,And take an Oath to be true to the Parliament. made them all take a new Oath to be true to the Parliament; which the Colonels and Officers of his own Army, and many of the EngliÅ¿h Forces willingly did: but thoÅ¿e who refuÅ¿ed or Å¿crupuled, he diÅ¿armed and caÅ¿heered. And now Monk had the Å¿ole power over both Armies, and received all Souldiers as bound by the Å¿ame Oath under the Å¿ame General.

Monk before this had removed his Quarters from Whitehall to St. James's: There amongÅ¿t others, Monk quarters at S James's. Here he receives Letters from the King, by the hands of Greenvile. March 18.
William Morrice was a chief Confident of the General's, a man of great Å¿olidity and prudence, as the times went. By his means Greenvile a Knight being introduced to Monk, and all company being removed,
he privately delivered him Letters from King CHARLES.

Having read them, he makes an anÅ¿wer Å¿uitable to the times and the doubtful Å¿tate of affairs, reÅ¿olving neither to Å¿ay too much, nor to conceal all his mind; and Å¿o tempered his expreÅ¿Å¿ions, that he might Å¿eem to reÅ¿erve a fuller anÅ¿wer in his actions. And this was the firÅ¿t Å¿tep to the reÅ¿toring the Government to Charles the Second.

Greenvile returned to BruÅ¿Å¿els to the King with the joyful and expected news of Monk's good inclinations towards his MajeÅ¿ty. But by how much the Parliament and Monk Å¿eriouÅ¿ly applied themÅ¿elves to the Å¿etling of affairs, by Å¿o much the more the bloudy Parricides uÅ¿ed all their Arts and Treachery, by Å¿owing Sedition in the Camp, and raiÅ¿ing Tumults amongÅ¿t the Sectarians in the City, to Å¿tir up new Commotions; nor did Treachery end with the War.A new ConÅ¿piracy of the Traytors. For the Abjurors having no more opportunity of doing miÅ¿chief in the Parliament-houÅ¿e, kept Cabals and Å¿ecret Conferences with the lately-disbanded Officers of the EngliÅ¿h Army, and being cruÅ¿hed in the head, Å¿tung with the tail.

As to what may be gathered from the preÅ¿ent actings of the Parliament, and the Å¿ecret inclinations of Monk, (Å¿ay they) the reÅ¿tauration of the Government of Charles Steuart is not far off: That therefore they thought to conÅ¿ider in time that their affairs were in a Å¿lippery condition; and that without their ruine and overthrow, Charles would not mount the Throne. That the Trophies of Å¿o many Wars, the glorying in the aÅ¿Å¿iÅ¿tance and protection of God, and the actions of Å¿o many years, would not now avail them.

That it was madneÅ¿s, after the Å¿laughter of Å¿o many RoyaliÅ¿ts, the killing of Å¿o many Nobles, and the unparallel'd Crime of the Murder of Charles the FirÅ¿t, to expect from a young baniÅ¿hed man, and exaÅ¿perated
by a long Exile, a Pardon,1660. which God Almighty would hardly give for Å¿o many Villanies.

That there remained then no remedy for them, but a daring boldneÅ¿s, whilÅ¿t as yet neither the Authority of the Parliament in the HouÅ¿e, nor that of Monk in both the Armies, was firmly enough Å¿etled. Let us therefore dare, Å¿ay they, and re-attempt Murders, Rapines, DiÅ¿turbances of State, and all thoÅ¿e Villanies that for twenty years paÅ¿t have Å¿o well Å¿ucceeded with us; rather than tamely and cowardly deliver up our Liberty purchaÅ¿ed by our blouds, into the power of an Enemy, who will the more cruelly be revenged upon us, that he hath been Å¿o often baffled and defeated by us. Let us either by greater Crimes juÅ¿tifie the paÅ¿t, or bury our misfortunes with our lives in the ruine of the Commonwealth.

q.l: âTrahere omnia Å¿ecum

MerÅ¿a juvat, genteÅ¿
que Å¿uae miÅ¿cere ruinae.
If we muÅ¿t Å¿ink, we'll drown the State,
And involve Nations in our Fate.

div.p: Having thus concerted a ConÅ¿piracy, there wanted onely an opportune Leader; but then Lambert being the perÅ¿on of greateÅ¿t reputation amongÅ¿t the Fanaticks, was thought the fitteÅ¿t to undertake that Charge.

Having therefore corrupted his Keepers, Lambert eÅ¿capes out of PriÅ¿on. April 9. he made his eÅ¿cape out of the Tower by night; then lurking privily in the City, and conÅ¿ulting with the Ring-leaders of the Party, they concluded amongÅ¿t themÅ¿elves, O damnable madneÅ¿s! by corrupting the EngliÅ¿h Regiments, and raiÅ¿ing Sedition in the Army, to renew a Civil War.

And Å¿o Lambert Å¿ecretly poÅ¿ts to Warwick, He gathers together an Army. the place appointed for their meeting: Thither came
Axtell, Okey, Cobbet, Crede, and other bloudy Traytors; where being joyned by Turncoats and the disbanded Souldiers of the EngliÅ¿h Regiments, whom they had allured into their Party, they Å¿uddenly make up an Army; and Å¿o the unhappy General is once more in command.
The firÅ¿t that gave Monk intelligence of Lambert's InÅ¿urrection was Colonel Streater, who was with a Regiment of Foot quartered in Northampton.

The Council of State hearing of the eÅ¿cape of the ConÅ¿pirators,
Lambert is proclaimed a Traytor. proclaim Lambert and his Adherents Traytors. Monk in the mean time, leÅ¿t leaving the City of London, he might bring the publick Å¿afety in danger, reÅ¿olved to reÅ¿erve his main Force for greater occaÅ¿ions, and to Å¿end in all haÅ¿te, Å¿ome HorÅ¿e after Lambert to cruÅ¿h the deÅ¿igne in its Infancy.

Ingoldsby is Å¿ent againÅ¿t Lambert.
Richard Ingoldsbey acquitted himÅ¿elf like a brave man, retrieving by a bold attempt the faults, that being a Colonel under both the Cromwels, he had formerly committed. He having Orders from Monk, with a body of HorÅ¿e haÅ¿tened to joyn Streater's Foot at Northampton; and on the two and twentieth of April, being EaÅ¿ter-day, within two miles of Daventry came in Å¿ight of the Enemy in an open Country fit for a HorÅ¿e-fight, and no leÅ¿s for flight.

Lambert, before his Forces were ripe for Action, being thus unexpectedly beÅ¿et, for a laÅ¿t proof of his Valour drew up his men in order to fight, leaving the reÅ¿t that was not in his power,Both prepare to fight, to deÅ¿tiny; and Ingoldsbey did the like: both for Å¿ome hours mutually expecting the charge.

WhilÅ¿t thus they delayed to engage, it was reported that Lambert made Å¿ome overtures of reÅ¿toring Richard Cromwel, whom he knew Ingoldsbey to have been much affected to, that Å¿o he might Å¿ave
Stakes: But he diÅ¿daining to Å¿ee the force of that Å¿cenical Prince plaid again, they muÅ¿t come to blows. Providence appeared in the engagement:And do fight. for hardly had they begun to skirmiÅ¿h, but that many of Lambert's HorÅ¿e turned to Ingoldsbey's Å¿ide; the reÅ¿t either daunted at the deÅ¿ertion of their Companions, or the force of the Enemy, took quarters and yielded.

Which when the Commanders perceived, they began to think of running. Ingoldsbey charging then home, put Lambert hard to it; Lambert is overcome, who far below the great fame that he had acquired in Arms, his Courage Å¿inking with his CauÅ¿e, and forgetting his former Reputation,And taken. tamely yielded himÅ¿elf PriÅ¿oner.
With Lambert, Cobbet and Crede were taken; but Axtell and Okey making their eÅ¿cape, delayed, but avoided not their deÅ¿erved puniÅ¿hments.

And now again Lambert, forÅ¿aken of his Friends, and a PriÅ¿oner, became Å¿enÅ¿ible of his fortune. Yet this freÅ¿h madneÅ¿s of Rebels, had it not been Å¿eaÅ¿onably quelled by Ingoldsbey and Streater, would have again embrewed the Nation in Bloud and Slaughter, and turned all things into new DiÅ¿orders.

The very day that Monk muÅ¿tered the Militia of London, Ingoldsbey brought his PriÅ¿oners to Town;Is carried a PriÅ¿oner to the Tower of London. who were now led in triumph where they had Å¿o often triumphed by their Villanies, paÅ¿Å¿ing diÅ¿armed through armed Souldiers. And thus the Civil Wars had an end.

Not long before, March the 17th,The diÅ¿Å¿olution of the Long Parliament. March 17. the Long and Black Parliament diÅ¿Å¿olved themÅ¿elves; a Parliament infamous for Å¿uch havock made in the State, Å¿o many impudent and unwarrantable Undertakings, and for the murder of Charles the Martyr; being twice garbl'd, twice turned out, twice reÅ¿tored, and
at length much more happily ended than begun.

And now, on the five and twentieth of April, a new and more auÅ¿picuous Parliament aÅ¿Å¿embled,A new one met. April 25. being made up, according to the ancient EngliÅ¿h cuÅ¿tom, of Lords and Commons. The Earl of MancheÅ¿ter was Speaker of the HouÅ¿e of Lords, and Sir Harbotle GrimÅ¿tone of the Commons. And this conjunction of both HouÅ¿es Å¿eemed a natural Prelude to the Kings ReÅ¿tauration.

The People deÅ¿ire a King.For the EngliÅ¿h accuÅ¿tomed to Kingly government, cried, that there remained no other way of remedying the publick DiÅ¿tempers, but a Å¿ubmiÅ¿Å¿ion to the rightful government of Charles the Second. So was it ordered above, that God and man Å¿hould concur in recalling the King to his Throne. And Å¿o great was the fame of the Virtues and AccompliÅ¿hments of this AuguÅ¿t young Prince, that though by reaÅ¿on of a long Exile, he was by face almoÅ¿t unknown to all, and though he had not had a lawful and hereditary Title to the Crown, yet they would have courted him to accept of the Government. Nor was he leÅ¿s deÅ¿irable, when compared and put into the balance with thoÅ¿e bloudy Æ²Å¿urpers. Nay, the compaÅ¿Å¿ionate Å¿enÅ¿e of his adverÅ¿e Fortune and tedious Exile kindled alÅ¿o in his Subjects an affectionate deÅ¿ire of recalling him to his Right.

And the inconÅ¿iderate miÅ¿takes of the imperious Traytors at length came to this, That the Commonwealth no leÅ¿s deÅ¿ired the King, than the King the Government; and the languiÅ¿hing condition of the Publick made it as, if not more, neceÅ¿Å¿ary for the EngliÅ¿h to have a Prince, than for him to have a People.

Th â¢
King comes to Breda. While theÅ¿e things were a doing, Charles, wholly intent upon the motions of England, leaving BruÅ¿Å¿els, a Town under the SpaniÅ¿h dominion, came to
Breda which belongs to his Nephew the Prince of Orange;From whence he Å¿ends Letters to the Parliament, &c. April 14. from whence he diÅ¿patched Sir John Greenvile with Royal Letters to both HouÅ¿es of Parliament, and Letters alÅ¿o to General Monk and the Officers of the Army, to the Mayor and Common-Council of London, and to Montague Admiral of the Fleet.

Which were received with Å¿o univerÅ¿al a Joy and ApplauÅ¿e, that the Parliament forthwith ordained him to be proclaimed KING in the City, and all over England, with the accuÅ¿tomed Solemnities, having made a Proclamation to this purpoÅ¿e.

Although it can no way be doubted but that his MajeÅ¿ties Right and Title to theÅ¿e Crowns and Kingdoms, The Parliaments Proclamation. is and was every way compleat by the death of his moÅ¿t Royal Father of glorious memory, without the ceremony or Å¿olemnity of a Proclamation; yet Å¿ince Proclamations in Å¿uch caÅ¿es have been always uÅ¿ed, to the end that all good Subjects might upon this occaÅ¿ion teÅ¿tifie their duty and reÅ¿pect; and Å¿ince the armed violence, and other the Calamities of many years laÅ¿t paÅ¿t, have hitherto deprived us of any opportunity wherein we might expreÅ¿s our Loyalty and Allegiance to his MajeÅ¿ty: We therefore the Lords and Commons now aÅ¿Å¿embled in Parliament, together with the Lord Mayor, Aldermen, and Common-Council of the City of London, and other Freemen of this Kingdom now preÅ¿ent; do according to our Duty and Allegiance, heartily, joyfully, and unanimouÅ¿ly acknowledge and proclaim, That immediately upon the deceaÅ¿e of our late Soveraign King CHARLES the FirÅ¿t, the Imperial Crown of the Realm of England, and of all the Kingdoms, Dominions, and Rights belonging to the Å¿ame, did by inherent Birthright, and lawful undoubted SucceÅ¿Å¿ion, deÅ¿cend and come to his moÅ¿t Excellent MajeÅ¿ty King CHARLES the Second, as being lineally, juÅ¿tly, and lawfully next
Heir of the Bloud-Royal of this Realm; and that by the goodneÅ¿s and providence of Almighty God, he is of England, Scotland, and Ireland, the moÅ¿t potent, mighty, and undoubted King. And thereunto we moÅ¿t humbly and faithfully do Å¿ubmit and oblige our Å¿elves, our Heirs, and PoÅ¿terities.

The King being proclaimed throughout the City with the joyful Å¿houts and acclamations of all, and all things being prepared for his reception, both HouÅ¿es of Parliament appointed an honourable body of CommiÅ¿Å¿ioners to be Å¿ent to the King with their Letters, all men of great Quality and Birth: Obery Earl of Oxford, CommiÅ¿Å¿ioners from the Lords to the King.
Charles Earl of Warwick, Lionel Earl of MiddleÅ¿ex, and Hereford ViÅ¿count of LeiceÅ¿ter, the Lords Berkley and Brooks, for the Lords.

CommiÅ¿Å¿ioners from the Commons. The HouÅ¿e of Commons choÅ¿e Fairfax, Bruce, Falkland, CaÅ¿tletown, Herbert, Mandiville, all Lords; AÅ¿hley-Cooper, TownÅ¿end, Booth, Holland, Chumley, and Hollis, Knights: Who beÅ¿ides Letters, carried InÅ¿tructions with them, humbly to beg that his MajeÅ¿ty would be pleaÅ¿ed to haÅ¿ten his long wiÅ¿hed-for return into England.

The K. Dukes, of York and GlouceÅ¿ter have PreÅ¿ents Å¿ent them from the Parliament.And becauÅ¿e they knew that the Exchequer of their exiled King could not be very full, they order them to carry him a PreÅ¿ent of fifty thouÅ¿and Pieces of Gold; and alÅ¿o ten thouÅ¿and to the Duke of York, and five to the Duke of GlouceÅ¿ter.
Clerges, a perÅ¿on in great favour with the King, carried General Monk's and the Armies SubmiÅ¿Å¿ion and Letters.

The Londoners Å¿end CommiÅ¿Å¿ioners and PreÅ¿ents.The City of London alÅ¿o Å¿ent twenty CommiÅ¿Å¿ioners choÅ¿en out of the Flower of the Citizens: and the wealthy Citizens preÅ¿ent the King and his IlluÅ¿trious Brothers with twelve thouÅ¿and pounds.

All things now Å¿ucceeding beyond expectation,
Monk was Å¿ecure in his fortune, having Å¿o dexterouÅ¿ly managed things,The Traytors with aÅ¿toniÅ¿hment beheld the Revolution. with Å¿uch innocent and harmleÅ¿s Arts defeated the Snares and Arms of the Parricides, and procured the publick Å¿afety without bloud, that the Å¿ame Virtue of the General was both hated and admired; whilÅ¿t the praying Sectaries in vain called upon God, who was not certainly the Lord of their HoÅ¿ts now.

The Eleventh of May the CommiÅ¿Å¿ioners Å¿et Å¿ail from England,
The CommiÅ¿Å¿ioners Å¿ail from England,
May 11. and wait upon the K. at the Hague May 16.
Sir Thomas Clerges the firÅ¿t MeÅ¿Å¿enger of the Kings coming. and with all dutifulneÅ¿s waited upon the Kings MajeÅ¿ty at the Hague; where they were gladly and kindly received by him.

Clarges had been with him before, whom the King having firÅ¿t knighted, Å¿ent back into England as a MeÅ¿Å¿enger of his coming; and having Å¿ent Letters to Monk full of expreÅ¿Å¿ions of good will and gratitude towards the General and Army, he deÅ¿igned Dover for his place of landing. In the mean time, by the Kings command, Admiral Montague (Å¿ince Earl of Sandwich) came with the Fleet upon the CoaÅ¿t of Holland, and waited for the King before Scheveling.

And now all things being in a readineÅ¿s for his departure, the beÅ¿t of Kings, The K. went on board, May 23. with the Dukes of York and GlouceÅ¿ter, came on board the Admiral. Thither they were attended by the Queen of Bohemia their Aunt, their SiÅ¿ter the PrinceÅ¿s of Orange, and the young Prince their Nephew; where after they had taken a glad Farewel, with a joyful Huzza of the Sea-men they Å¿et Å¿ail.

Charles the Second now in poÅ¿Å¿eÅ¿Å¿ion of his Fleet, (the firÅ¿t Pledge of his Government) which was Å¿peedily to waft him over to that of his Kingdoms, with a proÅ¿perous Gale directs his courÅ¿e to Dover. Monk having received Letters by Clarges, accompanied with a numerous train of Nobility and Gentry, Monk haÅ¿tens to Dover. haÅ¿tened thither to welcome him on the Å¿hore, and to pay Honour to that Virtue at home, which he had reverenced at Å¿o great diÅ¿tance abroad.

So Å¿oon as the Fleet with full Å¿ail came in Å¿ight, innumerable crouds of over-Å¿pied Spectators flocked to the Å¿hore, and Sea-coaÅ¿t, and to every other place from whence they might have any proÅ¿pect, being deÅ¿irous to Å¿ee and congratulate their reÅ¿tored Prince.

div.head: The Troubles of England CompoÅ¿ed by his MajeÅ¿ties happy ReÅ¿tauration.
div.p: There the King lands. May 25. On the 25th of May, amidÅ¿t the roaring of all the Canon in the Fleet, ecchoed and anÅ¿wered from the CaÅ¿tle and Å¿hore, and, which was a more glorious Å¿ound, amidÅ¿t the joyful and louder Acclamations of his Subjects, AÆ²GÆ²ST CHARLES landed at Dover, with Å¿o much Piety, Gravity, and GracefulneÅ¿s in his Countenance, that he Å¿eemed to be come to pay his Vows to God, the Protector of the Government. His department Å¿hew'd no Vanity nor Pride, but a mind rather above the reach of them, yet capable of any fortune; and Å¿o great was his MajeÅ¿ty in all his actions, that he Å¿eemed more to deÅ¿erve than to deÅ¿ire a Crown.

Monk receives the King upon his knees at his landing.Here Monk falling upon his knees to welcome the King, was by his MajeÅ¿ty embraced, kiÅ¿Å¿ed, and raiÅ¿ed from the ground; the reÅ¿t of the Nobility having alÅ¿o performed their duty, the Å¿ame night the beÅ¿t of Kings advanced to Canterbury,
The King haÅ¿tens to Canterbury.
There he made Monk Knight of the Garter. May 27.
and next morning created Monk Knight of the honourable Order of the Garter, the moÅ¿t illuÅ¿trious Princes the Dukes of York and GlouceÅ¿ter putting the George about his neck. Here the King Å¿pent Sunday, and reÅ¿tored the Å¿ervice of the Church in the Metropolitan Church of England.

May 28. He came to RocheÅ¿ter.Setting forward from hence, he lodged all night at RocheÅ¿ter, and next day upon Black heath he viewed the Forces drawn up with much military pomp and Å¿plendour: Forces heretofore onely
brave in Å¿hedding of Civil Bloud, whoÅ¿e Trophies and Triumphs were then diÅ¿graced with horrid Crimes; but now upon the return of Charles, The K. views the Army upon the Road, and praiÅ¿es them. loyally and deÅ¿ervedly triumphant. The Regiments drawn up in a moÅ¿t lovely order, made an Army worthy of King Charles.

The King having by the famous Colonel Knight received the Salutations and ReÅ¿pects of the Forces in their Arms, and having praiÅ¿ed them for their dutifulneÅ¿s and affection, proceeded forwards; the people Å¿trewing Flowers and Leaves of Trees in the way, and in all places offering him the choiceÅ¿t marks of their Honour.

When he was come near the City,The King is welcomed by the Lord Mayor and Citizens of London. the Lord Mayor and Aldermen of London welcomed him upon their knees. The Mayor delivered his MajeÅ¿ty the Sword, the Badge of his Dignity, which the King graciouÅ¿ly gave him back again; and being conducted into a large and richly-adorned Pavillion, was entertained at a Å¿plendid Collation.

From thence with a magnificent train of PerÅ¿ons of all quality, He enters London. May 29. over London-bridge he entered the City, amidÅ¿t Å¿uch a glorious appearance of brave and great men, that Å¿carcely in any Age the triumphal Bridge of Rome ever bore a greater Pomp, or victorious Tyber Å¿aw, or Euphrates of old,By Tyber, Euphrates, and Tygris, are meant the Roman, PerÅ¿ian, and AÅ¿Å¿yrian Empires, and their Triumphs. or the yet more ancient Tygris.

Along the Streets from London-bridge to White-hall, The Pomp of his entry. on the one Å¿ide in a continued order the Trained-bands of the City were drawn up, and on the other, the Companies in their Livery-gowns, the houÅ¿es on each Å¿ide being hung with TapiÅ¿try. The tops of the houÅ¿es and windows were filled with vaÅ¿t multitudes of Spectators,And Attendants. the People from all places flocking to this glorious and joyful Show.

There were no leÅ¿s than twenty thouÅ¿and richly attired on horÅ¿eback. The firÅ¿t that led the Cavalcade were Å¿ome Troops of young Gentlemen in a various & moÅ¿t rich dreÅ¿s and Å¿hining Arms, with Trumpets Å¿ounding before them. The Sheriffs of London's men with their Spears, followed after; next after whom marched Å¿ix hundred of the chief Citizens, in Velvet-coats and Gold-chains. Then followed the Kings HorÅ¿e-guards, led by the Lord Gerrard their Captain.

With the chearful muÅ¿ick of Drums, Trumpets, and Waits, next advanced the Sheriffs and Aldermen of London in their Scarlet-gowns, and their HorÅ¿es richly deckt with Trapings; their Footmen attending them, Å¿hining with Gold and Silver.

Then followed the Kings of Arms and Heralds in their rich Coats; and next to them the Lord Mayor, carrying in his right hand the naked Sword; and after him the IlluÅ¿trious Duke of Buckingham, and the renowned General Monk.

And now appeared Charles, the WiÅ¿hes of all good men, and the Joys of the happy, conÅ¿picuous in a triumphant MajeÅ¿ty: On the right hand rode the Duke of York, on the left the Duke of GlouceÅ¿ter; he himÅ¿elf on a Å¿tately horÅ¿e in the middle, carrying all Triumphs and Diadems in his looks, which Å¿eemed then more than humane.
After his MajeÅ¿ty, came his chief Courtiers and Servants. General Monk's Life-guard commanded by Sir Philip Howard; and then five Regiments of HorÅ¿e of Monk's Army, led by Colonel Knight.

This Triumphal ProceÅ¿Å¿ion was brought up by a vaÅ¿t body of Noblemen and Gentlemen, with red Colours fringed with Gold, in rich Attire, Å¿hining Arms, their Swords drawn, and Plumes of Feather in their Hats.

In this order the King marched Å¿lowly through
the City, amidÅ¿t the Å¿houts, acclamations, and joyful looks of his Subjects, which he triumphantly heard and beheld. And now entring his Royal Palace, he mounted the Throne of his Forefathers on the twenty ninth of May, heretofore the day of his Birth, and now of his ReÅ¿tauration; after he had been, Å¿ince WorceÅ¿ter-fight, ten years baniÅ¿hed his Country.

The Members of both HouÅ¿es of Parliament came to wait on his MajeÅ¿ty in the Banquetting-houÅ¿e,The two HouÅ¿es come to congratulate the King. there to expreÅ¿s their joyful Congratulations for his Return, and unfeigned Loyalty to the Government; which was eloquently done by the Earl of MancheÅ¿ter for the HouÅ¿e of Lords, and Sir Harbotle GrimÅ¿tone for the Commons. The King tired out with the Fatigues of his triumphant Journey, made them this Å¿hort AnÅ¿wer.

p.hi: I Am Å¿o diÅ¿ordered by my Journey, and with the noiÅ¿e Å¿till Å¿ounding in my ears, (which I confeÅ¿s was pleaÅ¿ing to me, becauÅ¿e it expreÅ¿Å¿ed the Affections of my People) as I am unfit at the preÅ¿ent to make Å¿uch a Reply as I deÅ¿ire; yet thus much I Å¿hall Å¿ay unto you, That I take no greater Å¿atisfaction to my Å¿elf in this my Change, than that I find my heart really Å¿et to endeavour by all means for the reÅ¿toring of this Nation to their Freedom and HappineÅ¿s; and I hope by the advice of my Parliament to aÅ¿Å¿ert it. Of this alÅ¿o you may be confident, That next to the honour of God, from whom principally I Å¿hall ever own this ReÅ¿tauration to my Crown, I Å¿hall Å¿tudy the welfare of my People; and Å¿hall not onely be a true Defender of the Faith, but a juÅ¿t AÅ¿Å¿ertor of the Laws and Liberties of my Subjects.

div.p: The night following was conÅ¿ecrated to Joy. The Conduits running Wine,The night-joys of the Citizens. and the whole City lighted by Bonfires. The loyal Citizens, willing to lull aÅ¿leep the memory of twenty years Calamities, merrily Å¿pent the night in the noiÅ¿e of Trumpets, Drums, and Volleys of Å¿hot.

A happy revolution of affairs from the Kings ReÅ¿tauration.The providence of God Almighty never appeared more viÅ¿ible in humane affairs: for now the Golden Age returns, a HappineÅ¿s too good for our times; the bleÅ¿Å¿ed day Å¿hone forth, wherein King Charles being reÅ¿tored to his Country, reÅ¿tored his Country to it Å¿elf, and united Liberty and Monarchy, two things thought incompatible under the traiterous UÅ¿urpers. The honour of the Laws, which makes all things firm and durable, returned: The Å¿plendour of the Church of England, and the ancient Rites of WorÅ¿hip, alÅ¿o returned; Piety coming in place of Sectarian SuperÅ¿tition.

The King appoints a Privy Council, and MiniÅ¿ters of State.The King having taÅ¿ted a little of the delights of his Return, Å¿eriouÅ¿ly Å¿et about the Å¿etling of the State, entangl'd with Å¿o many Civil DiÅ¿Å¿entions, and rent by DiviÅ¿ions; and in the firÅ¿t place appointed a Privy-Council, and diÅ¿poÅ¿ed of the chief places of his Kingdom and Court.
The Duke of York made Admiral. The King makes the moÅ¿t IlluÅ¿trious James Duke of York Lord High Admiral, a Prince renowned at home and abroad, and crowned with many Victories.

The Earl of Clarendon, Chancellor.
Edward Hide Earl of Clarendon, was made Lord Chancellor; in Eloquence not inferiour to the moÅ¿t famed Orators; nor in Prudence, to the greateÅ¿t StateÅ¿men.
The Earl of Southampton, TreaÅ¿urer. The uncorrupted Earl of Southampton, with Honour and Integrity, diÅ¿charged the Office of Lord High TreaÅ¿urer.

The D. of Ormond, Steward of the K.'s HouÅ¿hold.The IlluÅ¿trious charge of Steward of the Kings HouÅ¿hold, was conferred upon the Duke of Ormond,
a Peer of a Å¿teddy Judgment, of the HoneÅ¿ty of elder times, and renowned both in Peace and War.

The Earl of MancheÅ¿ter,
The E. of MancheÅ¿ter, Chamberlain. whoÅ¿e Loyalty had been proved, was created Lord Chamberlain of the HouÅ¿e.
Nicholas and Morrice, two aged Knights, Nicholas and Morrice, Secretaries of State. and conÅ¿ummated in buÅ¿ineÅ¿s, were the Principal Secretaries of State.

Monk the ReÅ¿torer,
Monk MaÅ¿ter of the HorÅ¿e, and Duke of Albemarle. formerly by the Kings CommiÅ¿Å¿ion made General of all the BritiÅ¿h Forces, is now advanced to be MaÅ¿ter of the HorÅ¿e, and honoured with the IlluÅ¿trious Title of Duke of Albemarle. For his noble Extraction gave him a claim to the Honour of the Albemarlian Family; and the bounty of the King in rewarding his good Services, an EÅ¿tate to Å¿upport it.

Nor was the moÅ¿t Religious King leÅ¿s careful of the Church.BiÅ¿hops reÅ¿tored in the Church. ThoÅ¿e BiÅ¿hops who had Å¿urvived the fury of the Hereticks, he reÅ¿tored to their Sees; and choÅ¿e others conÅ¿picuous for Primitive Piety, Learning, and a good Life, in place of thoÅ¿e that were dead; who with the Å¿ame Piety and Humility that they had Å¿uffered the Reproaches of Sectarians, and born the Calamities of a Civil War, now in their old age carried the Miter, and governed the Church of God.

The King made Juxon ArchbiÅ¿hop of Canterbury and primate of all England, Will. Juxon ArchbiÅ¿hop of Canterbury. a Prelate of Primitive Piety, venerable both in his books and words; heretofore ConfeÅ¿Å¿or to Charles the Martyr, and his AÅ¿Å¿iÅ¿tent to the laÅ¿t, whilÅ¿t amidÅ¿t the fury and reproaches of bloudy Traytors, he took his leave of this world.

q.l: âEt nullo gemitu conÅ¿enÅ¿it ad ictum,
DeÅ¿pexitque nefasâ
When without Å¿ighing, he received that Blow,
And bravely Å¿corn'd the Villanies below.

div.p: And now it was no Å¿mall comfort to many, that they to whom the Parricides had formerly been liberal, were as poor as thoÅ¿e whom they had robbed: but it was fit that Clemency Å¿hould uÅ¿her in the new AdminiÅ¿tration of the Government; and therefore Charles imitating God Almighty in mercifulneÅ¿s,An Act of Oblivion is paÅ¿t. paÅ¿t in Parliament an Act of Indemnity and Oblivion for all his Subjects, except thoÅ¿e who had embrewed their hands in his Fathers Bloud; the reÅ¿t of the guilty Rebels being wonderfully pardoned: but whether with greater Policy or Mercy, let PoÅ¿terity judge.

The Army receives their Pay, and is disbanded.The King now Å¿ecure in his own MajeÅ¿ty, and the Loyalty of his Subjects, reÅ¿olved to disband the Army, which for Å¿o many years had been the Burden and Grievance of the Nation; for the paying of which, a Tax by way of Poll, was impoÅ¿ed on every head in England. The Souldiers had alÅ¿o a Donative beÅ¿towed upon them, and many of the Officers were rewarded according to their merit.

AmidÅ¿t the Joys wherewith the firÅ¿t three months of his MajeÅ¿ties government was bleÅ¿Å¿ed,The Duke of GlouceÅ¿ter dies, Sept. 13.
Henry Duke of GlouceÅ¿ter fell Å¿ick, and was fatally too Å¿oon Å¿natched out of this world by the Small Pox; Å¿o much the more lamented by the King his Brother, and by the Kingdom, that at twenty years of age he had given Å¿uch Å¿ublime proofs of his Princely AccompliÅ¿hments: And this alone may Å¿eem an EclipÅ¿e of the Glory of Charles, that almoÅ¿t in his own triumph, he beheld the Funeral of his dear Brother.

q.l: âManibus date Lilia plenis,
Purpureos Å¿pargam floresâ
Bring plenty of white Lillies to his HerÅ¿e,
WhilÅ¿t Å¿ad there the purple RoÅ¿e diÅ¿perÅ¿e.

div.p:
The affairs of England being Å¿etled,The King takes into conÅ¿ideration the Government of England and Ireland.
Scotland and Ireland were to be taken care of: The King therefore appointed Privy-Councils of the moÅ¿t Loyal Subjects of both Kingdoms, to manage the Government, till he might adviÅ¿e about calling a Parliament in Scotland, and Å¿ending over a Lord Lieutenant into Ireland.

After the dutiful AddreÅ¿Å¿es of his Subjects at home, the neighbouring Kings of France, Sweden, Congratulatory EmbaÅ¿Å¿ies from neighbouring Princes to the King. Denmark, and many Princes of Germany, by honourable EmbaÅ¿Å¿ies congratulate the Kings happy ReÅ¿tauration; all which were outdone by the pompous and Å¿plendid train of the Prince Ligny, EmbaÅ¿Å¿adour from the Catholick King.

And now it was time to bring the Murderers of Charles the Martyr to their Tryals,The Kings Murderers brought to tryal. Octob. 10. many of whom were before clapt up in PriÅ¿on; others fled away Å¿ecretly, and wandered in foraign and diÅ¿tant Countries; and Å¿ome truÅ¿ting to the hopes of a Pardon, obeyed the Kings Proclamation, and freely Å¿urrendred themÅ¿elves.

Therefore on the tenth of October, HarriÅ¿on, Carew, Clements, Jones, Scot, and Scroop, who had been of the number of the Judges that condemned the King, Cooke Attorney-General, the famous infamous Peters Chaplain to the Traytors, Axiell and Hacker Commanders of the Guards, were brought to the Bar, not before an accurÅ¿ed and new-made High Court of JuÅ¿tice, but according to the ancient Laws of the Kingdom, before the chief JuÅ¿tices and
the reÅ¿t of the Kings JuÅ¿tices, to be tryed by a Jury of Twelve men, after the uÅ¿ual manner of England.

What they were accuÅ¿ed of.They were chiefly charged by the Attorney-General and the Kings Council, That they the aforeÅ¿aid Traytors, and others guilty of High-TreaÅ¿on, conÅ¿piring with an accurÅ¿ed Army of Fanaticks had carried away to PriÅ¿on, King Charles, Å¿ecurely treating a Peace with the two HouÅ¿es of Parliament, which was almoÅ¿t concluded in the IÅ¿le of Wight. So that the HouÅ¿e of Lords being abrogated, and the founder Members of the Commons, Å¿ix and forty Villains that remained took to themÅ¿elves the name of a Parliament, invaded the Government, and decreed to bring the King to a Tryal.

By whoÅ¿e authority theÅ¿e Parricides (an High Court of JuÅ¿tice being impudently conÅ¿tituted) had condemned and cauÅ¿ed to be put to death the King of England, who was above the Laws, contrary to the will, and to the great grief of the People.

They make an idle baÅ¿e defence.To their Indictment, rightly laid and fully proved, having made many falÅ¿e and frivolous AnÅ¿wers concerning the Å¿upreme authority of the Parliament, which indeed in this caÅ¿e had no authority at all,And are condemned. they were by the Verdict of a Jury of Twelve men found guilty of and condemned for High-TreaÅ¿on. The Å¿ame Verdict paÅ¿t alÅ¿o upon nineteen other of the Kings Judges, but with a different event, as Å¿hall be mentioned in the proper place.

On the third of October a Gibbet was Å¿et up at Charing-croÅ¿s near Whitehall, whither in the morning HarriÅ¿on being brought, HarriÅ¿on hang'd and quarter'd. Octob. 3. the firÅ¿t of the Å¿urviving Regicides both in guilt and puniÅ¿hment, with the Å¿ame madneÅ¿s and obÅ¿tinacy as he had behaved himÅ¿elf at his tryal, the cruel Traytor affecting an undauntedneÅ¿s at his death, was hang'd and quarter'd, as he well deÅ¿erved.

q.l: CAROLE, tuis jam Victima mittitur umbris,
Nec Å¿atis hoc fortuna putat, procul abÅ¿it, ut iÅ¿ta
Vindictae Å¿it Å¿umma tuiâ
Great CHARLES, a Victim to thy GhoÅ¿t does fall,
And yet thy Fates are not appeas'd; no, all
That juÅ¿t Revenge is not yet paid that Å¿hall.

div.p: HarriÅ¿on, rather of a baÅ¿e than low Birth, was the Son of a Butcher; bred at firÅ¿t a Pettifogging Country-Attorney: but in the heat of the Civil Wars, when the onely way to get into Power, was FanaticiÅ¿m and TreaÅ¿on, he fled to the Rebellious Army; and there turning a furious AnabaptiÅ¿t, and advanced to be a Colonel, he grew very intimate with Cromwel, and his Competitor in Villany. But being a proud and haughty fellow, and a moÅ¿t deÅ¿perate Republican, he fell out, and was highly diÅ¿pleaÅ¿ed with Oliver when he was made Protector; not that he hated the Tyrant Cromwel, but diÅ¿dained to be outÅ¿tripped, and to Å¿ubmit to one who from a fellow-Souldier was become his Prince.

The day following, Cook and Peters, The death of Cook and Peters. Octob. 16. in the Å¿ame place, Å¿uffered the Å¿ame puniÅ¿hment; where Peters by a drunken and baÅ¿e death, diÅ¿graced his infamous life.

Cook was an obÅ¿cure, ragged, beggarly Lawyer, and ambitious to get a Name by any kind of Villany. Peters a Fanatical Tub-preacher, and the Jack-pudding of the Ordinances. Sometimes he was Presbyterian, and Å¿ometimes Independant, as the Å¿everal
Factions prevailed. He was the firÅ¿t of the Jugglers that from the Pulpit Å¿ounded the Trumpet to Civil War, a fellow full of talk, and had a knack of Å¿porting the People into Sedition, with an inÅ¿ipid kind of Buffoonry and Lying, which paÅ¿t with them for Eloquence, and became a Crony of Oliver's by a flagitious compliance. October the Å¿eventh,Clements, Scot, Jones, and Scroop, executed. Octob. 17. Clements, Scot, Jones, and Scroop, Å¿uffered the Å¿ame death upon the Å¿ame Gibbet, without any regard had to a decent end.
Clements was heretofore a Merchant in London; a luÅ¿tful mercenary Traytor, who abuÅ¿ed his Parliamentarian Authority to Whoredom and Leachery.

Jones brought nothing with him out of Wales, his native Country, but Infamy and an ignoble Extraction; he was firÅ¿t a Robber, and for his exceÅ¿Å¿ive wickedneÅ¿s preferred to be a Colonel, he married Cromwel's SiÅ¿ter, who then enriched his Relations with the Spoils of the Commonwealth: nor was he leÅ¿s related to Oliver by Affinity than Villany; and to many men prejudicial by his ill nature.

Scot Å¿prung out of a Brew-houÅ¿e, and amongÅ¿t other Calamities of the Civil War, was admitted into the Parliament-houÅ¿e; and of all the Traytors perhaps, was the moÅ¿t inveterate Enemy to Charles the Martyr, of which Villany he bragg'd to the laÅ¿t: and Å¿o rejoyced in the Kings Murder, that he would have PoÅ¿terity remember him as an Author of Å¿o great a Crime; and beÅ¿ides the murder of the King, was guilty of many other horrid Villanies.

Of all the Regicides that Å¿urrendred themÅ¿elves, Scroop onely was hanged: for whether by indiÅ¿cretion, or obÅ¿tinacy, he drew upon himÅ¿elf this ill fortune; or that a mans deÅ¿tiny is not to be avoided, I Å¿hall not determine: for after that he had
Å¿urrendred himÅ¿elf, he Å¿eemed Å¿o much to juÅ¿tifie the Murder of the King, that he choÅ¿e rather to be looked upon as a Criminal than an humble Supplicant.
Then Hacker and Axtell at Tyburn had the reward of their TreaÅ¿on. Hacker formerly in London, Hacker and Axtell hang'd at Tyburn. Octob. 19. and Axtell in Bedford, had kept Å¿hops.
The Quarters of the Traytors, (their Bowels being burnt) and their Heads were Å¿et up upon the Gates and publick places of London.

The fugitive Regicides being Å¿ummoned by Proclamation to appear,The puniÅ¿hment of the fugitive Regicides. were afterwards by Act of Parliament declared guilty of High-TreaÅ¿on, and their EÅ¿tates forfeited.

Nor did the juÅ¿t Å¿everity of the Parliament Å¿o puniÅ¿h the living, as to quite forget the dead: for the like Sentence of High-TreaÅ¿on was pronounced againÅ¿t the deceaÅ¿ed Ireton, Cromwel, BradÅ¿haw, The bones of the deceaÅ¿ed raiÅ¿ed and buried under Tyburn. Jan. 30. 1660, 61. and Pride; who having, whilÅ¿t alive, uÅ¿urped the Government of the murdered King, they with no leÅ¿s impudence, when dead, were pompouÅ¿ly buried in Henry the Seventh's Chappel, the burying-place of Kings of England.

The Parliament therefore ordered their Bones and Å¿tinking CarcaÅ¿Å¿es to be raiÅ¿ed and buried under Tyburn; and in this poÅ¿thumous diÅ¿grace being dragg'd through the City, they had a Gibbet-interment.
I think it will not be amiÅ¿s to give the Reader an account of the Original of the laÅ¿t named Traytors, Å¿o famed for enormous Villanies; which here I Å¿hall once for all Å¿ubjoyn.

Ireton of a mean Extraction,Ireton 's Character. was Cromwel's Son-in-law, and the Confident and CounÅ¿ellor of all his Å¿ecret Villanies; who, though to all others he was moÅ¿t hidden and reÅ¿erved, yet to this man he opened his heart; as he on the other hand was
reported not onely to have kept his CounÅ¿els, but alÅ¿o to have adviÅ¿ed him to act many of his worÅ¿t Villanies. He was eÅ¿teemed the beÅ¿t Orator of all the Colonels, and had a canting kind of preaching Rhetorick, more copious than eloquent.

Of Pride. Pride deÅ¿cended of unknown Parents, and was Dray-man to a Brewer; but within a Å¿hort time, the affairs of England being in confuÅ¿ion, the rough-hewn Clown was dignified and made proud by the Title and Authority of a Colonel: nor is it certain whether he was the greater Knave or Fool.

And BradÅ¿haw BradÅ¿haw was of the fatal High Court of JuÅ¿tice, the more fatal PreÅ¿ident, a Lawyer of no account at the Bar, till being bribed by money, he got himÅ¿elf a name by a moÅ¿t execrable Villany. The Scarletrobed Brauler, and hardly more innocent than Pilate, Å¿urpaÅ¿Å¿ed the wickedneÅ¿s of all the reÅ¿t of the Kings Murderers, by his boldneÅ¿s in condemning an innocent Prince, and adding malicious Å¿coffs to the impudence of the Fact, without any Reverence to Captive MajeÅ¿ty.

The Original of Cromwel.
Cromwel indeed came of a better Race, but which he himÅ¿elf for ever diÅ¿graced. The ancient dignity of his Family by the name of Williams, changed afterward by his AnceÅ¿tors, in the time of Henry the Eighth, to that of Cromwel, had its original from a BlackÅ¿mith.

And his Manners.
Catalin luxuria primum, hinc conflata egeÅ¿tas, in nefaria concilia opprimendae Patriae compulÃªre. Flor. l. 4. His Youth was looÅ¿e, infamous and debauched; but having run out his EÅ¿tate, and from a prodigal Rogue turning Puritan, and then Fanatick, like another Cataline, incited by Beggary, he ventured upon the overthrow of the State.

Bearing a mind above a private condition, he Å¿till appeared as a private perÅ¿on, and had the art to Å¿et himÅ¿elf off undiÅ¿cerned: He had a wonderful dexterity amongÅ¿t the Fanatick Rout, (in
whoÅ¿e opprobrious friendÅ¿hip he chiefly delighted) of winning upon the minds of the Rebels, Å¿haking his bald pate, and Å¿miling with a deceitful Countenance; he was by Nature and Art excellently diÅ¿poÅ¿ed for alluring the affections of the DiÅ¿Å¿enters; nor do I know whether amongÅ¿t mortal men there was even a cunniner ArtiÅ¿t in pretended Piety, a wickeder or more crafty man, and bolder in attempting any Villany.

But by what deceitful grinning Arts having overturned the Parliament, and murdered the King, he raiÅ¿ed himÅ¿elf to Supreme Power; many great Wits and able Pens have already deÅ¿cribed: Much he did in War, but more by PerfidiouÅ¿neÅ¿s, HypocriÅ¿ie, Perjury, and FalÅ¿hood.

More cruel he was than the ancient Tyrants, whoÅ¿e Manners and Examples he imitated: with Tiberius he was Å¿ubtile and Å¿uÅ¿picacious, He had a crafty diÅ¿poÅ¿ition with a jealous head, Tacit. Annab. l. 1. p. 4. and delighted in none of his Virtues Å¿o much as in DiÅ¿Å¿imulation; more eaÅ¿ily concealing Hatred than Fear. Nero he acted in the Å¿laughter of his beÅ¿t Country-men, nor was he unlike him in driving a Coach. His Countenance carried the bloudy complexion of Domitian,In vitÃ¢ Agricolae.
and a redneÅ¿s that fortified him againÅ¿t BluÅ¿hing.

But that he might not onely appear famous through Crimes and Villanies, by intervals he made a Å¿hew of Å¿ome great actions; not from a principle of GoodneÅ¿s, but Ambition; nor out of love to Virtue, but Vanity, and future Glory. This alone was wanting to his fortune and our Å¿lavery, that he had neither a Son nor SucceÅ¿Å¿our able to match him.

Pity it was that that bold Orator,Milton. or rather Bagpiper, was out of the way at the Å¿hameful ObÅ¿equies of the Traytors, that the Å¿ame hand which (reproaching all Kings in Latin) vindicated the
Party, and juÅ¿tified in writing the Crimes of the Parricides, now might, though a Å¿urley lookt School-maÅ¿ter, have either made a Funeral-Oration for the deceaÅ¿ed, or Å¿ung their PraiÅ¿es in hanging Elegies; his Poetry Å¿urpaÅ¿Å¿ing his Oratory, eÅ¿pecially when he treated of Å¿uch monÅ¿trous Å¿ubjects.

Strangers may perhaps wonder, and no leÅ¿s our PoÅ¿terity at home, that Å¿uch baÅ¿e and contemptible fellows, many of them Brewers, others who drank as they had brewed, and Å¿pent their EÅ¿tates; and Å¿ome again whoÅ¿e ignominious Poverty was a Å¿candal to the Nation, Å¿hould overturn the flouriÅ¿hing Å¿tate of England, and get to the top of Authority and Government.

Would we know the cauÅ¿e of it? TheÅ¿e were the Spoils, and theÅ¿e the Trophies of HereÅ¿ie; which taking its riÅ¿e from the Sermonizing Presbyterian MiniÅ¿ters, increaÅ¿ed by the Independants, hurried on by the Kennel of all the Sectarians, and by a kind of flying Contagion Å¿pread over all the Forces, could not be Å¿topt till they had Å¿hed the Royal Bloud, Å¿ubverted the Parliament, and made one ruinous heap of all good Subjects.

Mary PrinceÅ¿s of Orange came into England Sept. 23. She died at London. Dec. 24.Some time before, (September the twenty third) the PrinceÅ¿s of Orange was come into her Native Country, more fatal to her than a foreign Land, to congratulate his MajeÅ¿ties return; but falling Å¿ick of the Small Pox at London, on ChriÅ¿tmas-Eve Å¿he died, being Å¿natched away amidÅ¿t the Triumphs and freÅ¿h Lawrels of her Brother Charles, Å¿he onely Å¿hared in the adverÅ¿e fortune of her Family, and renewed the Mourning wherein the Court Å¿till was for the untimely death of the Duke of GlouceÅ¿ter.

1661.I Å¿hall begin the year with the Solemnities of the Coronation of King Charles. On the two and twentieth of May, The Solemnities of the K.'s Coronation. the King from the Tower of London, as the cuÅ¿tom is at the Coronation of our Kings,
paÅ¿Å¿ed through the City; where in honour of Å¿o great a Solemnity, the Citizens of London, in the more eminent places of the Å¿treets, erected four Triumphal Arches of a vaÅ¿t height and bigneÅ¿s; elaborate Pieces of Art, and exquiÅ¿ite Engines of Pomp, bearing InÅ¿criptions and Devices, and adorned with Painting and gilding.

The firÅ¿t Arch bore in its FrontiÅ¿pice the Triumph of Charles upon his return,Triumphal Arches. The FirÅ¿t.

The Third.The third placed in the middle of the City, repreÅ¿ented the Temple of Concord, with this InÅ¿cription.

The BritiÅ¿h Sea and Land being appeas'd, and

The Fourth.The laÅ¿t exhibited the Garden of Plenty and Cornucopia's with the Statues of Bac â¢ bus, Ceres, Flora, and Pomana, with this InÅ¿cription:
