Under all theÅ¿e, the King rode on horÅ¿e-back Å¿treight to his Palace in a triumphant manner with Trumpets, MuÅ¿ick, and the joyful Acclamations of the People, being attended by the Nobility, his MajeÅ¿ties MiniÅ¿ters and Servants, the Heralds, Kings at Arms, the Kings Judges, and Knights of the Bath.

The Å¿olemnity of this day, The King crowned at WeÅ¿tminÅ¿ter. April 23. though it was not Å¿o great in the number of Attendents, yet in richneÅ¿s and Å¿plendour of Cloaths and Arms, it Å¿urpaÅ¿Å¿ed the triumphant Entry of the King upon his return.

Next morning the King was in great pomp conducted to WeÅ¿tminÅ¿ter-Abbey, where in his Imperial Robes, the Prelates in their Myters, and the Nobles in their Parliament-Robes, conducted him to his Throne, and the ArchbiÅ¿hop of Canterbury anointed him with the Å¿acred Oyl. Afterwards all the ancient and uÅ¿ual Ceremonies upon Å¿uch occaÅ¿ions were performed.

Â¶ The Author of this HiÅ¿tory deÅ¿igning the utmoÅ¿t brevity, hath not mentioned any of theÅ¿e Ceremonies; but Mr. Philips in his Continuation of Dr. Richard Baker's Chronicle, has very exactly Å¿et forth all the Rituals then uÅ¿ed, but hath omitted the Coronation-Oath, and onely given an Epitom of it; and there having of late years been Å¿trange Pretences raiÅ¿ed upon the account of this Oath, it is thought fit to inÅ¿ert the Å¿ame here, from Mr. SanderÅ¿on's HiÅ¿tory of Charles the FirÅ¿t, with that variety of CircumÅ¿tances which were uÅ¿ed in the Coronation here mentioned, expreÅ¿Å¿ed by Mr. Philips.

sp.p: SIR, (Å¿aid the BiÅ¿hop of London) will you grant and keep, and by your Oath confirm to the People of England, the Laws and CuÅ¿toms to them granted by the Kings of England, your Lawful and Religious PredeceÅ¿Å¿ors; and namely, the Laws, CuÅ¿toms, and FranchiÅ¿es, granted to the Clergie by the Glorious King St. Edward your PredeceÅ¿Å¿or, according to the Laws of God, the true ProfeÅ¿Å¿ion of the GoÅ¿pel eÅ¿tabliÅ¿hed in this Kingdom, agreeable to the Prerogative of the Kings thereof, and the ancient CuÅ¿toms of the Realm?
The King's AnÅ¿wer, I grant and promiÅ¿e to keep them.

sp.speaker: BiÅ¿hop.
sp.p: Sir, Will you keep Peace and goodly Agreement (according to your power) both to God, the holy Church, the Clergie, and the People?

sp.speaker: BiÅ¿hop.
sp.p: Sir, Will you (to your power) cauÅ¿e Law, JuÅ¿tice, and DiÅ¿cretion, with Mercy and Truth, to be executed, to your Judgment?

sp.speaker: BiÅ¿hop.
sp.p: Sir, Will you grant to hold and keep the Laws and rightful CuÅ¿toms which the Commonalty of this Kingdom have; and will you defend and uphold them to the honour of God, Å¿o much as in you lieth?

p.hi: I grant and promiÅ¿e Å¿o to do.

sp.stage: Then the BiÅ¿hop of RocheÅ¿ter read this Admonition to the King, before the People with a loud voice.

p.hi: Our Lord and King, we beÅ¿eech you to pardon, and to grant and to preÅ¿erve unto us, and to the Churches committed to your charge, all Canonical Priviledges, and do Law and JuÅ¿tice, and that you would protect and defend us, as every good King to his Kingdoms ought to be Protector and Defender of the BiÅ¿hops, and the Churches under their government?

With a willing and devout heart, I promiÅ¿e and grant my Pardon, and that I will preÅ¿erve and maintain to you, and the Churches committed to your charge, all Canonical Priviledges and due Law and JuÅ¿tice, and that I will be your Protector and Defender to my power by the aÅ¿Å¿iÅ¿tance of God, as every good King in his Kingdom in right ought to protect and defend the BiÅ¿hops and Churches under their government.

sp.stage: Then the King aroÅ¿e, and was led by the BiÅ¿hops of DureÅ¿me and Bath and Wells, to the Communion-Table, where he made a Å¿olemn Oath in Å¿ight of all the People, to obÅ¿erve the PremiÅ¿es; and laying his hand upon the Bible, Å¿aid,

sp.p: The things which I have here promiÅ¿ed, I Å¿hall perform and keep: So help me God, and the Contents of this Book.

div.p: On the eighth of May a new Parliament met, which continued many years.A new Parl. May 8. The traiterous Solemn League and Covenant is condemned & burnt. Since, the year before the Regicides had been brought to condign puniÅ¿hment, the three EÅ¿tates of Parliament, now condemned to the flames, the Solemn League and Covenant, the Bond of the EngliÅ¿h and ScottiÅ¿h ConÅ¿piracy, and Sacrament of the Presbyterian Villany. The Å¿ame was done by the Parliament of Scotland and Ireland; and that which had raiÅ¿ed a Civil CombuÅ¿tion, and propagated the Å¿ame all over Britain and Ireland, is now burnt by the hand of the Hangman, and by its own aÅ¿hes expiated at length the wickedneÅ¿s of three Nations.

The puniÅ¿hment of MouÅ¿on, Mildmay, and Wallop. Jan. 27. 1661, 62.This year was concluded, or the new begun, by the further puniÅ¿hment of Regicides: For by Order of Parliament, MouÅ¿on, an upÅ¿tart Lord, Sir Henry Mildmay, heretofore Keeper of the Jewels to the late King, and therefore the more criminal, and Robert Wallop, on the Å¿even and twentieth of January, the day whereon the bleÅ¿Å¿ed King had been condemned; were in Hurdles, with Halters about their necks, dragged to Tyburn and back again to Town, being Å¿entenced to perpetual impriÅ¿onment.

It was Å¿ufficiently made out that they had been Members of that execrable High Court of JuÅ¿tice; but becauÅ¿e they had not Å¿igned the Warrant for the Kings execution, they were onely puniÅ¿hed by Bonds and ImpriÅ¿onment.

Hazelrigg in the mean time, one of the bittereÅ¿t of all the Traytors, being Å¿entenced to the Å¿ame puniÅ¿hment, pined away with anger and grief, and unable to bare his diÅ¿grace, prevented the diÅ¿honour and his captivity by a timely death in the Tower of London.

The Traytors that came in:The Å¿ame puniÅ¿hment was inflicted upon the Traytors who (as we Å¿aid before) came in upon the
Kings Proclamation: For being brought to the Bar,1662. becauÅ¿e waving all defence,Hard. Waller, â¢ eveningham, Marten, Jam. Temple, Wayte, Tichburn, Lilburn, Downs, Penningt. Smith, Garland, Geo. Fleetwood, Roe, Millingt. Meyn, Peter Temple, Harvey & Potter. they humbly acknowledged their Crime, and that they were a Crew, moÅ¿t part of them, of Å¿illy Å¿educed RaÅ¿cals, drawn in either by the arts or threatnings of Cromwel: they redeemed their necks from the Gallows, which they had Å¿o often deÅ¿erved, by a perpetual impriÅ¿onment; to which being cloÅ¿ely confined, they lived to Å¿ee their Villany puniÅ¿hed by Infamy.

But fortune was more favourable to the Traytors that came in at home, than to thoÅ¿e who fled abroad: for about that time Sir George Downing being EmbaÅ¿Å¿adour in Holland, had intelligence that three of the Fugitive Regicides, Barkstead, Okey, BarkÅ¿tead, Okey, and Corbet taken. and Corbet, being come back out of Germany, lurked in Delf. He therefore having obtained a Warrant from the States General, Å¿eized them, and Å¿ent them over to England; where being brought to a tryal, Were hanged at Tyburn. April 19. they were condemned for High-TreaÅ¿on, and April the nineteenth executed at Tyburn.

They went all to death with a fanatical oÅ¿tentation of Piety. But Barkstead and Corbet approaching to their end, after many ugly delays, and cups of Strong-waters, unwillingly put their trembling necks into the Halter, which quickly put an end to the Wretches, half dead already for fear. But Okey being a man of an undaunted mind, and making uÅ¿e of his courage to the laÅ¿t, went off with the bravoury of a Souldier, and not undecently, had he Å¿o died for his Country.

Corbet was heretofore an inÅ¿pired prating Lawyer, more skilful in the Principles of Fanaticks,Corbet's Character. than in the Laws; he got to be a Member of that long and black Parliament, and no man was more profeÅ¿Å¿edly an implacable Enemy to the King.

The low extraction of Okey is buried in obÅ¿curity. Being a Tallow-chandler in London, Okey's. and
weary of his poor condition, he followed the profitable Wars of the Parliament; where his daringneÅ¿s advanced him to the place of a Colonel, and at length to be one of the chief Judges in trying and Å¿entencing the King.

And BarkÅ¿tead's.
Barkstead was heretofore a whifling GoldÅ¿mith in London, and had raiÅ¿ed himÅ¿elf upon the Ruines of his Country: But thoÅ¿e who knew the cunning of Oliver in chuÅ¿ing his MagiÅ¿trates, wondered that he preferred Å¿o Å¿illy and idle a fellow, even to be a Colonel, and Lieutenant of the Tower of London, beÅ¿ides other Offices.

But that kind of Å¿tupid fierceneÅ¿s was more uÅ¿eful to Cromwel than the cunninger knavery of others: for the Tyrant himÅ¿elf for the moÅ¿t part looked another way, and commanded the Villanies which he would not behold; Å¿o that this fellow, no doubt, was privy to the furious Councils of Cromwel, and a truÅ¿ty MiniÅ¿ter of his Protectoral Cruelty: And Å¿o long as he was chief Jaylor to Oliver, the barbarous Villain was never Å¿tartled at the Å¿ight of the Murders and ImpriÅ¿onments of Å¿o many Nobles and worthy Subjects. His head was Å¿et upon a Gate of the Tower, whereof heretofore he had been Governour, that upon the Å¿ame Stage where he acted his greateÅ¿t Crimes, he might Å¿uffer his greateÅ¿t PuniÅ¿hment.

The vanity of the Regicides even to the laÅ¿t.The firÅ¿t Prodigy of the Regicides was their matchleÅ¿s impudence in putting to death the King; and their next, their obÅ¿tinacy to the laÅ¿t. For when they had murdered the beÅ¿t of Kings, to the Å¿hame of ChriÅ¿tianity, the infamy of the Reformation, and the univerÅ¿al reproach and malediction of Fanatick Zeal; theÅ¿e godly Regicides were aÅ¿hamed, when TreaÅ¿on Å¿tuck in their breaÅ¿ts, to confeÅ¿s their hypocritical pretending Religion, even at the laÅ¿t gaÅ¿p. Nay, their GodlineÅ¿s made them
Å¿o impudent, as rather to know themÅ¿elves guilty and deny it, to Å¿ave their reputation amongÅ¿t their Brethren, than humbly and modeÅ¿tly to acknowledge their Crimes.

The Authority of Parliament was the onely thing that all of them alleadged to juÅ¿tifie their Parricide,And the cauÅ¿e of it. as if a Gang of fifty Robbers (who had Å¿o often violated that Authority) had been worthy of that name, when there was neither the colour nor reÅ¿emblance of a HouÅ¿e of Commons left.
div.q: Nec color Imperii, nec frons fuit illa SenatÃ»s.
div.p: But Å¿ince they could live no longer to do miÅ¿chief, their whole care was at their death to harden the minds of their Party by a fanatical aÅ¿Å¿ertation of dying good men: when it was rather the higheÅ¿t Judgment of an offended God, to let them fill up the Cup of their bold Indignities by a deÅ¿perate end.

It was time now for the King, The K. Think â¢
of Marriage. who was a Batchelour, to think of Marriage, that he might leave a PoÅ¿terity for the future Å¿ecurity of his Kingdom; and therefore communicating his intentions to the Parliament, he addreÅ¿Å¿ed himÅ¿elf to the moÅ¿t IlluÅ¿trious Catharine Daughter of Portugal, deÅ¿cended from the ancient Race of the Family of Braganza; with the univerÅ¿al ApplauÅ¿e and Congratulation of the EÅ¿tates. And a Fleet was Å¿ent to Portugal to bring over the Royal Bride; who having had a favourable paÅ¿Å¿age to the EngliÅ¿h CoaÅ¿t, was by his Royal HighneÅ¿s the Duke of York met and Å¿aluted with Naval Solemnities at the IÅ¿le of Wight.

The King received his Bride at PortÅ¿mouth, and was with great Solemnity, in preÅ¿ence of many Nobles, there married, the Office of Matrimony having been performed by Gilbert Sheldon BiÅ¿hop of London.

The King from thence conducted his Royal ConÅ¿ort to Whitehall,
He marries Catharine at PortÅ¿mouth. May 22. where, after the reiterated feÅ¿tivity of the Royal Nuptials, the dutiful Complements of the Great men, and the PreÅ¿ents of the Lord Mayor and chief Citizens of London, Å¿lighting the wanton PleaÅ¿ures of a Court, by the innocence of her Manners, and an exemplary Piety of Life, Å¿he conÅ¿ecrated the trancient Delights of a Palace to the Å¿everer Sanctity of a MonaÅ¿tery. A Queen that wanted nothing to render her Å¿elf and us happy, had Å¿he been as fruitful as good.

Sir Hen. Vane brought to tryal. June 2. On the Å¿econd of June, the laÅ¿t of the Traytors Sir Henry Vane, after a two years impriÅ¿onment, is brought at length to the Bar: where, after he had defended himÅ¿elf by Å¿hifts, and Å¿trained querks of Law, rather than by any colourable Plea, he is found guilty of High-TreaÅ¿on.

The firÅ¿t advance he made in the career of his Villany, was in the death of the Earl of Strafford; afterwards being a great Incendiary in the Civil Wars,His Character. and equally ungrateful and perfidious to Charles the Martyr, he cheriÅ¿hed and Å¿trengthened the Party of the Traytors: and though more cautiouÅ¿ly than innocently, he was not preÅ¿ent at the Condemnation of the King; yet after the Murder of Charles, he was very active in changing the Monarchy into a Commonwealth, and in aboliÅ¿hing for ever the Government of Kings.

But at length, when Cromwel got into the Supreme Power, being ill-affected and envious againÅ¿t all Government by a Å¿ingle PerÅ¿on, he was neglected and laid aÅ¿ide: But when the Rump came again into play, with the pretences of a Brutus or CaÅ¿Å¿ius, he Å¿tept again to the Helm of Government, and was one of the Committee of Safety. He was, as to Religion, a man of an inconÅ¿tant and unÅ¿etled mind, who profeÅ¿Å¿edly hating the name of a King,
was treacherous to Charles the FirÅ¿t, 1663. and envious to Charles the Second.

January the fourteenth, Beheaded. Jan. 14. 1662, 63. being brought to a Scaffold on Tower-hill, with a moÅ¿t affected Å¿hew of a compoÅ¿ed and Å¿edate mind, as the reÅ¿t of the Traytors had already done, he inÅ¿iÅ¿ted upon the Supreme Authority of Parliament, and Å¿pake much of the Presbyterian Covenant, the Engine of all our Evils, which heretofore when he was a far more refined Heretick, he had Å¿o often deÅ¿piÅ¿ed and laughed at.

And whilÅ¿t he Å¿till perÅ¿iÅ¿ted in aÅ¿Å¿erting his own innocence, not without reproaching his Judges, Sir John RobinÅ¿on Lieutenant of the Tower, wanting patience to hear any more, interrupted him. Being vexed at this, like a mad man, he tore the written Speech that he had in his hand, and though he had never Å¿hew'd great reÅ¿olution amongÅ¿t his Party, yet reÅ¿olutely, or rather ragingly, he Å¿ubmitted to the blow of the Executioner; and fell a Sacrifice to the GhoÅ¿t of the Great Strafford, and to the Subverted Monarchy.

But Lambert, who Å¿tood indicted with Vane,
Lambert is condemned; had better luck, and behaved himÅ¿elf with Å¿o much modeÅ¿ty in his looks and words at his tryal, that though he Å¿uffered the Sentence of Death, as deÅ¿erving the utmoÅ¿t Rigour,But obtains Mercy from the King. The Duke of Ormond goes Lord Deputy into Ireland. July 9. yet he taÅ¿ted the Kings Mercy, and ranÅ¿omed his Life by a perpetual ImpriÅ¿onment.

About the middle of Summer the Duke of Ormond went over to Ireland as Lord Deputy of that Kingdom; there to give as great inÅ¿tances of Civil Prudence, as heretofore he had erected Trophies of Military Glory during the IriÅ¿h War.

The Parliament now Å¿itting,The Ceremonies and Rites of the Church confirmed by Parl. May 29. the Convocation of the Clergie Å¿ate alÅ¿o; and the LicentiouÅ¿neÅ¿s of Fanatical Sects increaÅ¿ing, made the diÅ¿treÅ¿Å¿ed
Church look to the King and Parliament for relief: It was therefore enacted by the King in Parliament, That the Sacraments of BaptiÅ¿m and the Lords Supper, and the publick Prayers and Liturgie of the Church, Å¿hould be celebrated after the ancient manner of the Reformed Church of England, the Fanaticks on all hands crying out againÅ¿t it, and refuÅ¿ing to conform.

The licentiouÅ¿neÅ¿s of Fanaticks.For though they enjoyed Impunity with the rewards of their Crimes, yet no gracious condeÅ¿cenÅ¿ions of the King could oblige them. The Clemency of the Prince was maliciouÅ¿ly interpreted by the Sects, and the Power of this indulging Monarch was grievous to theÅ¿e Fanaticks. Nor had the King granted Å¿o much to Traytors, but that they Å¿till thought they might take to themÅ¿elves more; and the brazen-faced SectariÅ¿ts demand of the Son, the Å¿ame liberty of Religion which had undone the Father.

And without any reÅ¿pect or reverence to MajeÅ¿ty and the Laws, frequent Conventicles of Å¿editious men were kept: Meetings were to be found everywere in Towns and Villages, and the InÅ¿olence of the Rabble growing greater by the boldneÅ¿s of their Preachers and the Lenity of the King, there was nothing but a muÅ¿tering of Parties, boaÅ¿ting of Å¿trength, and polling of heads amongÅ¿t the Factious; all which Å¿eemed to threaten imminent Dangers.

The attempt of Vennet the Cooper.The year before, the Fifth-monarchy-men under Venner, raiÅ¿ed the firÅ¿t Stirs amongÅ¿t the Preaching Rout; but their Fury, like the thundering Rage of Marius of old,Flor. was confined within the City, and there expired, the fierceÅ¿t of the Traytors being killed upon the Å¿pot, and others at length brought to the Gallows.

But this year a darker, and therefore more dangerous
ConÅ¿piracy was hatched; the Å¿ame being the cauÅ¿e of this, as of all other Plots, to wit, a looÅ¿e and obÅ¿tinate licentiouÅ¿neÅ¿s in Religion.

Many of all Sects were concerned in it, Å¿everal Officers of Cromwel's late disbanded Army, Members of the late Rump-Parliament, and many who were turned out of the Kings and Churches Lands, which they had heretofore Å¿acrilegiouÅ¿ly purchaÅ¿ed. And a Å¿ecret Committee at London had the direction of all their Councils and Actings.

The chief deÅ¿igne of their Villany, was to kill the King and Duke of York, murder the Duke of Albemarle, Å¿et fire to the City, Å¿eize the Tower of London, rifle the Exchequer; and through the Bowels of the Nation, drive on a new Fanatical Government.

In the mean time,Infamous Libels are found. to make way to the bold Attempts of theÅ¿e RaÅ¿cals, it was reÅ¿olved, that impudent Libels Å¿hould be Å¿cattered about;Twine the Printer hang'd Feb. 24. 1663, 64. but the Papers being Å¿eized at the PreÅ¿s, the Printer was hanged, and payed dear for his officious medling.

But the licentiouÅ¿neÅ¿s and boldneÅ¿s of the Conventiclers growing greater and greater daily, the Parl. made an Act to put a Å¿top to the Å¿editiouÅ¿neÅ¿s of the People,Conventicles forbidden by Act of Parl. commanding the doors of the Meeting-houÅ¿es to be Å¿hut, or guarded by Souldiers, and impoÅ¿ing upon Delinquents, for the firÅ¿t fault a Fine; for the Å¿econd, ImpriÅ¿onment; and for the third, BaniÅ¿hment: that puniÅ¿hment might at length reÅ¿train thoÅ¿e whom Clemency could not gain.

NevertheleÅ¿s, a War with Holland breaking forth, and the Laws being Å¿ilent amongÅ¿t the noiÅ¿e of Arms, the domeÅ¿tick Calamity grew Å¿o Å¿trong, that the Authority of the JuÅ¿tices of the Peace not being able to prevail againÅ¿t the obÅ¿tinacy of the Rabble, the evil catched like Wild-fire, and all future Remedies
Å¿eemed poÅ¿thumous and unÅ¿eaÅ¿onable.1664.

Complaints of the injuries of the Dutch. The great injuries done by the Dutch to the EngliÅ¿h Merchants, having for a long time paÅ¿t unrevenged, did now occaÅ¿ion great grievances, and complaining at London. Though there was no Nation upon Earth whom the Dutch deÅ¿ired more for Friends and leÅ¿s for Enemies than the EngliÅ¿h, who in the late War had proved themÅ¿elves as formidable Enemies to the Hollanders, as heretofore they had been to their Enemies; yet they unjuÅ¿tly broke that Peace, which Å¿ome years before they had diÅ¿honourably begg'd of the Rump and Cromwel, (as being neceÅ¿Å¿ary for their intereÅ¿t) by humble AddreÅ¿Å¿es, Å¿ordid and baÅ¿e compliances of their EmbaÅ¿Å¿adours; and had Å¿ince confirmed by a Å¿tricter League with King Charles the Second.

For to that pitch of Arrogance and Perfidy was that State of FiÅ¿her-men, and croud of crafty Merchants, who under the Title of a Commonwealth diÅ¿liked all Monarchy, raiÅ¿ed, that (beÅ¿ides the detaining of the IÅ¿land of Poloron, which they were obliged to deliver up by the Articles of Peace) they took a great many EngliÅ¿h Ships upon the CoaÅ¿t of India and Africa, What were the injuries of the Dutch. and making Prize of the Ships and Goods, made the Sea-men PriÅ¿oners, and added cruelty and Å¿coffing to their InjuÅ¿tice.

They block up many Ports of the Indies which the EngliÅ¿h had long poÅ¿Å¿eÅ¿Å¿ed with Men of War; and having unjuÅ¿tly intercepted the EngliÅ¿h Trade, they Å¿old to other Nations at home, at the dear rates, the Commodities which they had for a Å¿mall matter bought in the Indies.

They injure, Holmes, who was Admiral for the King upon the CoaÅ¿t of India and Africa, behaving himÅ¿elf modeÅ¿tly in his CommiÅ¿Å¿ion, was by thoÅ¿e Dutch Pirats, by Sea and Land, whom neither the EaÅ¿t nor WeÅ¿t could Å¿atisfie, contrary to the Law of Nations,
often fired upon. At which, Holmes, a man of a daring temper, and unacquainted with affronts,And provoke Holmes. being provoked, reÅ¿olved to continue no longer on the defenÅ¿ive part, but to turn AggreÅ¿Å¿our; and therefore bringing his Guns aÅ¿hore, and planting them on Batteries, he took Å¿ome of the Dutch GarriÅ¿ons, and revenged the injuries he had received.

But with falÅ¿e AccuÅ¿ations they complain of Holmes, They falÅ¿ly accuÅ¿e him. who had been Å¿o often and baÅ¿ely uÅ¿ed by them, to the King, crying out againÅ¿t him as a Robber, and the cauÅ¿er of a War; as if by making a clamour firÅ¿t, they might ridiculouÅ¿ly excuÅ¿e their own Treachery.

TheÅ¿e and many other Encroachments of the Dutch Å¿o incenÅ¿ed the Parliament, The Parl. is moved at the injuries of the Dutch, and addreÅ¿s to the King. that they forthwith voted it neceÅ¿Å¿ary to revenge Å¿o many Injuries done to the Merchants, and a conÅ¿iderable Å¿upply of money to be given to the King, to carry on a War, which they judged Å¿afer than a doubtful and uncertain Peace.

Though the King was highly offended to hear of the Injuries done to his Subjects, and concerned in honour to right them; yet he reÅ¿olved to try other ways of adjuÅ¿ting matters, before he came to force of Arms; having therefore diÅ¿patched Letters to Sir George Downing, The King demands Reparation by his EmbaÅ¿Å¿adour; his EmbaÅ¿Å¿adour at the Hague, he demands a Å¿peedy reparation of the Injuries done to his Subjects from the States. But though the Kings demands were juÅ¿t and lawful,But in vain. yet it was in vain to repreÅ¿ent the Rapines of Dutch Merchants to trafficking States, Å¿ince they who were in Authority, and Å¿hould have puniÅ¿hed theÅ¿e AbuÅ¿es, reaped the profit of them.

But amongÅ¿t theÅ¿e ClaÅ¿hings about Injuries, a new cauÅ¿e of quarrel, not heard of till then, happened, through the treachery of the Dutch. For
the year before, the States General having been oppreÅ¿Å¿ed by the frequent Piracies of the Algerines, by EmbaÅ¿Å¿adours made earneÅ¿t application to the King, that joyning his Fleet with theirs, he would help to revenge the Injuries of theÅ¿e Infidels: Nor was the King wanting to contribute to the Å¿afety of his Subjects, and of all ChriÅ¿tendom; but Å¿ent Vice-Admiral LawÅ¿on, an expert Sea-Commander, with a well-appointed Fleet, to joyn and aÅ¿Å¿iÅ¿t the Fleet commanded by de Ruyter.

But whilÅ¿t LawÅ¿on was wholly taken up in fighting and purÅ¿uing the Pirats Ships (of which he had Å¿unk and burnt many) upon the CoaÅ¿t of Barbary, De Ruyter gave him the Å¿lip,De Ruyter's action at Guiny. and by orders from the States directed his courÅ¿e to Guiny; where falling upon the EngliÅ¿h who were Å¿ecure, and neither expected nor deÅ¿erved any Å¿uch thing, he committed no leÅ¿s Robberies upon us, than he pretended to revenge on the Algerines, but with far greater treachery.

The news of Å¿o baÅ¿e an action being freÅ¿hly brought to London, Å¿o incenÅ¿ed all People, that the King highly offended, commanded all Dutch Ships in the Ports of England to be Å¿topt, and all further Treaties of Pacification being laid aÅ¿ide, both Å¿ides prepare for a War.

The contumelious Å¿aucineÅ¿s of the Dutch. But during the preludes of the approaching War, the Dutch, a more contumelious than formidable Enemy, inflamed the rage and hatred of the EngliÅ¿h by Å¿currilous Libels, Medals, and many baÅ¿e and Å¿atyrical Pictures, according to the innate inÅ¿olency and barbarous vanity of that People.

De Wit the Dutch Dictator.
Holland more powerful both in Wealth and Cunning, led the reÅ¿t of the Æ²nited Provinces by the noÅ¿e; and Dewit Holland, a man of a crafty and Å¿ubtle Wit, malicious Eloquence, and of more reputation for cunning Policy than HoneÅ¿ty. The
greatneÅ¿s of the Family of the Prince of Orange, and the vaÅ¿t power of the King of Great Britain by Sea, Å¿tood in the way of the Artifices of this arrogant man, and of his own Holland.

To ruine therefore the Prince and Family of NaÅ¿Å¿au, he raiÅ¿ed Å¿ecret jealouÅ¿ies againÅ¿t him;His Character and Arts. and by leÅ¿Å¿ening the authority of Orange with the States, he alone managed all affairs, and under colour of Å¿tanding up for the liberty of the Commonwealth, ruled abÅ¿olutely at his pleaÅ¿ure; and Å¿o confident of himÅ¿elf grew this Butter-box, that having trode upon the Dignity of the Prince at home, he thought that by turns he might make fools of all the Kings of Europe. He hated the King of Great Britain the more, becauÅ¿e he feared him; and Å¿ince, through Å¿imilitude of Manners, he had been a great friend to the Traytor Cromwel, he was therefore the more implacable Enemy to King Charles. Certainly, next to the inÅ¿atiable Avarice of the Dutch Nation, all the hatred of that People to the EngliÅ¿h, is to be attributed to Dewit and his Faction.

To Å¿o great an Arrogance were the Dutch raiÅ¿ed,The confidence of the Dutch, and why. that it was given out amongÅ¿t the People, That the affairs of England were not in Å¿uch a poÅ¿ture, that the Civil War of England being juÅ¿t ended, they had money enough Å¿till to make War abroad; nor that the King was, as yet, Å¿o well Å¿eated in the Government, that he could revenge the Injuries of the Dutch: that it was not Å¿afe for him to truÅ¿t Arms in the hands of his Subjects, which afterwards they might be unwilling to lay down.

That the EngliÅ¿h were not now the Å¿ame Enemies as the Dutch had found them to be under the Rump-Parliament; that the warlike fierceneÅ¿s of that Nation was gone with the Sectarians, and that there remained amongÅ¿t them none but a company of Å¿illy Cowards: That there were a great many Fanaticks in England,
who perhaps would fight for the Dutch againÅ¿t the King, or at leaÅ¿t would not fight for him againÅ¿t thoÅ¿e who were for liberty of ConÅ¿cience. Nor was there wanting a great many of our fugitive Traytors amongÅ¿t the Dutch, who made theÅ¿e falÅ¿e reports to be believed.

The bloudy War which broke out the year following, was uÅ¿hered in by the taking of Ships on both Å¿ides; Alan's action. and Alan with a Fleet of EngliÅ¿h Ships, for Å¿ecuring the Merchant-men, and anoying the Dutch in the Mediterranean, fell upon the Dutch Smirna-Fleet in the Streights upon their return homewards; and having killed them many men, Å¿unk Å¿ome Ships, Brakell the Admiral of the Fleet being Å¿lain; he took and brought off four of the Enemies Ships, which was the firÅ¿t booty and glad Omen of the War; but one of them richly laden, being much Å¿hattered and leaky, foundered in the greedy Sea.

The K. viÅ¿its the Colledge of PhyÅ¿icians of London. April 15. 1665.Nor was the King Å¿o wholly taken up with the thoughts of the approaching War, but that he alÅ¿o minded other affairs, and his innocent diverÅ¿ions; he therefore on the fifteenth of April viÅ¿ited the famous Colledge of PhyÅ¿icians of London, and was received very honourably by the Doctors.

They therefore bear away to St. Helens Point, a very fit place to intercept the French Fleet, that then was at the Rochell.

The Fire of London. Sept. 2.But Å¿o many fortunate Å¿ucceÅ¿Å¿es over conquered Enemies abroad, were quaÅ¿hed by a Å¿udden and moÅ¿t diÅ¿mal Calamity at home; as if the beams of our Å¿hining Fortune were always to be intermixed and Å¿et off by AdverÅ¿ities: For on the Å¿econd of September, a Lamentable Fire broke out in London; a Å¿ad Judgment of an offended God againÅ¿t England. The Fire began in a Bakers houÅ¿e in the lower part of the City near Thames-Å¿treet, amongÅ¿t old rotten houÅ¿es apt to catch fire, and full of combuÅ¿tible Goods. The darkneÅ¿s of the night putting all things into terrour and confuÅ¿ion, increaÅ¿ed the horrour of the Calamity. The Citizens being frightened, delayed the uÅ¿e of timely Remedies; and which was no Å¿mall acceÅ¿Å¿ion to the Evil, the people neglecting too much their houÅ¿es, were too fatally Å¿et upon the haÅ¿ty removing of their Goods, which were yet at length devoured by the nimble flames.

The raging EaÅ¿t Wind that had much incommoded the EngliÅ¿h Fleet at Sea, did far greater damage in the burning City, by carrying the force of the flames through the greateÅ¿t part of London. The Conflagration grew Å¿oon inÅ¿uperable by the
blowing of the Wind; which raiÅ¿ing in a moment the fire from the bottom to the tops of the houÅ¿es, and Å¿cattering flakes in all places, it grew too Å¿trong for the endeavours of thoÅ¿e that laboured to quench it. Here the blazes of ruddy flames were to be Å¿een, and there the craÅ¿hing of falling houÅ¿es to be heard; and which was the Å¿adeÅ¿t Spectacle under the Sun, the doleful looks of Å¿o many Citizens, the wailings of deÅ¿olate women, and the cries of children and decrepit aged people: And in the forÅ¿aken Å¿hops of the wealthy Inhabitants, numbers of Thieves and Pilferers, greedier of Booty than the fire, villanouÅ¿ly skulked.

No man that had a Å¿enÅ¿e of humane MiÅ¿eries, could Å¿ee, and not be affected with the diÅ¿mal Å¿pectacle of the Ruining City of London. Now were there to be Å¿een almoÅ¿t an hundred Churches conÅ¿ecrated to God, and many HoÅ¿pitals, the Monuments of ancient Piety; beÅ¿ides other publick Buildings, raiÅ¿ed at the vaÅ¿t charges of our AnceÅ¿tors; the famed Sion-Colledge, and Royal Exchange of London, the Guild-hall, and Å¿tately Cathedral of St. Pauls, as Å¿ad Spectacles of the Calamity, either buried under their own RubbiÅ¿h, or Å¿tanding Monuments of the devouring flames.

WhilÅ¿t all things elÅ¿e in the Exchange were conÅ¿umed, without Å¿paring the many Statues of our Kings, onely that of GreÅ¿ham the Founder Å¿tood, to bewail the Ruines of his own Fabrick: Å¿o kind was Fate to the fame and memory of the liberal Doner.

The King, whoÅ¿e high-born Soul was above the ViciÅ¿Å¿itudes of humane Contingencies, could not but with grief and Å¿orrow behold the lamentable Calamity of his wretched Subjects, and native City, exhorting, comforting, and adviÅ¿ing them in their greateÅ¿t difficulties: And therefore he ordered,
that the next houÅ¿es to the fire Å¿hould be blown up, that a void Å¿pace being made betwixt the Buildings, the remaining part of the City, that which Å¿till Å¿tood, might be Å¿aved; this being the laÅ¿t Remedy that could be uÅ¿ed.

The Duke of York alÅ¿o, and many of the Nobility, praiÅ¿ed and encouraged the forward, aÅ¿Å¿iÅ¿ted the diÅ¿treÅ¿Å¿ed, and gave a generous example to all by the vigorous reÅ¿iÅ¿tance they made againÅ¿t the devouring flames.

The fire is put out, Sept. 4. After that the Conflagration had continued four days, to the ineÅ¿timable loÅ¿Å¿es of the Citizens, and had burnt down thirteen thouÅ¿and houÅ¿es, it was at length Å¿topt more at the direction of Divine Providence, than by any humane Arts or Means.

The more loyal part of the Citizens, affected with the Kings Å¿orrow more than their own, put an high value upon his Royal CompaÅ¿Å¿ion towards them.The Fictions of Fanaticks concerning the Fire. But the Fanatical Clubs, who turned even the Calamities of their Country into Reproaches, could Å¿carcely forbear to miÅ¿cal the Judgment a Command; or at leaÅ¿t did buz it about, that the Kings Guards were a hindrance to thoÅ¿e who laboured to put out the fire; but the commoner Å¿urmiÅ¿e was, that Å¿ome French Agents had fired the City: And many reaÅ¿ons were by fear or envy Å¿uggeÅ¿ted to confirm the Treachery; nothing being more uÅ¿ual amongÅ¿t the common People, than to make all CaÅ¿ualties DeÅ¿ignes.

But thoÅ¿e who Å¿till remembred the inÅ¿olent Rage of the Londoners, was the firÅ¿t cauÅ¿e of the Misfortunes of Charles the Martyr, that the City was polluted with Å¿acred Bloud, had beheld the Å¿ad fate of the King, and that Å¿ome of the Citizens had called for, and others permitted the murder of Charles, humbly acknowledged the avenging hand of God in the Judgment.

This was the iÅ¿Å¿ue of that memorable fire of London; which for above two thouÅ¿and years had been riÅ¿ing to that greatneÅ¿s, which now it could hardly bear. A City impregnable againÅ¿t all the Efforts of Å¿o many foreign Enemies, and civil Broils; could no otherways be ruined but by the breaking out of a Fire amongÅ¿t old wooden Buildings that were but too apt fewel for the flames.

Yet after the City was deÅ¿troyed,Liv. l. 5. the Londoners bore up with greater reÅ¿olutions than the Romans did of old, when after the Conflagration made by the Gaules, they removed to Veii: nor did any man, deÅ¿pairing to Å¿ee London again rebuilt, talk in the leaÅ¿t of changing his habitation; but the Citizens crowding themÅ¿elves into Booths and new-made Deal-board houÅ¿es, or into Dwellings in the Suburbs, took their meaÅ¿ures about the building of a new City.

The approaching Winter now put an end to all Naval Engagements for this year;The Fleets put into Harbour. Å¿o that both Fleets, the Dutch and ours, put into Harbour and were laid up; and left the Privateers on each Å¿ide to moleÅ¿t and take Merchant-men at Sea.

The King having laÅ¿t year tried the Å¿hifting way of his Enemies managing the War,1667. reÅ¿olved upon other meaÅ¿ures, that by intercepting the Dutch Trade, he might force them either to put an end to the War by fairly fighting, or willingly Å¿ubmitting.

So that without putting himÅ¿elf to the charge of a Fleet this Summer,The K. keeps his Fleet at home; he was adviÅ¿ed to order Å¿ome Frigats to cruiÅ¿e in the ScottiÅ¿h Seas, and others in the WeÅ¿t about Plimouth, thereby on all hands to Å¿hut up the BritiÅ¿h Ocean.

And by fortifying SherneÅ¿s and Æ²pnore-CaÅ¿tle,And Å¿ecures the CoaÅ¿ts and Harbours. and drawing a Chain croÅ¿s the River of Medway, to Å¿ecure the Royal Fleet at Chatham; which was better adviÅ¿ed than executed.

And now the powerful Kings of France and Sweden, Neighbouring Kings mediate a Peace. by their EmbaÅ¿Å¿adours mediate a Peace betwixt the King and the States; Å¿o that the heat of both Parties being Å¿omewhat allied by the mutual loÅ¿Å¿es that two trafficking Nations had Å¿uÅ¿tained in their Trade, as well as otherwiÅ¿e, they both condeÅ¿cend to Å¿end EmbaÅ¿Å¿adours to Breda, to treat of a Peace.

The Dutch by Å¿urprize fall upon the Kings Fleet. June 10. But the EngliÅ¿h truÅ¿ting to a Truce or CeÅ¿Å¿ation of HoÅ¿tilities, in order to a Pacification, laid aÅ¿ide all thoughts of War, and the Guard-Å¿hips were far off at Sea: A part of the Dutch Fleet in the mean time entering Chatham-River, and having forced the GarriÅ¿ons on the Å¿hore, and broken the Iron-Chain that was too weak to make a reÅ¿iÅ¿tance, fell upon the Kings Fleet, which had often chaÅ¿ed them, lying mored in the River, unrigged, and unprovided of Sea-men and Souldiers.

Our Frigats were burnt by the Dutch Fire-Å¿hips, and others Å¿natched, not carried away in triumph, to the reproach no leÅ¿s of the Dutch Knavery, than of our own vain Security; a loÅ¿s Å¿o much the greater, by how much it coÅ¿t the Enemy the leÅ¿s.

The King in the mean time paÅ¿Å¿ing by the Treachery of that People, and conquering his own ReÅ¿entment, (for the preÅ¿ent) performed his PromiÅ¿e; and that he might not delay the Treaty of Peace,EmbaÅ¿Å¿adours meet on both Å¿ides; Å¿ent the Lord Hollis, one of his MajeÅ¿ties Privy-Council, and Henry Coventry, on the Prudence of which two the King much relied, as his EmbaÅ¿Å¿adours for carrying on the Peace; which at length was concluded at Breda, And conclude a Peace. July 9. upon no leÅ¿s honourable Conditions, than what the King had demanded before the War.

And now this Naval War, carried on by the Å¿ucceÅ¿sful Valour of York, the Courage of Prince Rupert and Albemarle, is at length terminated in a
moÅ¿t Å¿pecious Peace; but Å¿uch as drew the fate of that perfidious People upon themÅ¿elves, the beginning of the fall of the Æ²nited Provinces being to be calculated from that War.

The King was not a little inclined to facilitate the profitable Peace,The building of London is taken into conÅ¿ideration. that the Citizens might have time to rebuild the City: And the War being now over, he made it his care to erect to himÅ¿elf Trophies of Glory, upon the Ruines and RubbiÅ¿h of London; inÅ¿tead of a wooden City which he had loÅ¿t, laying the foundations of one of Brick that might more powerfully reÅ¿iÅ¿t the flames. Nor were the Citizens allowed to build at their pleaÅ¿ure, but the Å¿treets being firÅ¿t Å¿taked out, and enlarged on each Å¿ide, every one built their houÅ¿es in a Å¿trait and equal front; London riÅ¿ing again with Å¿o much beauty and uniformity, that the loÅ¿s of the old City was hardly regreted.

October the twenty third,The Royal Exchange founded. Octob. 23. the King being honourably received in the City, laid the firÅ¿t Stone in the foundation of the Royal Exchange: the next was laid by the Duke of York, an auÅ¿picuous PreÅ¿age of the Å¿plendour of the Structure.

The loÅ¿s of a memorable and much-lamented perÅ¿on, muÅ¿t here have an honourable mention in our Annals: For this year Abraham Couley, The death of Abraham Couley. a man of famed Wit both at home and abroad, and for his delightful Learning, a Companion to the chief of the Nobility of England, departed this life. His Poetical fancy Å¿eemed to be inÅ¿pired with Å¿ome divine breath; which in Å¿weet numbers, the Monuments of his own glory, after Maro and the delights of Rome, equalled the Raptures of Pindar and the GracefulneÅ¿s of Athens. No man was more Å¿ublime, nor modeÅ¿t than he; and he lived with the Å¿ame politeneÅ¿s and grace as he wrote, in VerÅ¿e and Manners being equally conÅ¿picuous.

1668.The next year was taken up in building of the City,All hands are Å¿et to work in the rebuilding of London. with Å¿o great magnificence of modern Pomp, that it might be thought that the Citizens in digging and clearing the Ground, had found Mines of Gold amongÅ¿t the RubbiÅ¿h of the Ruines. Nor will it be more the wonder of this than of future Ages, that during the calamity of a dangerous War, and amidÅ¿t the many loÅ¿Å¿es of Merchants, there Å¿till remained in the hands of the Citizens Å¿uch vaÅ¿t Å¿tocks of Money to build new and Å¿tately houÅ¿es; and in their minds Å¿o much reÅ¿olution, as in time of War to promote the works of Peace. For now in leÅ¿s than the Å¿pace of three years, a new City was raiÅ¿ed; which being purged by Fire, and having expiated its former Offences, recovered more than its ancient Vigour and Glory.

Liv. l. 26.The Fame of the Roman Virtue will hardly Å¿ound Å¿o loud in future Ages, in that Lands were bought and Å¿old at Rome, whilÅ¿t Hannibal was at the Gates of the City; when now it may be heard, that after a late and devouring Plague, after a lamentable Fire that laid the City in AÅ¿hes, and whilÅ¿t three moÅ¿t powerful Nations were in War with us, The EngliÅ¿h Å¿till retained that confidence of their own fortune and height of mind, as to reÅ¿olve, and to be able to lay the Foundations of a new and Å¿o magnificent a City; and that under Å¿o much Affliction they dared to look beyond their Calamities.

The Monument of the dreadful Fire.And that there might be a Å¿tanding Monument of the Å¿ad Conflagration, or rather a Trophy of the Cities ReÅ¿tauration, the Citizens of London growing greater in their Misfortune, and magnificent in their AdverÅ¿ity, erected in the place where the dreadful Fire began, a Lofty Pillar one hundred and Å¿eventy foot high, all of Portland Stone, not much inferiour to Marble.

And that we may not always have need to return to ancient Annals for Monuments of magnificence,The Theatre of Oxford founded in the year 1664. is finiÅ¿hed. this year Gilbert Sheldon, after the death of Juxon, ArchbiÅ¿hop of Canterbury, perfected the Theatre of Oxford, a laÅ¿ting Temple of the MuÅ¿es, and a Capitol conÅ¿ecrated to Apollo; which he dedicated as a Circle to the learned ExerciÅ¿es and Acts of the Gown; and a new Ornament to the Æ²niverÅ¿ity, finiÅ¿hed at his own vaÅ¿t charges, and by the advice and contrivance of Sir ChriÅ¿topher Wren, a moÅ¿t ingenious Architect and Mathematician.

On the outÅ¿ide the Beholder may admire the magnificence of the Structure; and within be delighted with the comlineÅ¿s and beauty of the Theatre, being incompaÅ¿Å¿ed around with lofty and regular Benches for the convenience of Spectators.

Underneath is to be Å¿een a moÅ¿t excellent and well-contrived Printing-houÅ¿e: All which, will be a laÅ¿ting Monument of the Founders Fame, Å¿o long as men can Å¿peak in his Theatre, or Books be printed at his PreÅ¿s.

LaÅ¿t year the Duke of Ormond returned into England, after he had,1669.
The Lord Roberts Deputy of Ireland. Sept. 20. with the reputation of extraordinary WiÅ¿dom, governed Ireland as Lord-Lieutenant for the Å¿pace of Å¿even years; and this year the Lord Roberts, a PerÅ¿on of great Integrity, Prudence, and Worth, Å¿ucceeded in that Government.

In the mean time the Duke of Ormond, The D. of Ormond made Chancellour of the Æ²niverÅ¿ity of Oxford. with unanimous conÅ¿ent of the Heads, Fellows, and Students of Colledges, is choÅ¿en Chancellour of the UniverÅ¿ity of Oxford; and Å¿o being taken off from the care and troubles of the IriÅ¿h affairs, he had the direction of the Å¿ofter and more peaceful MuÅ¿es.

About the beginning of September, Mary the Queen Mother of England having for two and twenty years, in BaniÅ¿hment and Widowhood, lived
without the enjoyment of the King her Husband, and with the comfort of a flouriÅ¿hing Off-Å¿pring, having beheld her Son Å¿etled in the Throne,The Queen Mother dies in France. died at Paris in France, full of years, and of glory in all the changes of humane condition.

The death of the Duke of Albemarle. Jan. 2. 1669, 70. About the end of this, and beginning of next year, the Duke of Albemarle alÅ¿o finiÅ¿hed his courÅ¿e. And being now to Å¿peak the laÅ¿t of a man born for the publick good, famous in a high, and famous in a lower degree, I Å¿hall take a Å¿hort review of his Birth, Manners, and Fortune.

His Birth and Extraction. George Monk, the Son of a Knight, was born in DevonÅ¿hire in the WeÅ¿t of England, in the year One thouÅ¿and Å¿ix hundred and eight: He had an elder Brother who inherited his Fathers EÅ¿tate and Honour; and a younger, who being bred a Scholar, after the ReÅ¿tauration of the King, was made BiÅ¿hop of Hereford.

He followed the Wars in his youth. George the middlemoÅ¿t puÅ¿hing his Fortune in the Camp, followed the Wars; wherein he was firÅ¿t initiated in his youth at Cadis againÅ¿t the Spaniards, and Å¿hortly after in an Expedition againÅ¿t the French at the IÅ¿le of RÃ©, both unfortunate in their iÅ¿Å¿ue; but with better Å¿ucceÅ¿s he Å¿erved under the Earl of Oxford in Holland. The Civil Wars afterwards breaking out, Æ²nder Charles the FirÅ¿t he Å¿erved in the ScottiÅ¿h War. occaÅ¿ioned firÅ¿t by the accurÅ¿ed madneÅ¿s of the ScottiÅ¿h Presbyterians, he returned into England, and liÅ¿ted himÅ¿elf under Charles the FirÅ¿t, who then marched againÅ¿t the Scots, In Ireland alÅ¿o and next year after was made a Colonel in the Army againÅ¿t the IriÅ¿h Rebels.

But the Civil War of England raging more furiouÅ¿ly afterwards, whilÅ¿t the Parliament called in the Scots, their Brethren in Iniquity, to their aÅ¿Å¿iÅ¿tance; the King on the other hand having made a Truce with the IriÅ¿h Rebels, called over his Forces from Ireland, for his own defence at home: and Monk
being one of the Commanders of that Army,1669, 70. with the reÅ¿t joyned the King at at Oxford;He joyns the K. at Oxford. Is taken by the Parliament, and made priÅ¿oner in the Tower of London. but whilÅ¿t by orders from the King he muÅ¿tered the IriÅ¿h Forces in the Camp, he was unexpectedly Å¿urprized and taken by Fairfax, who Å¿erved the Parliament; and being carried to London, lay there almoÅ¿t four years PriÅ¿oner in the Tower. WhilÅ¿t he was there Å¿hut up and in diÅ¿treÅ¿s, the King Å¿ent him Å¿ecretly an hundred Pieces of Gold; which conÅ¿idering the Å¿treights his MajeÅ¿ty was then put to, was no Å¿mall Argument of his Royal Affection towards him.

Here it was that firÅ¿t of all he gained the good eÅ¿teem of Cromwel, who then commanded the Parliament-Forces in Ireland, having performed an action more advantageous to his General, than honourable to himÅ¿elf. The IriÅ¿h War being ended,He marches with Cromwel into Scotland. the Summer following he marched with Cromwel againÅ¿t the Scots, and did not a little contribute to his fortunate SucceÅ¿Å¿es in Scotland.

Having been Å¿o often victorious at Land,He fights againÅ¿t the Dutch under the Rump-Parliament. and now an old Commander, he tried his fortune at Sea; and under the Rump-Parliament was very Å¿ucceÅ¿sful againÅ¿t the Dutch, having in two Engagements beaten them and put them to flight.

At length when Cromwel got into Supreme Power, he was made Governour of Scotland;Is by Cromwel made Governour of Scotland. which TruÅ¿t, with equal reputation of Equity and Prudence, he diÅ¿charged during the Å¿pace of almoÅ¿t
five years: until Quarrels and AnimoÅ¿ities happening at London betwixt the Rumpers and Colonels of the Army, he laid hold on the occaÅ¿ion for reÅ¿toring of the King.

But at what time firÅ¿t he framed the deÅ¿igne of reÅ¿toring Charles to the Throne, I Å¿hall hardly preÅ¿ume to determine: Cavillers, and thoÅ¿e that make the worÅ¿t of things, gave it out, that his dutiful Å¿ervices to the King were but fortuitous; but they who judge impartially, affirm that it was a deÅ¿igne laid many years before. Certainly the beÅ¿t of Kings, more mindful of the effects of his Loyalty, than of its beginning, received the duty of Albemarle, as extraordinary and kind Å¿ervices, and honourably and liberally rewarded them.

The year before his death, he fell into a DropÅ¿ie; and being weary of the ordinary methods and advice of PhyÅ¿icians, he made uÅ¿e of a certain Quack-Medicine, which in appearance recovered him; but his body being opened after his death, a great deal of Water was found in his Bowels, and much congealed Bloud in both the Ventricles of his Heart, and other neighbouring VeÅ¿Å¿els: For the motion both of the Heart and Bloud being weakened by an inveterate DropÅ¿ie, gave occaÅ¿ion to the Å¿tagnating of the chylous juyce about the Heart; which Å¿topping the Fountain of the circulating Bloud, put at length a Å¿top to his laÅ¿t breathings for life.

The Marriage of his onely Son was in a manner the laÅ¿t thing he minded in this life; who a few days before his death was married to the Daughter of the Earl of Ogle, and Grand-daughter to the Duke of NewcaÅ¿tle; thereby to Å¿ettle, as well as honour, his Family by an Alliance with Å¿o Noble a HouÅ¿e.

After he had Å¿een Britain rejoycing in Triumphs,
beheld Charles confirmed in the Throne by ten years happy Reign, and after he had adminiÅ¿tred the greateÅ¿t Offices of TruÅ¿t under the King, both in Peace and War, being upwards of Å¿ixty years of age, he yielded to DeÅ¿tiny, which he willingly and undauntedly Å¿ubmitted unto; that after the Trophies of a paÅ¿t Life, he might at length triumph over Death.

He left but one onely Son, the IlluÅ¿trious Inheritour of his Fathers Fame, hopeful to the State, and cheriÅ¿hed by the King as his own. Charles who had often viÅ¿ited and condoled with him in his Å¿ickneÅ¿s, was with him to the laÅ¿t, and expreÅ¿Å¿ed the Å¿ame affection for dying Albemarle, that he had teÅ¿tified to him during his life.

From SomerÅ¿et-houÅ¿e, where he had lain in Å¿tate,The Solemnity of his Funerals he was with a Å¿plendid pomp of Å¿olemn Funerals at the Kings charges conveyed to WeÅ¿tminÅ¿ter-Abbey, and there amidÅ¿t the Tears and Condolings of all good men, interred amongÅ¿t the AuguÅ¿t Monuments of Kings, being the laÅ¿t Triumph due to his memory.

They who are curious to have a deÅ¿cription of the Å¿hapes and countenance of Å¿o great a man, may know; that he was a perÅ¿on more graceful than beautiful; of a middle Å¿tature, Å¿trong and well comparted, with a comely preÅ¿ence; and of a compoÅ¿ed, rather than Å¿evere or Å¿tern, aÅ¿pect.

He may eaÅ¿ily be reckoned a moÅ¿t valiant General in War,His Courage. not onely to be compared to the chief Commanders of his own age, but to the moÅ¿t renowned Warriours of elder times; and of Å¿o great reputation he was in Military affairs, that the modeÅ¿teÅ¿t do acknowledge too great a Courage in Albemarle. He Å¿pent almoÅ¿t his whole life in Arms, and at length growing old amidÅ¿t Victories, he became gray-headed under a Helmet.

In Britain and Ireland, by Sea and by Land, Å¿o happy was Albemarle, that Fortune traced out for him,His Prudence, Honour, Renown, and Titles. He had indeed a hidden and a Å¿ilent kind of Sagacity in the management of affairs; and improved almoÅ¿t all the Arts of Prudence by Silence.

And ModeÅ¿ty.He had a ModeÅ¿ty that Å¿et off all the other Virtues of his Mind; nor was he ever heard to brag of what he had done or deÅ¿erved. The Fame of Å¿o great a man, doubtleÅ¿s inferiour to no other Mortal, will propagate it Å¿elf to PoÅ¿terity; who, without Pride or OÅ¿tentation, gratified a baniÅ¿hed Prince with Å¿o Å¿ignal Services, and onely rejoyced in the conÅ¿cientious performance of his Duty and Obedience.

Tacit. HiÅ¿t. l. 3.Nor after the ReÅ¿tauration of Charles, did he behave himÅ¿elf as a Colleague in the Government, as Mucianus was of old reported to have done to VeÅ¿paÅ¿ian, but as a Servant; neither did he ever boaÅ¿t, that having the Power in his own hands, he had beÅ¿towed it upon another; whereby he burned, to his glory, the Arrogance of the Rump, and the Impudence of Cromwel: his Loyalty inclining him more to give up, than his Ambition to retain the Government.

We may, moreover; reckon Albemarle happy, not onely in the greatneÅ¿s of the Action, but alÅ¿o in the Å¿eaÅ¿onableneÅ¿s of the Service: That he brought back the Government to a Prince of Å¿o juÅ¿t and good a temper, who put Å¿o true an eÅ¿timate upon his Loyalty, and under whom it would never be unÅ¿afe nor dangerous to deÅ¿erve the moÅ¿t: For good Offices are acceptable, Tacit. Annal. lib. 4. eÅ¿pecially to Kings, Å¿o long as the obliged think they may be able to requite them; but when they are too great to be rewarded, inÅ¿tead of Thanks they procure Hatred: And it is rare, and almoÅ¿t
unuÅ¿ual, for Princes to think themÅ¿elves obliged; or if they think Å¿o, to love their Benefactors. Plin. Panegyr.

Peace being now eÅ¿tabliÅ¿hed at home, and Janus his Temple Å¿hut, Albemarle departed the more joyfully out of this life, that when he left no Troubles in Britain, yet he left behind him a Love for himÅ¿elf in the hearts of all good men: Å¿o much the more wanted, that he had taken care that nothing Å¿hould be wanting, having left nothing in the State but his own death to be bewailed; the King flouriÅ¿hing in his Government, and the Loyalty of the Parliament as yet vieing with the modeÅ¿ty of the Prince. Every one enjoyed the happineÅ¿s they deÅ¿ired at home, and Peace with all Nations abroad, till the League-breaking Dutch again provoked the EngliÅ¿h Arms.
But the Actions of that War, the Å¿teddy Fortune of the BritiÅ¿h Nation, and the future Triumphs of CHARLES, I have Å¿et aÅ¿ide as a Å¿ubject for my more advanced years.
